description:
My boyfriend and I came here for our 5 year anniversary this past weekend and had an amazing time. I can't recommend it enough. Both for the food and ambience. The soufflés are UNBELIEVABLE.  We ordered the prosciutto and mushroom savory soufflé and got both the chocolate soufflé and the fresh fruit strawberry soufflé. We hadn't eaten all day to prepare our stomachs for this haha. Do not attempt the amount we ate if you aren't starving or if you don't have a sweet tooth. All of them were delicious. 

We had felt confident that we would enjoy a good meal from reviews here but saw that most often the complaint was about bad service and long waits. That was not our experience. The waiters were extremely welcoming and friendly. As for the long wait times, you are eating at a restaurant that primarily serves soufflés. If you aren't expecting a bit of a wait for your food then you are not familiar with what a soufflé is. 

You wont be disappointed by a meal here. 

Thank you everyone at Cafe Jacqueline for helping to create such a wonderful experience and memory on our anniversary!
author: Katherine S.

description:
North Beach is one of my favorite neighborhoods in SF.   The neighborhood has retained its character in a world that is either depressing or cookie-cutter (or both).  Cafe Jacqueline is quintessentially San Francisco and North Beach.  I really enjoyed my experience here.

They do use a phone reservation system, which I didn't have any problem with.  The restaurant was even willing to be flexible and reschedule when my guest's flight changed.

Cafe Jacqueline is charmingly old school.  It's a tiny restaurant, with maybe around a dozen tables.  The ambiance is lovely.  It feels more formal than most SF restaurants, although honestly that's not saying much.  Most places in SF feel like eating in an Apple Store (lots of white and stainless steel).  This place has high ceilings, Victorian molding on the wall, dim lighting, white tablecloth etc.

The servers are friendly, but extremely professional.   As others have noted, the soufflés take a while to come out (more than an hour.  The servers really try to make sure you get in your order right away to minimize the wait time.  

We knew when we came in that the soufflés take more than an hour to prepare.  Part of the chef's vision is to have a small, intimate dining experience.   Given that, and the ample warnings about prep time, it feels cheap to talk about the wait.  That being said, we did wait a little more than 2 hours for our first soufflé (the second came about a half hour later).  It might have been our fault, since we came around 750 when the last seating is really at 730.   2 hours is a little too long, particularly when you can't really order a salad or soup without it setting your main dish back even further.   

I just don't have many friends - even foodies - who are willing to wait that long before having the first dish come out. It might be a better experience if we had an earlier dinner time, or came during the week .

We had a savory leek and mushroom soufflé which was delicious.  The soufflé was straight out of the oven, perfectly light with the right amount of veggies for a balanced flavor.  

The chocolate soufflé was also very light -  not too sweet, and with an almost neutral tasting chocolate flavor.  Again very well balanced, but almost the opposite in profile from our savory choice.

I'd love to come back and try the Grand Marnier soufflé.
author: Holly P.

description: Soufflesoisness - if that is not a word if you go to CJ it will be! Then service was fantastic and friendly. At the end of dinner - the waiters told us to go into the kitchen and meet Jacqueline. We told her we have been wanting to go there for 20 years and finally went for our anniversary. It was a truly romantic and memorable experience.....not hipster, not modern, not trendy or sleek. What is is - soulful soufflés that warm your heart in a way that cannot be found anywhere in SF.  It won't be another 20 years.
author: Marty J.

description: I have not eaten here but I was deeply frustrated by the reservation/scheduling process. I attempted to make a reservation a full week beforehand.  And it took a few days to hear back only to get a return call stating that there were no more reservations available. Another subsequent call let's me know that there is a reservation, and I confirm I want it. And yet another call comes to tell me that there is a reservation available. I attempt to confirm once again by leaving a couple voice messages that I had already confirmed. I don't get s confirmation until 30 minutes before my reservation that I'm informed that there is an available table for me. I was so frustrated from the repeated calls about how there's a table available I simply cancelled entirely. Whoever is responsible for reservations and scheduling: PLEASE be more organized.
author: Manny C.

description:
Our waiter last night was such a tool bag, he took away from our overall experience. It's hard to give four stars but meeting Jacqueline herself melted my heart. 

This place would never survive in NYC. Cafe Jacqueline is a cute French bistro, off the beaten path. There are 10 tables, if they're doing 50 covers nightly, God Bless them.

The waiter who represents the front of the house or more importantly, the face of the business? I wanted to snap on him, such a pissy and unprofessional demeanor. My wife & I walk in and he asked if we have reservations. We do not (the place is half empty) he shakes his head and says, a typical dinner is over two hours. I'm the only waiter here so I'll do my best. Um what?! Here's a correct response: 
You're first time here, great! Please be patient with us, our soufflés take a while to prepare but are well worth the wait. Isn't that a nice way to get greeted? And being the only waiter, it's his restaurant! He should be all smiles as he's raking in the tips with no splits. Again, why be all pissy? 

I'm not going to wait hours for dinner. Our body clock is on NY time, My wife would be out of her mind. I figured, let me speed up the process and order a funky salad, French Onion soup and a Chocolate Soufflé. 

The waiter comes over to take our drink orders. I said, we're simple and ready to order. He got pissy and said I'm not ready, you have to wait for me. Oh this guy.. I need to run everything. Ready? Put out a carafe of water on every table, no need to run around filling up glasses. Also, the butter was cold and hard to spread. It's your job to make sure it's not too cold for the guests. Or is that too hard and complex? 

I'm going to rate our meal from top to bottom:

Chocolate Soufflé:
This is the reason why we waited, once we took a bite everything else seemed secondary. I have never in my life had a soufflé as light and airy being served at Cafe Jacqueline. And I was stationed in France!

French Onion soup:
The soup was great but served boiling hot. Our waiter said it's going to be boiling hot so be careful. I'm not sure who's in charge of the soup but at midnight NYC time, I don't want deal with boiling soup. I waited for it to cool down.

Spinach & Bacon salad:
Why so expensive? It's spinach. It's bacon. Mix them in a bowl? For $20 bucks, it wasn't worth the price. Also, waiter?? Give me a damn serving spoon...

Beer:
I was hoping for Jenlain, a French beer. Nope, I was served a Belgium beer imported from Canada.

To use the restroom, you must walk through the kitchen. Sure enough, there she is, the cutest little thing, Miss Jacqueline! She smiled at me. I told her I traveled from NY and made a special stop just to dine here. She smiled, asked me my name and said Merci! How can you get mad and give less than four Yelp stars? She's so welcoming and her soufflé is award winning.

My waiter comes back from a smoke break (this guy is so annoying) and has pronoun trouble. How did "we" like our dinner? He think he also said did "we" rethink our order after I read the specials? What the heck is up with this guy? Dude, get another profession. "We" think your not worthy to work serving customers. 

It was so nice to meet you Ms Jacqueline. Thank you again for the award winning soufflé
author: Bill S.

description:
This place was amazing 5/5! And hidden in North Beach- I've walked by so many times and had no idea it was there. 

We ordered the garlic, basil and shiitake savory soufflé for our entree and it was cooked to perfection. It melts in your mouth. I can't even explain how delicious it was. One of the best meals I've ever had for sure.

For dessert, we had to go with the traditional chocolate. Another great choice; it did not disappoint.
 
This place has a lot of character. The waiters are all French men and the chef is one sole, elderly woman from France who was so sweet and makes the soufflés to order. I saw her in the kitchen and said hi. This is such a good spot for dinner and not hyped up at all, surpringly!

**edit to say they also have a great wine selection!
author: Mariam P.

description:
If you are looking for an intimate time with your partner, you may want to consider going to Cafe Jacqueline, a rather quiet and hard to spot restaurant in North Beach. If you can figure out that it does exist, be sure to get a reservation or else you may find yourself out of luck for dinner.
We came here one Friday night at 7PM and were seated right away. The wait staff were extremely busy and seemed to do everything in increments like giving us our waters and then menus.
All at the same time, we ordered a shiitake, garlic and basil souffle, onion soup, and a lime souffle to be paired with a pear cider. The pear cider was the first thing to come out and the wait staff did a great job diligently filling our glasses through the night. The onion soup came out after about 20-30 minutes and it was delicious. I don't usually do French onion soup ever, but I was starving and it was good to have something to eat when I knew the souffles would take a while. Little did I know that it wouldn't be for another hour until our first souffle came out. By that time, my boyfriend and I were irritated and tired since we had worked all day, but the moment we ate the souffle, we were revitalized and joyful again. It was so delicious and flavorful, but soft and bouncy. Totally different from what I was expecting. We enjoyed it in peace and then about 30 minutes later, our lime souffle came out and OMG, that was so delicious. You just wouldn't understand the type of joy we had consuming it. It was enormous, too!
This dinner was different as it forced my boyfriend and I to slow down and enjoy each other's company instead of letting us leave within 30 minutes to an hour. My boyfriend was awed by Jacqueline, whom he saw working in the small kitchen and that was what kept him from actually getting angry at the slow pace. Jacqueline puts a lot of care into each souffle and you can tell that she does things in a steady pace as she makes do with the limitations of her kitchen, but this is better than having dozens of kitchen staff running about trying to feed hundreds of people. The atmosphere in the restaurant was calm and pleasant as everyone enjoyed the company of those around them. Everyone was at peace, which isn't always common at restaurants.
The service here was superb with the waiters being incredibly friendly and easy to talk to, despite them having to converse with so many people. If you want to slow down a bit and enjoy dinner with good company, Cafe Jacqueline is the place. The price is a bit high, but come on; there are so many places in the bay area that are so much more expensive than Cafe Jacqueline. My only real complaint is that it's impossible to schedule a reservation by phone. I called multiple times over the course of a week and left messages but not once have I ever gotten a call back. The only thing that worked was that my boyfriend walked in and asked to schedule a reservation. It's really frustrating to have the staff completely ignore messages and make the whole experience of reserving a table frustrating, but I did enjoy everything else so I only took away 1 star.
author: Jenn T.

description: Best soufflé on the West Coast!  Always consistent with cloud-like fluffiness.  After over 30 years, Jacqueline is truly amazing.
author: Alfred C.

description: This place is a treasure. Super charming interior, amazing staff, absolutely amazing food. It's awesome to see a place that specialize so well in something - not as a gimmick but as a mastery. Both savory and sweet are exquisite.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Ooooooooh the agony!  It's all ramen and diced hot dogs for me for a while.  Chef Jacqueline is an expensive girl!  That said she knows what she's doing.  My uncle and I tried this place out last month and it didn't disappoint.  The first thing I'd like to mention is this place has so much personality.  The decor is quite understated.  I'm talking like one of the most bare bones establishments I've ever been in.  No ambient music, very dim.  This place must be more about the food than what I am used to. At one point in the night I had to use the little girl's room and funny thing you have to walk through the kitchen to get to the restroom.  I got to see Chef Jacqueline and give her a "Bon jour" to which she replied "Bon soir"  That made me happy.  I took 4 years of French in school and the only reason I remember how to ask where the restroom is is because of Saturday Night Live and Alec Baldwin.  I digress.  My uncle told me "It's a typical San Francisco restroom."  I thought that was the most ridiculous statement I had ever heard.......until I got in there and OH MY GOD HE WAS RIGHT!  You'll know when you see it.  

First.  We ordered 4 souffles and they take a long while so be prepared to wait like with most good things.  We ordered the crab souffle, white corn ginger and garlic souffle, chocolate souffle, and lemon souffle.  Maybe the wait was an hour and change.  I really don't remember.  Let me say this, if you are someone who is funny about eggs you should probably steer clear of this place.  If you have issues with texture stay away as well.  I for one love soft eggs so this place works for me.  I really love the corn souffle in that there isn't a big bold flavor to it.  The actual ingredients do the work, not the seasoning.  The same goes for the crab that was also stellar just to a lesser extent.  The egg acts as a blank canvas for the ingredients to be showcased on.  As for the dessert souffles get this THEY ARE RICH AS HELL.  Tread lightly.  I really liked the texture of the crispy crust versus the sweet soft filling.  

Even though we were there for a while the wait staff was very attentive.  They weren't especially animated or outgoing.  This ain't the wait staff at Applebee's.  Not even close.  I was not put off by them though.  Extra credit for serving room temperature butter.  My biggest pet peeve is cold butter with me bread!  "What am I supposed to do with this?!!!"
author: Herman T.

description: God I love this place so much. Such a romantic and relaxing dinner for this corner of the world. Really wish I could have Jacqueline's soufflés for the rest of my life. The hubby and I are currently huge fans of the cauliflower and garlic soufflé. And as always the complimentary bread to start is perfectly warm and toasty to compliment the end of your onion soup. How is that onion soup vegetarian? I swear it's the BEST onion soup I've had in my life, better than Paris! Normally it would also be nice to have a half bottle of the saint emilion french red wine, but I am currently preggo. Still love the endive salad. So simple, fresh, and crisp with the light vinaigrette and Roquefort cheese to add some tangy creaminess (also something I'm not supposed to have, sigh). But for now I am happy just to eat the soufflés and onion soup. Drooling and dreaming of the next time we come back. Merci madame Jacqueline!
author: Stine H.

description:
I am so in love with this cafe. Jacqueline is just the cutest most adorable lady you'll ever meet and she greets you with the biggest smile on her face and warms your heart! Her soufflés do just the same.

Be ready to spend a little extra at this place as Jacqueline individually makes these soufflés by herself - so don't be surprised when you have to wait 1-2 hours for your food, but with good company time will go by very fast :) 

My boyfriend surprised me on Valentine's Day with this place and we ordered the chocolate soufflé. The couple next to us were eating one already and I did not think two people could finish such a big portion.

When our soufflé came out, it was the most beautiful thing ever. The server was very cute and nice - he waited for me to take my foodie pics before he cut the pieces for us! Very delicious and light soufflé - a must try in SF!
author: Chloe S.

description: Absolutely disgusting soufflé. Got food poisoning the next day. Server was rude and the food was cold and dissapoint
author: Pratham A.

description:
This is a perfect place for a special occasion/romantic date night! A small restaurant of about 15 tables. Quiet, great ambiance, and unpretentious.

This is not a place to come with kids, large groups, or to dine and dash. The meal will take about three hours, as each soufflé is made to order by Jacqueline herself. 

Wonderful wine menu, mostly French wines, of course. I recommend getting a salad or appetizer to start, as your entree will take about an hour. A nice but basic selection of simple salads and a few apps, as well as soup. The French onion soup looked yummy, but we opted for the butter lettuce salad dressed with a Dijon vinaigrette to save room for the star, the soufflé.

Each soufflé is large enough to share between 2-3 people. We had the lobster soufflé- it was phenomenal! For dessert, we shared the chocolate soufflé, which was divine!

The staff is super friendly but they don't hover, which I appreciate. It's a place to relax, enjoy, and have a good conversation over wonderful, lovingly prepared food. 

Oh, and when you make your reservation, let them know ahead of time if you or someone in your party is a wheelchair user. There is one step up into the restaurant, and they have a little foldout ramp that they can bring out for you. It's good to give them a heads up so they are prepared. It is a space that is on the small side, so if you have a very large wheelchair or have several people with you in chairs, it might be a little challenging. However, talk to the restaurant. I am sure they can be more than accommodating.
author: Melissa M.

description:
We have been here at least 6 or 7 times when visiting the city the last few years.  I would give it 5 stars but requesting reservations is antiquated and when I happened to be in the  neighborhood of this cafe  today  I stopped by to check on a reservation request I had left by a voice mail (the only way) the mustached guy was very rude and said "we are fully booked" and didn't even say I'm sorry or thanks for stopping by to inquire.  Never have had this horrible non-greeting at any city in the world.  Makes Parisians seem like small town folks.  
Sorry Jacqueline you need to find a  maître d', or whatever he is, 
with more class and manners.
author: Cynthia J.

description:
I went here with three other people, and ordered two dinner souffles. They were perfect for sharing. We chose the mushroom souffle and then the salmon and asparagus souffle. Each was delicious, but I liked the salmon one a little better. I felt that it had more flavor. However ... you really can't go wrong here! We also ordered a chocolate souffle for dessert and split it between the four of us. The dinner was very filling and perfect overall. 

Don't be in a rush when you go here, because Jacqueline herself makes every souffle herself and you will have to wait. Make sure you take a trip to the restroom, because you will have to go through the kitchen and see her in action with your own eyes. She opened the restaurant in 1979 and has been going strong ever since. I don't know if she ever plans on retiring, but do yourself a favor and put this restaurant on your bucket short list because someday it will be gone forever.
author: Lori M.

description: I don't know what to say. Madame Jacqueline is an absolute master in her craft, but the mustached server is racist. It's a shame that this establishment should suffer this guy because he's not deserving of Jacqueline's name.
author: Joon Young L.

description:
This review is long overdue, I came here a few months ago but I heard of this restaurant almost 4 years ago.  I've been wanting to come ever since. The appeal of a woman run restaurant with two waiters and a sous chef, AND being at least 80 years old is too much to not go.  I mean you really have to admire someone who pours their life and soul into food when they could be retired. 

I made reservations only two weeks in advance so was able to get a 5 pm seating, since the restaurant is small and each meal take a good 3 hours reservations are definitely necessary. Located in north beach, parking is hard to find so park downtown at Sutter & Mason and walk. Or you could circle around to find parking. 

The service here is fantastic, they are quick to check on you and the restaurant is super clean.  I wouldn't suggest going here on a first date or with acquaintances because it's more of an intimate restaurant.  Find someone to go with whom you can talk to for a few hours. 

We ordered escargot, salmon asparagus souffle, and a lemon souffle for dessert. Each souffle takes about an hour to make.  The salmon asparagus souffle was amazing so light and fluffy and with delicious chunks of salmon and small pieces of asparagus. 

The lemon souffle was super light and fluffy as well.  I couldn't eat much because i was already full from the escargot and the savory souffle.  We took it home and had it cold the next day. It was still really good cold. 

This is a must come if you are in sf or planning to visit !! Probably one of my top three restaurants in sf
author: Tiffany Y.

description: Very disappointed with dinner 2 nights ago. The soufflé was okay but my party of 3 got food poisoning the next day. We all have been on medication for the last 3 days. To top it off the host was extremely rude and was very unfriendly. I don't want to say they were racist since SF isn't like that but we didn't feel comfortable dining at the restaurant because of how they interacted with us.
author: Eeshan A.

description: Best soufflé ever. We had the seafood soufflé entree and it was light and savory and the scallops were delicate and fresh. The chocolate soufflé for dessert was when I lost composure and wanted to lick the bowl. Perfection. Wait staff is fine. This is a unique restaurant, the care and attention to detail is apparent once you taste the food. Don't bitch.
author: Zelda H.

description: This is honestly in my top five places!! The food is amazing! Start with the French onion soup and end with the lime Soufflé for dessert! The staff have worked here forever and really make you feel at home. The owner is in the kitchen preparing everything from scratch. This is a small SF gem!!
author: Scott D.

description:
Absolutely 5 Stars Food. The soufflé is excellent. We had the shiitake mushroom, basil, and garlic for entree, lemon soufflé for dessert. Absolutely the best I've ever had. 

3 star services. The waiter is less than welcoming. 

0 star for overall experience. Dinner started at 915, we finished at 11:30. The first soufflé was served 1hr in at 10:15. The second was served at 11:15. The speed is slow as hell. It doesn't matter how delicious the food is, I would never return back to this joint.
author: Kelvin W.

description:
Oh geez...I believe I visited Cafe Jacqueline the beginning of last year.  I can't believe I hadn't written a review!  This place is deserving of one as soon as you walk out the door.

Make a reservation cause this place gets packed.  Also, each table takes awhile for peeps to leave because each souffle is made fresh and with care.    Soufflés take at least 30-45 minutes.  Keep that in mind so you don't miss a show or something.  

We started off with some wine and endives with Roquefort.  It was a nice, refreshing way to begin our meal knowing that the main entree would take a few. 

For our main entree, we ordered prosciutto and mushroom.  It was such a tough choice as every souffle sounded wonderful.  Each one feeds 2 people and are greater then $30 a pop.  Totally worth it.  The souffle was on the saltier side which could be expected from the prosciutto but tasty in all aspects.  I'd like to try the seafood one the next time I'm here.  

There is absolutely no point in visiting Jacqueline's if you don't order dessert.  Make sure you order it ahead of time with your entree to save time.  We got the grand marnier.  Every drop was gone.  Spoons were licked.  The souffle was perfect with the height and the fluffiness.  A must when you come here.

Even if you don't have the need, you must use the restroom.  Why?  Cause on the way, you pass by Jacqueline, herself, working away with a basket of eggs in front of her.  Such a sight to see.  

5 absolute stars and a staple in the city.
author: Jen W.

description:
I really wanted to like this place but the 2+ hour wait for a souffle made me not like it. I was sincerely disappointed. 

We sat down at 7:30p and got our first soufflé at 9:45p. That's crazy! Those soufflés were very tasty. I'd even say they were the best I've had but I was just too hungry to properly enjoy them. 

Here's how the night went:

Arrive on time for our 7:30p reservation. Order within 15 min. Appetizers arrive in another 15 min. Then... WAIT and WAIT and WAIT and WAIT and WAIT..... then more WAITING. Oh yeah, then some more WAITING!! Omg the leek souffle arrives. Eat the delicious souffle. WAIT and WAIT and WAIT. Then eat second yummy grand marnier souffle. Leave the restaurant at 11:15p. 

The crazy part is no one seemed to really care that it took so long. I don't even know how this place stays in business even with the expensive prices - 40-50$ per souffle.
author: CaliGirl X.

description: This beautiful places makes me realize how fortunate I am to be living in SF.  The food is amazing, the staff welcoming and the chef is Jaqueline. Amazing. Simply the best.
author: Krista L.

description:
My wife and I lived in North Beach for many years and whenever we would walk by Cafe Jacqueline, she would comment about how cute it was. Once we got married, I decided to make this our yearly anniversary spot and we have been coming here ever since. This is not an inexpensive restaurant, but the meal is at least 2-3 hours, and it is run by a small staff that has not changed since we began coming here. A duo of mustachioed waiters takes care of you, there is a busser who doubles as a dish washer, and Madame Jacqueline herself. The restaurant is simple, but elegant in fitting French country decor, with high ceilings and dimmed lighting, and maybe a total of 10 tables. Very intimate and very romantic.

As others have noted, Cafe Jacqueline is all about souffles! The way it works, is that you order your entire meal all at once, appetizers (highly recommend the French Onion Soup) along with a dinner souffle and desert souffle. Souffles take a LONG time to cook, so ordering both at the get-go is key. They usually have special seasonal souffles, as well as their regular menu of souffles. We've had the Fruits de Mer seafood seasonal and the chanterelle mushroom seasonals, as well as the Shiitake, basil and garlic and the tomato and cilantro souffles that are always on the menu. For dessert we've had the Meyer lemon, the chocolate and the seasonal fresh fruit souffles. All are amazing! They are rich, but delicate in their flavor profile; they are hearty, but light and airy at the same time.

If you walk to the restroom in the courtyard, you have to walk through the one-woman kitchen run by Madame Jacqueline, who will be busy at work behind a mountain of eggs stacked in a pyramid. It really is a sight to behold!

If you're in a rush, go elsewhere. If you're looking to laugh loudly with friends, go elsewhere. But if you want a unique, non-rushed dinner experience -- the kind that is less and less common to find, then you have arrived!
author: Rafael M.

description: My fiancé brought me here for my second birthday together. Lovely quaint place for authentic french cuisine. Love the restaurants personality and uniqueness. The chef herself is probably in her 80s. Super sweet and lovely experience. Will come again next year!
author: Sophie L.

description: I adore this place! Go with lots of time to enjoy company and just pretend you are in France. Service is exceptional and the onion soup is to die for, be reborn and die for it again. If you like soufflé there is no better place! Great location to celebrate stuff. Make sure to call, leave a message to get a reservation
author: Nils H.

description:
Delicious soufflés. Savory and sweet.
All are made fresh on order, account for some baking time.
author: Yann K.

description:
Yes, the prices are steep. Is it worth it? Absolutely. After the only place that served soufflés in my area went out of business, I went searching for a new place to get my soufflé fix. After researching online, my family and I made a reservation to come here. Note that the restaurant doesn't open until evening, and the meal will take a good two to three hours, depending on your party size. However, it's all part of the experience, plus, soufflés require time and skill to make. The restaurant has a fairly decent menu size, with both savory and sweet options. Savory options include spinach, prosciutto and mushroom, and shiitake, basil, and garlic. Dessert soufflés include chocolate, Grand Marnier, and others. For a party of three, we usually order two savory and two sweet soufflés. 

Reservations are a must. You can absolutely just dine here for dessert, but I usually have my whole meal here. May as well go all out. It's definitely a place reserved for special occasion dinners.
author: Sarah W.

description: A unique approach and a unique restaurant. I would never have found it other than my sister and her husband have been going there for years.  I love the waiters--San Francisco has to be a tough place for a restaurant and waiters due to the high tourist traffic--the attitude here was informed, the french onion soup is the best and I know how long it takes to get it to that place..its ok to be ready for a wait--have some conversation, wind down and get ready for a restaurant that has personality.  I regret I may have told too many people about it and wonder if I can get in next time!
author: K T.

description:
ABSOLUTELY THE BEST .. The soufflé was huge but it was soooo tasty and airy and just full of goodness ! It was our first time there and the waiter was right .. It wouldn't be our last ! We will come back for this . I want to come back already and try the rest of their soufflé !!! 

We came on a Saturday night around 530 and really just wanted dessert .. They were a bit hesitant to take us bc they were fully booked but bc we only dessert .. They let us in ... Soo glad they did cuz they changed my whole world on soufflé ... Nothing else will ever come close ....
author: Joyce W.

description: This is a hidden gem in San Francisco. From the outside, the restaurant is very simple...only about 10 tables, most of which only seat 2 people. But that is part of the charm. The soufflés are amazing, and you can tell that Jacqueline puts her heart into each one. I recommend peaking in the kitchen if you visit the restaurant as you will see Jacqueline, a very sweet older French woman, vigorously preparing everything that is served at the restaurant. This is truly a San Francisco gem that embraces the perfect mom and pop style small restaurant.
author: Brad P.

description: Not worth the effort. Called on Monday and left a voice message reservation for the following Sunday. No one called back. Called on Wednesday when they are supposedly open. No answer, left reservation again. No call back. On Friday get a call that they can't accommodate our party. Rude, rude and rude!
author: T G.

description:
We were nervous at first when we stumbled upon Cafe Jacqueline because the waiter was not initially warm -- the place was mostly empty, yet we received a long pause when we asked if they had room for 2, and we were haphazardly seated. 

...But following that, everything was absolutely wonderful!

This place is tucked away and entirely an authentic experience. Service was exceptional -- soft-handed, they answered our inquiries politely -- and yes, it was the most charming thing to walk via the kitchen to get to the restroom. Jacqueline was back there, making her souffles, and warmly responded when I thanked her for her delicious food. 

The French Onion soup was the best I have ever had. The bread, wine selection, and souffles were exceptional. The lemon souffle -- omg !! 
The amount is perfect for two people to split. 

As the waiters & all reviews fairly point out, this is an experience - so you sit back and wait to be served. But it is a small place and therefore quite easy to hear each other. The music is kept at the perfect volume, and never are you startled by noises from the kitchen, or from other parties in the dining room. 

At the end of our meal, the waiter wrapped up our leftovers without pretension (sometimes I feel as though fine restaurants sniff over that request). And when we thanked him for the food, he recommended we pop back into the kitchen to tell Jacqueline. Back there, we were met with a big smile, and she chatted with us for a few minutes in her charming accent. If you have family or friends that particularly appreciate French food, or just an intimate dining experience in general, I can't recommend this place enough. What a happy enclave in North Beach!
author: Lizzy B.

description:
A rainy San Francisco day called for hearty Soufflé and French onion soup... I couldn't pass up the chance to visit Cafe  Jacqueline, which is cited all over Steve Jobs biography. He used to bring his dates here.  Alton Brown states it's the best he's ever had. And it's fame is well deserved for the consistent quality of these fluffy dishes prepared enough for 2. The same woman, Jacqueline Margulis, is the one preparing every single soufflé  by hand since 1979. And because each is made from scratch, it takes awhile...

I arrived around 8:30 PM into a intimate, dimly lit café restaurant of 10 - 12 tables. "Do you have reservations?"
"No.."
"Ok, well I just want to let you know, it's a 1-2hr wait for the food. We would love to have you, but no food is fast here."
.......(damnn)........
"Ok, sure". 

We ordered wine, then fresh baguettes and  melt-in-your-mouth butter is served. A French Bordeaux and a Pinot. I highly recommend the French Bordeaux. It has so much personality, full bodied, and paired so well with a savory soufflé.
 
The French onion soup took 20-30min. The soufflé took about an hr. We got lucky coming in at the right time, the waiter says, but don't expect it to come out this quickly next time he warns. He serves it and it's death by soufflé... Mmmmmm... Creamy, perfect, and savory but delicate as expected... It was worth the wait!

From the intimate ambience, the impeccable service, the quality of the food... It's something you have to try at least once. The crowd is a more mature, well dressed group-The well polished type, sporting fun glasses. The waiters are well mannered, who seemingly take pride in their job.  

I'm hoping someone will make a documentary on this place, because these kinds of restaurants rarely exist in the states. What a gem. Next time, I'm coming for soufflé desserts. With advanced reservations.
author: Nguyen T.

description:
Come hither for your giant soufflé fix. 

I love the passion infused into this lovely restaurant. The darling little old lady who owns the shop and bakes the soufflés is like 90 or something but continues to bake away. Truly warms my heart. My buddy ordered the gruyere and broccoli soufflé and I ordered the chocolate soufflé. I am normally not a fan of broccoli but I actually enjoyed its fluffy yet rich cheesy flavor. I definitely enjoyed the chocolate soufflé more, it was like a cloud of perfection; not overly sweet with a very light fluffy texture. I love the gradient in texture from the cake-like crust to the ultra-moist and slightly gooey interior. At least as good as the chocolate soufflés at Gary Danko but much larger (3X the size?). You can expect to wait an hour before getting your first soufflé so be sure to come here with a good friend and plenty of conversation.
author: J L.

description:
Excellent souffles! I came here based on a recommendation from a coworker, and loved it! They basically only serve souffles, and my sister and I stopped by Sunday evening for dessert souffles. 

We had a tough time deciding between chocolate, white chocolate, seasonal fruit (strawberry), or grand marnier souffle, and decided to go with chocolate ($35). We ordered, and ~40 minutes later, it came out piping hot and gooey in the center. It was really delicious! But one dessert souffle definitely feeds 3-4 people. We couldn't finish ours so had to take the rest home, but would have been nice to share with some more friends.
author: Jeanette S.

description: The French onion soup was amazing and the white chocolate souffle was decadent. My only quibble is it took 1 hour to get our horderves. A must try if you are in SF, just be prepared to spend 4 hours on the experience. Make sure to purchase a bottle of wine, relax  and put the world on hold for a while :)
author: Bruce W.

description:
At $40 a souffle, it was definitely a splurge but we were celebrating a birthday so it was the perfect occasion. The lemon souffle was delicious and when topped with a candle for the birthday boy, it made for a dramatic appearance. 

Thanks, Madame Jacqueline!
author: Cyndi G.

description:
The good: everything! I went with my friend from France and she told me this is just like eating in France. Jacqueline herself cooks everything in the back so expect the homemade authentic flavor in anything you order. My favs were the onion soup, salmon & asparagus soufflé and strawberry soufflé (although that may be seasonal). 

The bad: it's a small restaurant so make sure to make a reservation. Also be prepared to order everything at once. App, entree and dessert so you don't wait too long.
author: Becca F.

description: Cafe Jacqueline is a timeless treasure. This small, elegant cafe is tucked away but simply makes the best souffles in the Bay Area. It fosters a romantic vibe but it can be more as well. You'll want a reservation and plenty of time - such a good dinner is not to be taken on the run.
author: Jeff Y.

description: You've gotta go here. The lobster and gran marnier souffles are lovely. It's just a cute iconic whimsy one of a kind place with an expiration date. GO!
author: Andrew K.

description:
last night i took my girlfriend whos visiting from tehran to experience what i had previously thought of as one of the more charming restaurants in the City...that's how i USED to think of this place. greeted at the door by an obviously bitter and crestfallen garcon we were asked 
" do you have a reservation ?" . It was 7 pm...peak dining hour so i assumed that one of the many empty tables would be perfect for us. this mustachioed and most miserable fool tries to tell me there are no tables available ( half the tables were empty ) that all tables are booked. whats really sad here is the food at C.J. is truly great....but their awful front of house staffers literally chase clients out the door.  they play a sort of Laurel and Hardy good cop / bad cop mix of halfway endearing bumblers that usually end up being seen as simply hapless oafs. look for a short, napoleonic man with a dali moustache who pretends to be always bitter and upset ( he may actually be ). please tell your friends to insist that Jacqueline FIRE this cretin who is such a disservice to her great legacy. my gf suggested that he is actually instructed to act that way as a kind of corporate hospitality protocol imported from a time in paris when waiters actually treated people that way all the time in every restaurant . NEWSFLASH bitter guy...your angst and misery do not mix well with souffle... or your great wine selection. go back to kansas or wherever you came from and be miserable there...not in Jacquelines wonderful haven
author: Very W.

description: This restaurant is a gem, the setting almost takes you back to Paris in another time. The food makes you believe you are actually there! I have seen other reviews about the service being surly but honestly, they just take their job seriously and if you respect them and what they are trying to achieve there... then all will be well. This is not fast food so expect to wait an hour (+/-) for each course. The staff protects Jacqueline, who is the heart and soul of this establishment. Just go.. its one of a kind!
author: tricia y.

description: I found out I'm not a fan of savory soufflé. I went specifically for the chocolate dessert soufflé. It was underwhelming. I much prefer Alexandars Steak House's dessert soufflé. Which is strange because this place is known for their soufflé. The atmosphere is dark, not fancy but ok. The service is weird, and I'll leave it at that. The soup is the only reason I'd go back, just amazing. I wouldn't go with less than 4 people based on how large the soufflés come. I like french food, I know a french dinner means at least 2 hours at the table, so I'm ok with that. This place was just underwhelming and for the price, it's not something I would seek out again.
author: Shana A.

description: This place was amazing. My husband brought me to Cafe Jacqueline because I've been wanting chocolate soufflé ever since I tried it at another French restaurant. I have to say, Chef Jacqueline's chocolate soufflé outdid the other one I tried and it was double or triple the size. We started with a Spinach, Bacon, and Pine Nut salad topped with a dijon vinagrette, accompanied by the most delicious bread. The bread was perfect crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. The salad was fantastic with the tangy dressing and the salty, crispy bacon. The pine nuts added a great flavor and texture as well. Then the main course was a Gruyere soufflé that couple probably feed 3 comfortably, especially if you have bread and salad. The flavor was spectacular. They have many different flavors, so we will be back for more. Chef Jacqueline is such a sweet lady. We found out she makes every soufflé that comes out of the kitchen, and has been since 1979! Highly recommend this place. It took us about 2 months to get a reservation and it is pricey, but totally worth it, especially if you don't do it often (like us). :)
author: Stephany P.

description: A horrible overpriced place that ruined my special occasion. It took them two hours to serve us their over-salted disgusting overpriced "omelette". I've never been so disappointed in my life! Don't ruin your night by eating here!
author: Natalie M.

description: Stopped by with my wife for some french onion soup and appetizers. After putting in our in order, we were kindly advised by the waiter that *she* (whoever that is) does not like it and gets upset when you don't order the souffle. Without thinking much about it, we got up and left. I want to use this as an opportunity to apologize for making the mistake of incorrectly assuming that I was the customer and for upsetting some of your kitchen workers with my menu choices.
author: Sergey M.

description: This is the most amazing, lovely experience you will have dining in San Francisco.  Jacqueline prepares the lovely and delicious souffle' , the likes of which I can guarantee you have never had before.  A charming, sweet, delightful restaurant.  If you are looking for a fast paced, noisy place this is not the place for you.  If you are seeking a warm and inviting dining experience with excellent waiters and delicious food please dine here, you will feel fortunate.
author: mi m.

description:
I didn't believe in perfection before my lady took me here for date night.

From the moment we walked in and were politely greeted by the wax-mustachioed Matt, I felt at home, at ease, and utterly happy. It's small and intimate without being stuffy or pretentious. And I'm sorry, but if the smell of soufflés baking doesn't warm your heart, you're already dead inside and you can kindly leave, thank you.

We ordered onion soup to tide us over while our savory soufflé, the fruits de mer, baked. We chose fresh strawberries as our sweet, then dug our spoons into that hot layer of melted gruyère in the soup ... I'm gonna go out on a limb and say that it's probably hard to make a bad French onion soup. Maybe? In any case, Jacqueline's more than did the job of keeping us happy until the seafood medley in baked eggs joined us.

We got a bottle of Gigondas, too, which didn't detract.

Meanwhile, being so comfortable, we lost track of time while we drank wine and talked. Good thing, too, because soufflés are like the polar opposite of fast food. As it should be.

After waiting a few minutes for the soufflé to cool, we each dug in, doing what we could to pick up bits of prawn and/or scallop along with crispy crust and soft, hot center. My effing god, the flavor, temperature, and texture were all mind-blowing. After that first bite, I was already sad that at some point, we would have eaten the whole thing. I wanted to eat that soufflé until end times.

We sadly, and with much regret, indeed finished our savory, knowing that the sweet would soon arrive to dull the pain. Okay, imagine the freshest strawberries topped lightly with powdered sugar, all sitting on top of an expertly cooked, sweetened soufflé. I'm not always keen on sweets and desserts. But coupled with a coffee, Jacqueline's sweet soufflé perfectly completed what would've already been an amazing experience.

We went into the kitchen before we left so we could thank this amazing woman who has been working her craft since 1979. She thanked us, mostly in French, and I knew that it was a night I would remember for the rest of my life.

Seriously, the only thing missing with this place and my experience there is that it's *not* in Paris. And that's only if I force myself to find a single thing "wrong" with it.
author: Jeff H.

description: 4 Stars for the Grand Marnier Soufflé - Yummy. The place is open till 11pm, we entered around 9:45pm and was advised that it will take over 1 hour for the soufflé before we were seated by the server. We opted to wait and have a drink -- which was a good idea and the soufflé arrived within 1/2 hour.  Worth the wait.
author: S W.

description: What a GREAT place!  We have been coming here for years.  The staff is super nice and service is very very good.  And the strawberry souffle is pure summer happiness.  Chef Jacqueline is a treasure.
author: Dean S.

description:
A return visit.
A cheery and gracious chef.
Birthday memories.

A wall of sea green.
A pair of red roses.
A flickering tea light.
Tables for two.

A duo of debonair waiters.
A warm and crispy baguette.
A spinach and goat cheese salad.
Bread to clean the plate.

A cloud of eggs. 
A salty gruyere and mushroom mix.
Prosciutto swirls.

A piping hot souffle encore.
A happy pile of blueberries.
Powdery sugar.

A two and a half hour
Souffle mandated conversation.

Serious sweethearts only.


(Merci Chef Jacqueline!)
author: Amy C.

description:
First off, if you read the review from C.K. I can say disregard as its a rubbish review.  Location is fine, not loud but subtle.  Inside is clean and tidy but not roomy.  Service was outstanding. 

Food, which is why we went is delicious.  Their French bread w/sweet cream butter let's say I had 3 baskets myself!   

Spinach bacon salad was good.  

French onion soup is as hot as a nuclear reactor, broth is to die for w/flavor and not a dinky bowl at all. 

The prosciutto quiche is huge, fluffy and delicious.  

We passed on dessert as plans to go to ghiradellis was in store but from What we saw and heard it's worth while.  

We'd def return and do recommend you try.
author: Rick H.

description:
Cafe Jacqueline is a quaint charming little French restaurant in North Beach with only two waiters, one dishwasher, and Ms. Jacqueline in the kitchen baking one soufflé at a time. 
There are only a little over ten tables in the restaurant, so I would make reservations in advance if possible. It's amazing to find these types of places in cities like this, but I'm all for it. Each soufflé is impeccable in taste. If anything, you have to save room for the strawberry soufflé dessert. You will not be disappointed!
author: Steve N.

description:
Reservations are a must at this cozy intimate place specializing and turning out the best souffles in the U.S.Chef Jacqueline is French and commands the kitchen and personally makes every entree or dessert souffle.She insists on the finest ingredients...grows her own herbs....that explain the incredible taste sensation.
The two waiters have been loyally with her for years,and have a great sense of humor,as well as providing a level of service that is a cut above.You cannot go wrong with any dish here.This is a 'Must Do" in San Francisco.
author: Mike H.

description:
I'd made a reservation weeks in advance for a Saturday and it was a good thing I did. Cafe Jacqueline is a small and intimate place and even as we were leaving, the tables continued to fill.
There were 3 of us and we knew to plan for a 2 1/2 hour meal. There is no way to rush the process so the key is to settle in, order salads and soup, and have a little wine to enjoy the time while your souffle(s) are prepared.
We ordered an onion soup, a butter lettuce salad and a cucumber salad. (all yummy) And we gave our souffle orders at the same time. 
Knowing that 3 people would do well with 2 dinner souffles and 1 dessert souffle to share, we had a difficult time in selecting from the delectable menu. 
We settled upon a classic gruyere and a fruits de mer (seafood). But we need to return during crab season because that would have been a have-to. Our dessert souffle? Lemon. Another hard choice. Neighboring tables had the strawberry and it was beautiful. 
What a fun treat to enjoy the flavorful fluffy wonders coming from Jacqueline's little kitchen. And, there she is, in the back of the restaurant whipping up each creation one by one. Merci, Madame Jacqueline!
We shall return and work our way through the menu, trying all the other beautiful souffles. Can't wait.
author: Jillian R.

description:
I do not come often but Chez J has been a favorite treat for over 25 years. Went tonight for a special occasion and both food and service was ok. Service - empty glasses, bottles and bread baskets left on small table while staff passed by several times.  Food - two savory souffles were good. We got the lobster and the white corn, garlic ginger. The Lobster was good. The corn one was fantastic. They recommended a terrific while and red Bourdeaux. The two salads were fine - cucumber and endive / roquefort. 

The dessert souffles were both service under cooked. Not sure if the oven wasn't working properly - after 25+ years I suspect they've perfected the cook time. As the waiter cut into the dessert souffles they were pure liquid beneath the surface. 

We were there for 3 hours. It was a lovely setting. Two significantly undercooked dessert souffles and no acknowledgement of the situation was a real bummer.
author: Olga M.

description:
With all the talk about how good the French Onion soup is and the amazingness of the soufflés and I can fully state that given the price of this experience Cafe Jacqueline is sadly overrated. Now perhaps my American tongue is doing a disservice to our French Allies here. However, since starting my journey for the best French Onion soup, I have had many bowls in many places and this was not one that stood out. Again I may be Impermeable to the genuine French taste evoked by our sweet chef. Alas the reason for my dissent is as follows.

The soup simply tasted as the most saltiest broth to ever hit my pallet. The cheese was not of the traditional stringy and creamy variety, but rather a gummy "Goyard" cheese. 

The Strawberry Soufflé had delicious strawberries, but after that the rest was actually pretty bland, and again not trying to sound unsophisticated, but we were hungry and yeah not blown away by the flavor.

My biggest criticism is simply that the flavor of the experience did not justify the price. There is an expectation where when you pay for $80+ worth of food you are going to get an awesome experience and that was not the experience here. The soufflé should be priced $30 and the soup at $12 not $45 and $18. Still plenty of margin for you here and I'm not left questioning if I made an error in special occasion judgement.
author: Dustin M.

description:
Good grief, while I totally love the vast culinary options San Francisco offers, reading some
of the negative reviews on this treasure exhibits how modern pretentiousness is warping what actually counts as a memorable dining experience.

No, Cafe Jacqueline doesn't have the hippest decor. The servers don't look like they spent a day chopping wood and styling their beards. The cafe doesn't dwell in artisan craft brews or cocktails made from 20
ingredients that you've never heard of. The place feels like it has lived in a time capsule and is perhaps one table too crowded, but this matters not one bit.

Cafe Jacqueline pulls one punch - handmade entree and dessert soufflés to order that are impeccable. The menu offers a handful of h'ordeurves, salads and soups to enhance the meal (the French onion soup is as good as it gets), but the focus are the sweet and savory cloudy creations of Chef Jacqueline Margulis, who can still be seen whisking eggs in the kitchen nearly 40 years after opening her establishment.

Make note, much of the negative marks presented in other reviews expose the diners' ignorance to soufflé process and quality. Complaints that the soufflés take too long - handmade to order, one at a time - are unwarranted. They do take long - up to 45 minutes for savory, 30 for dessert - but this is par for the course when you're receiving a made-from-scratch soufflé. These aren't prepped by line cooks. Each is made by the owner who executes every step of the process herself. You can watch her work as you pass through the kitchen on the way to the restroom. That some of the dessert soufflés are runny in their centers is a desired quality - it's not undercooked. The dessert soufflé is self-saucing. Lap up the sweet sauce with the baked portion - it's divine, not an error.

I don't advise stopping by Jacqueline on a whim. Even if you order dessert, it won't be an in and out experience. Time is supposed to stop here and focus is turned to the incomparable, yet simply presented soufflés and hopefully good company you're with.

Service will seem slow by comparison to restaurants that design their experiences to be 2 hours or less, but you quickly realize these guys are skillfully pacing a timeless dining experience that is supporting the work their chef is doing in the kitchen. I only deducted one star from my score due to coffee/tea not being offered until after or dessert soufflés on the table, leaving us with completely empty table - we'd declined further glasses of wine - for the 25-30 minutes we waited for dessert. A cup of coffee/tea would've bridged the expected wait nicely.

In a city overrun with talented chefs and creative dishes, this old school gem still deserves to be called original. I'd imagine that when Jacqueline retires, she will close her establishment rather than pass it on. She has to be approaching this time. Don't miss out on a truly unique and historically significant San Francisco culinary experience.
author: Charley C.

description:
According to the Walter Isaacson biography of Steve Jobs, his favorite restaurant in the world was Cafe Jacqueline. 

This quant 10 table soufflé restaurant is staffed by Jacqueline, her sous chef, and two flamboyant male servers in their 40s. Jacqueline is in her 80s and prefers to speak her native French. She's run the cafe for 40 years. Her servers have worked there for 30 years each. I've been there 3 time before and each visit has been divine. 

6 eggs per dinner souffle
2 eggs per dessert souffle
2 people per table
10 tables
2 table turns per night
50 weeks per year
5 days per week
40 years
========
Jacqueline has personally whisked 4,800,000 eggs at Cafe Jacqueline

Be sure to thank Jacqueline. You can see her in the kitchen whisking a handful of eggs behind the egg bowl I've ever seen. She whisks each souffle herself. And they are delicious.
author: Neal M.

description:
My boyfriend and I go here after our birthday dinners. We love it!

It's such a cute date night! It's a cozy and romantic place to take your significant other. On top of that, the soufflés are just phenomenal.
author: Van Bich N.

description: Are you tired of the same cookie cutter restaurants?  The same hamburger and fries?  The same salads?  Banal, boring and uninspired?  Or so overly inspired that they all still taste mediocre?  Well, then try this hidden gem!  How many restaurants have you been to recently where the fabulous chef owner is still standing in the kitchen behind a large basket of fresh eggs awaiting to impart her expertise and years of culinary experience in order to personally prepare your amazing dinner?  The souffle' is amazing, light, delicate, flavorful and a true treat to the senses.  The French onion soup is perfect. The staff is polite and professional.  You can actually have a conversation without yelling over the background music.  If you have not been to Cafe Jacqueline I encourage you to go.  It is a bucket list experience.
author: T H.

description: This cafe has a cute environment and great food. Jacqueline has been in the kitchen cooking every meal for the past 37 years. Her love for food and soufflé shows in her delicious meals. The restaurant itself has very dim lighting, the tables are too close together and the food is expensive. The experience, however, is very unique.
author: Natalia R.

description:
It's been yrs since I've been here, but the one time I did, sooooo good. 
That's all I've got to say. Seriously, go try it out.
author: Viv D.

description:
Extravagance, decadence, souffle, Steve Jobs. This was one of Steve Job's favorite restaurants... and now I see why. 

The chef, owner, grand dame of souffle chefs, Jacqueline herself is a passionate lady who dedicated her entire life to making souffles. It's that like documentary Jiro, except, it's a woman who makes souffles... 

She is there every night and only has one person washing dishes, another prepping food, two waiters, and herself making the food. Talk about loving what you do... she could have easily had an apprentice or paid someone to take over some nights, but she didn't. This restaurant is definitely not under any financial monopoly because it's almost always a full house. Jacqueline doesn't own an electric mixer, she beats those eggs manually herself every night... have you ever tried to whip up cream with a whisk? Exhausting right?! Not for Jacqueline. It's very admirable how rigid she is with her practice. She refuses to have an electric egg beater or hire anyone to beat the eggs.

Tips: Call and make reservations ahead of time. If you want to walk in and dine then do so on a weekday, the earlier the better- they open at 5:30. If you plan on having appetizers, mains, and dessert then prepare to have a long dinner up to 3 hours. Parking is tricky so make sure you give yourself ample amount of time to hunt for a spot and walk. Cash and credit is accepted. Souffles are large and big enough for two or three people. Ideal date night spot. Steve Jobs had his bachelor party here and ordered souffles all night long.

I absolutely love her FRENCH ONION SOUP, it is perfection. The Grand Mernier is my favorite soufflé... all the souffles are delicious, however this is the most delicious one! and remember to thank Madame Jaqueline before you leave the restaurant! If you want to be fancy and say something in French say "tout va bien, merci beaucoup! Bonne Nuit" (toot va bien, mercy boo-coo! Bon newie).

Getting a bottle of wine is rather reasonable, they have bottles starting at $25, she stays true to French table wine standards.

It kind of scares me to think what will happen to this restaurant once she retires if ever... At that point in time would she decide to train others and have them take over? Would it just close? All I'm really concerned with is when I'm going to visit next. Do yourself a favor and treat yourself!
author: Trisha W.

description:
Best onion soup, impressive soufflés!

Jacqueline's work really demands respect, knowing how hard it is the create soufflés in the first place. She offers a variety of savory soufflés as well as some dessert soufflés. We ordered the white corn, ginger, garlic soufflé and the chocolate soufflé. I think they were strong choices, and I was just so excited to have them arrive at the table (takes about forty min for a soufflé to come out from the kitchen)

This is definitely a quaint restaurant and should be a place you come to to have an intimate dinner since you WILL be sitting and talking to whoever accompanies you for at least an hour (assuming you order a soufflé). You will be provided baskets of bread and butter to entertain yourselves before the entrees come out ;) Those were quite delicious as well.
author: Kathy Z.

description: I eat a lot in this city. I love Statebird, Liholiho...all the usuals. From taquerias to dim sum to Michellin, this city is great. But this place remains maybe my favorite dining experience in SF. Jaqueline and her bowl of eggs are creating something magical. The waiters are professional and no-nonsense (for the experienced diner), yet considerate and warm. The atmosphere is perfect for this type of place. But food is always what counts the most, right?  - the souffles and french onion soup are insanely good! Jaqueline and her bowl of eggs...
author: William A.

description:
Everything was way overpriced. French onion soup (single portion) was $15. Was it the best french onion soup I've ever had, yes; but I don't think it's $15 dollars good. Another example is a can of coke. Yes, there is a mark up at any restaurant so go ahead and charge $2 or even $3 but no, they charge $5 here.  Souffles are not as common so price point is hard to gauge. We had a mushroom and leek savory souffle for $35 (portion for two). It tasted like an omelet. For dessert we had the strawberry souffle for $40 (portion for two). It came undercooked so it was still watery in the center. We didn't say anything since it took over an hour to come out, we didn't want them to make another one and for us to wait another hour. The flavor however was great. I would come back for dessert if I had over an hour to spare.

I called to reserve, they didn't pick up so I left a message. They called me back in a few hours and confirmed. I mentioned to them that we are celebrating a birthday. They said "all we do is stick a candle in it". I said ok. The day that we dined there, the dessert came out without a candle.

Service was good but they could not help us when we could not decide what to order. They said everything on the menu is good. So we asked if there were any more popular items, they said they are all popular. 

I say order what you usually like. For example, if you like mushrooms, order the mushroom souffle. The base of every souffle essentially are the same.  

Our entire meal took 2.5 hours. Be prepared to wait for your food and pay a lot for it.
author: Andy W.

description:
Came here for dinner at 5:30 pm on a Saturday with friends and we were so excited to try the soufflés after reading the other Yelp reviews on here.

FOOD:
Our table of 4 ordered quite a few things but here are some notable highlights that make me drool.
-Complimentary Bread: Maybe I was just hungry but that bread hit the spot! Nice crusty exterior with good chew.
-French Onion Soup: Usually not a fan of French onion soup, but this may have converted me. The soup was served piping hot and so delicious. Definitely get this!
-Chanterelle Mushroom & Garlic Soufflé (special that day): First thought: These souffles are huge! It was my first time having a savory soufflé and it was delicious! The texture and flavor of the cheese with every bite kept me wanting more. I can't wait to try the other savory soufflé options. 
-Grand Marnier Soufflé: Also huge but MUST GET. It's that good.
-Chocolate Soufflé: Really good. Nice chocolate flavor, but if I had to choose just one, I'd go with Grand Marnier.
-House coffee: Both regular and decaf coffee with our dessert soufflés went perfectly together.

SERVICE:
Excellent service. We had a great time with the waiter who helped us. 

TIPS:
Definitely get reservations ahead of time since I saw some people turned away at the door when they tried to do a drop in. Seatings are only at 5:30 pm or 8 pm since soufflés take time to prepare! Go with a few friends and take the time to chat and catch-up while you wait for the soufflés. This also allows you to try many different soufflé flavors! Also, one dessert soufflé serves 2-4, but if you order 2 soufflés for 4, you won't be sorry.
author: Clarissa L.

description:
I had great expectations as i went but they were totally unwarranted. The place is really elegant, and might be ideal for a romantic getaway and intimate soiree, though i would not recommend it for big groups since the indoors is not that spacious and it might be a little hard to swing a table for a bigger one as well. Of course the souffles are somehow famed and i wanted to definitely try them.

Onion soup might be your appetizer to go, which also goes well with the french bread they bring at the beginning. They also bring you a tasty butter that is a good accompaniment, but for the pricetag, i am not sure it is that superior or exceptional. I have to give to Jacqueline though, the place feels and tastes genuinely french not somehow americanized and feels definitely old school.

Salads are also a good bet, especially the one with spinach and bacon is really tasty. 

Souffles will be your next meals. They are pricy and not that big. You might be a fan of seafood so get the fruits de mer which is one of the best thing they make among the souffles, and it is definitely tasty. Though for the price again, i am not sure it is worth it. 

Spinach or tomato souffles might be better for vegeterians and those who don't enjoy seafood. Chanterelle mushroom one looked good when the next table ordered it but i am definitely skeptic about how the prosciutto complements the taste, cause it kinda seemed a little bit disintegrated/hanging over the thing just like that.

Dessert. Well that is a lot of souffle but i still would go with the strawberry or the berry one instead of the acridy lemon souffle or the mushy chocolate one, which one the biggest disappointment of the night. Beware the plates, they are scorching hot.

They also have nice reds to sip with your meal which i feel is essential as this is a french place that gets as french as it could. But i have to repeat, the place is really squeezed somehow and that romantic atmosphere can be a little too crowded to tolerate, especially when you consider the fame the place has built itself which causes every single table to be filled.

People are not rude, that is a plus, especially when you consider the price! (I am not counting the tips or the drinks and tax, but the price for 2 people might easily exceed 200 before even those.)
author: Jacqueline H.

description: This was my first time here.  I will be going back. Quiet, intimate, impeccable service.  The food though, I can't even describe how delicious it is.  We felt like we were in France.  Do not come here if you are in a rush though.  This place makes you want to sit back, relax, and have some great wine between courses.  Jacqueline is a culinary genius
author: Shannon T.

description:
This is one of the toughest reviews I've had to write simply because it's souffle.  But I'm honest and I'll call it how I saw it.

Rule #1: Call head and make a reservation because this place is super small (in other words, don't start bitching when you try to walk in and find that the wait is enormously long).  In fact, just call days ahead and leave a message, because that's how I got my reservation squared away quickly and painlessly.  Might not matter as much for a 6:30 PM reservation, but 8 PM?  Yeah, might want to make sure of that.

Rule #2: Make sure you go with people that you enjoy the company of, because the wait for your food is long...EXCRUCIATINGLY long.  I understand it's souffle, and it's not going to be quick to make souffles.  That said, it does take a long time and there's really no way around it.  I try to make a rule about not eating too much bread before the food gets there because I want to save my stomach for the main event.  But when you're hungry and it takes over an hour to bring out the souffles, rules tend to be broken.  And of course you can't just sit there twiddling your thumbs waiting for your food in the meantime.  So practice those conversation skills, you'll need them.

Rule #3: Go to the bathroom at least once so you can see Jacqueline at work.  It's in the back of the restaurant, and you have to pass through the kitchen to get there.  

The food itself varied from underwhelming to amazing for me, so here's the rundown:

Cucumber Salad: Not bad, appreciated how thinly sliced the salad was.  Quite refreshing and very light, but personally wouldn't have gotten it.

French Onion Soup: Rare is the occasion that I get to try to french onion soup, so when I saw it on the menu no decision had to be made.  Phenomenally good soup.  Not too salty, perfect blend of cheese and croutons.  Definitely worth getting, and quite necessary given how long the wait for souffles is.

Prosciutto and Mushroom Souffle: Very fluffy, but too salty for my preference.  Probably because of the prosciutto, but still.  Given that this was my call, I was disappointed.  Not my favorite for sure.

Seafood Souffle: Definitely the better savory souffle I tried.  Nowhere near as salty as the prosciutto souffle.  The scallops blended well with the fluffiness of the souffle.  Worth the $53, although I'd probably want to try the other ones first before anointing automatic repeat status.

Peach Souffle: Easily the best thing I had all evening.  When I think souffle, I think sweet and sugary, and this peach souffle delivered on all counts.  Not TOO sugary to overload the senses, but the right combination of peachy and sweet flavor.  This is worth having dreams at night about.

Last notes:

The souffles are surprisingly very massive.  One savory souffle and one dessert souffle will unquestionably be more than enough to fill up two people.  And when you're all done, you've probably ended up spending 3 hours here.  Long, long dinner, but with the right person (or persons), it's time well spent.
author: Alexander Y.

description:
Parisian, shabby chic, romantic and intimate. Just a few words I would choose to describe this cafe that brings you straight back to Paris... Until you step outside and see the steep streets of San Francisco and you snap back to reality.

The menu is simple and has quite a selection of savory and sweet soufflés. The soufflés are large and shareable between 2-4 people depending on people's appetites. We shared a French onion soup which was buttery and hot to perfection and for dessert the seasonal strawberry soufflé. The soufflé was very fluffy and more dense (the ones that my mom and I made in Paris were less dense, but it could be due to the different ingredients) but overall it was the perfect sweetness, fresh and fluffy! 

Our bill for just a soup and soufflé was $60 but the soufflé was so big in portion we definitely had leftovers. If you're craving a soufflé and don't have a budget for a Michelin star restaurant then I would give this place a try. Good soufflés are hard to find so I'll be definitely be back!
author: Andrea P.

description: Cafe Jacqueline is one of my favorite restaurants! I've been there multiple times with my sister, and we always have a good time. The soufflés are amazing, and so tasty. Jacqueline makes them one by one, with so much love. I had the one with mushroom, garlic, and basil. The service is also great!! And the chocolate soufflé is something you should not skip on. It's delicious!!!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I haven't been to Café Jacqueline for way too long...Four of us went which is a good # to share..Jacqueline at age 80 ( she might not be happy I divulged!!) remembered a dinner she cooked at my house more than 20 years ago!!!

we shared two entrée souffles ...tomato and cilantro...mushroom and prosciutto..both recommended by our wonderful server Matt....we opted for a tangy lemon for dessert...the wine pairings..Bandol Rose and a Sancerre were perfect.

I speak French so had a delightful chat with Jacqueline ..until..she said.."assez" and shooed me back to our table....
If one lets their imagination wander a bit ...simple décor..narrow street...you are IN PARIS

I plan on returning SOON...twas worth every penny !!!
author: Bart G.

description:
We were thrilled to have a reservation here for my father's birthday dinner. Very humble-looking on the outside (and on the inside)..it kind of feels like you're visiting a French lady's home. This intimate experience continued when our waiter really got to know us, and wondered what kind of flavors we were looking for. 

Oh! Warning for those of you who may be putt off by ill-mannered people: There was a gentleman there with an impressive mustache whose behavior towards us left us speechless, really. He waved his hand and looked away as he gestured towards another table and said that "he would rather us sit there, instead of where we wanted to." (The restaurant was 3/4 of the way empty, by the way). He said another comment during dinner, that left us feeling unwelcomed (I'm forgetting what he said, but I'm remembering that all four of us were confused and put off by his demeanor). We were surprised, however, that he treated the table next to us with such kindness, calling each person by their first name. We suspect he favored them because they were regular paying customers. 

The waiter's behavior was completely different! Quite refreshing. So. on with the food. 

It's a wonderful time to be with people you like to be with (because you will be there for at least two hours). The food is a wonderful experience...and that being said....GET THE FRENCH ONION SOUP. DO IT. I promise you will like it. (unless you despise onions). The souffles: I'm not sure if I'm not a souffle person, or what...but none of them really "wowwed" me. It was a great experience, though, overall!
author: Miriam F.

description:
This has been my favorite restaurant in SF since before Yelp.  Last month I got to visit again and it is as good as I remember it.  

Our waiter is really nice in that old school way, treating us like regulars even though it has been a few years since our lat visit.  The savory souffle entrees are good, the desserts are divine.  We tried the seasonal apricot one and loved it.  

Their wine list is very reasonably priced, especially compared to the food. Red, rose and whites from many regions of France, and I do mean many regions, beyond your regular Bordeaux and Burgandy.  The waiter let us sample before deciding on one.

If you use the restroom, you'll walk pass the kitchen and see Jacqueline hard at work beating up eggs.  It's eggs everywhere!  Jacqueline is the soul of this place, so if you haven't tried this place, do so before she retires!!
author: Krys P.

description: Fantastic, beautiful, artful, fresh and absolutely savory soufflés!  This place is one of a kind, you won't ever have an evening like this anywhere else.  Take your time and enjoy it all!  Bring a bottle of wine or two, and love the experience of incredibly meticulously crafted food.  Jacqueline is totally adorable and so friendly and welcoming.  The waiters were wonderfully endearing and fun to chat with.  And the food, the food the food.  Bring an appetite, these soufflés are big, no joke.  But hey, if you don't finish them, best breakfast you'll ever have the next day!  We had the crab and the seasonal morel mushroom, and both were out of this world.  For desert we picked a a lime soufflé, dreamy!  All was paired with a light chardonnay.  Bon appetit!
author: Pseudo E.

description:
Our good friends said they managed to get a last minute reservation here and were very excited.  They warned us that this restaurant is a commitment.  It's made to order soufflés.  Neither my wife nor I really think much of soufflés, but we trust our friends' taste.

We absolutely loved it.  The restaurant is quaint and reminds you that there are still unique wonderful establishments in this city.  They have the best french onion soup any of us have ever had anywhere--including France.  The soufflés were marvels to the eye and mouth.  Both servers who ran the front of the house were absolute pros.  They weren't syrupy, but genuinely engaging.  

Here's the deal though.  It's a commitment.  Don't come here unless you want to spend time having some wine and chatting with whomever you're here with.  All the food is made from scratch in a tiny kitchen by the owner.  So if you have a show to get to, don't want to talk to the person you're with, or just otherwise have ants in your pants, there are lots of restaurants that are happy to keep you busy and turn tables.  This place is super leisurely and super good.
author: Jason S.

description: I'm French, so yes, I wanted to give this a 5. I can't however. I was dumbfounded by the waiter, though he did provide entertainment, not necessarily of the professional sort. He thought the word, "No" would suffice as an answer when a bottle of wine was ordered that they happened to be out of. So we followed up with an odd look - no response, and then a request for different wine. Then we ordered the figs. Which was then followed with a "No" again. This time however, after another odd look and an eyebrow raise - he did say they were out of every appetizer on their menu. Hmmm. We then ordered several salads and 2 souffles. Only when he needed us to move tables in the middle of our meal, due to incorrectly seating people without planning for a reservation of 6 did he become more friendly.  He thought a glass of wine would suffice as a thank you for one member of our party.  It was just an overall less than impressive experience - including watching him dissuade two walk ins by telling them "we only serve souffles and it takes hours"... I just don't understand that approach or his role at the restaurant. It's not an experience i need to have again.
author: Sheryl F.

description:
Really feels like you are in a sweet little French restaurant in Paris. Simply and beautifully decorated. Ordered the Grand Marnier soufflé which was an amazing experience. Wonderful wait staff -  knowledgeable about their wines and very accommodating and gracious hosts.
