Be sure to bring your appetite, and your wallet. It is a little pricey but worth every cent. 

Cannot wait to return here.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
My bff took me here for my birthday last year as a surprise after I had been talking about this place for years. Honestly I didn't know what to expect because it was in an interesting part of town (not bad, just interesting), and the place looked small and intimate but nothing like what others had described.

We sat down and were promptly served with waters and menus. The service was good, and the waiters were very friendly. The whole place is cute, but kind of quiet so it's not really a good place for a date or if you're shy.

I was really particularly curious about how the savory souffles would turn out since I only had sweet ones before. I would say although these souffles are absolutely delicious and amazing, they're definitely not what you would get if you ordered one at a 2 Michelin Star restaurant. The texture and taste is different. The ones here are a little less airy and a little more dense, but still puff up and the flavors are AMAZING. But just be prepared for it to be different.

With that said, the peach dessert souffle. OMG. Must. Get. Definitely recommended!
author: Lorrie M.

description: Arrived with reservations at 6:00pm knowing that it takes time to get your order with my sister and brother-in-law in tow back in March, took 3 1/2 hours to get two soufflés that were like salt licks. When I asked if Jacqueline had started our desert soufflés and found out she hadn't after placing the order four hours earlier I cancelled and left with a $300 tab.  I had tried to pre-order the week before but Jacqueline refused.  Had told her the day before I wanted a lobster soufflé and she had no lobster when we came, really disappointed the second time around.  Sorry Jacqueline but sending your dishwasher out and around the block on his bike to ask us about our dissatisfaction was just sad, why didn't you just come out to our table and talk with us?
author: Mark T.

description:
The soufflé restaurant.  The uber romantic restaurant.  And contrary to the location, the miraculously very quiet restaurant. Once you step inside, there is no evidence that you're on Grant Ave. btwn Green & Union.  Amazing.  Intimate as all get out.  Candlelit, fresh roses, the whole nine yards.  Gentlemen, this is your destination when you want to romance your lady.  

The deets...
Aside from starters like French onion soup, caviar, & salads, it's all a soufflé.  Entree soufflés range from $30 - $60 bucks, but are meant for 2 people to share.  The dessert soufflés range from $30 - $40 bucks.  My 2 cents?  The crab soufflé & the peach soufflé for dessert.  Peaches being seasonal, it's not always available.  Pro tip...you can call ahead & request a bottle of champagne be chilled & waiting for you @ your table.  I was lucky enough to be treated to this surprise once.  A memory forever.

Tiny, sweet, & indulgent, Cafe Jacqueline is a destination restaurant that is meant for memories to be made.  Go.

5 stars
author: Veronica M.

description:
Went here for my anniversary. The service was phenomenal and the soufflés will stick in my memory for a long while.

Ordered the Gruyere Soufflé and Chocolate Soufflé for dessert. Amazing!!!
author: Melissa F.

description: Such a cute romantic spot!! Tiny seating area so it's intimate, candle-lit, and overall fantastic ambiance. I actually had my first souffle here and it was incredible! So was my french onion soup. Overall, wonderful place that I'll come back to for special occasions and date nights.
author: Ke D.

description:
Cafe Jacqueline is a small gem in San Francisco.  Specializing in souffles, it's long been a favorite as a date spot and for those intimate meals. 

We first tried Jacqueline years ago and were excited to return again. In some ways, the place has not changed.  It's still small and charming.  The menu is essentially soups, savory souffles and dessert souffles. 

Other areas are less appealing. Although they aren't quite as busy as they used to be, reservations are still a phone call, leave a message, and call back.  They don't answer during the day and the call backs can happen up to a week later.  

Service was a little bit more perfunctory than I recall and despite not having several options (prosciutto and mushroom, several drink selections), the waiter tells you they don't have any and proceeds to leave as you decide only to come back minutes later.  This was with a mostly empty restaurant.  Our final order:

French Onion Soup - absolutely delicious. Piping hot, gooey rich cheese and fantastic broth flavor.  It was a touch salty. 

Shiitake, garlic, basil souffle - all the souffles and all food, even the soup, takes time.  This isn't a quick in and out place.  The souffle was delicious but admittedly salty, even more so the soup. We drank water constantly through the meal. 

White Chocolate Souffle - the highlight.  The dessert was perfect.  Not too sweet and super light and fluffy. 

Cafe Jacqueline is a great choice for souffle fans.  The perfunctory service, long waits, and salty food though perhaps explain why the crowds are not quite as prominent as they were a few years ago. 

Cafe Jacqueline accepts credit cards including American Express.
author: Randy F.

description: Have been coming here since the 80's.  A true san francisco landmark.  Great place for a romantic date and dont forget to do the dessert.  Great wine list and remember to always make a reservation especially on the weekend.  I Love this place.
author: Michael M.

description: We've walked by this for years and finally came tonight. And wow...I'm ashamed I didn't make it in here sooner. It's everything you want from your neighborhood "go-to". The service is on point and real and the food is fresh and home feeling. Jacqueline melts your heart. She loves what she does and loves having you there and you taste TNT in her food. Lets just say my walk to the bathroom was just to her in action and my heart actually fluttered. She's the most loving person you'll see - and I hugged her after my meal. Been there 37 yeArs doing what she loves.  Come here. But don't tell too many ppl because it's a Goldmine
author: tricia m.

description:
For the price of a meal for 4 here, you can fly to Paris and have a wonderful dinner instead of in this "hole in the wall",  literally.
You will wait a loooong time with no forwarning of the length of time the wait will be. This would for a nice courtesy wouldn't you say?  So  much for outstanding service for the outstanding prices, crinkly paper menu, 15 year old dusty fake flowers in the window, a door full of ugly stickers which are such an eyesore (a well-esteemed eatery in S.F. would never clutter their door or window with these ugly pasties). When you wait for so long you notice the cruddy look of the place such as the dirty worn door frame and unattractive bathroom. The place could really use a do-over....too much competition in S.F.
Prices are a king's ransom for what you get, (such as well over $10. for a little spinch with a few bacon bits and pine nuts) and the  food is not as memorable as the high price.
author: Claudia K.

description:
Delicious little restaurant, where soufflés are an art form - Jacqueline is a culinary genius! I've been there several times and have sampled a number of the soufflés: the garlic and the leek savory soufflés are subtle, foamy and delicious. The chocolate and Grand Marnier dessert soufflés are equally amazing and unique.
The setting is nice and lends itself to a romantic dinner. Even if the note ends up a bit pricey, the experience is every bit worth it :)
author: Bérénice B.

description: This was Steve Jobs' favorite SF restaurant. You can't get more romantic, or delicious, than this. Take your time with salad, soup, wine, a savory souffle for dinner and a sweet one for dessert. It's an intimate, low-key, candlelit place. Be sure to visit the ladies' room, as that includes a walk past the venerable chef, Jacqueline, in her element--wearing a white chef's hat over her white hair, and reaching her beautiful aged hands into a hanging wire basket of eggs to begin her magic. She personally makes every souffle that is consumed in this place, which is why there are only about 10 small tables. Call for reservations. I ask to go here every year on our anniversary. This place is not to be missed.
author: Patsy F.

description: The place had character but is way overpriced.  Seating was uncomfortable.  Service was so-so and the soufle was sub-par.
author: Rob R.

description:
Amazing is not the word to describe this experience. Even the water was amazing.  The smell alone was enough for a five star review. Matt was super nice. Our table wasn't ready because the previous table wouldn't leave. He handled it very well. 
Well worth the wait.
author: Tim G.

description: Fabulous place!! Delicious food!! French onion soup the best I've ever had. Jacqueline is back there in the kitchen cooking each soufflé with love.
author: Jennifer R.

description:
Cafe Jacqueline is unquestionably one of the best restaurants in San Francisco.  However, it is not for everyone.

Here's why you should go to Cafe Jacqueline:

* You want a truly spectacular souffle -- or two.
* You're looking for a very romantic night out with your sweetie.
* You want a leisurely dinner with plenty of time to talk.
* You enjoy classy, friendly service with lots of personal attention.
* You enjoy interesting and inexpensive French wine.
* Jacqueline can't be that far away from retiring, and once she does, there will never be another restaurant like this in SF.

Here's why you should NOT go to Cafe Jacqueline:

* You're vegan (you can have ... a salad?) or paleo.
* You're in a hurry, and  don't have two hours or more to spend on dinner.
* You don't have $70 each to spend on dinner.
* You want something other than a souffle.
* You didn't make a reservation.
* You need to park near the restaurant.

Oh, also: if you do make a reservation for the second seating on a Friday or Saturday night, be prepared to wait.
author: Josh B.

description: Having lived in the Bay area for three years and been visiting San Francisco on vacation and business probably 35 times. We love the North Beach area and have eaten in the neighborhood regularly. We had been walking down Grant Street during the afternoon and spotted this quaint place with multiple awards posted on their door. We loved to atmosphere and called for reservations for that night. 28 seats require reservations any night of the week. The food, incredible, the service, friendly and responsive, the experience, memorable and we will return when back in the city by the bay.
author: Jeff B.

description: Absolutely overpriced and underwhelming. Soggy eggy $30+ dollar soufflé entrees and desserts. A plate of sliced tomatoes with basil "herbed tomato salad" for $19? Also prepare to wait 2+ hours for your meal. Not great.
author: Adele A.

description:
Oh My God!!!!

Sister & brother in law brought me here tonight and I'm in food heaven. 
We had:
*cauliflower soufflé 
*leak soufflé 
*strawberry soufflé 

You're going to have to take me home with a crane but I'm in food coma and it was the coolest unique experience -
The music is classical or choir 
The ambiance is simple but perfect as of we should just wait for the main attraction which is the soufflé. 
French French French 
And Jacqueline has been here for thirty five years making about 60 soufflés a night and only She Makes them! That's crazy and so incredibly awesome. I want yo kiss her. 
Thank you !! 
I will be back.
author: G T.

description:
What a fun and unique restaurant! Delicious french bread (hot and fresh), French Onion Soup had a lot of flavor, Garlic, Basil and Shitake Mushroom souffle was very good too. Top honors go to the fresh strawberry Souffle. Sooooo damn good! 

Good wine selection and fun staff. Hope to meet the famous Jacqueline one day!
author: Ginger L.

description:
wow, all these great reviews.   We must have been in an alternate universe.  Our reservation was at 8 pm.    We were not seated until 9 pm and we  immediately placed our orders.    At 10 pm the appetizers arrived.   Onion soup was good.    The waiters assured the us that the $40 escargot dish was incredible.  It was an average preparation.  At 11 pm two totally burnt soufflés arrived.   We should have sent them back, but by this time we were ravenous.     Sometime after midnight the lemon soufflé  arrived.    I should say the lemon soup arrived.  There was nothing soufflé-like about it    At 1 AM  we finished our meal. We're not slow eaters.  We suffered  insanely slow and bad service.   Am sure the waiters wondered how we could have put up with this bad act.    We shouldn't have, but did.  

What's incredible about this, aside for the fact that we put up with this awful experience,  was that we had the same exact experience the last time we went there, 10 years ago. We wanted to like this restaurant.     There won't be  another visit.
author: S P.

description:
So.

Let's say you've been on a couple of dates with this guy (or gal) and don't know whether you've reached couple status or even if you have, nobody's said anything to finalize it so you can have a date to celebrate.

Cafe Jacqueline is so romantic, (by that I mean, old school romantic) I'm certain by the end of today's date you would've changed your facebook status from "it's complicated" to "I'm in a relationship with ___" 

I can only assume the little lady whipping up these magical souffles is Jacqueline herself -- you can see her when you go to the restroom as you pass by the open kitchen. No mistaking the giant pile of eggs in the big wooden bowl will be used up by the end of the night. 

Make sure to order a salad or some kind of app, your souffle can take half an hour or so to make. You love to sip wine slowly? this is the perfect place to linger over a bottle. 

The CRAB SOUFFLE!  It's $60! Whoa nelly. Serious chunks of snow crab legs in there. The souffle itself is pleasant to the eyes, silky on the tongue, and opens up to a full bloom in your mouth. I mean, who knew eggs and cream could be THIS good? (um, that's what she said??) 

So what, the service isn't the best. Order a bottle of wine (or two) and you won't even know the difference, you lush.
author: Janice C.

description: I loved this place. When you decide to come make sure that you allow to give the food and experience some time otherwise you'll go crazy. I highly suggest (if you're old enough) to enjoy a drink with the meal. Even just coming for dessert is amazing. We opted to do both savory and sweet. We did the prosciutto for dinner and grand marnier for dessert. Both were incredible. I decided to go use the restroom because I wanted to see the inside of the kitchen and to my surprise the chef! A cute little lady hard at work with a few people helping. If you want a true experience come here.
author: Guisela L.

description:
Saying "Yes" to everything landed me at Cafe Jacqueline one night recently.  

"Yes" I'll join a group going out to SF last minute because someone else was sick.  "Yes", I can drive too.  "Yes" to dinner before a show.

Whatever you do - be sure that you have TIME on your hands for this place.  First off parking is a nightmare in North Beach, so you are probably better off finding a garage you can park at.  Second, if you end up ordering several courses - it can take up to two hours easily.  Well, they are souffles and they are made from scratch.

When I see French Onion Soup on a menu, I say "Yes" immediately.  Theirs was exceptional.  Again, not a normal bowl of soup - it came piping hot out of the oven and took about 20 minutes - but was worth the wait.  (Yelp lists this at $10.50.  It is actually $15.00).  

The main course souffles feed two people each - so be prepared to team up with someone at the table and/or be willing to share.  Since I was in "Yes" mode, I ended up having the prosciutto and mushroom souffle - even though personally I am not a huge fan of prosciutto.  It was still really good!

Dessert - the table split the Lemon and Chocolate.  Warning - be CAREFUL when you eat the dessert souffles!  It's easy to inhale the powdered sugar they are topped with - and the flakes go right to the back of your throat if you aren't watching out.  COUGH- COUGH! 

Think of this place as a "special night out".  A place where you take a date on an anniversary?  It might even pass as a unique spot for a marriage proposal.  Just hope that they end up saying "Yes"!
author: Christian H.

description:
Jacqueline is the sweetest, cutest, little old French grandma I've ever met! She lovingly hand makes every soufflé that come out of her kitchen, often meaning that there really is only probably one seating per night here. You can say bonjour to her as you walk through the kitchen on your way to the bathroom, and she will greet with you a beautiful smile and a nod and a wave.

My friends and I came here for a birthday dinner (three of our birthdays are within 13 days of each other). Cafe Jacqueline is a small and romantic restaurant tucked into a crowded street in North Beach with no street sign - only the name written across its windows.

We ordered the following:
- soup du jour - leek and celery soup - perfectly seasoned with a nice thick texture
- French onion soup - the absolute BEST French onion soup I've ever had...I barely even have words to describe it, but I could barely stop eating it!
- fruits de mer soufflé - with scallops and shrimp - just perfect. Perfect. Whole pieces of shrimp and large pieces of scallops littered this soufflé so that every bite had at least one piece of seafood. The soufflé itself tasted amazing and came out piping hot, fresh from the oven.
- lobster soufflé - LOTS of lobster in here...oh man...and the soufflé was just as good as the fruits de mer.
- chocolate soufflé - I nearly choked on the first bite from the inhalation of the thick dusting of powdered sugar on top, but once we passed that, it was absolute heaven! The soufflé was almost custard-like inside and the chocolate flavor was so aromatic throughout every bite.
- strawberry soufflé (seasonal) - oh man...this may have been my favorite one of the night. It was piled high with strawberries on top and had such wonderful strawberry flavor throughout the entire soufflé! 

The best combination was actually eating both the chocolate and strawberry soufflés together...OMG...I'm drooling just thinking about these again!!

It should also be noted that the bread that was served with the meal was incredible! Talk about real rustic French bread...the crust and crunch in this baby was so perfect, and the inside was like warm, pillowy clouds.

Finally, the service for the night was absolutely amazing. Our server, Scott, did a great job making sure that we were satisfied with our food, consistently made sure our water glasses were full, and just made friendly conversation with us in genera. He made an already- delicious night even more enjoyable!

Also, just a note to people who may be looking for a quick meal - this is a place to really sit down and take your time. Jacqueline makes each soufflé from scratch and as ordered, so, yes, it will take time. Our entire meal took us about 3.5 hours, so plan accordingly!

This restaurant is great for special occasions - the prices are not so conducive to eating here often - but I will be sure to make my way back!!
author: Charissa L.

description: An outstanding, somewhat hidden gem that is among the rapidly-declining list of San Francisco restaurant treasures.  Jacqueline is positively adorable, but that didn't distort my view of the food, which was divine.  A couple of the staff have been there for many years.  Our group of four shared a single order of outstanding in-shell escargot, hearty salads, and two savory souffles.  While it was a struggle to make room, the chocolate souffle did not disappoint.  DON'T go if you're in a hurry, are cheap, or don't appreciate an old-fashioned, unpretentious dining experience.  DO go while you have the chance, as Jacqueline isn't getting any younger.
author: Andy H.

description:
Savory souffles? What??

That's right.. the most unique dinner I think I've had in SF yet. This place wowed us with their savory selections..I have only tried grand marnier souffles, and although theirs was unREAL... I want to go back to try the other dessert options as well. 

I'll keep this one short and sweet- just go here... it's worth it. And take someone special :)
author: Courtney M.

description:
I love their souffles!!  I wish I could go there more often.  It's just about its location...  It's so hard to find a parking space there but that's not their problem.  it's MY problem..

By the time I finish a savory souffle, I'm usually full.  I haven't tried their dessert, so I definitely go back there again.

5-star for sure
author: Mike M.

description:
My first souffle experience EVER.

... which is really sad considering I've been to France. Still, Cafe Jacqueline brought France to San Francisco so there's no need.

This was definitely one of those nights when all caution would be thrown to the wind. And by that, I mean we ordered a bottle of champagne and a souffle. The souffle Grand Marnier to be exact. Watching your carbs, sugar, and cholesterol? Get outta here! Life's too short.

The waiter is a character. New Yorkers won't probably be offended by his odd temperament since we're used to people like him BUT for all you other humans from small local towns and areas filled with happy people, just don't take it personally.

The champagne was just what the doctor ordered. The souffle? Words can't even begin to describe my first spoonful. I was a souffle virgin. Now I am a woman who has given into absolute sugar sin.

I desperately want to come back for a savory souffle. The thought of having lobster within one of those fluffy creations has been taunting me since I left.

Oh and make sure you go to the bathroom so you can walk through the kitchen and see Madam Jacqueline at work. I suggest having a bottle of champagne since that will guarantee a trip (or two). There is literally a basket filled with 200+ eggs next to her workstation as she's busily whisking and composing these sinfully scrumptious masterpieces of culinary perfection. Don't miss out.
author: Leslie D.

description:
My girlfriend had never had a souffle and we made a spur of the moment decision to rectify that. After a great dinner at Mission Street Oyster Bar, I called Cafe Jacqueline and made a reservation for 2 for dessert only. Because it's North Beach, parking was an absolute disaster. When I first walked in, I was a bit let down. The decor is tired and rundown and the seating was hard and uncomfortable. Also, it was stuffy and too warm. For this, I'm deducting a star. We went all out and ordered a souffle each when, to be honest, one is more than enough for two people. We enjoyed a couple of glasses of so-so wine (but at $10 a glass, I'd do it again) and chatted while we waited. The servers are classic San Francisco and added an air of timelessness to the evening. Oddly, I recommend you use the bathroom. It's a tiny nondescript bathroom but you get to walk back through the small spotless kitchen and see the huge bowl of eggs that Jacqueline goes through to make her masterpieces.

Souffles I've had before came with sauces. These did not. One chocolate and one grand marnier and they were huge, light and perfect. Pricey at $35 and $45 but I'm thrilled that my girlfriend had her first souffle that was so wonderful. 

The lighting and music were indeed romantic but if I were to want a really romantic dinner for this kind of money ($118 plus tip for the above which was basically dessert but could have been $80 had we split one), I'd want a more upscale dining room.
author: Brian B.

description:
A little cute spot hidden inside of North Beach. 
I had been here two times for their dessert, it was about 30 to 40 mins waited for the soufflé and it was HUGE, right level of sweetness and sooo fluffy. Must have a reservation before you go otherwise it will be a long wait.
author: Mavis L.

description: This place is so ridiculous - Jacqueline is great.  Make sure if you go here, you stop by the kitchen to give her your compliments!
author: Megan H.

description:
This is a very special place. We took my mom here for her birthday and it was perfect! The service is impeccable the souffles are delicious and the ambiance is perfect for an intimate meal with close friends, family or a date.

We had the Gruyere and Shitake souffles. I thought the Gruyere was a bit boring, but everyone else in our group loved it. The shitake was delicious - just the right amount of garlic and basil to make the flavors quite rich. We also ordered the spinach salad, tomato salad and two onion soups. All were extremely delicious. We ended with the Gran Marnier dessert souffle, which was good, though I think a seasonal fruit dessert would probably be the best way to go.  We were a group of 5 and this was a perfect amount of food.

Overall, I would highly recommend this place for a special occasion or a perfect date!
author: Kate B.

description: this lady knows how to make the best soufflé in town. gotta order the chocolate soufflé. you'll be hooked and coming back for more.
author: michael m.

description:
My family and I have been coming here for years, and I'm still so surprised that Cafe Jacqueline is not on more of the Bay Area's "best of" lists. It's exceptional in every way -- the food, the service, and the ambiance all are wonderful. As others reviewers have noted or alluded to, this is not a place to come if you want a quick in-and-out experience. But why you would want (or expect) that of souffles is beyond me. Jacqueline uses the freshest ingredients and her souffles are made to order. 

All of the souffles are delicious; however, the ones that stand out in my mind are the cauliflower and the leek (savory) and the lemon, the lime and the peach (sweet). While I encourage getting a savory AND a sweet with groups of three or more, when it is my husband and me, we generally begin with the French onion soup, move on to a salad (to cleanse the palate), and end with a dessert souffle. (Although, we've been known to add a savory souffle to the our order as well, and then we just take a portion of it or the dessert souffle home with us.) We enjoy a glass or bottle of wine with the meal, but even without it, Cafe Jacqueline consistently offers one of the most special nights out we've ever experienced.
author: Alison R.

description:
***EDITED: Wow, after reading 10+ reviews in a row saying how TERRIBLE the service/wait staff is, I feel like my 3 star rating is being way too generous. THE STAFF IS ATROCIOUS.***

It was the best and worst dinner experience that we have ever had.

We had the whole menu planned out: french onion soup, appetizer, lobster soufflé, and grand marnier soufflé for dessert. However, we had reservations at 6 and had tickets to the 8PM showing of Lion King, and had we known that our menu would take over two hours, we would've done things differently.

Expect a wait, seriously. Even though there are empty tables in the restaurant, they're booked, and with only two waiters and one chef, whatever you order will take...a...long...time...
 
Our waiter was off-putting from the beginning. I have very high standards for customer service, and this guy made me feel belittled or depreciated. I agree 100% with Gautam S.' review just below when they said that the staff made it seem like it was a burden to wait on us. He made me feel like we were too young for the establishment, and almost guilty for not ordering wine (yeah, we don't drink wine).
 
Our spinach and goat cheese salad, though a very tasty one, took forever to come out (such a simple salad should not take 30 minutes to come out. you lay down some spinach, crumble some cheese on top, drizzle oil over it, and voilà). While the dressing/oil was pretty light, they put a bit too much.

Another 30 minutes went by when we realized that the soup hadn't even come out yet, let alone our two soufflés. We had a show to catch, which we could not be late for. We pulled our waiter aside (which shouldn't take several attempts) and told him that we're on a tight schedule and needed to leave no later than 20 minutes before the show (which, at that time was probably 40 minutes away). We understand that we should have let them know that we were on a schedule so that they can time everything because the soufflés had specific bake times, so yes somewhat our fault. However, making us feel guilty about it made it worse than cancelling our dessert soufflé.

The redeeming factor that actually gave this place any stars at all was the FRENCH ONION SOUP. Definitely started a "best thing that I ever ate" list because of this soup. It was THE best. Five stars.

Our lobster soufflé came out, and the waiter cut it up before I could even take a picture of it, and it was hurriedly plopped onto our plates. The lobster soufflé had absolutely ZERO lobster taste. It just tasted like a regular savory cheese soufflé with chunks of chewy lobster, which could have been shrimp for all we knew. It had NO TASTE. For $60, definitely NOT WORTH IT. I probably would have been happier with one of the $30 mushroom or garlic soufflés. We swallowed that soufflé in less than 10 minutes. NOT because it was delicious, but because we were rushed. And telling us that the chef is not very happy that we had to cancel the soufflé did NOT make me feel any better.

Overall:
Service: *
Spinach and Goat Cheese Salad: ***
French Onion Soup: *******
Lobster Soufflé: **

I would come back though, just to have my own serving of the french onion soup and finally have the dessert soufflé. Have at the very least 3 hours open on your schedule for this place.
author: Vivian L.

description:
Absolutely delicious meal last night at Cafe Jacqueline.

We ordered: cauliflower souffle as well as the corn/garlic/ginger souffle for dinner, and then the lemon and strawberry (seasonal) souffles for dessert. There were 4 of us, and it was PLENTY of food.

All was delicious, although my favorites were probably the corn/garlic/ginger (I was super apprehensive about the ginger, but it gave it just a touch of tang that was perfect) and then the lemon was to-die-for.

The service was impeccable and I loved seeing Jacqueline cooking away in the kitchen. Lovely San Francisco gem!
author: K. D.

description: Jacqueline makes out-of-this-world souffles!  Start w/ their yummy French onion soup (surprisingly light & not over-whelmingly heavy) which goes well with their freshly-baked crispy & crusty bread, follow by their refreshing watercress salad, then share both a savory souffle so you can savor a sweet & delicious souffle.  That was perfect portion for the 3 of us.  Enjoy!!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
My wife and I have been meaning to go to Cafe Jacqueline for a little while now and we finally got round to it last night. The first thing I would say about it is that in San Francisco, it is about as unique a restaurant as the city can offer. I can't think of any other restaurant that specializes in just souffles and has been doing so for 35 years.

The room is a lovely romantic setting. So very understated, very French. Not very big, about 12 tables. As the souffles are all prepared and cooked to order, a meal will last about 2 hours at least. I think we were there nearly 3, depends on whether you have dessert as well really.

The wine list was very impressive. Obviously there were some local California ones but I was so pleased to see an extensive French list which isn't very common in SF/Bay Area.

The starters listed on the menu were generally quite light. They need to be to make room for the main event! First listed are soups, French onion and a soup du jour. We each decided on soup for some reason. I had the soup du jour, which was cream of zucchini and it was very flavourful and delicious. My wife opted for the already much celebrated French onion soup, which was as good any I've had in France. So good! The other starters were things like figs wrapped in proscuitto, salads etc... All very nice, not what I wanted at the time though.

The main course, souffles. Made to be shared between 2, as pointed out by the waiter, all made fresh with Gruyere cheese. These are not diet-friendly and taste all the better for it. They are all quite simple ingredients to really showcase how good they are: mushroom, leek, broccoli, lobster, crab. Perhaps the most complex used 3 ingredients: shiitake mushrooms, basil and garlic. We opted for a mushroom souffle. It is pretty tricky to try and describe in written words how good it was. You could taste the mushrooms and the cheese and the love and care that went into producing the dish. Fantastic! It was huge too, we took the rest home and had it for breakfast this morning, on toast.

We were unsure whether to go for dessert, but to really do justice to the whole experience, you have to. We'd heard the peach souffle is a standout despite hearing the daily specials. Yet again, when food is so good, I'm lost as to how to describe it. We were worried it would be too heavy but I guess as it is not loaded with cheese it was just light and fluffy and completed the meal with such a delicate peach flavour that lingered until we got home.

I strongly recommend putting on a shirt and trousers and going to Cafe Jacqueline. As close to eating rustic French cuisine in a rural French setting as you could find 5,000 or so miles away from rural France. 

As the restroom is situated just outside, out the back of the restaurant in a tiny garden of potted plants, you have to walk through the small kitchen. Be sure to thank Jacqueline for the food as you see her behind the biggest bowl of eggs whisking by hand all the souffles. An unforgettable experience.
author: Lewis F.

description:
Made a reservation and was super excited to share a souffle with my boyfriend, but in the end the meal left much to be desired.

Cafe Jacqueline is a very small and intimate restaurant, which explains why you need to make a reservation. I had made one the week before, and my boyfriend and I arrived a bit early for our 7:30 time slot on a Saturday night. Entering the restaurant was a bit awkward because the middle tables are facing the door, so my BF and I were left standing there for a bit looking around, unsure if we should walk to the back to talk to a waiter or just wait. The couple sitting in the middle row also gave us a weird look when we walked in, which definitely added to our anxiety. We ended up waiting and a waiter came to us, asking if we had a reservation. We confirmed and he sat us at a nice, cozy table near the back. 

The prices are quite exorbitant but we knew this and only wanted a dessert souffle. We decided to get the strawberry because it was the fruit souffle and my BF wasn't feeling the chocolate. I was aware that we were going to have to wait awhile for our food, but we waited close to an HOUR for one souffle. I'm really glad we ate dinner at home before coming. 

After a long long long time our strawberry souffle finally arrived. It was huge and we decided to eat it straight from the enormous ramekin. It was HOT and my tongue was burned immediately. OUCH =( Also beware of the powdered sugar on top, I inhaled a bit while eating and it made me cough. They add a good amount of fresh strawberries on top, but we had to eat them quickly because the flavor wasn't as good when they started to get warm. The outside of the souffle was yummy because it was crisp on the outside and soft on the inside. But as we started to eat towards the center, the souffle had the consistency of thin oatmeal... it definitely wasn't appealing. The waiter warned us it would be softer near the middle but I don't think it was supposed to be oatmeal consistency. As for the flavor, I could taste the strawberry (as well as a bit of eggy flavor which took some getting used to), but my BF said the strawberry wasn't pronounced enough.

Overall we paid $35 to wait almost an hour for a whatever souffle =( The service was good and they refilled our waters constantly, but I thought it was a bit presumptuous of the waiter to ask at the end of the meal "So what will you have next time?" Not going to be a next time sir.
author: Sam F.

description:
Probably one of the best dessert experiences in my life.  The chef is a tart, but pleasant elderly french lady that loves her craft, and so do I.  she bakes right in the back of the restaurant, so you can see her as you timidly walk through her kitchen to as you fake a "restroom break" (located on the back right).  If you walk too far, the pizza shop employees in the back will stop and redirect you.  Be sure to awe at the amazing basket of eggs in the kitchen.

The souffles offered are savory and sweet.  We went only for dessert, so we tried the chocolate and the lemon.  Both were amazing, but the lemon was the most pleasant surprise.  I would describe it as a fluffy lemon bar.  Unlike many souffles, these don't come accompanied by any whipped cream.  They're around 7" diameter and sit 4" tall.  The ramekins are huge.  It reminds me of Morton's souffle, but better.  Cost is around $30 each, and can be shared with friends.  Atmosphere was candle lit romantic, so I don't recommend large parties.  They can probably only fit 25 people in there at a time anyway.  Parking is a pain, so be careful.  Street only, and you're competing with the bars.
author: Jerry A.

description:
Ho
ly
smokes.
Didn't know I wanted to eat souffle for hours until I did. I went with a group for my sister's birthday, there were six of us that shared 3 dinner souffles - salmon/asparagus, mushroom, and broccoli cheese. We also did 2 dessert, the strawberry & the lime. The lime was so amazing, I kept looking in the dish wanting to scrape out more. We went around the table and every person had a few different favorites, none were left out, and everyone loved everything. Split a couple bottles of wine too, that was killer. I want to go back by myself and order a chocolate souffle and then just eat it by myself and stab at anyone who comes near. They are light, fluffy, eggy, creamy, and everyone at the table kept closing their eyes and making whimpering noises. Eating at this place sounds more like sex than actual sex does.
author: Elyse P.

description:
When my cousin took me here for the first time, I thought it was pretty ridiculous to take us to try a $40 soufflé. However, splitting it between the four of us was not bad at all. We knew it would be a long wait but I'm all open to try good food. We ordered the white chocolate soufflé and omg it was sooo good. Best soufflé I've ever had. The batter wasn't too sweet, perfect consistency, and the white chocolate complimented it very well. To me, it was worth $40.

I found an excuse to go back and splurge when I decided to take a good friend of mine for her birthday. I wanted to see what she thought of the expensive soufflé. We shared the strawberry soufflé and wow it was so good. It's a bit on the sweet side but the consistency was perfect. Between the two of us, little Asian girls, we finished the whole soufflé. Although we both expected to wait for 45 mins, we came on a weekday and waited for only 20 minutes. This place is definitely a place I will choose to bring people for special occasions!
author: Tita T.

description: So I have to say that my 3 star review is really is based on the service that we received a few weeks ago while dining at this location on a Friday evening.  We had made reservations a month in advance since we were traveling from orange county and my gf really wanted to eat here.  Although the wait staff was excellent, what was really disappointing was the time it took to get the food out on the table.  We ordered a French onion soup which took about 45 min and then then our entrée soufflé took about 1.5 hrs to arrive on the table.  By that time I was so hungry I really didn't get to enjoy the food.  Finally our dessert soufflé took another 45 min after.  All in all, dinner lasted about over 3 hrs so we didn't leave the restaurant until after 11pm since our reservations wasn't until 8pm. The food was good and probably the best seafood soufflé and grand marnier soufflé I ever had but the food just took too long.
author: Wellington C.

description:
I FINALLY came here after having it bookmarked for years. It's probably been sitting in my Yelp bookmarks for a whole decade.

....I've been missing out. 

PHENOMENAL. What a perfect little spot. I had the most amazing post-dinner date here, complete with a strawberry soufflé and 2 glasses of wine. I was befuddled as to why the prices were so high, but I chalked it up to it being a classy spot. 

I have to say though, it got unclassy pretty quickly when we had our respective first bites. The way we dug into the soufflés you would think that we've been starving in a third world country. 

I'm tempted to kidnap the adorable Miss Jacqueline and force her to make me soufflés on demand.
author: Mel L.

description:
Cafe Jacqueline holds a sentimental place because my husband proposed there. 

Jacqueline, it is clear imparts love into each soufflé. As you walk by the bowl of eggs larger than her she warmly says "Bon Soir!" To passers by. The simplicity of the gruyere soufflé and a great Bourdeaux is sheer heaven!  Amazing food and service.
author: Fitzwilliam D.

description: We came here on a weekday night, the restaurant was not busy, only a couple of tables there besides ours. The ambiance is great. Food is amazing! We had the Grand Mernier Souffle for dessert and it was sooo delicious. I do think this place is overpriced.
author: Navjot K.

description:
this place was indeed amazing. we didn't get the reservation made till 9pm, but it doesn't even matter... most of the guests have left by the time we finished our meals, which was even better! the service was really nice... i don't think they are slow at all... they are just 'relaxed'? and try not to rush things.

four of us shared two entree souffles - one prosciutto & mushroom, the other crab. i loved them both - but prefer the crab one. super tasty and fluffy and yummy and you seriously won't feel anything heavy afterwards.

we shared a seasonal fruit dessert souffle - i picked strawberry, it was super yummy too! 

everything was perfect, the bread was crispy and warm, fresh out of oven, wines are tasty, i think the price is reasonable too.

i would definitely come back to try more stuff on the menu - onion soup, lobster souffle, and white chocolate dessert souffle too! i can't wait...
author: Bonnie Y.

description: I can pontificate for hours about why I love this place. This place has no shortage of rave reviews so it certainly doesn't need mine. But I am a fan and would certainly go back in a heart beat. I went there a few weeks ago with a friend. All the wonderful things I had heard were true. I enjoyed the slow service that allows you to savor every bite and every moment of the meal. The recommendations for wine with dinner were spot on. Our server really knew his wine selection and knew exactly what to pair with the divine seafood soufflé. The chocolate soufflé was rich and sinful. This restaurant is worth every minute of the hour and forty five minute drive into the City.
author: Adrian H.

description:
We really enjoyed Cafe Jacqueline. We loved eating leisurely like you would do in France. After eating and sharing the endives with roquefort and onion soup (gruyere was wonderful and glad they used it instead of swiss cheese) with my husband, I wasn't sure I could eat the souffle. You get one souffle for two and that was good. We had mushroom and prosciutto souffle and it was delicious. It was nice to digest the  salad and soup first. So, when the main dish souffle came, we were able to eat again. We had the chocolate souffle for dessert and I'm glad it took its time. It was the size as the main course. I thought I could only eat part of it but we both scoffed it up and nothing was left. It was so light. I loved that we were not rushed to eat. We were able to savor each bite of our dinner. If you plan to go, plan only for this dinner. This is a "NO RUSH" restaurant.  We were at the restaurant for two hours and we could have stayed a little longer if we had more coffee. 

The waiters were so efficient, professional, and friendly (friendly meaning not palsy wellsy type). The waiters reminded me of waiters in Paris.

I don't think it's fair to take children because of the time you spend waiting for dinner. It should be spent with friends who can spend time to talk or for lovers who would stare into each other's eyes.

This restaurant is a place where you can enjoy food by taking your time to eat and remember it's not a fast-food place where you can just drop in and dinner is served in 20 minutes.

I love this place!!!
author: Diane H.

description: Seriously wonderful souffles, wonderful, quaint ambiance and generally charming! It's a must-do experience if you like souffle. I've never had better.
author: Koshika S.

description: Slow service and slightly expensive prices, but an exceptionally charming experience if you can handle the 45 minute wait for your soufflé. I take family and friends here and they are always delighted. Make sure you over order a bit, and come hungry.
author: jason c.

description:
Items selected:

Coffee
Baguette and Butter
Peach Soufflé

With my curiosity regarding Coi happily satisfied but still with room for dessert I made my way through Telegraph Hill to the soufflé-centric Café Jacqueline hoping that the small French restaurant's seemingly exorbitant prices would yield the sort of dish I'd not soon forget; a task it achieved admirably for all the wrong reasons.  Beginning first with a harried welcome from one of two pseudo-French accented servers and progressing through impossibly slow coffee refills as I munched on a baguette bordering on stale for nearly fifty-five minutes until my $40 soufflé arrived there were at least two moments where I nearly stood up and walked out but understanding that a good soufflé takes time I stuck it out only to receive a sopping wet mess that was neither sweet nor interesting yet excused by my server as "the chef's way."  Never one to complain about prices if a meal truly shines Café Jacqueline ranks high amongst the most disappointing dining experiences of my life - certainly something I'll not soon forget.
author: Michael U.

description:
It is actually unfathomable to me that anyone would give Café Jacqueline anything less than a 5-star review -- one of the best meals, and restaurant experiences, I've ever had. Traditional soufflé restaurants are few and far between (even in Paris), and I would say this place is as good as Le Soufflé. 

First of all, lovely atmosphere -- quiet, low lighting, lovely classical music. The only thing I was nervous about from reading the reviews was that the wait staff would be rude, or at least cold. Not so, at ALL. Perfect service. Friendly, unobtrusive, warm, endlessly helpful. There were two waiters (Scott and a man with an incredible mustache) handling the whole place, and they each treated us (and everyone around us) like royalty. They would talk and joke with us when appropriate, and back off a bit when we were having a little romantic moment. : )

Now onto the most important thing: the FOOD. Oh good God, the food. I'm shocked more reviewers haven't mentioned the bread! I haven't had better bread or butter outside of Paris. Warm and crispy, and they keep it coming. We had the watercress and the arugula and goat cheese salad, both made with a traditional French vinaigrette -- fresh and light and delicious.

When it came to soufflé, we went for one of the specials -- yellow chanterelles and garlic. Just. Heaven. Fluffy and flavorful, but the garlic wasn't too overwhelming... my mouth is watering recounting it now.

We had the chocolate soufflé for dessert (duh), and it was, if possible, even more sublime than the savory. We were so stuffed, but we scraped the dish clean. One reviewer mentioned that their chocolate soufflé was "runny" -- I can't speak to that particular experience, but a good soufflé should have a slightly runny center, just in the very middle. Like a little chocolate mousse surprise!

I don't really understand complaining about the price... it's really reasonable, maybe even too reasonable, for what you're getting, which is hand-crafted gourmet food made with high-quality ingredients. You can get three courses and a fairly expensive bottle of wine and spend about $100/person (including tip). If you do that, you will leave STUFFED. Seems like a steal to me.

Other things: it will literally take you three hours to eat here. It is not a pre-show or pre-movie restaurant; it is an experience unto itself. The food takes forever because one person is preparing it, and it's a time-comsuming food. Go with someone you want to talk to and eat the amazing bread. So, so worth it. Make a reservation, because... duh. If you show up with no reservation and complain about the wait, I just have no sympathy. There may be empty tables, but can I mention again how **ONE person is making all these soufflés**? (Also, not fair to deduct points from the restaurant because it's difficult to park in North Beach.)

We were encouraged to go in back and say a quick hello to Jacqueline after the meal. She was so sweet and gracious, and that bowl of eggs is a sight to behold. There was a lovely older French man in the kitchen as well (Her husband? I don't know!) who exclaimed (in French), "These soufflés are bigger than the ones you get in France, yes? Bigger AND better!" Jacqueline just shook her head modestly, and my heart melted.

Thank you, Café Jacqueline, for the most magical evening!
author: Darcy B.

description:
"IT'S SO FLUFFY, I'M GONNA DIE!" 
(In Agnes's voice from "Despicable Me")

Just one of MANY nostalgic conversations that came in to mind when chowing down at Cafe Jacqueline's.

My girlfriend and I made reservations an hour prior for Sunday, 7:30PM (just in case, since there was no OpenTable for CJ). It was difficult finding this place (not the most flashy or decorative restaurant out there) but we found it after circling around the block for a bit. When we entered, we were INSTANTLLYYY greeted by a slightly rude gentlemen (Matt, whose mustache is very distracting!) and directly asked if we had reservations -- and after a little mix up, we finally sat down.


Appetizer - 
French Onion Soup: 
[http://s3-media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/0vgvaD5Ve5E8coTOkQXcOw/l.jpg]
THIS IS THE BEST SOUP I'VE EVER HAD, PERIOD. Granted it was a tad salty but the onions dissolved in your mouth magically while the oven melted cheese gave way to a chewy delectable crust. IT. WAS. AMAZING.

Entree:
Prosciutto and Mushroom Souffle:
[http://s3-media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/WifaiynwQ5KgZv4b-f9upw/l.jpg]
There was a total of 4 largely wrapped slices of prosciutto on top of a beautiful mushroom souffle. This is where the whole "IT'S SO FLUFFY" comes in -- because it was! It was hearty yet so light, and fluffy yet so filling. Oddly enough, it was also a tad too salty.. (maybe because of the prosciutto) but it was divine. At this point, I was already full [my GF ate 1/4 of it and I finished the rest] and was contemplating on either keeping or canceling the long awaited ... 

Dessert:
Chocolate Souffle:
[http://s3-media3.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ppsCedRWOBofMdqdB6diDA/l.jpg]
What Madame Jacquline is famous for -- the Chocolate Souffle! It was HUGE -- literally. I love my dessert like no other but this one was so overwhelming ginormous! At first I laughed at the "serves 2-4 people" caption on the menu, but seeing this shut me up good.. It was disappointing though how they only had chocolate (no fruits) but regardless, it was an amazing way to end our meal. Did I mention how FLUFFY it was? It sucks I couldn't finish it.. there was still about 1/3 left (I almost cried, kinda).

My first impression of Cafe Jacqueline was.. well, they could use a renovation. Also, the lack of choices of dishes (two soups, few salads, and only souffles) felt disappointing. I didn't know they only served souffles and their prices are on the $$$ side.

However. it has the old French style decor with dimly lit candles and lighting everywhere -- perfect for a romantic date. Matt, the only waiter at CJ, is actually a charming funny guy after you get pass his business mentality (he tends to shoo away walk-ins by stating "it'll be 45minute-1hour wait" -- but this leads to a more quiet and romantic atmosphere, so kudos).  Also, be prepared to have TONS to talk to with your date or party because the food will take a long long time. We sat down at 7:30PM and left at around 9:15PM. Overall, a lovely different experience on the French take and will definitely be back for seconds! 

PS: Make reservations -- even though there's no OpenTable and don't forget to say hi to the head chef and owner, Madame Jacqueline, on your way out!
author: Albert L.

description:
My husband and I made a reservation for 7:30 pm, and arrived there on time.
After ordering our savory&dessert soufflé, we had to wait for them more than 1 hour.  So it was already 9:30pm when we only finished our savory soufflé. Since the parking garage we had parked is supposed to close at 10pm,  we had to leave soon. When we asked them about our dessert soufflé, they answered it'll take another an hour. So we had to cancel our dessert soufflé... WTH?! They excused they were too busy on the day, but is it possible to take more than two hours to make two soufflé? If they recognized the delay, they should have asked us to be late at the beginning. The ambiance of the restaurant was so grace, and their complementary baguette was awesome, but the savory soufflé was partly too salty which was not that impressive considering the price ($50).
author: Natalie P.

description:
Sucks!!! Four of us walk in at 10:20pm to hear a rude mustached man tell us "I'm sorry but we're done." To which I replied "But it's 10 and you close at 11" and he annoyingly continues with "yeah I'm sorry but we're done". What does that mean?!?! 
If you're "done" then at least flip the sign to closed BEFORE ppl show up not after we step foot out the door. To add insult to injury I called beforehand to confirm that we could come in.
My overall review is that their costumer service SUCKS and I guess I'll never find out whether or not their soufflés are worth it nor do I care to find out now.
author: Vanessa F.

description:
If you're looking for a cholesterol-laden meal, Cafe Jacqueline is your place. Eggs, eggs and more eggs are the main ingredient at this souffle centric spot. 

If you go, you must excuse yourself to go to the bathroom, whether you have to go or not, just so you can walk through the kitchen to see how many eggs are stacked up waiting to be cracked and made into delicately fluffily souffles. 

There's a nice wine list and a couple of salads to accompany a large assortment of savory souffles.

This charming spot is a nice surprise amongst the Italian places of North Beach.
author: Lee H.

description: The soufflés were so good that it was worth the very long wait time to receive our appetizers and main dishes. Our total meal time was 3 hours. I would go back, but next time I'd eat a snack before dinner.
author: Gilda M.

description: Must get reservations because they only serve a small limited amount of people per day! A souffle loving girl tricked me into coming here with her. She seems to extremely enjoyed her Chocolate Souffle. I'm more of a savory guy so the Prosciutto & Mushroom souffle was what I requested - big mistake! This thing was just a huge, soggy, unappetizing, weird tasting puff ball. Actually, all of the souffles seems to be pretty big, but guess sweet is what works well. Their (French) Onion Soup is pretty rich and hearty, using Gruyère as the cheese.
author: Nam B.

description: The atmosphere has old world charm, the wait-staff is very friendly and professional, the onion soup was one of the best I've had (and that includes my vacations in Europe), and the crab soufflé and the lemon soufflé were fantastic! My wife and I plan to make many more trips to this wonderful little restaurant.
author: Frank S.

description:
This place was all about the soufflé. Don't come here in a rush because it will take at least 45 mins to get your food.

But if you have good company and plenty of time, there is no place better for a soufflé. It's not cheap either, but aren't good experiences priceless overall?

Got the chocolate souffle for 40 bucks. It was delicious. Watch out for the magma hot center, and the sugar will make you cough
author: Ben F.

description: The fruits de mer and grand marnier soufflés were delicious but be prepared to wait an hour per soufflé. I was not and am now irritated beyond belief. I would think the second soufflé would be prepared to serve 15 minutes or so after the first, but this was not the case. I've never had such a delicious meal that I would never ever want again. You're better off stealing someone's soufflé and serving two years in jail. At least you'll enjoy it immediately before dealing with the wait. It will feel the same. You've been warned. Enjoy with caution
author: Vina H.

description: I love this place so much, I don't know what I will do when Jacqueline moves on. There really isn't another restaurant like it in SF. The soufflés are delicious--I have never had one short of delicious, though I am especially partial to the citrus dessert ones, like the lime--and the experience of dining there as a whole feels like a mini-vacation from the world outside. Be prepared for a leisurely meal, say three hours or so, and don't take anyone whose conversation and company you dislike. Make sure to stop by the kitchen to see the giant bowl of eggs and to say thank you in person to Jacqueline!
author: Rose G.

description:
Cafe Jaqueline is that rare treat - something I hope people will come and experience sometime soon.

  The Onion Soup is out of this world - thick, hearty and uplifting.  Each spoonful makes you smile and reminds you the power of good food.  

   The Strawberry Souffle was life changing.  Seriously, there are few restaurants that push the envelope on what you thought was good and this was one of them.

  I cannot wait to come back and try the other dessert souffles.  I did enjoy the savory souffles, but I enjoy desserts more.
   
  The wait can be long, but this is a restaurant where you savor your food, your time and your company.  Definitely not recommended for people in a hurry.
author: Anthony N.

description:
How does she do it?!  Cafe Jacqueline is a true treat and Jacqueline herself is a gem.  She makes all the soufflés herself in her walk-through kitchen. 

Tip from the staff: when you go back to say hi, no photos and keep your comments short and sweet, then move on.  Makes sense...she's a busy lady!

The staff was amazing and our waiter had worked there since the early 90s. He knows a good thing when he finds it. He guided us through the best items on the menu and he was right! We had the shaved cucumber salad, corn/garlic/ginger soufflé and the chocolate soufflé. 

Reservations are a must and expect to have a relaxing and delicious meal over the span of about three hours.  Read: think of plenty of things to talk about with your significant other before you are seated--then you can dazzle he/she with how fun you are because time just flew!  

The food dazzles on its own.
author: April B.

description: Went here after reading all the reviews. It is as good as everyone says. The French onion soup is awesome. They were out of the seafood soufflé:( but we got the prosciutto and mushroom and it was really good. So fluffy and airy. The chocolate soufflé is what heaven must taste like, goes great with a nice bottle of French Pinot noir.
author: Leah S.

description: I absolutely love this place! Make sure you go with someone who you could have a long conversation with because the soufflés take time to make. I would allow at least three hours for dinner! We ordered the French onion soup, white corn ginger garlic soufflé, chocolate soufflé, and strawberry soufflé. Overall it's pretty pricey, but you are getting such great quality of food and a very special evening. I highly recommend taking a trip to the bathroom so you can walk through the kitchen and say hello to the chef! You can see the huge bowl of eggs she uses to make all of the soufflés too. Also, before you eat there you should check out her segment on the Food Network on Alton Brown's Best Thing I Ever Ate.
author: Claudia L.

description: The best soufflé I've ever had! Not to mention you can watch them being made in the kitchen! Reservations required.
author: Marwa K.

description: I have been going to Cafe Jacqueline for many years and find it continues to remain the "jewel" that it has always been. Delicious, unique, authentic and original with the beautiful Ms. Jacqueline whipping up soufflé after soufflé - one at a time.  Plan to wait for a long time!  She makes the soufflés one at a time.  Yum!!!  We always go with good friends knowing we will have a long wait and we  enjoy a nice visit before the soufflés come out.  Worth the wait!
author: Dr. Colleen K.

description:
Very excited that I get to write this review. I've been wanting to try Café Jacqueline for a while and finally made it a point to make reservations. Reservation process was very easy, although I left a message, I also called around 4:30pm on a Wednesday to make reservations for that Saturday evening. 

Parking is a pain, so make sure you plan ahead with enough time to scout the streets of North Beach. I was seated promptly after letting them know I had a reservation. So here is my impression on the service. I had a great experience, yes they did take a while to get my wine order and all of that, but the service was authentic. And when I say that, I say I know that the wait staff was not trying to pretend to be overly nice to me for a tip. They were extremely helpful in helping us order, serving our soufflés, and answering all of our questions about the restaurant - you can just tell they enjoy working where they work. And that's a plus with me, real service over forced service any day.

For appetizers, I had the French Onion Soup and the Spinach w/ Goat Cheese Salad. Both were amazing, the goat cheese they used was so creamy. It was all delicious and made us anticipate our entrée. 

The prosciutto and mushroom soufflé was well prepared - I just don't think that I am much of a savory soufflé gal. It was a bit salty for my taste, but we still devoured it. Very light!

The seasonal fruit soufflé was blueberry (although I was hoping for strawberry) and it was DELICIOUS. Wow. Their dessert soufflés kick butt - I really could've eaten the whole thing by myself. If you can just imagine a mouthful of light airy creaming, but not overwhelming goodness that's what you got!

Our meal was also paired with a very balanced wine recommended to us by the staff. I am a fan and did not leave disappointed. Reason for it being shy of 5 stars was just probably the very steep pricing and parking chaos. But I would go again in a heartbeat if it were a special occasion. 

Best thing was that I didn't feel too bloated because everything was light, just that perfect balance of satisfaction from a good meal. 

We probably spent $200 after everything for our meal. Merci Chez Jacqueline!
author: Diane P.

description: Soufflés made with obvious care, love and expertise by Jacqueline herself for the past 35 years? What more do you need to know? Not much, in my opinion. Cafe Jacqueline on the charming Grant Street reminds me of the San Francisco so many of us love and long for. Tonight, we shared a simple butter lettuce salad, a Gruyere and broccoli savory soufflé and a requisite chocolate soufflé for dessert. C'est magnifique.
author: Danielle L.

description:
Jacqueline, je t'adore. Je suis a votre service.

And I didn't know a single word of French before dining there.

Cafe Jacqueline is as far as I know, a unique experience in the San Francisco Bay area.  And when you go there, you must visit the restroom.  Not necessarily for the facilities, but simply for the excuse of walking through the kitchen (the WC is off the courtyard behind the kitchen).  In the kitchen you will see Jacqueline herself at the counter with a large copper bowl full of eggs whipping away, stirring, and creating the wonderful dishes that she serves.  She smiles at you and at that moment you know that the food is prepared with love (the key ingredient to truly great meals).  The place radiates warmth and friendship, and it all starts with her.

The waiters are friendly, helpful, and knowledgeable.  Listen to their recommendation on what works and doesn't, they know what they are talking about.  They also know the wines and what pairs well with what you are ordering.  If they don't know, they have a large "The Book of Wine" in the back that they will bring to your table to discuss the options.

Take a date a share.  Better yet, go with four or six so that you can get two or three souffles (they are sizable).  Get the French onion soup, well worth the onion breath you will have later.  And do I even have to tell you to save room for dessert?  Yes, the chocolate is heavenly, but don't be so typical.  But this is another reason to go as a group of four or six, more people means more options to try get the chocolate and one of the fruit based souffles.

The wine list is primarily French.  Don't be a CA wine snob, order a wine that fits the food - maybe a nice Rhone Red, something you don't have in your cellar at home.  Show your date some self confidence by getting something you don't normally drink at home. First time there (second date with a woman who is now my wife) I ordered a wonderful half bottle followed by another.  One word of warning if you get the half bottle, make sure you are clear to your date that you are getting more wine or she may think you are cheap.  I almost lost her right there :).  But the wines are great, how could you try just one.  Another reason to go with a group of four.

Only one word of warning about dining there, well actually two.  First, ask for a table away from the door.  If you get one of the tables right by the door "on a cold San Francisco night", you will get a cold blast whenever someone come in.  Plus when people show up early there is really no place to wait, and some people choose to wait right by the tables inside the door.

The other word of warning is, don't be in a rush.  People, A Souffle takes time to be made properly.  So if you have a show to go to, you might want to dine somewhere else.  Each time I have dined with Jacqueline, there has been at least one table of diners that were trying to rush off somewhere.  One guy was snapping at the waiter "I told you when we arrived that we were short on time, now we don't have time for dessert" - BTW, he arrived after us, was late for his reservation, and made an ass out of himself.

Dining with Jacqueline is all the romance you need for the evening.  Save the show for another night.  Take your time, enjoy the evening, say hello to the master herself, and let the romance of the evening warm you up "on a cold San Franciscan night".
author: Jeff H.

description: My Mom, Sister, Aunt and I went to dinner her during our Sister's Weekend! We had so much fun! Our waiter was WONDERFUL! He was personable and very helpful. The soufflés we ordered were the best I've ever had. We would DEFIANTLY come back to Cafe Jacqueline.
author: Sydney C.

description:
Love Jacqueline's and Jacqueline! She works there too! This restaurant is amazing! Very romantic and charming. But definitely go there with time on your hands, it does take a while. But once the souffle arrives - wow! And the onion soup is delicious and when I went there last it was a vegetarian base!
Great place, can't wait to go back!
author: Jenny B.

description:
We crawled into the cafe after a concert at Yoshi's.  We had dinner at Yoshi's and wanted to grab a desert and some coffee. 

Ambiance:  GREAT- Old century French
Service: acceptable- we weren't swept off our feet
Specialty Souffle-  5 Star quality
Pricy

We have grand Marnier souffle- one serves 2 to 4.  You definitely don't want to go here alone- need company.  Price tag 35 to 40 bucks. A great variety of souffles- lime, white chocolate, Chocolate and ...


Best suited for special occasions.
author: Megan K.

description:
I've been here several times and always recommend it to out-of-towners because there aren't many places quite like it.  Everything is good here especially the white chocolate souffle which I look forward to each time.  

Go with someone who can carry a conversation and expect a three hour meal.  Better yet, go on a double date so you can try more of the massive souffles.  The place is tiny so don't book a large party.  Don't forget to order a soup or salad to fend off your hunger while Jacqueline whisks the eggs and pops the fluffy creation into the oven - you do know souffles take 45 minutes to bake, right?  

Get a peak at the mountain of eggs and the chef on your way to bathroom.  

You'll have to make reservations the old fashioned way by picking up the phone.  It may seem like a lot of fuss but it's worth it to try souffles mastered by someone who's been making them forever.
author: Aileen N.

description:
One of the best meals I've ever had. We ordered the shiitake/basil/garlic souffle for dinner and the white chocolate souffle for dessert. Both were utterly incredible. The puffiness of the souffle makes them intimidating, and we were sure we would have to be rolled out of the restaurant by the time we finished, but this fear evaporated upon the first bite. Despite wonderfully rich flavors, the incredibly light texture allows you to eat and eat and eat, and to savor the flavors for almost as long as it took to cook, without getting uncomfortably full. I also worried I might get tired of a souffle before finishing it, but between the crisp top, chewy edges, fluffy sides, and moist center, every bite is a new experience.

I would describe the staff as french, professional, and funny. If you want them to be bubbly and friendly and to ask about your day, you might be disappointed, but they are not rude.
author: Chris M.

description:
For the quality of the food, it's totally worth a try. We had butter lettuce salad as a starter, the mushroom and prosciutto soufflé and the chocolate soufflé. So full already after the main dish but I'm glad we did try the dessert. The sweetness of the chocolate was just right - not too sweet but very rich. 

Our server was very kind too. It was our first time having soufflé as a main dish and he asked whether we wanted him to serve us. Yes and he did a very nice job, we've got to try everything in the soufflé in a bite!
author: Emily C.

description:
Minus 1 star for running out of the fresh strawberry souffle!!!! I guess that means I will have to come back to try it :)

The savory salmon and asparagus souffle entree is delicious! As for the chocolate souffle covered in powdered sugar (see my picture), it was good but HUGE for just 2 people.

Overall a very cute French restaurant!
author: Helen Y.

description:
This was a delightful evening of salad, soufflé, wine and soufflé!  Fantastic, memorable and we are grateful. 
The homemade bread was the first indication that things were going to be a bit special. Crusty, hot, out of the oven bread that you can only get in France (or so you thought).  The soup was a creamy, pure, roasted red pepper that was unexpectedly light and fresh. The salads were exactly what we hoped for--crisp, lightly dressed and very satisfying on a warm spring afternoon. As the last evening light faded from the sky (we had a 7:30 reservation), our crab and Brie soufflés arrived. Two soufflés were the perfect amount for a family of four to share. They were beautifully created; light and airy, full of flavor and slightly indulgent.  I think the crab was my personal favorite.  The lemon soufflé was a perfect ending to a remarkably fun evening. Greeting Jacqueline upon our departure was such a pleasure.  She seemed to be very happy to have customers that were extremely satisfied with her creations.   If you have been to France, you will appreciate being able to dine at this level in Northern California.
author: Renee M.

description:
My husband and I came here for an anniversary dessert. We got a chocolate souffle and it was to die for.

We went back again a couple of week later, but this time we wanted to eat dinner there. We walked in an the waiter/host came hurriedly to us and asked us what we wanted. We saw that the restaurant was full and knew full well that we didn't have a reservation (our bad). We asked the gentleman how long the wait would be for dinner and he looked at us and snarled "Do you even know what we make here?" When we told him we did, he shooed us away.

We were appalled by this awful service. I was shocked, especially because when we went the first time we met Jaceueline and were treated so wonderfully!

I sure hope they stopped treating returning customers this way to keep loyal business.
author: La Tache T.

description:
Atmosphere: A
Dinner Souffle: D+ (a big expensive omelet)
Dessert Souffle: A+
author: Amal D.

description:
I came here for my girlfriend's birthday and yes, all the other reviews are true.  You need to allocate at least 3 hours for dining.  I wasn't really sure if other reviewers were exaggerating, but from start to finish it will take you that amount of time.

With that said, the souffles are amazing.  Everything we ordered, I would highly recommend.

Onion Soup, Prosciutto & Mushroom entree (serves two -- yes, it really does feed 2, its pretty big), and the Chocolate dessert souffle.

The food really is great, you just have to commit the time.  I don't think this would be a good first place unless you have a ton of things to talk about.
author: Kevin L.

description:
My family has been coming to Cafe Jacqueline for over 7 years now. It is hands down my favorite and most memorable place in San Francisco. The food is to die for. The ambiance is easily the most romantic in the city (I've seen two proposals here) and Jacqueline - well, she's just as charming as you could ever imagine.

Don't miss the french onion soup or the strawberry soufflé if it is in season. I'm typically a chocolate kinda gal, but you cannot miss (i repeat... you cannot miss) the strawberry soufflé. 

To all the reviews criticizing Matt, the lead garçon, he is a wonderfully personable and warm man. His brusque mannerisms are part of the French charm of Cafe Jacqueline. It took a couple visits for us to break him, but we finally did and now he greets us with hugs every time we dine at Jacqueline.
author: Mac W.

description:
Soufflés were unique and delicious. Tried the crab, mushroom/basil/garlic and black diamond truffle for savory, as well as strawberry and grand marnier for sweet. French onion soup was also authentic. Each soufflé can easily feed 3-4 people. 6 of is split all of these... Lots of good, but no leftovers!

When you go, please say Hi to Jacqueline in the kitchen. She is adorable and makes everything from scratch, by herself. Dinner is an ordeal, be prepared to dine for a couple hours minimum.
author: Meagan P.

description: What an amazing place, probably the best soufflé I have ever had! I would highly recommend the chocolate desert.
author: Guille B.

description:
It's rare that I write a review by proxy, but I felt compelled.  As decades long lover of Cafe Jacqueline, I was moved to suggest it when my teen son wanted a special place to take his girlfriend for a "little" anniversary. I tried to talk him into staying in the East Bay, but he wanted something special and romantic in the city so they could have an adventure, and because he, in his words, "REALLY likes her". It was really also a first formal date for him, unlike the usual movie dates or just hanging out playing video games.

Of course Jacqueline's lovely place came to mind.  Elegant enough to feel special, but not so much as to be intimidating, and always intimate because of J's policy of not filling all tables, it seemed like just the right choice.

When he came back, he couldn't stop thanking me.  He said the food was like "God's.." - well, I won't tell you what he said, because we have a strange and wonderful relationship, which is often based on tasteless and offensive humor. The fact that he could speak to Jacqueline in flawless and unaccented French couldn't have hurt, but he said she and the waiter were both totally charming. I can only imagine what some restaurants would have done with a couple of 17-year old kids.

He thought that the few negative Yelp reviews just showed some people's ignorance - "of course they can't hold a table for someone late for their reservation on a Friday night", or "don't they understand about how she doesn't want to seat every table so people have some privacy?"

Btw, his girlfriend is vegetarian, so it was perfect for her.  They were full after the delicious tomato-cilantro entree souffle (how can something made mostly of air be so filling), but couldn't resist the strawberry souffle for dessert, and were totally in love with the "2 long spoon" feature of the latter, for sharing. He went in knowing how much it would cost, and said it was worth every penny of his hard-earned camp-counselor money.

Two souffles by a master, about $80 with tip.  Having your teenaged son thank you a million times with enthusiasm and sincerity? Priceless.
author: Kimberly V.

description: As my 100th review I would like to review something spectacular. Cafe Jaqueline!! So yummy. So worth the wait and the "weight". Our waiter was friendly the other one was sort of short, and curt good thing we didn't have to deal with him. Everything was delicious and beautifully presented, yet not pretentious. It was romantic in the sense it was intimate. Perfect for our date night. My personal fave of the night was the decedent yet light and fluffy raspberry soufflé, but I don't think you could go wrong with any of the dessert soufflés!
author: Courtney M.

description:
My boyfriend and i went there last night . Oui,  you have to wait because jacqueline does it all. But why would you wanna rush when you are in a nice restaurant with nice company ? I went to the restroom so I got to meet her. She is a lovely lovely lady and it was a pleasure to meet her. 
The service was good and our server told us he s been working with Jacqueline for 20 years. It shows a restaurant who respects their employee and vice versa . I recommend ! 
And no it a not a coffee and tea place, it s a restaurant , so like the review I saw from Amelia M.  complaining the server told him that. Good for the server, because if you just want coffee go to a coffee shop , it's north beach and you can find some coffees shop at every corner. 
The souffles are great and jacqueline is wonderful. Just go a try it!
author: Brand B.

description:
My search for the perfect soufflés have finally ended in Cafe Jacqueline.  Merci beaucoup, Madame Jacqueline!!
