I have had very delicious soufflés in Europe and Asia.  Ever since those wonderful experiences, I've tried to find the same soufflé experience in California.  I've had soufflés at many fine dining restaurants such as Gary Danko and Fleur De Lys, but nothing can compare to the soufflés here at Cafe Jacqueline.  In addition, everything else I tasted here was very delicious as well!


After reading the reviews from Yelp, I decided to: 
1) Make a reservation first;  
2) Study the menu before we go (thanks to Steph L.'s photo!);  
3) Try to speak some French to the waiters, haha!


I called and left a message to make a same day reservation on Sunday.  My husband and I were in SF enjoying the amazing Gaultier exhibits at de Young Museum, and we got a call back from Madame Jacqueline herself confirming our reservation at 6:30pm.  What a lucky start!

The parking situation around the cafe was terrible, so be sure to arrive early to hunt for spaces.  We kept circling around and finally found a parking space right across from the cafe.  Another lucky sign!  

As we walked into the cafe, it was half packed with many party of 4's.  We waited for a while, told them we had a reservation, and finally a waiter told us to sit at any tables for 2.  Not very welcoming at first, but I can tell they were busy.  I was in a very good mood, so that didn't bother me at all.  As we sat through the evening, we actually found both waiters were very friendly and nice to have some conversations.  So make friends with them!  :)

The waiter promptly brought us water and menu, and we told him we are ready to order now.  He was surprised at first, and then he informed us the special of the day was the Oyster soufflé.  We went with our original planned menu at the end.


What we ordered:


1)  Escargot:  It has 8 pieces.  When we first saw the price, we were shocked by the $35 price tag.  However, the escargots were pretty big, and the seasoning tasted just right!  Not too salty, and you can taste the "umami" of the esargot.  Recommended.

2)  Spinach salad with bacon & pine nuts:  I ordered this dish only because I am a pregnant woman who needs some iron.  I usually don't like raw spinach, but the spinach was very good and fresh.  The dressing is vinegar-based, and the bacon bites are very crispy.  All together this salad was a surprise hit for me!  Recommended.

3)  French onion soup:  The onion soup was one of the best onion soups I ever had in CA.  It had a perfect balance of cheese, bread, soup, and onions.  The soup was well seasoned (not too salty), cheese was gooey, and the soaked homemade bread was very good.  Very recommended!

4)  Cauliflower soufflé:  My husband and I both wanted to order this for no reason.  When the soufflé came, the waiter asked us "How did you know to order this?  It is very simple, people don't order this often, but this is my favorite soufflé here!"   As I don't have much expectation for the savory soufflé (well, we all know that the dessert soufflé is the main course, right?), this turned out to be very good!!  The soufflé was fluffy, with a little moist in the center and crispy on the edge & top.  The baked cauliflowers made the soufflé sweet & tender without overpowering the taste and the color of soufflé itself (although I still found it to be slightly too salty).  Totally loved it!  Very recommended!

5)  White chocolate soufflé:  The white chocolate soufflé made me felt like in heaven!  Before it arrived at our table, I could already smelled the aroma.  The soufflé was fluffy, tasty, and dreamy!  Just like the savory soufflé, it had a perfect balance of fluffiness, moist, and crispiness!  I personally hate those soufflés that were added too much syrup / sauce in the center (and became super runny and way too sweet).  The soufflé here doesn't have any sauce to add on, and I love the way it is!  The white chocolate chips on the top melts as the waiter caught and served the soufflé.  Although I am usually a dark chocolate person, I love, love this white chocolate soufflé!!  It was definitely the perfect soufflé experience I've been looking for in CA.  I've finally found my true love here, and I will come back to try more of the dessert soufflés!!  Very, very recommended!! +++

6)  Others:  Warm homemade bread before meal & decaf Earl Grey tea after meal were both very good as well!  The bread was super crispy outside and tender inside.  Tea was perfect pairing the soufflé.


We started eating at 6:30pm, and our dinner ended at around 9:20pm.  We were prepared to wait for the soufflés, so the serving time didn't bother us.  The place is very cozy and intimate, and I've had wonderful conversations with my husband (and we had a lot to talk about after seeing the Gaultier exhibits!)  After all, this is a French restaurant, where you should take it slow, enjoy your food and company :)
author: Emily C.

description: It was my first time, and I Came here with a group of friends on a business meeting. Everything thing taste soooo delicious. My favorite is the crab soulflle. Service was amazing. Everything
author: Jessica L.

description:
No doubt about it, this is a place to try. It's all about soufflés in there so be prepare to get stuffed! I went with my gf and we ordered the crab souffle and a lemon souffle for dessert. It was way too much food so we had to get half the dessert souffle to go.
The Crab soufflé was good but not to die for. I got tired of it about half way.
The Lemon soufflé was amazing and still delicious the next day.

I think 1 salty soufflé + 1 dessert soufflé is the good amount of food for 3 ppl. For 2, I would either only get 1 salty soufflé or get an appetizer (I heard the onion soup is fabulous) + 1 dessert soufflé.

The 2 reasons why it didn't get 5 stars:
- It took over an hour for us to get our food. I know it takes time to cook but my stomach was starting to eat itself. Good thing, they bring you very good home made bread.
- At the end, I got soufflé-ed out. I like soufflés, but this was too much and I would have rather have less but a soup or salad on the side.
author: Boris H.

description:
Cafe Jacqueline is one of those places that warrants a visit for special occasions. I don't think I could just pop in casually to have a meal here, but for a celebration or milestone, it's perfect. 

We came for our anniversary, and it was definitely a different experience than any other ol' restaurant. The interior is the very definition of intimate, and the servers were courteous, attentive, and mustache-envy inducing. They weren't afraid to talk with you either, which under other circumstances I might have not liked. But since your food will take upwards of an hour or two to prepare, they help pass the time.

We had three souffles, which is entirely too many. One will do ya. But we weren't gonna be back any time soon, so we said to hell with it and ordered two entrees and a dessert. And french onion soup. And it was all worth it. 

Our entrees were Shiitake Basil & Garlic souffle and the Lobster souffle. They puff up to giant proportions, but every bite of em got eaten. Light, cheesy, delicate, all-around tasty. And we didn't stop there.

The dessert souffles take time to prepare as well.  Luckily all that waiting gave us time to digest and prepare ourselves for the Strawberry souffle. I dunno where we found the room, but we muscled it down just as easy as the first two, not letting any go to waste. 

This is one of those places where it's easy to go over the top. But it's well worth it.
author: Christopher M.

description:
I've heard souffles were good and amazing and all that jazz, but never having had one before I assumed it was just another food hype, like how some people love bacon and I really just don't care for it. (bacon lovers don't hurt me) But oh my lord, I am now a believer. 

I love everything about this place, from the quaint decor to the patient helpful waitstaff to Jacqueline in the back whipping up delicious dreamy melt-in-your-mouth-orgasmic souffles. I want to kidnap Jacqueline and her ginormous basket of eggs in the back and take her home with me so that I can eat souffles for the rest of my life. 

The lobster souffle is absolutely amazing, and they serve it with lemons on top for a nice counterbalance of sweetness and acidity to the cheesy fluffy goodness. The chocolate souffle was the perfect decadent dessert, really it's like eating clouds of chocolate. We also tried the onion soup - YUM! although a bit salty for me - the endive salad with roquefort, and the escargot. I'd pass on the salad and go for the escargot. It was AMAZING. However it was they prepared the escargot, it made them taste like tender bites of steak. I kid you not. Each bite was....bliss, and yes I realize it probably was the butter. 

Beware, these souffles are ginormous and my date and I were stuffed to the gut by the end of the meal, slightly regretting having ordered so much food, but it was so worth the after meal food coma. Also note that the meal itself takes quite a while (2-3 hours) but it's worth the wait for these souffles.

Plus at the end you can go to the kitchen and see Jacqueline and her staff in action. She seriously is the most adorable lady ever! Go say hi, really =] you'll leave feeling extra happy and satisfied.
author: Grace C.

description:
Three dishes, three and a half hours, strident "at best" service... give it a pass.

The pros
     A very veggie friendly menu-lots of choices.
     Super tasty dessert soufflé

The cons
     Wait staff who act as if its a burden to take your order, get you the wine list or get coffee
     Insanely long wait times for food items.... Each of our items took almost an hour each to get made and delivered, even though we ordered everything at the same timT
     
The bad service and long wait times far outweigh the quality and tastiness of the soufflés... Unless you are looking to kill many hours, give this place a pass.
author: Gautam S.

description: We came here for my birthday, as i had heard good things and since we live in the hood.  We really enjoyed our meal.  We shared the French onion soup and a salad.  They were both fantastic.  Then came the gruyere soufflé and later the chocolate soufflé.  The meal was perfect!  At the end of the meal, we were gushing to our waiter who told us to go in the back and tell Jacqueline herself, so we did.  She was so gracious...and adorable.
author: Scott And Jim H.

description:
Came here for our 8th wedding anniversary and had such an amazing time. Now that we have kids its such an amazing treat to just go out to dinner alone. 

We both loved our strawberry souffle. LOVED.

we went all out that night and had the lobster souffle. It's rather heavy, and after a few bites you are ready to be done. It would of been better to either skip a dinner souffle, or order a cheese or veggie one. You'll want lots of room for dessert!

great service. GREAT service. super cozy atmosphere, which is what we wanted. We were in early and hardly anyone was there until we were leaving (8pm).

great selection of wines and even better recommendations! 

perfect date spot!
author: Deirdre P.

description:
OK. a few basics. Unlike one of the reviews here, do not wonder in off the street on a weekend night and then become indignant when they don't immediately seat you. This place has about seven tables and they serve souffles. Souffles! You know how they make a souffle, right? They don't exactly flip the tables several times a night. It's dark and you are pretty much in for a very good, long French meal. So call and get a reservation.

I've been here about eight times. I drag everyone here. When was the last time you made a souffle? When was the last time you saw a souffle on a menu? Never? Me, too. Here's how it goes down. You go in and order both a dinner and dessert souffle. Each souffle will serve about two people. A dinner souffle might be salmon and leek. Dessert might be chocolate or lime. They are all excellent. Do the chocolate at some point. It's not a cheap meal, but for San Francisco it's very reasonable and a very excellent experience. The service is fantastic. 

At the end of the evening you might even go back into the kitchen and say a few words to Jacqueline. She's the only one in the kitchen behind a giant bowl of eggs. I usually say a few words of thanks in my version of French and she always nods graciously.
author: Craig B.

description:
Why would I go to the same restaurant for about 28 years? Because it's very special. Coming to Cafe Jacqueline is a fabulous night; a wonderful way to spend a romantic evening with the one you love or a close friend you want to catch up with. Yes, it's a long and leisurely evening, it's supposed to be. Ask for advice on a bottle of wine from the fairly priced list. Start with the French onion soup (it's vegetarian) and be ready to be wowed by the soufflés. 

Spend an evening at Cafe Jacqueline once and you'll return again. It's that good and it's that special. It will be a sad day indeed when Jacqueline decides to retire and we can no longer enjoy an evening of lobster or corn with ginger and garlic soufflés.
author: Steve K.

description:
You should understand that they *only* serve souffles.

Yes, there are a couple non-souffle appetizers, but you will eat souffle as your main course.

That being said, it was pretty tasty! I imagine this place got a big bump in patronage after the biography of a recently deceased Silicon Valley visionary said it was his favorite restaurant. I really enjoyed it, especially the chocolate souffle dessert! It was also fun to meet Jacqueline and thank her on the way out, as you are encouraged to do briefly if you are nice.
author: Mike G.

description:
Mmmmm...mmmm..mmmm! I am a health nut. The thought of souffle's just made me think of  feeling of heaviness after dinner. I was amazed at the seafood souffle, then the fluffy, light chocolate souffle dessert, , just melts in your mouth! 
To top it off, the wine suggestion paired with the food was spectacular!
Madame Jacqueline was in the back, I got to meet her and say thank you personally! She is amazing and very friendly!
Souffle made just right!
author: Neelam M.

description: Jacqueline and her Team are simply amazing.  The food, location, ambiance are magical.  Jacqueline is truly a GENIUS!!! To deliver complicated soups  and soufflés with perfect timing exemplifies The Cafe Jacqueline experience.  Still Dreaming of THE NIGHT.  Love,  Lisa and Cindy. 5/5/2016
author: Cindy P.

description:
Food:  5 stars
Service:  5 stars
Value:  4 stars
Ambiance:  5 stars

Cafe Jacqueline is a truly unique San Francisco gem. Had to write an update review after another romantic and delicious experience at Cafe Jacqueline.  The souffles were again excellent and staff fun and welcoming.   The girlfriend and I both love this special restaurant.
author: Duke K.

description:
This has to be my favorite restaurant in San Francisco!  If you look at my many many many Yelp reviews, you'll see I'm pickier than any age/race/religious critical eater stereotypes you can fabricate.  The soufflé is a magically airy dish that is executed perfectly here.  I really like how the sides and top are crispy while the insides are gooey -- never a need to pour sauce into it as a cheating moistener.  Yes, this is a long meal, but wine and good company will make an enjoyable interlude between courses.

French Onion Soup: The broth is rich.  There are plenty of onions and they are translucent in large pieces.  The cheese is plentiful and caked on to the sides.  Extremely hot though, so don't rush in despite the hunger!  I really enjoyed the heavy black pepper notes.

Leek Soufflé: Gotta love the leek, an onion for snobs.  The gruyère base does a good job of allowing this subtle flavor to permeate the soufflé.

Chanterelle Mushroom Soufflé: Not too mushroomy.  The flavor was contained to the mushroom morsels so the gruyère really came through in the plain portions.

Lobster Soufflé: Yes, it's really that good!  More buttery and garlicky than cheesy, but that works well since the main ingredient is lobster.

Crab Soufflé: I actually liked this more than the lobster.  The crab chunks were large and seemingly fresh.  Since San Francisco is more known for crab, this felt like a true local specialty instead of the over hyped lobster.  There were a few minor flakes of shells though, so be warned.

Prosciutto Soufflé: The only soufflé I didn't care for.  When the proscuitto is cooked it tastes like common ham instead of the complex charcuterie.  Even so, the soufflé is so heavenly you'll overlook that.

Chocolate Soufflé: Obligatory and necessary.  A mark of true perfection since you don't need chocolate syrup; the filling is both airy and super moist!  Chocolate lovers won't be able to avoid this one...

Blackberry Soufflé: For those that like tartness in their desserts, the blackberry is the fruit for you.  I preferred the others because of my insatiable sweet tooth, yet still a crowd pleaser.

Strawberry Soufflé: AMAZING!  Tastes like fresh, warm strawberry jam.

Lemon Soufflé: Not my first choice, but glad someone ordered it.  Reminded me of lemon meringue and blew away expectations.

White Chocolate Soufflé: Tastes more like creamy cream than chocolate.  A typical dessert soufflé here is moist and creamy to begin with so this is pure indulgence!
author: Adam B.

description:
This is an interesting restaurant.  
They specialize in Souffle; it takes forever to cook them but I guess it's worth the wait.  The food is rich and tasty, though we found the food to be extremely salty as well.

There were two waiters and one of them was really nice (I'd give him 5 stars without question) but the other was extremely rude.  Many people showed up without reservations and we enjoyed seeing how his attitude changes depending on the customer.  He would offer a table to a well-dressed couple, after giving a polite apology telling them that he would have to make them wait for someone to finish their meal.  On the contrary, a group of tourist with kids were first asked if "they are sure they knew what kind of food this place offers", then were immediately told to phone in the next day to book a reservation if they "really wanted to dine here".  

Wear nice clothes and make a reservation.
author: Durif M.

description:
There are few things better than sex.  Jacqueline's soufflé is a religious experience that transcends words.  If you are a human being that enjoys extraordinary food, make a reservation and go to Cafe Jacqueline.  

Understand that good food takes a while to make, so go there with someone you love talking to.
author: Andres T.

description:
Best 3 and a half hours ever spent at a restaurant. Do your research before you go so you know what to expect and the poor waiters don't have to put up with you attitude. It's good that it is a slow meal because you will be about to freeze time and actually enjoy the moment. You know when you are in the middle of something and you think "I wish I could freeze time and enjoy this forever"? Well, here you actually have plenty of time not to have the experience slip through your hands.

Bombass French onion soup. Love the dessert souffles. The service is so good and professional - Matt is the man!

Also, let's talk about the chairs. Proper, solid wood chairs that don't wobble and actually succeed in making for a comfortable sitting experience. Some of the best restaurant chairs ever....I like to be comfortable.

Enjoy!
author: Ramin R.

description: The soufflé, it is all about the soufflé . The wonderful chef in the kitchen is strait from France and is so charming. She makes magic withe the flavors of the season. The savory soufflé is rich and wonderful while the sweet is tasty and like flavored air. Yum!
author: Leigh S.

description:
This is a dining experience, and one of our favorites.  Do not go simply looking for a meal.

Cafe Jacqueline is owned and operated by a wonderful woman who has been offering the same warm, inviting dining experience for over 30 years.  She makes everything herself, and does so wonderfully. 

The two waiters have been with Jacqueline for years, and offer excellent service.  They don't hover or dote on you, so don't expect that.  They do offer quality service and manners.

We always start with one of the simply prepared salads.  The cucumber with herbs is light and refreshing.  If you prefer the soup, the french onion soup is the best I've ever had.  It has a great complexity of flavors but is light.  (Or just get both.)

We've a few of the main course souffles, and all have been wonderful.  The lobster was well done.  My favorites have been the prosciutto and the crab.

The chocolate souffle for dessert is divine.  

Quality takes time, and there will be a lot of time between your courses.  Go with someone with whom you enjoy wonderful conversation, and bring a bottle of wine.  Enjoy the atmosphere, which is part of the experience - think a warm, cozy space that smells of gruyere.  

Only the bathroom, out back, is a bit odd - but on the plus side, you can see Jacqueline at work and say hello and merci on your way through the kitchen to get there.
author: Grace R.

description:
I am giving them Five star for the sweet souffle's.  I have never tried the savory ones. I was very impressed to see the owner Jacqueline cracking the eggs and making each one of the souffle's one at a time. You know that lots of love goes into the recipes when you taste the food. 
The wait is at least 45-1:00 hour from when you order your souffle, but that is to be excepted. Once Souffle is definitely plenty for two.
author: T B.

description:
I had been wanting to go and eat here for a long time. (Since I saw it mentioned as the best egg dish he ever ate by Alton Brown on food network).
I tried to get a table a couple of times before but they were all booked.
Finally got around to making a reservation a week in advance and going here for dinner.

The restaurant is very low key. Very quaint in a classic french way.
The wait staff is jolly and very helpful.

We ordered the french onion soup and the soup of the day which was a pureed red pepper soup. The french onion soup was awesome. The soup of the day however was on the saltier side.

We shared the Brea and Broccoli souffle as an entree and it was so big we had some left over to go.

There are pretty long waits in between courses. So be prepared to wait at least 45 minutes to an hour between entree and dessert. Fortunately for us this gave us enough time that we could enjoy the dessert. If it had arrived immediately after we would not have been able to eat it.

And Eat it we did. The Chocolate Souffle we ordered for dessert was simply out of this world. We managed to clean that one up despite being full. It had a nice crust and was super fluffy inside. The powdered sugar on top added just the right amount of sweetness to the bittersweet chocolate.

All in all worth the visit and wait for just the dessert. 
Next time I will be making a reservation just for dessert if I don't have the time to do a full meal.
author: Sac C.

description:
YUM!!! 
My GF and I started with salad before the rich and amazing gruyere and leek savory soufflé followed by the chocolate soufflé for dessert. 
Jacqueline is a treasure. The only thing I suggest is go hungry!!! It's wonderfully rich and decedent. 3 and a half hour dinner... I'm a happy girl!!!! (But won't need to eat for a couple days after).
author: Nana W.

description:
Had or fifth Valentines Day dinner here last night, as always e LOVED the experience. 

French Onion Soup, Lobster Souffle, Wonderful salad and a Chocolate Souffle for dessert

The food is always incredible, and the staff now treat us like family. We try to not go too often but every time we do go, they know what we want to drink, call us by our names etc. It was great to see folks from last year and years before. One couple was there for their 16th Valentines Day dinner, so they must be doing something right. 

I understand how disappointing it must be to have gone on the weekend and find that the restaurant was closed, but I understand that Jacqueline was in the hospital for three days and that they called as many people as they had the numbers of. 

All that being said, anyone going to Cafe Jacquline should know in advance that it's a long meal, so if your in a rush or aren't with someone you could talk to for hours...you may want to avoid it! 

The restaurant has been in business for 33 years and I would highly encourage everyone to check it out!
author: Chad C.

description: I am really confused where to start overall experiences was awesome . It's like life time remembers meals what I had there soufflé . If had enough time only u can go service was top notch. I really looking forward to go there .
author: raja g.

description:
Picture a tiny shabby chic restaurant and a darling little old French woman bent over an enormous wooden bowl of eggs.

This is Jacqueline, and for a moment we can all pretend we are visiting a grandma for dinner in the French countryside.

Make reservations for you and one friend for the first seating on Sunday.  Order a salad and a Kir Royale (champagne with creme de cassis) to enjoy while you wait for the piece de resistance: the white chocolate souffle.  

A light meal is all you need;  it covers all food groups and will take the appropriate amount of time.  Believe they also serve you French bread and butter.

We've tried ordering savory and dessert souffles in a group, and we were in for a long evening, but the above instructions won't fail you. Promise ;) Enjoy!
author: Elizabeth W.

description:
Okay....so you really have to not be uptight when you come here. We had a reservation for four and at the last minute an additional friend decided to join our entire evening.....Cafe Jacqueline was the finale.  Our dear hostess (you know - the one who got stuck making all the plans for us) actually stopped in 4 hours before our reservation to see if it would work to add the friend.  They said they couldn't guarantee it, but we could come by at 9pm to check.  Okay....fast forward to 9 - we arrive and they can't take us right now. One of the ladies in the party was in a bit of a huff about it.  She had a few words with one of the waiters and came out incensed.  I watched the whole thing and I felt she was over the top.  Well, I would have none of that.....it was MY freakin' birthday and I was going to CafeJacq. So I went in and said - "It's MY birthday, I want to come here - I understand you'd like a phone # to call when the table is ready - here's mine."  He was extremely nice to me and took my #. I said "we'll be next door" and he said "at the Savoy? I'll come get you!"  Are you listening people? One small smidge of kindness can go a long, long way.  So we went to the Savoy and sure enough, 15ish minutes later he ran over and got us.  Yes - it was now 9:35 for a 9pm reservation. But I don't stress over that stuff when you look at the size of the place.  Plus, I was having DRINKS. At the SAVOY. Life is GOOD.

Okay....so now we go back and sit at our table, order our dessert souffles and wine and whatnot and enjoy ourselves.  Got the chocolate and the key lime.  I have to say I very much enjoyed the key lime.  Next time I'll get the grand marnier instead of the chocolate. Chocolate's fine, grand marnier is better.  We had a different waiter and he was a crack-up.  Absolutely enjoyed banter with him and all in all walked away a very happy birthday girl.
author: Laurie H.

description:
I've been here 3 times always only for the dessert.

The chocolate souffle is really good. We always share it between 4 people (because we're typically full from dinner). 

Souffles are fluffy and not too dense. IT has the perfect consistency and sweetness.

Love it!
author: Linda T.

description:
OMG! OMG! that was what I was thinking when I tasted my first spoonful of the Tomato & Cilantro souffle.  It was so DAMN good!  It's so fluffy and flavorful that makes my mouth salivate just thinking about it. My friend and I shared one and we were stuffed.  It was really hearty.  
BUT we HAD to try the dessert souffle.  I really wanted the seasonal berry souffle and just our luck, the last couple before us ordered the last one!  So we got the chocolate one.  Man, was it heaven!  Just sinking that spoon in the souffle and watch the warm googy chocolate oozes out.  It was sooooooo rich and creamy!  You can tell this is some good sh** quality chocolate like from Europe.  
The chef allowed us in the kitchen to thank the chef herself, Jacqueline.  She seems like those forward sweet grandmother.  She makes everything herself and all from memory.  Props to her for doing it so long!  I gotta come back for the strawberry souffle dessert!!!
author: Vu D.

description: Omg so good!  You have entered Souffle heaven!  Jacqueline is always in the kitchen. She makes everything herself. Food can take a while, but definitely worth the wait.   Great wine list and attentive staff.  Highly recommend!!!
author: Coraly S.

description:
I go here every time i visit SF.  It's very intimate with just a few tables.  The sommelier/waiter/receptionist is friendly, professional, and knowledgeable.  As soon as you walk in, your nostrils are filled with the smell of Gruyere cheese since all the entrees are soufflés based in Gruyere cheese.  Actually there's really nothing on the menu other than soufflés besides a couple soups and salads for appetizers.  The bread is amazing and the cheese soufflés are good - I favor the mushroom and prosciutto ones - but the best part is dessert.  There's the standard chocolate and lemon and lime, but what you have to try are the seasonal ones: kiwi, peach, blackberry, strawberry, etc.  Sometimes I just go for dessert.  

One soufflee is plenty big for 2 people.  The first time we went, I didn't know the drill so we each got a soup or salad, shared one cheese souffle, and got 2 dessert ones (since we couldn't decided between chocolate and strawberry).  They were all great but we barely made it through half of either dessert souffle so we took the leftovers home.  They were actually decent reheated the next day :D
author: barbara b.

description:
My only reason for not giving 5 stars is because the length of the meal was quite long. Did I expect this going into it. Absolutely. Does it take away a bit of the experience, possibly.

Since this was for our anniversary and we don't get out to eat at nice gigs with peace and quiet without kids we made sure to sample most of the menu items from each section.

I'm addicted to french bread... especially when it tastes like the loaf I had in Nice, France. Sure brings back memories. Sorry back to the review.

We started with the escargot. I'm not a huge fan... they are snails... but man were these addicting. Almost to the point we paused to think of ordering second round (NOT). You'll see in a minute.

We then shared the French Onion Soup and a Spinach Salad with Bacon and Pine Nuts. That soup was excellent. It isn't overly salted at most restaurants and the flavors were balanced very well. The skill level to cook that soup with all those different strong flavors...something to remember. The salad was well balanced between the crunchiness of the bacon to the crisp spinach leaves and pine nuts. The oil dressing was light and simple.

We ordered the mushroom and prosciutto for our main course. It was well balanced and wasn't heavy. Very filling.

Dessert was the chocolate souffle. Wow... wow... and wow. Just make sure you don't take a breath when eating it cause you'll inhale the powdered sugar which nearly killed me. Wouldn't have been sexy if on a date.... fortunately I was with the wifey so she saved my life. J/K. Water took care of that. Anyways we definitely wouldn't order as much next time, but would definitely go back again sometime.

Service was excellent. The waiters (2) were very attentive and followed up constantly. Be prepared for a very long wait between dishes and absorb the atmosphere. It was quite relaxing and quiet even though the place was packed.
author: Derrick W.

description:
something fun and unique to try - a restaurant full of souffles! however, did not enjoy the long wait for VERY expensive souffles. I will give them credit for atmosphere and authenticity though. I was pretty full afterward but not sure that I enjoyed filling up on such a rich and fluffy food.

Glad to have done it once for a special family occasion but can't see myself going back.
author: Katie B.

description:
Could you be any more rude? 

I came here with friends over the weekend wanting to try the famous souffle and a little over half of the tables were taken. When the host came up to us and we asked how long the wait was (we figured around an hour to eat) all he said was that they were very busy it would be at least 45 minutes to be seated then another 2-3 hours to eat. Then he asked us to stand outside...I'm sorry but that isnt the way you treat potential diners and we will definitely not be back to try!
author: Michelle N.

description:
People on Yelp are not lying when they say that service is impeccable! 

For those who have never had a souffle: It is like a cloud and a cake had a baby. And yes I had the French Onion Soup $10, worth it. and Chocolate Souffle $30. SOOO worth it! 

I got a butter lettuce salad which was pretty overpriced for just plain lettuce. Nonetheless this place is abso-AMAZING!
author: Jacqueline H.

description: Overly rated. Over priced.  Really the food is not as good as expected...could be better...
author: Bubu B.

description:
SERVICE- ***
For a 3-dollar-sign French restaurant, I can just give three stars out of five for the service I received. They were attentive. . . for filling up my water while I waited hours for the food. 


FOOD- ***
I ordered onion soup, lobster souffle and Grand Marnier souffle. Took almost three hours from ordering to leaving.

The onion soup was too salty for me. It was not as awesome as I was expecting. This soup was not made to be drank by itself; bread would be a great complimentary food with it. 

The lobster souffle was a bad idea, maybe it was just the Gruyere cheese that I did not like. My friend and I could hardly finish it. The texture was just too thick. Also, if we brought one more person, finishing this huge souffle could have been an easier job (I'm not kidding, it is quite large and can feed at least 2 people). Aside from the cheese, there was a good amount of lobster cubes in the souffle. Also, the fresh lemon slices that came with this souffle helped me much on eating it. 

Lastly, it's dessert time! After the first bite of the Grand Marnier souffle, I found my confidence in souffles again. I have to give this dessert souffle five stars. I could actually taste the alcohol. This souffle was more fluffy  than (not as thick as) the lobster one. I would recommend try this or other dessert souffle which I will go back and try.
author: Pui L.

description:
I'm not sure what the real rave is about.

Tips:
1.) Basically, you need patience.
     It's gonna be a long wait.

2.) Bad place for a 1st or 2nd date, do this in the 10th+ date or so.
    
3.) Very quiet and very dark atmosphere.

4.) Not the best place for photos, almost impossible in the low lighting.

5.) We were in a group of 6, and we ran out of topics by end of the night.

Pro:
DESSERT IS AMAZINGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGG
SO WORTH THE WAIT. We had the Blueberry filling.

Con:
Lobster and Salmon, ehh.... could be better.  Not much lobster, Salmon,
was on the weak side.

DESSERT IS A MUST! Lesson learned after 3 hours of wait.
author: Calvin C.

description:
I'm a twenty something ethnic fellow and I came in more towards the end of the night to ask how long the wait was.  I was greeted by a scruffy unshaven not well groomed waiter who rudely said "come back in 45 mins and you might get a table" 

I said ok.  I come back in 10 minutes because I realized I never put our name down on the list. I talk to the same fellow to also get an update and he says "oh itll only take 10 more minutes, I said 45 before because I thought you weren't coming back". 

I was shocked at the rudeness of this waiter to say the least. 

ON TO THE SOUFFLE 

I don't know if it was just that night but to be honest, I've had better,  the puffy cloudiness factor was there but the sweet and chocolate factor was not on point. 

I'll have to try gary Danko's to compare.
author: BJ G.

description: What an intimately romantic restaurant that serves soufflés only. As if sharing a soufflé for two is not romantic enough - red roses, low amber light, a small candle brought to your table, and very attentive service by two waiters keeps the spirit of love alive. A cold glass of Lilet begins the evening affair. Perfect endive salad made with crumbs of Roquefort, champagne vinaigrette, fine parsley and chervil. Artists could make models of her French onion soup and dramatic soufflés. The egg lady is Jacqueline Margulis who learned to cook in a French convent. You meet her beaming self and an enormous bowl of eggs if you take a trip to the wash room which passes through the ovenly kitchen. Holder of many worthy recipes she serves probably the finest French Onion soup to be found outside of France. The art work uses a slice of French bread, Gruyere, and what may be a veal broth and the essence of caramelized onion. 11 tables makes this a tough place to get into. A note to the beginning budgeting gourmet - instead of ordering a main and a dessert soufflé and a bottle of wine - simply share a basic soufflé ($30+) and a French onion soup ($10+) and have a romantic experience and you like everyone who dines here will talk about the eveing for the rest of your life.
author: Mark Richard B.

description:
I think I hyped up this place too much for myself and the souffles are definitely somewhat overrated. Let's just say dinner went from 8p to a bit over 11p. Woowee! You definitely have to come here with someone you LOVE talking to or else you're pretty much SCREWED. No joke. 

Out of the 3 things we ordered: French Onion Soup, Crab Souffle, and Chocolate Souffle, the only thing I want to keep raving about is the awesome French Onion Soup. 

FRENCH ONION SOUP
We had to wait about 30-40 minutes for this to come out. When it did, the cheese on top was baked to a good crust, and the soup was pippin' hot! The onions were tasty, the bread that was soaked in it was awesome, and overall the soup was not TOO salty. It was THE BEST. I would have totally wanted this all to myself but 2 ppl shared 1. 

CRAB SOUFFLE
Waited about another 45-55 minutes for this to come out. When it did, I didn't get a chance to take a picture because our waiter began cutting it up and serving it to us. This was nice of him, but I wanted a picture. It's okay. At anyrate, after having a few bites, I felt like I was eating fluffy air. I kinda wanted to throw up after a few bites but told myself to keep it down. This was okay but I definitely didn't want more. I was then settling on the chocolate souffle....

CHOCOLATE SOUFFLE
So we waited perhaps another 40 minutes for this. And WOW can there BE anymore powdered sugar on top? Mmm this definitely hit the spot and it was pretty tasty. I think their dessert souffles trump the savory ones. We only ate the top half of the souffle since everything else was too mushy and fluffy, just like the crab souffle. Soon, the rest of our souffle looked like dog food and I felt somewhat bad for not finishing it. Sorry Madame Jacqueline.

TEA
If you order tea after your meal, they bring out a heart shaped box filled with various tea packets -- all from France! Woowee! Being Asian, I picked up some green tea packet and had the server prepare it for me. It came in a teacup sitting ontop of a teaplate and a bowl of cubed brown sugar...mmm! I want to say the tea was better than the crab souffle...hmmm??

Let me comment about the servers. There are two of them: one is an older man and the other one is younger. The older man is definitely more grumpy than the younger one. The old man started walking off on us when we were deciding what we wanted to drink. He was so impatient. Had he been the only server there, I would have thrown a fit at how bad the service was. We tried avoiding him all night especially since the younger man was SO much more friendlier, helpful, and definitely MORE patient than the old man.

One recommendation for Cafe J is for them to make the souffles smaller so that customers can try more flavors AND it can be cooked better. I think the dessert souffles would have been 10x better had it not been served in such huge portions. 

Total for 2 people was $145 after tip/tax. Not too bad for a French joint but the souffles were NOT worth it. Everyone says to make sure to use the bathroom before you leave and yes, do it. Let me give you a warning and say that the bathroom IS outdoors so on a cold SF night, don't go running out there in a tank top or something. At anyrate, Madame Jacqueline http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/6fyZbXqYZESX2yANZwi5HA/l keeps this HUGE HUGE HUGE wooden bowl filled with eggs in her kitchen. On top, there's one painted lucky egg. http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/B0abxjf35tIHgcVnlsI9Yw/l

I don't think I'll be returning to Cafe J....sorry!

More photos to be loaded.
author: Heidi C.

description:
Outrageous. Superb. Unbelievable. My favorite restaurant up and down the state. 

Wine- Les Carabenes- a French
Pinot for $35. Their wine prices are ridiculously low. 

Onion soup. The best on the planet. 

Souffle- Ginger, corn, garlic with asparagus added. 

Dessert- refreshing lemon souffle. 

The bread and butter- ooh la la. Warm French bread with a crispy crunchy crust and soft inside. The butter could be eaten alone. 

Be sure to walk through the kitchen (you have to to get to the bathroom) and see the master chef - Jacqueline- at work. She was trained at Cordon Bleu in France. 

A truly unique dining experience. Don't let Matt the waiter turn you off. He is really personable and nice one you get past his business persona.
author: Chris S.

description:
I love this restaurant!  This was my first time dining here.  I've heard such great reviews on this restaurant.  I had to give it a try.

The place is quite quaint and had a warm ambiance.  As it got darker during dinner, the dim lighting gave it a bit of a romantic feel.

It's true what others have said that you will wait a while for your food and to expect to be here for a few hours.  The brocolli and brie souffle took about 30 minutes, but it was worth the wait.  The lemon souffle was a little on the tart side for me, but I enjoyed it still.  I think I'll stick to my usual grand marnier next time, or I might try the chocolate.  I love the consistency of the souffles here.  It's not as runny or undercooked as some people on yelp had described it to be.  It's just right.

The souffles are huge!  Good for 2-3 people to share.  The best souffles I've ever had.

I got to meet Chef Jacqueline in the kitchen.  She's such a sweet lady!  Oh, and the server does catch a cab for you if you need one!  I don't know where he went, but he came back with a cab for one of the patrons.  Is that service or what?!
author: Marlette C.

description:
My wife and I got engaged here. For years afterward it was our default place for special occasions and honored guests. We love the food, the atmosphere, Jacqueline herself, etc. But we can't forgive how shabbily we were treated on our last visit. Note: this incident occurred a few years ago. 

As usual we made plans to celebrate our wedding anniversary at Cafe Jacqueline. We arrived on time for our dinner reservation. After waiting 90+ minutes for our table with no explanation, I confronted the waiter politely. I appreciate that they were busy, but his manner and tone said 'F#ck off."' So we did.
author: Sid D.

description:
This place has been on my list for the looooongest time. Reservations are a must here! It's extremely hard to get a table for walk-ins unless you go right when they open. It takes a while to eat since Chef Jacqueline makes everything fresh when you order it.

- French Onion Soup: very salty but delicious flavor, cheese was very good
- Shitake Mushroom, Garlic, Chive Souffle: light, fluffy, savory, not too dense (had a tiny piece of hair in my share, but whatever)
- Strawberry Souffle: fluffy heaven, not too sweet, lots of fresh strawberries piled on top - yummy!

The souffles were very light & fluffy and made fresh! The savory one was okay, but the strawberry one was scrumptious! Topped with fresh strawberries (my favorite fruit!) and I'm in heaven.

The restaurant is small, intimate, cute, and romantic. Having more than 4 people in a party may be difficult. Service was excellent. It is a bit pricey considering the size of the souffles ($30-60), but I have never tasted a souffle that comes close to these. Besides the small hair in my savory souffle, everything was great!
author: Linda C.

description: It is a great restaurant!!  It has original wood floors, original decor and beadboard but a simple style . They serve beer and wine-- no mixed drinks,  Scott was a great waiter, snarky and snide but all in good fun.  The asparagus soufflé was absolutely delicious!! Then the grand marnier soufflé was also divine.  Food as art- art as food....
author: Leela B.

description: Great to see a place do basically one thing and do it to near perfection.  I wish more places were like this.  Nice little local spot, and worth a visit when you want to go somewhere fancy/pricey.
author: Click C.

description:
I dined at Cafe Jacqueline last night for my birthday with my husband and we loved it. We started off the meal with warm crusty french bread that was just a little sour. Mmm I swear it was the beast bread I have ever eaten. Next, we each ordered the french onion soup, shared the prosciutto and mushroom souffle, and a strawberry souffle for dessert.  The french onion soup was delicious and very cheesy. The prosciutto souffle was light fluffy and very decadent. Lastly, the strawberry souffle was divine. It too was light, airy, and not overly sweet. The strawberries on top perfectly complimented the souffle. We finished everything and went home very full and happy. 5 stars for the food.

My husband and I really liked the waiter. He was like out strawberry souffle... not overly sweet. I dislike fake, sickly sweet waiters and he seemed real to me. He was upfront, honest, and didn't sell us on more expensive items to beef up the bill to increase his tip size. Also, he made sure my wine glass was never empty and wished me a "happy birthday" on the way out. The other waiter was quieter and kept our water glasses full.  We liked him too. I give them both 5 stars. 

The restaurant itself was quaint and elegant. And the lighting was perfect - mood lighting but not too dim. I also thought the roses were a cute touch. The room is small but the ceilings are very high which made it feel roomy and open. I also loved going to the bathroom. You get to walk through the kitchen and see Jacqueline with a big basket of eggs making all the souffles by herself! Unbelievable. This restaurant is a gem and it is so unique. It is exactly what I was looking for. I am so sick of the same old trendy restaurants that turn out to be the all the same versions of each other. I highly recommend Cafe Jacqueline to anyone looking for a special evening. 5 stars for ambiance.

What to know:
The dinner did take a long time but i really liked the anticipation and was able to have good conversation and enjoy my wine between the meals. It gave me time to digest my food before the next course was brought out. That was a good thing because I was able to enjoy everything without feeling too stuffed.
author: J M.

description:
The boyfriend took me here for a birthday dinner, and it fit the bill perfectly - small, sweet, romantic spot with long waits made for long conversations.

We had:

1. The French onion soup - gooey, cheesy goodness.
2. Mushroom and prosciutto souffle - soft and fluffy and served beautifully. This was a little on the salty side and not my favorite of the evening.
3. Lemon souffle - holy mother of flavor in my mouth. AMAZING. I'm definitely partial to lemon flavored deserts and this was the perfect balance of tangy and sweet. Loved it. I'd definitely come back just for dessert.

Our meal was about 2.5 hours long - plan on waiting since the souffles take a while, and are made as you order. Share a bottle of wine to help pass the time.

As everyone's said, make sure you peek into the kitchen (if you need an excuse, it's on the way to the bathroom). All that's in there is Jacqueline, her oven, and baskets of eggs. And that's really all you need.
author: Lisa W.

description:
1)  I'm amazed that this establishment has only a dozen small tables, and almost 200 reviews.
2)  I'm even more amazed that I haven't heard about it before.  Even though I can now see that my friend Virginia Y has written a great review of it.

My husband found it right here on Yelp, and we lucked out because there was a 7pm cancellation for that night.  Serendipity.

I'm always impressed by a great sommelier.  He asks what kind of wine we like.  We mumble something inarticulate and he asks a couple more questions.  He runs off brings us each exactly the perfect wine.  How do they do that?  The sommelier here was like that.

The french onion soup was very good as previously reported. We shared one bowl because we wanted to have room for the main attraction.  

The souffle menu had so many compelling choices, it was very hard to make a decision.  We had the crab souffle because we both love us some crab.  And we went with the chocolate souffle for dessert.  Both souffles were wonderful, with a perfect consistency.  We have already picked out which ones we are going to try next time, and we will be back.

Definitely a good choice for a romantic special date.  The leisurely pace of the meal gives you lots of time for talking, gazing into each other's eyes and hand holding.  And of course sharing the entrees is an intimate touch.  

Cafe Jacqueline est une recette de l'amour.
author: Linda M.

description:
Simply THE BEST DATE SPOT IN San Francisco, or ANYWHERE for that matter. Jacqueline is so wonderful and does a fantastic job still cooking all the souffles on her own. We got to visit her in the kitchen after our meal, and it really made the night even better.

This was my wife and I's second time here, and we loved it even more this time. Our waiter was great, helped us pick out a perfect wine to match our meal (and didn't pull the old, let me pick the most expensive wine we have trick). They really know how to let you enjoy the full meal, without leaving you hungry or feeling like you are waiting at any point.

We had the onion soup to start and it was delish, really tasty since they use veggie stock instead of beef.

Tried the Cauliflower souffle and WOW, simple but delish. I do have to say that the white corn and garlic one we had last time was just a little better, but still...awesome.

Nothing beats the simply atmosphere of this place. No more than 10 tables, each decorated very nicely and the perfect amount of low lighting. It's pretty much all reservations, so no one is waiting around or making a ton of noise in this very small spot.

Take your date here, and you both will be glad you did!
author: Ryan D.

description: I had waited for a long time to go back and I was very disappointed. The savory (mushroom) souffle was way too salty. My companion didn't even finish her half and she was hungry after a long workday. The strawberry souffle was topped with too may strawberries and the inside was completely mushy/watery. On top of it all, the dinner took three hours I love a long meal but it has to be worth it.
author: E M.

description: I dine at Cafe Jacqueline about four times a year. For me it's like going to Paris for the night. Madame Jacqueline, at an age when most have long-since retired, still stands all night, mixing the souffles by hand. She seems to get shorter every year. This is not the kind of place to go on your way to someplace else. This is your destination. You take your time with each course and you savor the food, the wine, and the company. I see that some people here have made comments about the decor - but to me it's part of the charm. Every course is made for you individually. Share the soufflés - as they're too large for one person. The onion soup is an exquisite meal unto itself. The corn ginger soufflé is to die for. Try the seasonal berry soufflés, or whatever the waiter suggests. Mme. Jacqueline is an artist - so go as you would to a gallery or a museum. Open your mind, open your heart, and slow down as you would if you were in Paris. Parking may be difficult, but at least you don't have to take a 10 hour flight to get there.
author: Susan D.

description:
1. Charming & romantic ambience. 
2. Excellent service. 
3. Incredible soufflés. 
4. Lime soufflé blew my mind!!!

Bottom Line: I'll definitely go back.
author: John W.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place forever. I went through this souffle craze last year and have been jonesing to come here. Finally I got a chance to come with my BFF and her parents. Honestly this place is overrated. Took forever to get our food, which I guess I can understand since there's an 80 year old lady cranking out souffles one by one in the back. But when the souffle's came out the flavors were just so so. 

We had two savory ones and two dessert ones. The savory ones (corn ginger and prosciutto) were just ok. One of them was overcooked and tasted kinda dry. The dessert ones (chocolate and strawberry), the chocolate one was undercooked and the inside was all watery... we mentioned it to the waiter and he said that's how it's suppose to be. REALLY? I doubt that. The strawberry one was excellent tho. Super moist and flavorful. I'd come back just for that if they would allow it. 

I still feel bad for the old lady in the back pumping out the souffles. She needs a better retirement plan. Doh!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
So, after several attempts to dine in the quaint little cafe, I finally made it to Cafe Jacqueline. The past few times I was in SF with the wife, she had really wanted to go here, but we were never able to get a table. This time, we called several weeks in advance and got ourselves an 8:30 reservation. 

FYI - I asked the server if they are okay with diners just coming in for dessert, and he said "absolutely".

The place is tiny, and I am pretty sure that they only seat 1, max 2 seatings per table per night. I was expecting a stuffy place with up tight service, but it was the opposite. Our waiter was a larger set, jovial gentleman who was absolutely delightful all evening. Very friendly, very helpful and really helped us enjoy our evening to the fullest.

I would suggest coming early. Waiting for your food can be a nightmare. We were literally there for over 3 hours, and we only ordered 2 things. When in Rome...

Unfortunately, they had run out of the French Onion Soup, which apparently never happens. We ordered the Corn/Ginger/Garlic main course, and the chocolate dessert with fresh whipped cream. Both were delicious, airy and perfectly savory. I feel like I would appreciate the main course more now that the huge portion it isn't in front of me anymore. Looking back, it was damn good.

We were encouraged to go into the kitchen (TINY!!!) and thank Jacqueline personally. She is a sweet old lady who was very kind and appreciative. Really helped close out the great evening on a special note.

HIGHLY RECOMMEND - unique experience.
author: Adam D.

description:
It's been a while since I've been to Cafe Jacqueline, but the fact that I still remember some of the things we had, says a lot about the place. The setting is cute, there's a certain kind of homey elegance to the place. Dimly lit. The interior painted over so many times, the molding grows into its own character like half-spent candlestick.

And the food was good. Not earth-shaking. Not utterly delicious. Just--pretty good. I found our seafood souffle to be a little dry. The little bits of goodies inside were just a touch overcooked--a little unfortunate when it's a dish you're paying fifty bucks for.

Add to the fact that parking here is nearly impossible (I'd almost suggest taking the bus, how's that for a fancy night out?), and I have to say it may be a while before I come back. Though I would recommend Cafe Jacqueline for something different or if you're hankering for soufflet.
author: Tony L.

description:
It's all about the fluffiness. 
You have to be committed to a souffle-only meal to dine here. 

Start off with the french onion soup, really nice and savory, will warm you up in no time on a typical, cold, sf foggy night. 

Savory souffle for the main course, I got the mushroom and lobster. Really really fluffy. 

Finish off with another souffle for desert, sweet this time. Chocolate's always the safe way to go!

I was stuffed. It was so fluffy. And the fluffiness just keeps getting fluffier in your stomach. 

I would even skip the main course and just go in for soup and desert.

The kitchen is packed with eggs. baskets of eggs. 

It's pricey, but if you like souffle, go for it!
author: Erica L.

description:
Loved it!!!!! 

Mme Jacqueline did a great job!... definitely worths the wait!!

The place is very romantic and cozzy. 

I'm certainly going back to try the rest of the soufflés.
author: Angelica V.

description:
Oh what can I say? I'm a Fine Food Gigolo! It is sooo true-The Way To A Man's Heart Is Through His Stomach, and, for well over a decade, Cafe Jacqueline has been one of my Greatest Culinary Lovers in SF! Madame Jacqueline, Je t'adore!
 
This veritably is one of THE MOST Romantic restaurants in San Francisco with soft candlelight, small and intimate tables, and delicious aromas coming from the kitchen.  It's also the totally perfect place for one to make a heartfelt marriage proposal (mine took place in a Howard Johnson's, but that's another story).
 
For those who have written a negative review of our beloved Cafe Jacqueline, I have to ask you, Have You Ever Tried Cooking A Souffle Yourself?!?!?!
Here are four undeniable truths about Souffles:
 
#1 They ARE Delicious for Dinner
 
#2 They ARE Delicious for Dessert
 
#3 They take an inordinate amount of time to cook (there is a reason why most fine restaurants will ask you to place your souffle order well in advance of the rest of your meal)
 
#4 They are very difficult to prepare (I have tried three times in my life to make them- First Try it melted and became expensive Incontinent Looking Pudding, Second Try it burned and became a Ghetto Tasting Funnel Cake, Third Try I can't even talk about...)
 
Any visit to Cafe Jacqueline is a truly magnificent dining experience! Be prepared to share spoons, lovingly linger for a few hours over bottles of champagne and wine, engage in quiet conversations, and savor excellent salads, appetizers,  and souffles that are painstakingly created through the loving talents of beautiful woman's heart! 

Well worth the price and wait! But, if you want cheap and deep, just go to North Beach Pizza across the street!
 
Madame Jacqueline, A la prochaine! A votre sante!
author: Richard T.

description:
Dessert:
I'm normally a chocolate dessert girl, but the strawberry souffle here is one of the best things I've ever tasted.

Restaurant/Service:
The restaurant is small; it probably seats about 30 people at most, and is waited on by two servers who are extremely attentive. The service is definitely five star. Low candle lighting makes it perfect for a romantic date. 

Overall:
I can't wait to go back to try a savory souffle!
author: Kristen E.

description: Haven't been there in years, so feel free to discount this review in its entirety. But for what it's worth, this souffle dinner & dessert was the most incredible meal I ever ate in San Francisco - and I'd go back there in a heartbeat. Plan to share your souffles so you can try as much as you can.
author: Susan L.

description:
What an wonderful experience! 

Knowing how much and for how long I have wanted to try this place, my amazing husband booked a reservation for my birthday.  Wow - we were very impressed!  We shared a light salad to start, a herb and cheese soufflé for our entrée and a chocolate soufflé for dessert.  Everything was wonderful. Our service was great and I liked how on the way to the restroom you walk through the kitchen and get a shot of Jacqueline herself in action.  

Having made soufflé myself, I know it takes a long time to make and even longer to cook.  You cannot rush perfection!  As such, we thoroughly enjoyed our 3 hour dining experience.  It's so nice to just sit with your partner to take a break, have an absolutely amazing meal, and just enjoy each other's company.

I guess if you don't really like your partner that much, or if you're super awkward and/or boring, this may not be the right dining experience for you.  I don't know how you can hold that against Café Jacqueline though.  That's kind of your problem and not hers, don't you think?
author: C S.

description:
Since seeing this place on the food network I had been aching to try it out. Too bad San Francisco is not a day trip away from Houston. Well we went to the Bay area as part of a family vacation and my bro and I were able to drop in.

When we first walked into the door they asked if we had a reservation. We said no but they kindly gave us a table. If you have your heart set on eating here I would highly recommend calling ahead for a reservation. Secondly, I wish I had dressed nicer than just wearing a henley and pants. This is obviously a place popular for special occasions and thus the rest of the clientele was well put together. 

The waiters were kind and explained everything to us including the long wait time. THIS IS NOT A PLACE TO GRAB A QUICK BITE. Allot yourself at least 1 hour per souffle. 

Is the wait worth it? Well another customer turned to us and said the wait is well worth it and that the souffles are euphoric. We ordered the white corn, ginger, and garlic souffle and 1 hour later we were chowing down. The souffle itself was extremely light and delightfully oozing with gruyere cheese, however, the standout was the white corn. Crispy and sweet you could tell that it was fresh off the cob and blended well with the mild ginger and garlic flavor. Definitely a winner. Even my carnivorous brother found it amazing. Next was the white chocolate souffle. Wow. Just wow. Coming from a man who loves white chocolate this was the absolute best white chocolate dessert I have ever eaten. Quite possibly even the best dessert I've ever had the pleasure of eating. The souffle provided a perfect fluffy vessel for that rich white chocolate flavor. It took all of our willpower to not finish the entire dish since we wanted to save some of the love for our other brother and parents. 

Cafe Jacqueline will always be a priority stop every time I am in the Bay Area!
author: Miguel L.

description:
My companion pointed out, "Do you notice the waiters don't ask us how the meal is?" The food speaks for itself... Literally the best meal I have ever had ever. Yelp needs six stars, darnit. 

Atmosphere: The waiters were awesome, very attentive and polite, and extremely dignified without being condescending. The table settings were simple, and perfect that way. They played good classical music in the background, added a very nice touch.

Food: We ordered the french onion soup, garlic shiitake mushroom souffle, and chocolate souffle... I can't really say very much about the food besides that it was fantastic. I enjoy cooking and such, but I have no idea how that much flavor manages to get into every bite... The two of us managed to eat all of it without feeling too full. Mmmm...

After we paid, we left and one of the waiters (dude with the mustache) basically chased after us thanking us and telling us to come back sometime. I can't argue with you folks that have had some rude encounters, but at least from my experience, they were extremely nice to us.

To the people upset with being "mistreated" for not having a reservation... I don't even.. just.. facepalm.. The food takes time for a reason. You should know what you're getting into before walking into a place like this... And yes, they will prefer you to wait outside if you don't have a reservation because you will just crowd up the place. To the guy claiming this restaurant is racist against Asians, I saw the waiters were superbly polite and accommodating to an Asian couple when the husband was going to have to show up late for their reservation... You're just mad you didn't get to eat here. And maaaan you should be.

So good...
author: Emily Z.

description:
This place is great! Jacqueline has been making souffles for about 30 years. Our waiter was very helpful in picking out a wine for us. My favorite dessert souffle is the white chocolate. 
For a small intimate dinner, with flowers on every table, and serene ambiance this is the place to go. (Don't ask for a straw - they are so french they don't have them)!
author: Carolé A.

description: This place is very "old-french sheik". Its not a place you go by yourself. Friends/family is a must. Sharing dishes is a must if you're into that. They have good food here. Beware its not typical american-french food. Its soufflés galore. This last week was my 3rd time here and it is expensive for sure but you get what you pay for. Keep in mind....#1--you're in sf......#2--your'e in a very french restaurant...and #3--service can be charming to add to the experience. I know it can get busy with reservations especially on friday or saturday night so if its hectic, your server might not be in the best mood. I guess I'm tolerable of that having worked in customer service for 15 years myself. So if you're patient, the wait staff will warm up to you. Its a special occasion place for sure which is why we only come when our family from Taiwan request to come here.
author: Chris Y.

description: This is our favorite restaurant in SF.  Their french onion soup is so good, other soups are jealous!  The souffles are amazing, we always order both an entree and dessert souffle, yum!  Service was excellent as well.  Our last visit was on a Wednesday night, early, with a reservation and the restaurant was not busy at all.  We parked our car in the Union Square parking garage and took a cab from the Westin, much easier than trying to find a parking spot in North Beach.  It is expensive, and worth every dollar.  Bravo, Jacqueline!
author: Joan W.

description: If the waiter with the ridiculous Picasso moustache is in sight RUN away fast or he will ruin your experience as he did ours. He is rude, pretentious and makes you feel like being waited by him is a privilege. No one can enjoy anything when the waiter is on a constant power trip - makes it very uncomfortable and really not worth it.
author: Alex O.

description:
I dragged my hubby here one year to celebrate my birthday. We had such a huge fight over finding a parking space that my birthday was almost ruined!
But the escargots and souffles made up for it.
I think this was probably the last and final time I was able to persuade him to come to North Beach!
author: Lisa T.

description:
Would you like to eat an amazing souffle?  Follow these simple steps:

1. Call Cafe Jaqueline, leave a message on their answering machine that I'm pretty sure uses a cassette tape as its recording medium.
2. Answer your phone when they call back.  Schedule a time.
3. Ask someone you enjoy conversing with to join you.  You'll be talking with them for a few hours while you sip a glass of water and Jacqueline beats eggs.
4. Show up at that time, you'll probably be seated promptly.  The reverse side of this is that you'll probably be asked to leave if you've eaten and your table is reserved for a later seating.
5. Sit down, order the French onion soup (you'll get one bowl and two spoons, so don't order this when accompanied by someone with questionable mouth biota), a dinner souffle, and a dessert souffle.
6. Talk with your friend/lover for an hour or two, which won't be annoying because you've chosen an interesting date and you've come prepared for this step.  The waiters and your date are quietly judging your level of sophistication, so don't complain.
7. Enjoy the great soup and a couple of amazing souffles.
8. Don't act surprised when you get the huge bill, uber home, and, if you've been sufficiently engaging and flirtatious with your date, get to second base at a minimum.  If you didn't want to share the soup with them, you should probably go home alone.

Note: If the mustachioed man happens to introduce you to Jaqueline, the appropriate thing to do is gush.
author: Josh B.

description:
I think this restaurant is great if you are prepared to eat very heavy meals. My date and I shared the seafood souffle and it was SO heavy with cheese, etc. It was delicious but extremely filling. I believe almost everything on the menu is a souffle so be prepared for that.

The ambiance is wonderful - very charming and romantic. It definitely feels like a mom and pop restaurant.

My FAVORITE part was the chocolate souffle dessert. It was amazing! Probably my favorite dessert in the city. It is also really big and could probably feed 5 people.
author: Jenna Q.

description:
My husband and I came here to celebrate our second anniversary. I was surprised he suggested Cafe Jacqueline since he does not like eggs unless they're used for french toast or diced in fried rice..

The cafe is small so definitely make a reservation ahead of time. The inside is quaint, a single rose in a vase at each table that doesn't seat more than about 4 guests. 

There were two waiters there that evening, one of whom was the more typical snooty type (when he asked if I wanted anything to start with and I told him I hadn't decided on what to drink, he responded, "That's not what I asked.") but fortunately he warmed up later when we complimented the food. The second waiter, brown hair and glasses, was just delightful. Warm and friendly, he helped pick an outstanding bottle of French wine for us.  And it was reasonably priced so that was a bonus.

We chose the French Onion Soup for the first course. While in France, my husband ordered it everywhere. The soup here trumps the French Onion soup in France.

We chose the Mushroom and Prosciutto souffle for our main course (large enough to serve two) and my heart stopped for a moment when the waiter plated our food as the souffle was obviously egg mixture all the way through. I thought my husband was going to be miserable. Fortunately, he has become more adventurous since meeting me. Upon first bite he absolutely LOVED it! He decided next time, he needs a souffle all to himself because half of it wasn't enough. This coming from a man who hates the smell, texture, taste of eggs.

For dessert, we got the chocolate souffle. This was a beautiful, light, fluffy piece just like the savory souffle but this is chocolate with a dusting of powdered sugar on top so of course this was amazing. This chocolate souffle is better suited to those who like dark chocolate as it is not too sweet. For me it was perfection.

We enjoyed the meal completely and it was a great start to our anniversary. Merci beaucoup Cafe Jacqueline! Tres manifique!
author: Nicole T.

description: Another North Beach gem. The best French Onion soup ever and the soufflés, ah the soufflés, are the best! Everything's made to order so don't be in a rush, but why would you whilst in such a great space. The waiters are great too. We are blessed to have Jacqueline prepare such out of this world meals for us. Thank you!
author: Katt D.

description:
Souffle Souffle Souffle!!! 

Expect to eat souffle and only souffle. These things are huge. I mean HUGE. I went here on a date once, and we had the cheese and broccoli souffle. This thing was gigantic. It was very good...but it was huge and I felt so bad for not finishing it. The atmosphere was romantic. Small and quaint. Service was great since the place was small. 

Caution: Dessert souffle was just as big as the main course. It was so rich and filling, we wobbled out of there. Not romantic.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Okay, so I went here for Valentine's day and spent $250 for the courses of garbage and dropped a $50 tip so the girlfriend wouldn't think I'm so cheap. All the rumors of this place having good souffle or whatever else is a straight up lie. 

Pros- They filled the glass full often, nice romantic scenery, and they take your coat for you.

Cons- 
Souffle: Dry, Bitter Chocolate, and it doesn't have that "melt" it has that "dry crunch".
French Onion: Boiled salt water with extra salt.
Salad: 3 mini cloves of romaine lettuce with sauce.

I forgot what else there was, but seriously all of the food were super salty and disguisting. Went to In-N-Out right after to quench my mouth in flavor. Truly a rip off place for worst than out-the-box taste.
author: Jonathan D.

description:
A perfect anniversary/date french restaurant i may say.  This place is hidden in the streets of San Francisco and very romantic with its dimmed lighting, small tables, and different aromas coming out of their kitchen.  When I went to celebrate an anniversary, we were mainly the only young couple amongst everyone else there.  I believe everyone else was also celebrating an anniversary or whatnot.

The service was very friendly.  We shared the french onion soup there for appetizer.. and let me tell you... this soup was what made me put french onion soup as my favorite soup of all time now.  I always compare it to the one that I first had at Cafe Jacqueline.  It was to die for.  There entrees were very flavorful also.  The dessert that we ordered was the white chocolate souffle.  When it came out of the kitchen, it surprised us because it was pretty big for two!  I love white chocolate...so this hit the spot!
author: Kathy D.

description:
The bread, the french onion soup, the souffles - AMAZING, each and every one of them.  Jacqueline the owner is friendly and serves a plate full of love.  The atmosphere is cozy and intimate and it's not a fast food kind of place.  It is a place where you spend a leisurely evening savoring each course.  It takes time because each souffle is lovingly prepared by the owner. The strawberry dessert souffle is divine and a nice follow up to some soup and salad starters.  The savory souffles are tasty, but you'll never have room for all of it so I'd skip this in favor of starters and dessert.  

Good things come to those who wait, and if you're complaining about having to spend a couple hours eating and conversing with your companion then you have bigger issues.
author: Rebekah D.

description:
I adore cute neighborhood restaurants like this that specialize in one thing (souffles), but honestly it is too French for my taste. I don't like rude waiters. I don't like inflated prices. And I don't have the attention span for a leisurely dinner where two souffles require 2.5 hours. This was a good meal but make sure you come with thick skin, a thick wallet, and lots of time.

My friend and I split the lobster souffle ($60) and two other friends split the shiitake, basil, and garlic souffle ($38). We all shared the strawberry souffle ($35). The lobster souffle was delicious with large chunks of lobster, but the taste became monotonous after several bites. I kept wishing for corn or a kick somewhere in there. I enjoyed the strawberry souffle more because some pieces of fruit were sweet while others were tart--it was very balanced.

While Cafe Jacqueline has not instilled me with patience, it has inspired me to look up recipes for souffles. I have ramakins, so why not? I'm pretty sure with my taste, speed, and magic touch, I can whip up two souffles in under an hour. Yup--no self-esteem problems here.
author: Liz T.

description:
Oh, Jacqueline, how I love love love your food and am driven crazy by how long it takes to make souffle!

Three things you must know before you eat here (which you must):

1.  this restaurant ONLY serves salad and souffles
2.  if you're hungry, one souffle is NOT enough for two people
3.  your souffles take AT LEAST one hour to arrive.  as in, after you order.  even when you order dessert souffles with your main course, they mysteriously take an hour after your dinner has gone by.

Ok, got the three things?  Now know that these are the best souffles that you will find for a good 100 miles.  This place is amazing; it's really tough to find a restaurant like this even in many places in France.  The savory souffles include mushroom, leek, bacon, potato, asparagus, salmon, and melt in your mouth.  For dessert you can order chocolate, strawberry, blackberry -- all impeccably made.  They bring spoons for the table and you all just dip in.  Gorgeous.

The decor is intime, quiet, lovely -- candles and tablecloths; they hang up your coat. 

The souffles run about $35 each, so, now that I think about it, this is a great spot for dessert and coffee if you don't want to overdo it money or egg-wise.  

The wine is all French, and the selection is ok -- some really expensive ones, and just a few down the bottom.  :)
author: daisy s.

description: One of the advantages of living in North Beach is that we don't have drive around like the Lost Dutchman looking for parking in North Beach. The other advantage is living in the same neighborhood as San Francisco's best-kept secret: Cafe Jacqueline. Yes, there really is a Jacqueline and she is on site  every evening, at least when we've been there. Her restaurant does one thing and one thing well: souffles. You won't find finer savory or sweet souffles anywhere outside of Paris. One dinner souffle satisfies 2-4 people. Share a dinner souffle and you'll have plenty of room for one of the exquisite dessert souffles. Just make sure to tell your server from the beginning that you intend to order a dessert souffle also so that they can time its arrival at your table. Don't forget to order Champagne of one of the other sparkling wines on Jacqueline's wine list. Nothing pairs with egg dishes like bubbly. Many locals like us make Cafe Jacqueline their special occasion restaurant. One bite and you'll understand why. One last observation: this is one of the few restaurants in San Francisco where acoustics are good and tables are far enough apart so that one can actually hear one's table companions talk. So Cafe Jacqueline is equally a delightful venue for a large group AND for a romantic duo.
author: Scout F.

description:
This charming restaurant made for a splendid evening.  The four of us split an Onion Soup, Red Pepper Soup du Jour, Shitake Basil & Garlic Soufflé, Tomato Cilantro Soufflé, Chocolate Soufflé, and the seasonal Strawberry Soufflé. While all amazing, the fresh strawberries were by far the biggest hit. 

I think the best part is that the food is delicious without being overly decadent. You get the feeling of light, airy, heavenly spoonfuls. We luxuriated over the meal for 4 hours, and never once wondered where our the next course was. 

You must walk through the kitchen to get to the restroom, which is actually a special treat where the chef & owner greet you with a, "bonsoir," while she whips the next soufflé.
