You can see the quaint French kitchen full of eggs, shredded Gruyere, and fresh farmer's market ingredients, and it makes you want to pull up a counter stool and a glass of wine to learn the secrets. 

The whole dinner felt like an out of country experience in all the best ways.
author: Belén T.

description:
Semi-good service for a semi-good souffle.
I was excited to try Jacqueline's but after I have,
 I would not go again.
author: Erin G.

description:
18 years of coming here for my birthday and it is still delicious! All I'm going to say is, I can now die happy....that is how good the souffles are.
Kill me now, because life isn't getting any better.
author: Bianca L.

description:
This is the worst place I have eaten in the city.
1. With reservations we still had to wait. We waited 40 minutes, but tolerated it because we were counting on the experience being great.
2. I wish we would have been told upon making reservations that the entrees take an hour to cook.
3. Our waiter was unfriendly; didn't check in with us after serving our tea, soup, nor our souffle. In addition, he had not collected our used dishes. I actually had to ask him to take our dirty dishes after we had been served our souffle.
4. Improvements could be made to the bathroom. I have been in portal-potties nicer than this! Considering the amount they are charging for an egg dish, I think they can afford to clean, replace, and update their restroom.
5. The $60 souffles were bland and over cooked.
author: Megan H.

description:
Jacqueline's souffles are simply amazing. Share one of her strawberry souffles with your loved one on a romantic date and you will know what I mean. However, there is a lot more to Cafe Jacqueline than tasty souffles and a superb onion soup.

Here is what I mean: My pregnant wife and I were traveling around the world for six months and simply never lost our craving for Jacqueline's strawberry souffles. After returning back to San Francisco, on our baby's official due date, my wife called Cafe Jacqueline to check if the strawberry souffle was on the menu that day and to reserved a table for two to celebrate our special day. As it so happened, Jacqueline herself answered the call and confirmed our table and the strawberry souffle on the menu. We could hardly wait.

Shortly after arriving at Cafe Jacqueline, our bliss abruptly ended. The waiter informed us that our craving wouldn't be satisfied today. "No more strawberry souffles". Well, what can you do, the restaurant was completely packed, guess we were just too late. We accepted our fate and ordered the mushroom and prosciutto souffle with extra tomatoes and decided to try the chocolate souffle as a dessert instead.

The main course was delicious. We both liked the saltiness of the prosciutto blending with the sweetness of the tomatoes and mushrooms. But seeing all the tables around us getting one strawberry souffle after another was kind of tough. It quickly turned into a running gag with our nice waiter who mentioned that Jacqueline indeed remembered a woman calling and explicitly asking for the strawberry souffle.

When the dessert was finally served, we could hardly believe our luck. It wasn't the chocolate souffle we ordered. It was the strawberry souffle we had craved for so long. Jacqueline had managed to come up with one more out of nowhere. I am not sure how she did it, but I do know that I won't forget the perfect taste of her hot souffle with sweet strawberries and a little bit of powder sugar on my palate.

Seth Godin once said you have to invest 10,000 hours to be great at anything. Jacqueline is way past that mark. That evening, we learned that she opened her cafe in 1979 and hasn't miss a single shift. She has personally cooked every single souffle that ever left her kitchen.

And it shows.
author: Soeren S.

description:
i dont know about the people with gripes about the service but we had EXCELLENT service there! when we first called to make the reservation, we spoke to jacqueline herself and she even explained to us that we should have a FULL lunch meal the day our of reservation becuz we will be waiting awhile since the souffles are made to order. very very pleasant french lady!

i already knew about the long wait, after reading all the reviews here and other websites. we were looking for a romantic, one of a kind, french restaurant for our anniversary and decided to go with this one. and boy, was i impressed! first of all, the restaurant is located on a cute little street with victorian style buildings. its actually not hard to find cuz for some the reason, the store next door to it was boarded up.....must have been a fire or something. 

we sat at a table closest to the door becuz it was actually a really warm day and the restaurant itself was pretty warm. oh and there were a total of 10 tables......yes 10. so if you plan on going for a special occasion on a weekend, make reservations just in case. there were only two waiters and both were extremely friendly with their french accents. our waiter was soooo nice, he even helped recommend a french wine to go with our meal. we shared the spinach with pine nut salad, the french onion soup and had the shiitake, basil and garlic souffle (yes, risky for a dinner date). we were sooo tempted to order their seasonal strawberry souffle but i knew we wouldnt be able to finish it and didnt want to have to carry leftovers later that night.

but oh YUM!!! everything was just delicious!!! even the complimentary bread came out nice and warm and toasty, as soon as you spread the butter on it, it juss melts. it was such a lovely dinner, i would definitely go there again whenever im in town. 

and yes, in order to get to the restroom, you have to walk thru the tiny little kitchen where you'll see HUGE bowls of eggs and jacqueline cracking away. they even grow their own flowers that they put on the tables in their back yard garden (you'll see them when you go to the restroom). 

such a wonderful wonderful time there!

*my 50th review and its one of the most memorable experience*
author: Sara C.

description: Came here for a romantic birthday dinner.  We ordered tomato soup, a mushroom souffle (one of the specials), and white chocolate souffle.  The service was good and our waters were refilled often.  The bread is very warm and fresh.  The souffles do take a lot of time to prepare, but this is to be expected.  It felt like a good date spot to give couples time to chat.  Our dinner was about 3 hours total, but we never felt neglected.  Our favorite was the dessert souffle which had a lot of lovely textures and right level of sweetness.  We'd consider going back just for dessert, but I'd like to try some of their other savory souffles too.  Parking garages are only a few blocks away.  This place is absolutely worth a try, but be sure to call in for a reservation and give yourself plenty of time.
author: Amanda A.

description: This place is excellent, made a reservation for a Saturday night date and was promptly seated, served with perfect service and a wonderful atmosphere, the food was impeccable, and i mean just perfect. I can't  imagine any  one being unhappy about this place for a romantic date. The price was a little steep, but that's the only negative thing i can even remotely come up with. This place made an amazing night and if your looking for a place to take a special date, this is, for sure the most romantic restaurant in all of SF
author: Scrapp H.

description:
Took the boyfriend here for his birthday and he loves lobster so you know what we had: the lobster souffle.  It was perfectly cooked with big pieces of succulent lobster and pockets of gooey gruyere goodness.  The top was covered in thin slices of lemon upon which the waiter laid the tender souffle when he plated it.  When cutting into it, a bit of lemon coated every bite and balanced out the richness.  

As soon as you order, they bring freshly toasted baguette and sweet butter.  We had a simple salad of lightly dressed zesty watercress on the side... it was the perfect combination. The waiters were super helpful and when I asked for a recommendation for a glass of white Bordeaux on the tart side, he poured a sample before bringing the glass.  It was delicious.  

The chocolate souffle was a lovely finish, topped with an orange slice cut into a diamond with a candle on top.   What a romantic, unhurried, decadent experience.
author: Elena E.

description: This is not a comment on the food, which is wonderful.  It is a comment on the deplorable customer service attitude of one of the Cafe employees.  I left a phone message as instructed during restaurant working hours to try to make a reservation at the restaurant for the following evening.  I did not hear back until 4:30 pm the next afternoon, just hours before the requested reservation time (no table was available).  Not knowing the status of my request until just hours before the requested dinner time was frustrating.  The man who called me told me that they were too busy to listen to their phone messages.  When I commented that I thought it was poor business practice to ignore reservation requests, he said "Thanks for the tip!" and hung up on me.  Wow!
author: Joel P.

description:
Picasso isn't too bad once you get to know him. 
We succeeded to get in after two failed attempts. 
We started our journey with some hot toasty French bread followed by escargots and French onion soup. All there were amazing. 
Our main course was the shrimp and scallop soufflé which warranted a review of its own. Amazing flavor. I can't find the words to explain...  
Dessert was the chocolate soufflé. Quite possibly the best soufflé I've ever had in my life. I was extremely lucky that my wife was pretty full by dessert, so I got to devour most of it myself :) 
We also enjoyed a bottle of Pinot throughout our meal. Followed by a dessert wine I let Picasso choose for us. 
All in all very worth it to visit at least once. I would be more inclined to revisit had the price not been so expensive. Like I said. Worth doing it at least once. If you plan on going Make A Reservation. Otherwise you will meet the mean Picasso who will either turn you away or make you wait out in the cold for at least an hour or two. 
While dining make sure to go to the bathroom through the kitchen to say hello and thank you to Jacqueline who is hard at work preparing everything from scratch.
author: Andy K.

description:
Fantastic.  
Romantic.
Expensive.
Notable.
Calming.
Homey.

What does that spell?  F-R-E-N-C-H! :)

We were promised a slow, European dining experience.  It was lovely.  I also loved seeing the huge basket of eggs in the kitchen and the patient stirring of the large pot of batter (is that what it's called?) as I wound my way to find the restroom.

All of the souffles have gruyere, and we ordered one with white corn, ginger, and garlic [we wanted to get 3 bangs for our buck -- many of the savory souffles only have one ingredient].

Dessert was a strawberry souffle.  It was absolute heaven in a ramekin.

I'll have to come back when I (or someone else) have/has the money...
author: Catherine H.

description:
I would give this place 0 stars if I could.  I have eaten here before with my wife and were looking forward to eating here again to celebrate Valentine's Day this year.  We drove 40 minutes and spent another 30 minutes looking for parking.  When we arrived, we saw a sign that said they were closed due to illness.  
   Are you kidding me?!  I understand if you have to close due to emergency, but someone had the time to put that sign up.  That means you would have the time to call the customers with reservations that night to inform them so that we can make alternate plans.  Especially given that this is Valentine's Day weekend!  Sorry for the inconvenience?!
   I hope someone from the restaurant reads this review.  This is completely unprofessional.  I really enjoy your restaurant and food, but you have lost a customer.  If my friends ever ask me about your restaurant, this is the experience I will tell them about.
author: Stewart W.

description:
tres romantique!
First and foremost (as Elley said), go use the bathroom here because you have to walk thru the kitchen... you'll see a lone woman with a long braid and a chef's hat hard at work, and the largest basket of eggs you've ever seen. You'll then understand what kind of thoughfulness was put into your meal (and why it takes so long...she's making one at a time!)

The lobster souffle was excellent, the salad was a nice touch so we didn't feel like we were consuming only carbs, though they were brought out with quite a bit of space in between. 

The waiter knew his wines and which bottle goes with which type of souffle. 
The thing to remember is this place takes time, and it's not going to change, so once you get over the fact you've been there for two hours you discuss politics, future children, life and love, order a chocolate souffle and take your lover home to get lucky.

Reservations are a must...we went on a walk-in and waited a long time for a table (we were told an hour, so we walked around and came back, but still ended up waiting) and we were eating around 10pm, but we were so charmed we didn't mind it. We had a great night together, thanks Jacqueline!
author: Nikki M.

description:
After hearing for months about Cafe Jacqueline's delightful assortment of made-to-order souffles, I finally made it out last week for my birthday dinner. In general the reviews tell all - quaint and cozy ambiance, hit-or-miss service, and expensive but delicious souffles that make it worth it all.

My boyfriend and I started with the soup du jour (a creative pairing of carrot and chestnut) and the french onion soup, healthy helpings of cheese perfectly browned on top. We then shared the lobster souffle, which at $60, was decadent and delicious. It was perfectly executed, light and fluffy, buttery with garlic, and with no shortage of lobster chunks. The waiter recommended a great bottle of Sancerre, which did a fine job of pairing with both our starter soups and our entree souffle. We finished with the grand marnier souffle and a glass of sauternes, full and satisfied. 

One of the waiters was somewhat aloof and even smug, but to the point of actually being quite amusing. The other was good fun, helpful, and attentive. For the record, I hear a lot of complaints about "French service" but both were American.

Lastly, it's hard not to mention Jacqueline, the adorable elderly chef in the kitchen who makes all these souffles to-order. Bop on back on your way to the restroom and say hello or thanks; she is appreciative and quite charming.
author: Britt M.

description:
So romantic.  So lovely.  Such wonderful starters and Souffles.  The onion soup is one of my favorites.  Many of the Frech restaurants I've been to in So Cal can't compete with Jacqueline's.  The escargot was good too so was the endive sald...but it's all about the SOUFFLES!

I loved the prosciutto souffle.  The flavor was wonderful and it wasn't overly salty as I was afraid the prosciutto might be.  

We had the white peach dessert souffle this trip - the white peaches were in season at that time and it was totally awesome.  I couldn't believe how gentle the flavor of the peach was and a bit of the powder sugar on top only added to the over flavor.  That was my favorite!!

I defintely want to try the lobster souffle next time...sounds so delicious!  This is anything but an inexpensive meal and since the place is so small...difficult to get reservation...so PLAN AHEAD!
author: Kathleen H.

description:
While in all honestly there is nothing new I can add which hasn't already been said, I had to write a review to counteract some of these bad ones. 

First off, I agree with yelpers re overuse of salt at times. I am a sucker for a good French onion soup and it does tend to be a smidgen salty here. I don't like salt, period, never use it and don't have any in my house so I am weird. And more importantly, an over salted edible screws up the taste of my wine. That said, I still order it time and time again. Why? Because it's the best. I don't care, its delicious in its caramelized overflowing deliciousness. Ditto for my fave, the corn garlic ginger soufflé. And all of the deserts are to die for- especially the strawberry soufflé. 

Secondly, I am amazed that anyone could give a negative review based on wait time! Its not McDonalds people, a French meal is is averagely timed at about an hour and a half (or something like that).  If you have a packed and scheduled night, simply plan accordingly if you are eating at Café Jacqueline, just chill and bask in the atmosphere until your magnificent treats arrive. Soufflés take time to make. Lots of time- I can say that this is one of the only restraints where I have sat for HOURS and I'm not the most patient person in the world. But like I said, that's how they do food in other parts of the world, kids- you know, in cities where dining is a social affair and people are not rushing through life so quickly they have a heart attack before they hit the age of 40. 

OK, so I agree that a few waiters here are rude beyond belief.  Which I could grasp (or simply deal with) if I was actually in Paris but ... Yes, these are some cantankerous ass waiters. Whatever, they are grumpy, I get it (or don't) but I don't care. 

If you like souffles, incredibly rich food, an excellent wine list and beautifully intimate dining experiences, you really need to eat at Cafe Jacqueline at some point in your life.
author: Dolores A.

description:
Rare find - a souffle-specialized restaurant!  My husband and I shared a wonderful chocolate souffle years back at the CIA-Greystone in St. Helena.  For multiple years and visits thereafter, we would go back and request the chocolate souffle to no avail.  My husband then secretly searched for alternative places to enjoy a generous chocolate souffle, and came across Cafe Jacqueline in San Francisco.  Much closer, and much more reliable!  He took me to Cafe Jacqueline on my birthday as a surprise, and it was quite a treat.

First of all, they serve my favorite soup, French Onion, and unusually, they prepare it without the use of beef consomme, which makes it vegetarian.  For non-vegetarians - do not fear - it is just as tasty as the non-veg version served elsewhere!  Their house bread is very soft and chewy on the inside, and crusty on the outside, and they are generous with bread.

Their entrees are all souffle's and unless specified as including a different cheese, they all contain gruyere, one of my favorite cheeses.   We shared a mushroom-gruyere souffle as our entree, which was delicious

Their desserts are all souffle's, and of course, we chose chocolate.  I was tempted to try two flavors, but maybe next time...  The chocolate flavor was strong and the sweetness was just right.

The atmosphere was quiet, with occasional classical music in the background.  From time to time, one could hear the Kitchenaid mixer/grater in the background, from the tiny kitchen at the rear of the restaurant.  The waiters were attentive, and the dinner took approximately 2-3 hours, which was very relaxing.

We had diet sodas, which were a shocking $5 each, but otherwise, we were fully satisfied by our delightful dinner.
author: Dr. M.

description:
My aunt took me here last week because it is one of her favorite restaurants in San Francisco, something that I totally agreed with after the meal.

We started the meal with French Onion Soup which was delicious. I usually do not like French Onion Soup but I LOVED it here. We then had the Spinach Salad which was good as well, but then came the best part of the meal-the chocolate souffle. Yum, yum, yum, yum, yum. So good! Who knew that eggs and chocolate could be so divine?

As for cons that other people have been saying, I did not find either to be true. Our waiter was fantastic and very friendly, as well as the rest of the staff. They do have a dry/sarcastic sense of humor which I loved. And sure the wait time is slow, but it's part of the restaurant. It's a French restaurant-slow down and just enjoy the delicious food and company you are with. 

I also enjoyed that to go to the bathroom, you had to walk through the kitchen. It was very cool to see that and say hi to Jacqueline-she's so cute(and a fabulous chef).
author: Lauren K.

description:
Service was great. Onion soup was among the best I've ever had. Asparagus and garlic souffle' with apricot for dessert. I will mention though not for the light wallet, or for those in a hurry at all....Took my girlfriend for her birthday and had planned on seeing a movie afterwards, but we got out at about 11pm. (8pm reservations)
Got to meet Jacqueline  as well, who was very sweet. Wonderful spot for a date.
author: Loren W.

description:
I had the corn & garlic souffle.  It had a huge amount of corn, which is good.  The spinach salad with bacon and pine nuts was okay but not great.  

They brought warm bread with cold butter.

The restaurant decor is cute, with fresh long-stem roses, candlelight, and good lighting.
author: Niniane W.

description:
The souffles are definitely a 5 star.  Had
*Broccoli and brie - VERY fluffy and RICH.   Almost too rich for me.  I shared this and eating half was too much.  A 1/3 would have suffice.  This is a person who LOVES cheese and can eat 2 black and tans at Fenton's with no problem. 
*Chocolate - absolutely delish!

Salads are a 3 star. Had
*Spinach with goat cheese
*Spinach with bacon and pine nuts
These salads were $10.50 each.   They were tasty with a light mustard vinaigrette.  That is the ONLY dressing available.  The spinach was a small mound. Not worth it. 

Yes, do plan to spend a long time here.  There is only one person in the back making the souffle.  You walk through the kitchen to get to the restroom.  The kitchen is very small and it's amazing how the chef can do all that by herself in such a small area.  

The waiter.... BOOO!!!!  Not helpful at all.  We told him it's our first time here and what would he recommend.  He acted as if we were bothering him and answered "Everything!"  Service was sloooooowwww.    There were only 4 people at one table and our table which had two in the entire place.  

Minus .5 star for the salad
Minus 1.5 star for the waiter.

Dinner again..... not sure, but definitely will come back for a dessert souffle!
author: Ling K.

description: If I could describe this experience with a couple words, I would say "SLOW and FILLING". By the end of the 3 hour dinner, I was literally falling asleep. Cafe Jaqueline offers Souffles, souffles, and more souffles. This is a great place to come for a romantic date. The souffles are big enough to share amoungst two people and there are many choices. There are also dessert souffles (im not a big fan of sweets but this was good). If you dont want to have a LONG dinner, an option would be to come here for dessert only.
author: Tania D.

description:
Terrible service!! I am those kind of person who expects good service from professional server so that I can enjoy my meal with my beloved ones!
We went there in one of the weekdays evening and wanted to try out their famous amazing  souffle. We seat down in a round table and ordered one souffle to share among 4 girls, (we arrived around 9ish after dinner) the waiter doesn't seem to be happy with this and he was well rude and left us the bill soon after we finish the dessert and rushed us to pay and go!!!
Ignoring their terrible service, they did have tasty  souffle there!
After one week, we invited some other female fds and would like to go back and let other fds try out their tasty  souffle, we arrived their door around 9ish and asking for 2 tables for 7 of us. The horrible waiter DID NOT EVEN LET US THROUGH THE DOOR and REFUSED TO LET US IN FOR NO REASON!!!!

We are chinese if that could be the reason that he didn't let us in, maybe he wasn't too happy for us sharing one dessert among a group of 4 girls last time...Even that is the reason, that is just so not professional out of all!
Anyways, even they did have tasty  souffle, I don't think I am going back there!!! NO MONEY FROM MY POCKET PEOPLE!!!
author: Ana F.

description: Great food. Very unique place. From what I understand there is only one " Souffle" restaurant left even in Paris. Definitely a special occasion place. Go when you have a lot of time and you are with some one that you are either romantic with or have a lot to talk about. If I go back though, it will be just for dessert!
author: Dena A.

description:
One of the best experiences in gastronomy! 
Perfect Souffles, Onion Soup, and the Salads and Bread. All lovingly hand-prepared by one person and an assistant. When she's out, she's out! Been going there since the mid-80's. I cant begin to recite the details of being the best. The correct cheese and bread in the Onion Soup, the perfect amount of lemon in the souffle, the perfect amount of oil in the salads. 
Wonderfully romantic as well. Try the Lobster (when in season), Basil and Garlic, Proscuitto and Mushroom, Lemon, Grand Marnier and Chocolate Souffles, and the Butter Lettuce and Spinach Salads. Truly an unique epicurean delight.
Summary: Heaven to the palate and senses. If there was one unique restaurant that you needed to try in SF, this is it!
author: A K Y.

description:
Went back here as part of a foursome, so we got to try more of the menu.  Glad to finally be able to try their french onion soup, which was definitely as good as the hype.  Their soup of the day, which was some sort of pureed vegetable soup was on the lighter side but also very good.

For our entrees, we got the lobster souffle and the prosciutto/mushroom souflee.  The lobster souffle was awesome and definitely worth the money.  I'm not usually big on lobster but I thoroughly enjoyed the souffle.  The prosciutto and mushroom souffle was also very good, it was nice to have a little bit of meat to go with the souffle.

For desserts, we got the chocolate (how could I not?) and strawberry, which was their fresh fruit souffle of the day.  We only got through around half of the chocolate since we were so full, but it was as good as I remember.  I didn't try the strawberry since I'm not into fruity desserts, but everyone else loved it, and actually ate more of it than the chocolate.

Their wine list is very reasonably priced, and we got 2 bottles at around $30 each.  The wines (cotes du rhone and minervois) weren't wow, but they went well with the food and were a good value.  If more places had good reasonably priced wines like this then we would never bring in our own wine.  

Still don't understand the complaints about the service.  I actually really liked the leisurely pace of dinner, so we had a chance to recover between courses.  It took a while for our soups and souffles to arrive, but we had wine, bread and good conversation to pass the time.  Definitely go here with people you don't mind spending 3+ hours with!  '

The waiter was very friendly and attentive, and we could always find him when needed.  His wine recommendations were good, and our water glasses were refilled promptly throughout the night.  After hearing us casually mention that we were there to celebrate my sister's birthday, he put a nice candle on the strawberry souffle which was a great touch.  

Glad we came back, and will definitely return again and again.
author: Arlene M.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here for the first time on a Saturday with a couple friends to celebrate a birthday.  Our reservation was at 6pm and we were seated promptly.  Cafe Jacqueline is a quaint restaurant that seats about 20-30.  Service is slow, but that is to be expected when Jacqueline is making all the souffles herself.  Yes, she really is back there making everything.... and there is a HUGE bowl of eggs back there.  I definitely went to the restroom a couple times just so I could peek into the kitchen, haha.  

We ordered a couple bottles of champagne, the escargot, two cups of onion soup, a lobster souffle, that evening's special - oyster, spinach and garlic souffle, and a strawberry souffle to share amongst four people.  Everything was wonderful!  If/when I return to Cafe Jacqueline, the only thing I would change about the evening is that I would order my own soup, entree souffle, and dessert souffle.... yeah, I don't like to share, especially not such delicious food!  All in all, it was a great night with great food, great service, and great company.  The only part where they were not on their A game was with timing.  I understand that food service is slow, however they took way too long to give us the check... like it felt like we had been sitting at the table for 25 minutes after everything had been cleared and even amongst good friends it got a little awkward...haha.
author: Jaclyn L.

description: Simply put, the food is divine!  Had both a savory and dessert souffle, and they were both extraordinary.  While awaiting the preparation of the entree, we shared a bowl of French Onion soup--it was delicious!  The lime souffle alone will keep me coming back. Cozy atmosphere, and great service as well.
author: Laura P.

description:
Ok this rating is simply based on the service (because the white chocolate souffle was tasty)

Came here for my birthday and was seated right away. The server didnt actually take our order for about 10 minutes after we sat though. That should have been the first red flag. So after waiting another 10 minutes our wine came out. Another 20, 40, 60 minutes go by and still no souffle!! The server Never once came by our table to tell us anything!! No "im sorry for the wait" No "it'll be just a few more minutes" nothing! I had to go back toward the kitchen just to get someones attention and was told it was coming out 'now'. 10 minutes later the dessert came out... 
at that point we should have walked out because it really should not take over an hour and a half to bring one item. (Meanwhile ALL the other tables got their desserts including the tables sat after us) 
Once the souffle was brought the server was incredibly rude not apologetic at all...
I will never return to Cafe Jacqueline! Very sad the service was this awful =(  crappy way to end my birthday
author: Natasha I.

description: The souffels were fantastic and cooked to perfection. We had proscutto and mushroom souffel for entree, endives & Roquefort salad, and chocolate souffel for dessert. Big portions but you do have to wait, so pace yourself.
author: Z K.

description: Now I get it...This is a RACIST establishment! I couldn't understand why the moment we walked into this place we were treated so rudely? Now as I look over the reviews it clearly shows that every Asian that's ever walked into this place has nothing good to say about it. Everyone else raves about the place yet everytime I walk pass it's always empty. The night we went we walked in they asked if we had a reservation? No, but the place was empty. Every other restaurant was packed! Anyway, after ten minutes of dealing with rudeness we walked out. There are too many good restaurants in San Francisco...don't believe the hype. Bunch of a-holes. Btw, I didn't want to give them a one star rating but I had no choice. You however do have one...pass on this place.
author: Rupert L.

description:
It's all been said. Bottom line - amazing souffle.  Service - our initial greeting from the first waiter - he was a jerk.  Smug, sarcastic and rude.  Thank goodness for the second waiter who was at least cordial and nice.

I will have to say,  that I won't be able to order souffle from anywhere else again without comparing!
author: Heidi M.

description:
For my birthday, my friend made reservations (definitely recommended to make reservations as this is a small place) for a party of two. We were seated promptly in a quiet and intimate dining room with soft classical music playing in the background. The ambiance of this restaurant was definitely romantic. Every table was set-up with a single rose and a candle. 

Cafe Jacqueline is unique because they exclusively serve souffles. I was surprised when I found out this place made souffles as an entree, since I've only had souffles for dessert. The souffles are huge and is designed to be shared by two people. The dessert souffles are a bit larger, it can be shared by four to six people. For the dessert, I decided to go with the Strawberry Souffle since Chocolate is so original. Wow! It was yummy. The only thing I would complain about is the wait for the souffle...but it was definitely worth it.
author: Candice H.

description:
I have been here a few times now, and every single time it is SO GOOD!  I am never disappointed.  It really is an event to go here because fluffy souffles take time, so make sure you have said time when you go, and want to be with the person you are dining with for a while.

I was just here I believe, 2 weeks ago.   We got the onion soup, which was great.  Then I sort of got overzealous and ordered the proscuitto AND the salmon/ asparagus souffles!  I think the salmon is my new favorite- very tasty- I love you proscuitto, but..eh-  (We definitely had leftovers- one souffle would have sufficed.)  Then the grand mariner souffle for dessert- which is so fantastically good-  yummy melty in your mouth- I need to learn how to make these...been looking up recipes online and everything..

Anyway- for those of you contemplating going here for the first time, I say do it- it is worth the expense, especially if you like your dining mate, and want a leisurely not-so- typical experience.
author: Lisa M.

description:
These souffles are larger than my head.  3 of us at dinner there.  I did ask for not the table by the door and guess what, we got the table by the door.  Service, well, it's French.  

We had 2 watercress salads + one onion soup to start with.  Very fresh watercress.  Then we shared the lobster souffle (fluffy, cheesy, couldn't ask for more).  I think it was at least an hour between the lobster souffle and the chocolate souffle.  

Very affordable wines by the bottle.  The Muscadet was pleasantly floral and light.  Only $25 a bottle.  

Overall, very fun place to catch up with your friends and to fill your egg quota for the month.
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
I remember this place serving great food from my last trip here. I was walking by with my fiance tonight and even though we had already had dinner, decided to go in to have dessert. We were seated and handed menus. The cheapest dessert option was $33 for a fruit souffle.  We didn't feel obliged to spend that much on just dessert. So we asked for Earl Grey teas, at that point the waiter with the waxed Picasso mustache asked is to leave because "we are not a coffee or tea kind of place."
We will not be back.....it's a pity that the service staff needs to be so rude.
author: Amelia M.

description:
This restaurant is almost hidden on the street. I walked right by it and had to turn around at the end of the block. So I paced back and I knew I was near Cafe Jacqueline because I could smell the souffles! So, I stopped in the door and took note of the quaint and cutely decorated interior. It's very small, with a beautiful chandelier and decorated with a Frenchy theme.  

Since we were a party of four, we ordered two souffles and ended up ordering the specials: chanterelle mushrooms and garlic for the first and leek and chestnut for the second. Their souffles definitely feed two. They also took our dessert order, which we ordered the strawberry souffle...

To begin with, we had then french onion soup, which was delicious. It was all that and more. It had oozing cheese, bread, oils and yummy onions. I'm a big french onion soup lover and this hit the spot.

Our two souffles came and unfortunately was that I found them to be good, but too salty for my taste. I can take salt, but I felt it was a little on the heavy side. My friend Karen said it was just right for her though... Of the two, I preferred the leek and chestnuts.  The chanterelle was good, but more salty than the leek.

The absolute best part by far, and I would actually just come here for it, was the dessert. While pricey ($30+) the strawberry souffle was heavenly. The cake inside was delicious, the strawberries were fresh and it just melted in your mouth. The desserts get 5+ stars. Actually 10 stars if I could. Desserts are a MUST. They also have a grand marnier dessert... and I can only imagine how that will taste.
author: Natalie S.

description:
Like many have mentioned, the onion soup was delicious but extremely salty. 

I went there with my bf and we shared the crab souffle. Like the onion soup, it was extremely salty as well. We couldn't even finish it because it was THAT salty. It was interesting and different, but I don't think we'll be getting this again.

The thing that makes this place a 4-star is their Chocolate Souffle. Absolutely delicious! So fluffy and moist inside...we both loved it! 

Be aware...the serving size for their souffles are very big, we were stuffed just by having a bowl of soup each and sharing 1 crab souffle and 1 chocolate souffle.
author: Hui Nee C.

description: I've been visiting Jacqueline for over 30 years. She is wonderful and dinning here in itself is a very special occasionl. The soufflés are stellar and the atmosphere is warm.  A real San Francisco experience not to be missed.
author: Christopher S.

description: The best chocolate soufflé! A little price, but worth! Come for a dessert!
author: Erica A.

description:
I definitely enjoyed my experience here.  We split the onion soup, leek souffle and white chocolate souffle between 2 people.  The (French, duh) onion soup was fantastic; easily the best I've ever had.  The leek souffle was simple and cheesy and tasty.  The soup and entree souffle were somewhat salty but not excessively so.  At this point we were wondering if we should have ordered more food.  This notion was instantly shot down once we saw the size of the white chocolate souffle.  It was a bit bigger than the leek souffle and quite rich.  It was really enjoyable but I thought it lacked in the white chocolate department.  I would go with the fruit souffle next time (though the highly praised strawberry wasn't available).  We also had a bottle of Côtes du Rhône that was reasonably priced.

I thought the service was really good.  Our server was pleasant and helpful.  I just wanted to mention this since so many people seem to be dogging on the European-style service employed at CJ.  Its slow and not overly attentive, which can be a tough adjustment for those who prefer the service at Applebee's, and lends to a more intimate feel.  Our dinner lasted a pleasant 2.5 hours.  

Overall:  CJ was really good but the food (which is not cheap) didn't quite have what it took to reach 5 stars.  I rate it at 4.5 stars.  Save room for dessert!
author: Chris P.

description: Matt, The guy with moustache is 'gentle with gentle people' as they say!    Food great!   Souflait master at work.,.
author: Robert C.

description: My daughter wanted to visit this place for 5 years.  I had no idea what to expect and I was as pleased with the meal as I could possibly be.  The wait staff were excellent.  The food was spectacular.  I am so happy we were able to share a lovely meal at Cafe Jacqueline!  I have since recommended this restaurant to at least 6 friends.
author: Patricia B.

description:
Ignore those that moan about the prices and that this restaurant is over rated. If you are a foodie with a love for time honoured tradition, if you appreciate the art of souffle making (oh and it is an art!), if you appreciate perfection of flavour and are prepared to accept that $35-$40 (split between two) is not just about food, but an experience then don't think - just book and embrace the atmosphere and experience of Cafe Jacqueline.

The restaurant is just as people describe: simple in it's elegance, romanticly lit by candlelit, cosy, warm, welcoming and feels distinctly French. Appetizers range upto $25.00, the main souffles from $30-$45 and the desserts $30-$40. Whilst you might balk at the prices, please don't! If you are all about the experience as well as taste of souffle, then avoid the appetizers and simply go for one savoury and one dessert (the dishes are made for two) - you will be full after both and if you appreciate the art of this food, you will feel entirely satisfied with what you have paid on leaving.

We chose a delicious Pouille-Foussy white wine ($45) to go with our mouth wateringly, heavenly, hallelujah-worthy main course special: a sumptious leek & chestnut souffle. Through our suprised and in awe smiles, the stifled moans of food-ecstasy, we savoured every mouthful until I actually felt sad to see just one last mouthful left. There is something poetic about Jacquelines souffles. Something sacred!

With time to relax, take it all in pre and post our main course (expect anywhere from a 2-3hour meal - these are made by one person, all to order remember), with more sips of our perfectly matched wine, out came the Lemon Souffle delivered by our waiter who i just loved - apparently the 'mean one'  (now my favourite meanie!) We promptly devoured the lemony, sweet, fluffy perfection and can only conclude it as a triumphant balance to the previous course.

I totally and utterly love this restaurant. It is worth every penny as far as quality, experience, happiness and taste sensation goes. My favourite part was when I nipped to the ladies, through the Kitchen, I was able to thank and watch the legend that is Jacquline at her clearly loved work. After telling her the taste was like magic to me, I asked her 'how do you make them so light & fluffy'. And with a twinkle in her eye, she just replied in her gorgeous French accent 'one at a time!'.

Go forth & find foodie heaven and make sure you get the 'mean' waiter. And remember, restaurants such as Jacequline come packed with personality so I say this: don't think too much, I'm sure every night is different, just smile and go with the flow and it'll be hard not to get carried away by the whole experience...
author: Emily C.

description:
i've been dying to try this restaurant for soo many months, and finally got to last night!  read so many good things about the lobster souffle.  unfortunately, when we got there, the waiter told us that c. jacqueline couldn't buy any lobster OR crab for the day because nothing looked good.  very very disappointed, but he did suggest to call ahead next time to make sure they have the lobster for that day :)

so the bf and i each had a french onion soup (we both loved it, but i can see why some think it's on the saltier side).  and then we shared a fruits de mar (seafood) souffle which was really really good.  we were stuffed at the end of the meal, so no room for dessert!  but we saw different tables ordering the chocolate / strawberry souffles... will have to come back next time for those!  

seems like there are quite a few regulars that come to this restaurant... i definitely like the small coziness atmosphere of the restaurant!

the waiter was pretty funny too.  haha.  great overall dining experience!
author: Cal C.

description:
You gonna wonder, what's with this dude?  5 stars?  One of the main reason I rated this 5 stars is to create an urgency.  

We've been coming here for many years, Jacqueline makes all the souffle' fresh and herself.  She is old and I think she will be retiring soon.  There hasn't been another place that I can taste souffle' like this ever.  I gotta take my kids here before she retired.

We came here after having dinner at Silk at Mandarin Oriental.  So purely for dessert.  I would love to try the entree' souffle' and french onion soup but it was too late and too full.  

We ordered the strawberry souffle' but I remember last time I loved the chocolate souffle'  Either way, it was as good as it gets.  Fresh foamy souffle with rich flavor that melts in your mouth...  If money is an issue, go to Trader's Joe and get one of the frozen one.  But if you want to try a unique serving of delicious souffle', call and make a reservation at Cafe' Jacqueline.  

Cons:  Prety long wait.  She makes them fresh, so it takes time.  

"Take a step, never look back and regret"  Do it before she retires.
author: Mark L.

description:
This is a fantastic place to surprise a loved one with, but keep the following important info in mind ::

Souffles take 30 - 40 mins to cook, sometimes longer depending on how busy they are. So if you're looking for in & out service, or if you've had a long day, this is not the place to go. You will get antsy, you will get irritated, you will not love it.

HOWEVER, if you're cool with lingering over a bottle of champagne (or two) and devouring some delicious souffle, then you are in good hands.

I personally think this spot is best enjoyed for desert only.  Just let them know you are making a desert reservation when you call.  A complete meal here can drag a bit, even for the most romantic couple.  Although I must say, the lobster and crab souffles are ridiculous **drool**

Be sure to peep the kitchen on your way to the restroom, for a glimpse of miss J. herself. 

Oh and yes, it's true - the waiters, one in particular, can be a real drag, so plan on ignoring their less than stellar attitudes. I recommend ordering a bottle to your table ASAP (do not doddle on your bev'y order, you will regret it), focus on your date, sip your bubbly and enjoy.

Oh, and another thing - I have only dined here as a table for 2, but the 4-tops I observed looked to be having a fabulous time tasting each others souffles. Double date!
author: miss L.

description:
"Eating a souffle should be like walking into a cloud." -- Google

Thank you for the many things I learned from you, Google, while dining at Cafe Jacqueline because our one main course and one dessert took *two* hours to serve. That seems to be the math here: for *n* courses ordered, prepared to seat your tushy in that adorable vintage-looking wooden chair for *n* hours while rolling your eyes at your dinner companion. 

Luckily for Cafe Jacqueline, this is the most cloud-like, absolutely marvelous chocolate souffle I have ever dreamed of tasting. It's like eating air in a Willy Wonka factory. 

Definitely take a date here for dessert after 9 pm, when the first and only seating of customers are starting to leave. 

Skip having dinner here. I liked the white corn/garlic/ginger/gruyere souffle, but it was more like hiking on a little hill than walking in the clouds. Plus, your iPhone battery will die from the continued 2-3 hours of usage.
author: Gloria L.

description:
Review only for the Chocolate Souffle
I was a bit taken back by the price, although the place has 4 money signs. $32 for a chocolate souffle? Holy!
The souffle took about 25-30 minutes to bake; a tip, call in advance a place the order. The size of the souffle was overwhelming! It was HUGE!
The souffle was light and airy, but It was missing the ooey gooeyness from typical souffles. 
Overall, great souffle, but not what I'm used to.
author: Christina P.

description: Such a great place.  Delicious food and an attentive wait staff.  Great location in North Beach and Jacqueline is charming.  I can't wait to go back.
author: blake w.

description: BEST souffle I have ever had.  My boyfriend and I were in town on business and discovered this place two nights before we left.  I wish we would have known about it sooner as we would have gone back for more.  The waiters were great, very friendly and outgoing.  We went in the kitchen to compliment Jacqueline and she was a doll!  What talent she has.  This will be our first stop the next time we are in San Fran.
author: Rae G.

description:
The actual star count is 2.5.  (My friend and I are splitting a review)  So we came here to try their crab souffle, which was on 7x7 Big Eats SF List.  The results?  *drum roll*  

Someone at 7x7 got paid off!  Seriously, there's no way throwing crab bits inside burnt cheese and overcooked mushy stuff in a fire marshall's SRO nightmare for $55 with a side of no AC and attitude from the server would've made anyone's non-casting couch list!  The menu has some appetizers that you won't bother to write home about, dinner souffles for approx. $50, and dessert souffles for approx. $30.  The saving grace is that 1 souffle serves 2.  Also, maybe if you go early enough, your souffle won't be burnt?  (I'm assuming zero AC and an overheated oven were the partners in crime for our dish.)

We decided on the extra 0.5 because the off-hospital green wall decor was actually very cute and quaint.
author: Caitlyn K.

description: French onion soup was better than in Paris.  Gruyere souffle was light, airy and flavorful.  Chocolate souffle was fantastic!  When in San Francisco, make a reservation for dinner.  You won't regret it.
author: Upset P.

description: AMAZING white chocolate souffle. Probably the best I've ever had, actually. The only gripe I have is that they can be rude and disrespectful of people's time. When you take a reservation for a particular time, you don't tell them to wait for 30 minutes or so.
author: Sylvie T.

description: Just finished eating dinner here and it was delicious! I went with my daughter and we ordered the onion soup, shiitake spinach and basil soufflé for dinner and the chocolate one for dessert. A lot of food so we brought home leftovers and plan to eat them for breakfast tomorrow. The waiters were all attentive and very friendly - great service. A bit pricey but definitely worth it!
author: Roxanne P.

description:
Cafe Jacqueline is in a class of its own.   Yes, you must have a souffle.  Or two.

I ate here sometime in the mid-1980s and came back for the first time two weeks ago.  It is exactly the same.  

I came alone one quiet weeknight with no reservation.   I was courteously seated immediately.  The waitstaff are professional and very big city.....those whose Yelp reviews have expressed frustration with their "unfriendliness" are, I think, misguided.  This is the classic old style of how to wait on customers....unobtrusive to the extreme.  But quite attentive to service.  I appreciated and needed the crumb brush after devouring French bread.

I had a bottle of a white Bordeaux, cucumber salad, and the Gruyere souffle.  A friend joined me to finish the souffle and the wine.

This restaurant is marvelous, exceptional, and to be savored.  Slow down when you come here.  Because when you order your souffle, you will wait until Jacqueline herself makes it....with the care and attention a souffle needs and deserves.   In the meantime, have a salad, some wine, and enjoy the calm green room, your companion(s), and the other diners.

This time I didn't have room for a dessert souffle...but the next time I am in SF it shall be my fate.
author: Jim B.

description:
It's good souffles, but yes, it's quite overpriced. 

Get dinner elsewhere and come here for a spendy dessert.

I dont know WHY people think that's just cause it's French that they can smack you with an overpriced bill. I've made fluffymoist souffles and it takes attention to details, but it's no trickier than balancing a good fishsauce dressing or getting an eggplant basil stirfry to keep it's skin color and having the flesh turn silky/luscious (Sorry, I'm on my Lers Ros craving again).

Souffles arent really that great for savory flavors... it feels a little... gimmicky. Where as say, a savory crepe/gallette is amazing if not preferrable to sweet desert crepe, salty (and at times a lil too salty) souffles feel like you're eating an oversized amuse/appitizer, and actually, at Jacqueline's, it's not that oversized... Speaking of which: salad prices are a little ridiculous. The oil is really good (how did you get that umami flavor in there... omg- it's warm SALTED isnt it?!), but for 10bux, can it separate itself with some tomatoes before slathering itself of that childhand portion of watercress (and I love my watercress!), but really, greens and oil?

Service is appropriate but the attitude is kinda not.

This place something close to an institution here in SF, but it's really more like a relic. It would take me alot to venture inside the douchebag triangle, and Jacqueline: I'm just not that into you.
author: Jonas D.

description:
As that kid says in Despicable me, "IT'S SO FLUFFY!!!"

These souffles are effin' huge.  I knew I wanted dessert off the bat, so we split one savory (prosciutto and mushroom) which was rich and filling.  And then, the chocolate souffle...if you love chocolate this was soo good.  Seemed like we had to wait a while for the chocolate souffle, but it was worth it. I don't think I'd had anything like this before.  Warm, fluffy, delicious...chocolate!!!

Like others mentioned, this is a very french place.  So set aside time--your dinner will take 2 hrs.  The interior is tiny, quaint, homey and cute.  It's like stepping into a restaurant in a small town in france.
author: Caroline I.

description:
Easily one of the best meals I've ever had.  Two visits over a monthlong stay.  Waiters are seasoned veterans and wonderful.  Even if you don't need to go, request a trip to the bathroom;  that will require you to pass through the kitchen so you can see Mademoiselle Jacqueline in action.

The menu, like the room, is simple, elegant, non-fussy.  The souffles are spot-on perfection.  This onion soup is nothing like what you may have had before.  The chocolate souffle is pure evil.

A perfect romantic date destination if ever there was one.
author: Muffy F.

description: So originally I would have given this place 3 stars based on the chocolate souffle alone. It took way too long for our one souffle to come out and after all the hype from what I expected after watching The Best Thing I Ever Ate (chocolate episode), I was indeed disappointed. It was good, but not AMAZING, and definitely not worth the price or the time it took us to get it. My boyfriend and I headed out and when we were about two blocks down,  our waiter Scott came running out to flag us down so that he could return my measly looking but personally significant necklace that any other waiter, I'm sure, would easily have thrown out. I had carelessly left it on the table at the restaurant but he chased us down and because of his incredibly thoughtful gesture, Cafe Jacqueline definitely has my vote :) Thanks Scott!!
author: Shira C.

description:
I am going to keep to the point. The most perfectly special romantic restaurant in San Francisco!

Over the past 10 years my husband and I have been to Jacqueline about 10 times. (One of our first dates that many years ago!) After our wonderful pre-Valentines Day dinner as newlyweds, this past Saturday, we are committed to going at least 3 times a year! (I mean, for the price, why not?!) Not to mention the more than kind and wonderful waitstaff, the pleasure of  a leisurely 3 hour meal, the excellent wine list, low corkage fee and the cozy atmosphere.

We are always recognized and treated warmly from the moment we walk in. The salads and souffle's are extraordinary and never disappoint and the lovely Jacqueline ever so sweetly bids us adieu when we are finally (gently) nudged to leave a place that feels like home.
author: J d.

description: I came here with my family for dinner. I loved the cozy atmosphere. We ordered and shared the leek. brie and broccoli, prosciutto and mushroom souffles. We also had the French onion soup yummy. The strawberry and chocolate souffles were great. The waitstaff were friendly and helpful. Everything was really good. The souffles were quite expensive so if I came back I'd only get the soup and a dessert souffle.  Definitely worth a trip and wonderful to celebrate a very special occasion.
author: K A.

description:
Amazing food , but BAD Service. 
the Waiter with glasses gave us a SHIT face, and took away our dishes even though we were not done yet ! it was the first time i bought my friends there, i was expected to surprise my friends. but it turn out to the other way. when we ask the waiter for suggestions, he silenced and gave me a bad attitude that he wanted to work off on time and we better hurry and not wasted any his time in taking order. the souffle was Delicious ...but i really had a hard time to enjoy the food when the server with a such BAD attitude. 

for the next time,i rather bring my friends/dates to Fleur De Lys...
author: Wyman L.

description:
Ah oui... L'amore. And what says love more than creamy, savory or sweet soufflés? I imagine cupid would compare love to soufflés in that a soufflé does not wait for you, but you wait for the soufflé.

And such is the case at the charming and oh-so-romantic Café Jacqueline. Each course takes an hour or so to be cracked, whisked, risen and served. All the better to languidly stare across tables into candlelit eyes and wine dappled lips.

The charm extends beyond the rosy dining area into a kitchen swimming in eggs. Here Jacqueline herself smiles and wishes you a fair "Bonsoir."

Our salad was delicate with a savory vinaigrette. The crab soufflé was a tad overdone, but utterly buttery with chunks of juicy, decadent crab.
For dessert the classic chocolate soufflé offered endless delight.

Unfortunately service stole Café Jacqueline's last star. We were greeted with a trite "Pick a seat, here here or here" before the waiter disappeared. And the rest of the evening service remained sporadic and disoriented - the worst being when the waiter freaked out when he thought he'd given us a lobster rather than crab soufflé.
author: Brady K.

description:
I came here for my birthday last year. We almost missed it when trying to locate the restaurant.  The place is small and intimate, nice atmosphere. 

We ordered a salad, a savory souffle, and the chocolate souffle as dessert.  They are HUGE, we (2 ppl) could not finish everything. Warning: if you don't like having only one flavor/taste for the entire meal, this is not a place for you, unless you come here with several people to share several flavors.  The savory souffle was very rich.  The chocolate souffle was very delicious.

The service was very, very, very slow.  There was a very long wait before the savory souffle, and then another long wait before the dessert.
author: Ling Ling Z.

description: This was a GREAT tasting experience and a wonderful cozy ambiance.  Jacqueline is the cute little 'grandmaman' chef lady in the back making all the Soufflés. We had only had sweet dessert soufflés up until this point, but we definitely have to come back here and try some other savory soufflés again... and of course, the other sweet dessert soufflés.   We had the onion soup, which was very tasty. The bread was just out of this world. We kept asking for more and more of it. We love french baguettes/breads and this is one of the best ones around. Hot and soft on the inside, but crispy on the outside.  My wife and I had a number of choices we wanted to try but because the soufflés are so large, we shared one. We ended up with the Mushroom soufflé which did not disappoint.   We had the traditional chocolate soufflé and that was amazing as well.  We are looking forward to going back and trying another from the list of savory and sweet dessert soufflés  (and of course, the bread).  If you have a chance, walk back to the restroom and walk by the kitchen and watch the sweet grand maman looking Jacqueline preparing and making all the soufflés.  She will say hi, but she was shy to pose for a picture citing that she was too busy making soufflés. She was extremely polite and nice about it.  Again, we have to go back and try the other soufflés.
author: Andy W.

description:
2 words: souffle galore! I really like the concept of this restaraunt, but in the end my BF & I only really liked the french onion soup & the dessert (strawberry souffle). Unfortunately, our main entree was disappointing. We got the lobster souffle, which turned out to be more salty.

All in all, this is a very cute, intimate place. If it wasn't so pricey I would totally come back and give it a second chance.
author: Krystel M.

description:
I'm so bummed that with all the 5-star reviews, we didn't have a similar experience. We arrived right on time for an 8pm reservation and were given menus immediately, though no one returned to share specials, take drink orders etc, for a while (I didn't check the time though and didn't let it bother me at that point). The waiter finally came over, explained what they had that evening and literally walked away as I asked a question --and apparently didn't hear me as he didn't come back. We waited and waited and he finally returned to take our food order, then said he'd be back for drinks, which I get, it's souffles, so they want to get them in the oven. The drinks came fairly quickly and my glass of champagne was filled to the brim, definitely a plus! My husband had a half-bottle of wine which was poured only one time by the waiter, not a huge deal, but overall, service was seriously lacking. I joked when we got home that I would be more tolerant of the nonchalant, arrogant service from French waiters, but from what I could tell, ours was not French.

So my husband thought they forgot our salads, but they finally came out at 9pm on the dot, again, we arrived at 8pm. The salads (spinach with goat cheese and spinach with pine nuts and bacon) were both really good. Bread was a bit too crusty/crispy for my taste. Salads were done within minutes, and then we waited, waited, looked back at the kitchen. The waiter never came to mention anything about our food. I know a few things about souffles and by no means expect them to be rushed but our dinner souffle didn't arrive until 9:45pm, again, with no check-in from the waiter. At that point I said we'd probably need to cancel our dessert order as we had a babysitter and at this rate, we wouldn't be home before midnight. He said he could cancel it, but I really wanted the dessert souffle so asked how long it would be and he said 'at least 45 minutes'. So for a 3-course meal, including 2 souffles, it would have been AT LEAST a 3-hour dinner. Our dinner at Saison was 3 hours and I think it was 17 courses...

The waiter sort-of apologized, saying something like 'I'm sorry about the time issue and that you won't be able to try our dessert souffle. We hope you'll come back to try another time.'

We were so looking forward to trying this place but to be honest, are more into sweet souffles versus savory so it was a huge letdown to leave without trying the chocolate souffle. I have to imagine an oven was broken or something but a little explanation goes a long way. My husband even said 'that's the worst service we've had in San Francisco'. We try a new restaurant (of similar quality) every Thursday and have eaten at a range of good, and great restaurants around that city and this experience was pretty disappointing. So why even 3 stars? What we did have was good, the salads and the lobster souffle. Too bad about the rest.
author: Lauren M.

description:
Overall, the soufflés were really good!  We ordered three savory soufflés and one sweet.  My favorite of the savory was the Prosciutto mushroom.  The leek soufflé was slightly boring and disappointing.  The third I can't even remember, so it must have not have been that great.

The dessert soufflé was awesome!  Light, fluffy, and not overly sweet.  

I would go back just for the Prosciutto and dessert soufflés.  

Overall, quite pricey though of great quality.  Ah, and you gotta love the snooty French waiter in this tiny quaint restaurant.  Reviews were mixed on the guy.  I am big on service, but I think he was just oblivious.  Kinda blended with the atmosphere and expectation of the French.  Was that bad I said that?  :)
author: Yeelo N.

description:
Definitely Romantic

Sitting with my back faced to Grant and looking in at the cute little restaurant, I felt like I was in France.  Jacqueline, this cute little lady, is in the small kitchen in the back creating this soft fluffy aroma that made me so excited for the food to come.  It was almost a four hour meal so they do leave you waiting and wanting.  I didn't mind the wait at all since the bread they offered was one of the best baguettes I've ever had.  It was super crunchy on the outside and warm, moist and fluffy on the inside.

We ordered a bottle of wine, French onion soup, special soufflé of the day (oysters and spinach, JACKPOT!!) and a strawberry soufflé for dessert.     

The onion soup, wow wow WOW!!  Best onion soup ever!  The soup was perfectly flavored and perfectly cheesy.  One was enough to share for two but if I were to come again, I'd get my own!

I don't know if I'm much of a soufflé person, but this soufflé was made for me.  The soufflé was topped with a tons of thin slices of lemon which giving the zest I always need with my oysters.  I love trying things I've never tastes before and this was a very enjoyable experience.  The dessert soufflé was a bit much for me, it had pretty much the same texture as my oyster entry so it was a bit odd.  It's like going straight from a beef burger to a chocolate covered strawberry burger.  Maybe next time I would stop in for a soup and dessert only :)
author: hanh b.

description: One word for this place ! Rude service!  Wanted to get dessert only and a waiter told us it will take an hour and fifteen minutes although they were open tables. Of course all this happened outside the restaurant with the door almost closed with a table so we never went inside. Recommendation: Make reservation and go early!
author: Alex D.

description:
This is going to be a short review as it seems most people agree on these things:

Souffle - PHENOMENAL
Service - sucks!

That's the bottom line, are you willing to sit through the crappy service and long wait for food?  For me is yes.  But if they had better waiters, 5*s!!!!
author: R L.

description:
Most romantic restaurant in SF, hands down.  The lighting is perfect, the aroma of butter and sugar are amazing.  Jacqueline in the kitchen is super gifted with her talents of making the best souffle...in the world.  (The only rival in SF is Gary Danko's Chocolate souffle with the 2 sauces).  

My most ideal meal there would be Onion soup, then a salad, then the white chocolate Souffle, followed by the fresh Strawberry souffle.

YUM
author: Lesley H.

description:
Just stopped by to have a dessert souffle and some wine on a beautifully sunny San Francisco day. We had the fruit of the day - white peach - and it was delicious, but expensive. It looked big, but it is really light and fluffy so I didn't walk away feeling sick. The waiter was really nice. Next time I'm going to have to try the chocolate. 

This place has like 100 american express stickers on the door. I wonder what's up with that...
author: Tim C.

description:
Cutest restaurant ever.  I went with a couple of friends, and we split the corn and ginger savory souffle, and then had the Grand Marnier dessert souffle.  Both were delicious, and I cannot wait to go back again.  

If you go, definitely make sure you walk to the back to use the bathroom, because then you will see cute little Jacqueline doing her thing in the kitchen.  My only wish is that we got two dessert souffles, so I could get more tastes. 

And, yes, to be fair, I have never met a French Onion soup I did not like.  But the one served here is literally perfect.  Literally.

ADDITIONAL NOTE:  After writing my initial review, I went through and read what some of the other posters wrote.  Listen, I totally get it if you think the prices are high.  However, there really is a cute little lady in the back whipping up these babies by herself.  Sure, I can go out and give the same amount of money to tons of other dining establishments in SF, but does Michael Mina or other large restauranteurs really need more of my money?  This money is going to her and her staff, and when you think about helping the local economy, and how much love she puts into those perfectly done souffles, I can't think of another place I'd rather be dining.
author: Julie B.

description: Cafe Jacqueline is wonderful.  Service is friendly and unhurried and the souffles are great.  It is a great place to linger over a wonderful dinner.  Start with the onion soup and any of the savory souffles -- but save room for a chocolate souffle!  My favorite special occasion restaurant in S.F.
author: Deb W.

description:
Worth the wait!
Went there recently for my husbands birthday.  Seated immediately by friendly, helpful staff.  Had to wait about 40mins for our starter (soup) - that was delicious, then more wait for our main (seafood souffle) but it was FANTASTIC.  We'll definately be going there again!
author: Beekay M.

description:
Definitely a San Francisco classic, Cafe Jacqueline has quietly been going about its business for almost thirty years, developing a steady and loyal following. And last night, I joined that growing legion. 

We made reservations (recommended) for a party of four and were seated promptly in the quiet and intimate dining room, soft classical music the only background. I had brought a bottle of Mumm de Cramant, which our server promptly chilled for us (there is a $20 corkage fee, but well worth it with the right bottle!). 

The menu is of course focused on souffles and I'd recommend going for the full experience. For us that meant splitting a fresh salad and the escargot starter - on the latter, all I can say is wow, I don't think I've had better. The savory souffles are meant for two, so we ordered two to share, and the prosciutto and mushroom was particularly tasty. For dessert, we again chose to split two, which at first seemed like overkill. However, just being able to taste the flavorful contrast between the chocolate and the fresh strawberry souffle was reason enough, and we actually ended up pretty much finishing up both anyway. 

I don't know how Chef Jacqueline does it, but obviously she's doing it right. She's a sweet woman herself, working every night, clearly in love in front of a stove. Go to the bathroom - which you get to through the kitchen - just to say hello, and mind the step!

Perfect, as other reviewers have said, for a romantic evening, but I think just as good if not better with a close group of 4-6 friends. Our servers were great, but expect a long meal, this is not a rushed experience. If you get there early like I did, some of the stores on Grant stay open late so you can browse and shop before eating. Just like Paris!
author: Nish N.

description:
After hearing so many positive experiences here because of the great food, ambiance, and it being so romantic, I decided to try this restaurant on Valentines Day. My expectations were high because of the all the great comments I have heard and seen, and because of the $100/person Valentines Day prix fix menu. And I also canceled another reservation I had already, at Chaya. Here is what I had: 

Course 1 - Stuffed Mushrooms - Dry and bland. 

Course 2 - French Onion Soup - Excellent! Pipping hot, extra cheesy top, and full of great onion flavor. 

Course 3 - Lobster Souffle - Lots of succulent lobster pieces, extremely moist souffle, and great contrast with the lemons on top. 

Course 4 - Salad - Good, nothing special. 

Course 5 - Gran Marnier Souffle - Really tasty and great flavor. 

Service was just very average. Waiter wasn't helpful when I asked him for his opinion on the menu. He just said everything tastes good. I also brought my own bottle of wine, and I had to refill my date's glass as well as my own the whole night. I really didn't like paying the $20 bottle charge after that. 

Jacqueline does have a romantic feel to it and its a great place to bring a date. I just wouldn't go there again on Valentines Day, or bring my own bottle of wine again next time I come.
author: Allen L.

description:
Yep. Hardcore romantic date spot. Use with caution.  I went with a friend and realized that we were the only ones not on a date. I tried to stare lovingly into my dinner companion's eyes, but I don't think we had anyone convinced. 

Due to the romantic ambiance of the place, I think I was the only person in the room not getting laid later on that night.

But who needs nookie when the souffle is already so mind-blowing? (for my sake, don't answer that.)
author: Umami Y.

description:
The food definitely deserves 5 starts, we had the roquefort soufle which was amazing. For the desert we had the strawberry soufle and OMG! It is just delicious. All of that with a bottle of Veuve Cliquot. 
Jacqueline, felicitations!
The only reason why I'm giving 4 stars is because the service was a bit slow.
But it still was a wonderful experience, I'm definitely coming back.
author: Paula L.

description:
This place is nothing less than heavenly. It's wonderfully romantic, quaint, and very French. It's also a serious time commitment, seeing as how all the souffles are made to order (45-60min avg). 

The reviewers who gave this place a one star review are idiots. I've been here several times and never once experienced a bad dish, bad service or anything else that would taint my opinion of Cafe Jaqueline.

It's best suited for a special occasion when you and your lover want to have an out of the ordinary dining experience. 

The onion soup is great, and really any souffle that you have will certainly be one of the best you've ever had. I'm a chef....trust me on this.

All in all, you can't go wrong here. If you've got the time, and the cash, this is the place to take your girlfriend, boyfriend, husband or wife. You won't regret it.
author: Aaron S.

description:
So this place isn't a first date place, not because it's not cute in an unassuming way - it is - but because you better plan on spending 3.5 hours sitting there.  If the conversation isn't already lively between the two of you, it's going to a painful wait for those fluffed souffles.  

Actually, while I had a splendid time there with one dinner companion, I would recommend going there with a larger group - say 4 people because each souffle is HUGE.  No really, HUGE..  That way, you can try more different souffles - yeah, I'm pretty sure they're ALL fantastic.  We had the corn, garlic and ginger dinner souffle - which was really the perfect souffle texture, if a little creatively flavored.  That, and with 4 people, you could potentially get 1 dinner souffle and 2 dessert souffles.  Oh the glory goodness of our chocolate souffle.  It was like Jacqueline's gentle, warm, and sweet "bon soir" as I passed her on the way to the bathroom out in the back.  Bittersweet velvety love in a giant  ramikin.
author: Audrey T.

description:
I've wanted to try this place for the longest time, and perhaps my prolonged anticipation led to over-inflated expectations.  Yes, the souffles are giant and fluffy, but they just weren't the mindblowing dishes I was expecting.  

Hubby and I shared the crab souffle and chocolate souffle.  Both were fine.

In a city full of restaurants offering the latest spin on mac n' cheese, and molten chocolate cakes, Cafe Jacqueline offers something a little more special and different.  It's worth checking out, but I probably won't be rushing back any time soon - maybe I'll return in the summer to try the strawberry souffle.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Simply put, don't bother. We had an 8pm reservation, were told there would be a 15 minute wait. At 8:30, when I asked for an update, the guy with the attitude rod up his ass shortly said it would take at least 20 more minutes, and then turned and walked away from me as I was asking him a question. 
I don't care how good the souffle might be. Asshole service is just that. We took our business elsewhere, and so should you. That's the only way the service will get any better.
author: Purnima M.

description:
Bordering on 5 stars.  Great place to take a date or go in a group that you really enjoy spending time and catching up with.  There will plenty of time to talk while you wait for the souffles.  And it is definitely all about the souffles.

The French Onion Soup is six stars.  When ordering, you will be tempted to share a bowl between two people, but I would say a bowl per person is a better idea.  If you really want to share, you can share two bowls one after the next ;-)  

The wine glass pours and prices are five stars.  The dinner souffles that we got were very good, four stars.  We went with the specials, but the menu has many flavors on it as well that I am sure are worthy.  The souffles are light, fluffy and very flavorful.  Natalie said they were a bit salty for her, but honestly, I did not notice that and I am usually a bit sensitive about salt.

The desert souffle was over top delicious.  We got the seasonal fresh fruit souffle, which was strawberry.  Wow.  I don't think you can go wrong with it.  We finished with some espresso, which really the coffee shop 

The check was $230 with tax and generous tip for four.  Pass your own judgment on that one.  I was not upset.
author: Paul W.

description:
Oui Oui Oui! 

Que Magnifique!!

small, quaint, intimate, french, verrrrry french. Jacqueline can be found in the back whipping up a huuuuuge bowl of eggs for the souffles, giant floppy white chef hat in tow!
the waiters are friendly and attentive and i love the way they scoop and serve the souffles for the entire table. now that is service!...if only they'd wipe the crumbs off my face :)

now, onto the FOOD! 
major points for a vegetarian Onion Soup!!! a-fucking-mazing! besides  indulging in my favorite soup of all time every now and again,  i have been without a good bowl of vegetarian French Onion soup for years!...and now, finally i have found it. i feel so complete!
the souffles were HUGE and deeelish! one with Leek, and one with Shitake Mushroom, Basil & Garlic. yumm!
and for dessert we had the Chocolate and the Blueberry souffles, round it all out with 2bottles of wine and you have yourself one verrry satisfied table!

I will definitely be back to Cafe Jacqueline for special occasions & for that veg French Onion soup!

mon coeur et estomac sont pleins des oeufs et des oignons!!
author: Kaylan S.

description:
Wowowowowowowowowowoweeeee!

I am in LOVE with Cafe Jacqueline. I enjoyed the entire experience from start to finish. These peeps really know French food and seeing as how it's not often I indulge in such extravagances, it was a real treat. 

We ordered the French Onion Soup for starters and it was the best I had ever had. The broth was so flavorful but not overly onion-y. The cheese was melted to perfection and had seeped in to the bread forming a perfect combo. For our main entree we ordered the Ginger, Garlic White Corn Souffle which was cooked to perfection and tasted phenomenal. We were so happy with our choice even despite the fact that we had horrendously stank breath afterward. We ended the evening with the Chocolate Souffle which was huge (serves 2-4) and topped with powdered sugar. We poke, poke, poked at it until we got to the middle and it oozed melted chocolate.  Ahhhhhh....it doesn't get better than that.

My friend and I were there for 3 hours but it didn't feel that long at all. This isn't your place if you're in a hurry because all the Souffle's take quite a bit of time to make. It is so worth it though - go with a friend or on a date. You will be so happy you experienced it.
author: Julia N.
