description: I called the Cade last week to get a reservation, i made it for Friday night. When I arrived I was greeted by a very rude waiter who basically said i must be crazy, they don't take reservations and would never hold a table for a Friday night. How rude.
author: Matthew A.

description:
Who knew such a pleasant classy gem could be in the same little nook of North Beach as some of the city's most obnoxious bars (and by "obnoxious bars" I of course mean "establishments I frequent from time to time"). 

Very pleasant atmosphere inside: small, cozy, and soft lighting. 

We started with the onion soup which was incredible and reminded me of what I used to get at Le pot au feu in Paris: a nice beef onion broth hidden under at least 3 centimeters of cheese. 

Next we had the prosciutto souffle and it was divine. Split between the two of us, it was a lot of food, but I could not stop eating it. The combination of the savory flavors really took this to another heavenly level. 

We finished with the chocolate souffle, which was also great, but was a little "soupy" in the middle, which made it more like chocolate moose. But lucky for everyone, I also love chocolate moose so I enjoyed this immensely. 

Speaking of immense, I walked out of here incredibly full and happy. 

A note on the time issue that so many other reviews have pointed out. From my understanding, the cook (Jacqueline) makes the souffles one at a time once they are ordered. This adds to the charm not to mention the quality of the final product. 

So this is not a place to grab a quick bite, but it is an excellent place to linger over a wonderful dinner and stare into each other's eyes.
author: James M.

description: I would have loved it. Except for the waiter. Who only spoke to the person I was with. Who was male. Who, unfortunately, in his chauvinistic world, was not paying. I was. It got to the point where I would say something to the waiter and he would look to "the man" to repeat it. I almost left, but it was a celebration dinner. Completely ruined the evening for me. I'll make my own souffle from now on, thank you.
author: Danielle L.

description:
I came here on Friday for my bday with 3 of my girlfriends (and one of their bf's who came late).  I'm glad I came with the girls cuz I think we were able to really appreciate the experience together rather than hearing boys complain about how long everything is taking or how souffles aren't real food.  The restaurant is really cute and lights are dim, but it's pretty loud with all of the chatter (but no cell phones allowed).  

We were debating how much to order but definitely didn't want to under-order since we wouldn't be able to order more later.  We decided on 2 savory (mushroom/prosciutto and lobster) and 1 dessert (peach since there was no strawberry).  The savory souffles were very flavorful and they didn't skimp on any of the ingredients.  However, we were disappointed about how eggy they were.  We were surprised they almost had an undercooked omelette-like texture.  I've had yummy savory souffles in the past and I don't think the eggs should dominate the dish.  

But the fresh peach souffle made us forget all about the others!  After one bite, I wished we would've ordered another dessert souffle.  It was smooth, silky, oh so sweet, and not eggy at all.  I love the crusty, sugary parts too.  I think the savory ones should've had a similar texture.  A group of 6 had come in around 10 pm for dessert only...their souffles came out in less than an hour.  I would definitely go back for the dessert souffles only...I'm pretty sure I'd be able finish one on my own.
author: Mimi L.

description:
A-OK. Don't get me wrong, I thought the dinner souffle was yummy as was the soup & the dessert souffle & the waiter assisted in picking a nice bottle of wine, but for $175 for two (2 souffles, 1 shared soup, 1 bottle of wine), I would have rather picked some place with friendlier service.

The oyster, spinach & garlic souffle was my favorite. If the service had been more approachable or attentive, I would have asked for a replacement dessert souffle. I don't like a watery souffle & the dessert souffle was definitely liquid center.

What is truly great about Cafe Jacq is that you have plenty of time to get to know your new date or discuss the world with an oldie, but goody date. They don't rush you here & the pictures are exactly what you get, but perhaps we would have liked more wine or perhaps when we ordered soup, we didn't want to share. We didn't feel like we could flag down a waiter without receiving a huff &/or a puff.

I am still a fan of Morton's dessert souffle, but you just can't compare this quaint cafe with the steak chain. Go here if you've got extra dough or somebody super special you know would adore a good souffle & hours of romantic conversation. I've been here & there are so many other places to try, I doubt that I'll be a repeat customer. Then again, that dinner souffle was damn tasty, but certainly not priceless.
author: Amy D.

description:
So much love it's practically spilling out onto the street.

This is not the love shared between the couple tucked into the table in the back corner, leaning over the table, gazing into each other's eyes. It is not about the love that walks into the quaint little cafe, young love, old love, new love, long lost love. 

It's what creates an evening to remember: the pair of pastel long-stem roses, the warmth and glow of the votive brought to your table upon your arrival, the sweet voice that answered your call when you made your reservation - the voice you knew belonged to the heart and hands that would create your meal.

Steam billows out from beneath the white cloth, protecting a soft interior and a hard, thick crust that will leave a trail across the tablecloth. The champagne bubbles - intoxicating. When you can't chose between one great wine and the next, the waiter fills your glass with satisfaction - what you wanted when you didn't even know it yourself. 

You've come for souffle but while you're waiting...
The salads are exactly as written on the menu: butter lettuce is butter lettuce. Nothing more, nothing less. Okay, plus some house-made vinaigrette. and it works.

You go for souffle, you stay for souffle. This is the place, the one, the only. All the years over a bowl of eggs and bechamel are apparent 45 minutes or so after you place your order and the steam-filled wonder arrives. While they sound so simple on the menu, they are complex. Mouth-watering. Satisfying. Satisfying beyond walking away satiated but mentally satisfied knowing you had something special, made with care - that extra ingredient sometimes forgotten, that makes all the difference in the world.
author: Alissa A.

description:
Came here because of Jacqueline's ex-husband. Super sweet Argentinian who made conversation on a crowded muni and recommended his ex-wife's restaurant for a romantic night for two. 

Souffles are hard to make, they're ridiculously sensitive, so this is definitely something I only have at restaurants. They're on the pricey side but one savory souffle is enough for two people to get FULL. You may even have to go back for the sweet one next time.
Nice, private and quaint. Service was really attentive (then again, we had a really early reservation and had the whole restaurant to ourselves) if a bit stuffy...but having lived in France a while, I just take it as part of the experience.
To anyone docking stars for the wait, please stick to your McDonald's drive-thru. It's a French restaurant, run by a French lady (also, the only cook!) that makes French food. You're going to experience a meal LIKE the French, leisurely and looooong.
author: Leslie A.

description:
My hubby & I came here on a 7pm on a Thursday evening ready to gorge ourselves on souffles.  I'm not sure I agree with the "romantic"-ness description of the cafe, but it was definitely an intimate setting.  And given it's a 2 1/2 hour dining experience, I will definitely second other Yelpers' recommendation that you dine with someone you hold a solid conversation with.  You should also order everything you want upfront because it takes awhile to make the souffles.

To kill time, we ordered the French Onion soup, which was the BEST french onion soup ever!  Perfect proportions of onion, gruyere cheese, & crouton.  We wanted to try the proscuitto & mushroom souffle, but alas, they were out of proscuitto.  We went with our second choice, the white corn, ginger, & garlic souffle, which was quite yummy.  Lastly, we got the fresh strawberry souffle as dessert.  DELISH!

If you have a big appetite (or are in your second trimester of pregnancy & have a hollow belly like me :P), 2 people can easily polish off an appetizer & 2 souffles.

We will definitely come back to try the proscuitto souffle.  YUMS!
author: Jenny M.

description: Soufflés reminiscent of le soufflé in Paris.  Hard to find in the US.  That said, ambiance and service are lacking.  It's eerily quiet and the room could use an upgrade.  Service looks the part (head waiter had a great mustache), but didn't seemed trained to the standards befitting the food.
author: Alex T.

description:
Tonight was a Cafe Jacqueline redux evening.  I was rather hesitant about walking into the restaurant because of the "gruffy" waiter.  I warned my BFF about him beforehand.  He was in his usual perfunctory manner.  She commented that he reminded her of "those waiters in France".  But, she managed to get him to laugh when she asked about the cost of a bottle of wine & he told her some outrageous amt. as a joke.  After that, it was a much nicer evening. His co-waiter was very nice.  They kept our water glasses constantly filled but a couple of times, we refilled our wine glasses when they started to get real busy. 

I had the watercress salad, which was a small pile of watercress with dressing. The butter lettuce would've been a better choice.  I wanted to try the escargot but couldn't see paying $30 for a few gastropods when Chinatown was just blocks away & I could've ordered platefuls for that price. 
 The French bread baguette was crunchy.  The brie and broccoli souffle was just as scrumptous and not as salty compared to our last visit. The proscuitto mushroom souffle was quite good.  I was expecting the ham to be baked into the souffle but 4 slices were folded, then topped over the baked souffle.  For dessert, we had the Grand Marnier.  It was light, fluffy and infused with the tasty liquor.  I still prefer the fruit souffles and smiled when I saw a strawberry souffle pass by to the next table. I knew they were going to have a great time enjoying that souffle.

As tiny as this place is, there IS a unisex bathroom.  You pass the tiny kitchen and out the backdoor, make a right turn to this room that was probably a garden closet turned toilet.  Make sure you walk SLLLOOOWWWLY back to your seat thru the kitchen so you can see petite Chez Jacqueline in her chef uniform and toque blanche, hard at work with her huge wire basket full of eggs.  I could kiss that woman.  *smooch*
author: Ry T.

description:
I've only ever been here for dessert and this place has amazing dessert souffles. Depending on the time of year, the seasonal fruit dessert souffle will vary from strawberry to peach to raspberry to kiwi. They're all wonderful. 

Favorites like lemon and white chocolate are staples available all year round (so is the chocolate, but I'm not a big fan since I can make my own chocolate souffles). I would not recommend getting the lemon and the white chocolate on the same visit, because then the lemon is just too tart.

Some general advice: you need to call back and nag for reservations since they don't always return voicemail messages. The better bet is to call in the evening when they're open (Wed-Sun after 5:30). Also, the service staff and Jacqueline can be very brusque. I've been coming here for over 10 years, and it's always been like that. Because of the lengthy cooking time of the souffles, reservations can run behind, but don't expect them to be apologetic if they push you off for 30 or 45 minutes.

The place is very intimate and not good for large groups. There is a lot of downtime while the souffles are in the oven, so take that into consideration if you are on a first date. Also, very tiny, so make your reservations for weekends well in advance. Reservations used to be 1 month in advance at most, but recently my sister called in and was told that they are now taking 2 months.

Btw, I've seen people try to drop in for dessert and walk out because of the price. It's not cheap: $30-40/dessert souffle. Coffee refills cost extra.

Bottom-line, souffles are perfect, service is not.
author: Cynthia Y.

description:
All I can say is, the creator of this restaurant hit upon a brilliant business idea.  Small kitchen with maybe a staff of three.  The ingredients are essentially eggs and gruyere cheese.  Charge people $30-50 per souffle (which can barely feed two relatively hungry people) and another $30 for a dessert souffle, and convince them that it's worth it because "eet ees Flench!"

The souffles themselves were underwhelming, and we ordered a spinach salad that was ridiculously small and uninspired considering how expensive it was.  The little woman in the back making the souffles one by one is cute, but the service was snotty and the food took so long to arrive that I thought they were still hatching the chicks that would grow into hens that would then lay the eggs.  It's also supposedly "romantic" but all that meant was it was a poorly painted (thus rustic) room with old wood floors and with a door that banged every time new customers came in.  I often wonder what criteria people use when they describe a place as "romantic."  Perhaps it is romantic because "eet ees Flench."

All in all, it was overrated and pretentious without the food to back it up - cardinal sins when it comes to restaurants!
author: Betsy T.

description:
I came here with my sweetheart on our honeymoon and it was a memorable and romantic experience.  We had eaten a late lunch that day, so we each limited ourselves to French onion soup for dinner, but we were really here for the dessert, which did not disappoint.  We went for the chocolate souffle, and it was divine.  The word "fluffy" does not do this souffle justice.  It was quite possibly the greatest dessert I have ever consumed.

The ambience in the place is simple, old-world, uncluttered and extremely romantic.  Our server sported an old-timey, turn-of-the-century mustache, which I have to say added to the whole experience.  We will be going back next time we're in the Bay Area, this time to try the lime souffle.  Five stars easy.
author: Kennedy, J.

description:
This was our first time eating at the restaurant, and all we can say is that this place is amazing! This place is the perfect package for a lovely night out.

The food was incredible.  My husband and i shared the salmon-asparagus souffle as an entree and the white chocolate souffle for dessert.  The texture, taste, presentation, and size of both were perfect (two people can easily share the entree souffles and feel satisfied.  I would say 4 people can eat a dessert souffle and be satisfied).  It's pricy but well worth it, especially if you are sharing with others. 

The feel of the place was really nice too.  I was pleasantly surprised to see that it can be perfectly suitable for a romantic dinner with my husband or a nice dinner with friends. 

What sealed the deal for me was the friendly disposition of everyone who worked at the restaurant.  Our waiter was thoughtful and helpful when taking care of us and of others.  The other waiter was also very approachable and helped our regular waiter take care of things for us.  We had nice exchanges with everyone working including Miss Jacqueline, who was lovely in person.  We greeted her in the kitchen and thanked her for the wonderful food she had prepared for us.  

Overall, a magnificent experience.

The only downside is that there was about an hour wait on the first souffle and the second came about 30 min after we were done with the first one.  I really don't think it's a big deal because the quality of the food more than made up for it.  But it's not a place to go to if you are in a rush.
author: D R.

description:
We went here last night and service was HORRIBLE.  We had reservations so they knew how many people was expected.  

The waiters are rude, stuck-up, and very inattentive.  Every time our waiter came and asked us if we were ready (there was 4 of us), he'd walk away.  Hardly ever making any eye contact before he would walk away again.  On top of that a lot of what was on the menu, "they ran out" .  We asked for 3 different bottles of wine and again "we ran out"  Mind you the restaurant opens only from Wed - Sun (dinner service only)  Plus there were only 4 other tables that were being occupied last night along with ours.  (Total of 10 tables)

The menu is made up most entirely of souffles.   They did have a few standard starters, such as hearty French onion soup (the ran out of) and a lightly dressed baby spinach salad (this was good). 

The experience is to share a souffle for two.  Savory souffles are big enough to share, from the classical Gruyere cheese souffle to a creative pairing of salmon and asparagus, or shitake, garlic and basil (this was okay) and,  prosciutto and mushroom (ran out of) or the lobster souffle which was good but overpriced at $55. 

For desserts, they offered a bittersweet-chocolate souffle and  fresh strawberry souffle (I recommend this)

The dessert was the only thing worth going there for.
author: Nestle L.

description:
J'adore le souffle'.
J'adore l'ambiance.
J'adore le garcon Matthieu
J'adore Jacqueline.

There are pertinent conditions that must be met in order to be an authentic French Restaurant.  The important ones are:-

Souffle must be in the menu- as an entree or dessert.

The ambiance must exhibit a french taste and atmosphere.

The waiter must exhibit a certain "je n'ai sais pas quoi" air about them- (may it be their succinct and punctuated  "oui oui"  or that affirming cordial laugh followed by " mais bien sur!")

AND most definitely a FRENCH COOK who still speaks in that audibly delicious, mellifluous  voice exclaiming- "c'est merveilleux!" :-)

This restaurant is a special place- where one oven, one blender, one cook and a whole lot  of eggs - produce these beautiful souffle's done to perfection!  It is unfathomable that each one ordered by the diners produced that same indelible mark of  a tan top hat  rising inches above  the white porcelain bowls.  If there is anything else used to suggest attention to detail- it would be attending to a souffle' while in the oven!

The ambiance reminds me of a french country cafe- lit with amber sconces and candles, table covered with white crisp table linens, joined by french country style chairs and roses that adorned the vases.  With the sound of Mozart in the air, one can only think- quelle bonheur!

I don't  think anyone can go wrong with the souffle' choices...My personal favorite (without the having had the others) is the LOBSTER!!! Chunks after Chunks of sweet succulent slices of tender meat- wrapped in that warm spongy egg cake.  The flavoring was exquisite and simply complimentary .:-)  

PS- If you ever decide on going out for a dessert only place- this would be a wonderful choice- the chocolate or strawberry souffle's would make any gourmande happy!
I may have found a favorite restaurant in North Beach!
author: Arissa C.

description:
I grew up with Jacqueline.  Her husband, Silvio and she were my parent's dear friends (he was even my pediatrician and there when my mom gave birth to me)

I have eaten here, and of course, i am biased...Jacqueline is the best cook I've ever seen.  I can still remember going over her house and her saying "Leezah...would you like a little shocolat moooz?"

Oh, my god, YES! 
The chocolate mousse is absolutely to DIE For...and she can make a souffle that would make God cry.

I love her, though I haven't seen her in years.
Her warmth is phenomenal :)
author: Lisa B.

description: If you have the time for a beautifully made souffle then Cafe Jacqueline is the place. It's small and romantic and despite his surly-ness the waiter is very efficient and I got a smile out of him by the end of the meal.  Madame Jacqueline has been in the kitchen for 35 years breaking the eggs as you order. The onion soup is classic and don't worry about ordering a salad and the soup, you'll have time to digest. The entree takes a while but is well worth it.
author: Rodney K.

description:
My wife and I have had Valentines dinner here every year for the past 18 years plus many other occasions.  This is the resturant I recommend to out of town guests and friends for the incredible food and wonderful service/atmosphere.  There is a learning curve here.  Two people do not need two dinner soufles and a dessert soufle along with either soup or salad.  We made that filling mistake the first time.  

Any time you make reservations later in the evening (after 6-7) expect to wait a bit due to the people before you (the knowledgeable ones who come at 5:30) taking their well deserved two to three hours to enjoy a wonderful meal and conversation.  Want faster food, go somewhere else, it's that simple!

French onion soup is the best on the west coast and maybe east coast also (I've sampled 50 or more over the past 5 years) .  Yes it takes time  duh!  Inspect it, and the pan the onions were cooked in, look closely, it's done the old fashioned way.   Leaves all others far behind.  Endive salad or red pepper soup also good.

The souffles ...   OMG   Procuitto and asparagus, gruyere, fruits de mer, shitake mushroom, crab, etc.  Heavenly, light but filling and they're SOUFFLES they take a good 45 minutes to prepare and serve.  Want fast food go find a pizza!

Dessert  souffles..   Yee HAH  raspberry, strawberry, chocolate, grand marnier,lemon, etc.!  

Tips   .. for 5 people    3 dinner and two dessert souffles plus soups or salads...   Share the souffles with the whole table! (you could add another dessert souffle if you're really decadent.)

Jacqueline is a most gracious chef and a wonderful person.  Nat (the head waiter) has been with her for years and is a gem also, very knowledgeable about what wine goes with what dinner!

So don't be in a hurry, allow 3 plus hours and order a glass of wine or a kir and relax  for a great meal.  

And once you figure it out (don't be afraid to ask someone who looks like a regular)  You'll be hooked!   &*)
author: Glen B.

description:
I wish I could just say it with one word...... OVERRATED.

The place is very warm and adorable. The chocolate souffle could be better than Gary Danko IF ONLY they make it faster. Be prepared to wait for more than 40 mins (in my case, it is an hour). Don't worry they have lots of french bread to hold your appetite though.

Finding parking in Little Italy itself has been a stressful moment, adding the super slow service, a cocky waiter, and a mediocre dessert...A big disappointment. Being objective, maybe it was just not my day to eat souffle in Cafe Jacqueline.

But believe me, the reservation could make you think twice to go dine there. I've called 3 times and they always said, "We're fully booked" and they cannot take reservation for more than 2 people. The guy in the phone really creates this image of an arrogant french cafe that do not tolerate people who desperately wants to try their souffle. Even if the food is super delicious, lack of hospitality could bring a drawback to them.
author: Jazzleen H.

description:
Fantastique!!!

This was one of those transcendental dining experiences I hope to repeat very soon.  Jacqueline took me to another world on her little souffle-shaped spaceship. 

We had:

dubonnet rouge aperitifs
spinach & bacon salad
prosciutto & mushroom souffle
lobster souffle
strawberry souffle
Chateauneuf-du-Pape blanc

All perfect, all heavenly... particularly the sliced prosciutto topping the prosciutto &  mushroom souffle -- where does she find it so lean yet melt-in-your mouth buttery?  Her ingredients are superb.

When can I eat here again please?
author: Molasses C.

description:
It's been one of the best food discoveries in a while. Perfect place - small and cozy, good noise level, attentive service. I like my menu options simple and straightforward - souffle: sweet or sour. Pretty simple. Great food.

I am on a hunt for a perfect kir royal in SF (after living in France, I somewhat have idea what it should be), this place had a decent one but not the best, I could not taste Crème de cassis
author: P I.

description:
This place is Sick...

It deserves every bit of its 4.5 rating and you should go as you will not regret it.  

I think I made some inadvertent sex noises while enjoying the French Onion Soup.  Keep that on the DL though.
author: Nick B.

description: Its cute, the soufflés are tasty (yes the Lime is amazing) but I just don't get and all soufflé restaurant.  I don't think i will do back.
author: Ken p.

description: Amazing soufflees of course.  Very romantic atmosphere.  My favorite moment of the meal was when I walked through the kitchen (to go to the restroom), and found the chef with a whisk going to town on a huge bowl of what must have been fifty eggs.  I have one problem with this restaurant and hence the 4 stars, rather than 5 stars.  The problem is that the souffles are extremely rich (as they should be), so by the end of the main course and before desert I already had the worst heartburn of my life.  Not surprisingly, downing gobs of TUMS/Maalox/Rolaids mid-meal dramatically decreases the romantic feeling of the restaurant, though I was happy to discover that there is a corner store across the street that carries all three.
author: Zac A.

description:
OMG. I tell everyone about this place even though it's been years since I've had one of her amazing souffles. No one has ever ever come close. The savory souffles are so delicate and pretty, that even I feel delicate and pretty eating them!!

The chocolate souffle is (as everyone has already mentioned) divine, but I recommend getting a fruit (pear, raspberry, whatever) souffle as chocolate is pretty standard on many a french restaurant's menu. Also, it's not as heavy. 

mmmmm...
author: Louise O.

description:
STRAWBERRY SOUFFLE TO DIE FOR

A restaurant that only serves souffle? I've never heard of such a thing so when my boss told me about Cafe Jacqueline, I was intrigued. It's a small cozy restaurant and there are only about 12-15 tables. I wouldn't come here with a large group. Think intimate. Your souffles aren't made until you order them (duh) so a full dinner here can take over 2 hours. While you wait for the souffle, you can have French onion soup, salad, or escargot if they are available.

The souffle can be split by two people--I'd split it with three to save room for dessert! The dessert souffles are huge and you can split those by 4 people.

The first time I went here, I was in heaven with a full souffle meal--I think it was the novelty. The second time, I got a little tired of the souffle texture for an entire meal. I would come back here in a heartbeat for a dessert reservation though. The strawberry souffle was amazing. It came out covered in hand sliced strawberries and sprinkled with powedered sugar. You can call and let her know you just want to come for dessert and she'll allot your group with an hour. You can drink champagne while you wait for your creation to be made. Reservations should be made a week in advance since she is closed Monday and Tuesday. By the time Wednesday rolls around, the weekend slots are all booked.

Don't forget to make a trip to the restroom at some point in the night. You'll pass the kitchen where Mademoiselle Jacqueline is busily making all the souffles. There's a giant bowl full of eggs and one tiny jeweled egg resting on top.
author: Cindy P.

description: Two of us shared the tomato salad, onion soup, crab souffle, and chocolate souffle.  The souffles are huge- we weren't able to finish the chocolate- but for the price, I was wishing for something more.  Everything was good, but not especially memorable.  Crab could've had more crab and the chocolate could've been a little more decadent.  However, service was impeccable.
author: Christine L.

description:
So, there's no mistake, the food is good. damn good.

The souffles are delicious but, are they filling?  Go with a date but, avoid this romantic yet, frantic eatery with groups 4 (that's pushing it) or more (highly do not recommend).

After waiting for what seemed like an eternity (because it was) the four of us split two souffles, mushroom and spinach.  The waiter kindly divided our souffles up in fours and each of us were left to look longingly at the two, small morsels on our plates.  "Eat slowly. Small bites. Lots of sips of water in between." I repeated. 

After the four of us had finished our rations my heart sank as the men at the table grabbed the last remaining pieces of bread from God-send basket.  (Aha, so that's why they don't clear away the bread).

Our large, chocolate souffle (which, we ordered when we ordered our main course) arrived a half hour later.  The souffle redeemed the meal with its size but its taste, unfortunately, was sub-par for the chocolate lovers at the table.

The best part about the evening for me was going to the bathroom. No, I'm not bulimic. I very much enjoyed passing through the kitchen only to witness little, old Jacqueline herself, complete with 100 some-odd eggs by her side, whisking away.

In sum, I'd go back.  With one other female.
author: Caitlin L.

description:
Can you say OVERRATED? I really cannot believe this place and what's even more shocking is it's averaging 4.5 stars on Yelp. Am I seriously alone here when I think $40 for a souffle is beyond ridiculous? $40!!? Are you %!&@ kidding me?

Sure, they're gianormous, but am I the only here that remembers the ingredients are eggs and AIR??? I came here with some friends after it was highly recommended and touted as the best souffles in town. Ordered the Grand Marnier and Chocolate dessert souffles and was severely disappointed. I mean don't get me wrong they are decent, but when you're charging $40 per and making customers wait 1-2 hrs from order to arrival, you're leaving a lot to be desired. That's a whole lotta hype to live up to and I don't even think it comes close.

I'm guessing these outrageous prices reflect the limited foot traffic and patronage. When you're making customers occupy each table for 2-3 hrs, I guess for damn sure you better charge an arm and a leg to make up for the lost business.

If not for the beautiful ambiance with dark, yet candlelit tables, I might have given this place a one star. Some people say that when it comes to souffles you're either going to love it or hate it; there's no middle ground. Call me unclassy all you want but give me a Mcdonald's soft serve ice cream with an apple pie for $2 any day over this crap.
author: jeff c.

description: I've never had such good delicious Soufflé's before. Expect to wait at least an hour or two for your Soufflé(s) to be made/served. I believe there is only one person in the kitchen making the soufflés. The service wasn't too great. The server wasn't very polite when we asked for  some napkins. His response was "There are some in the bathroom I believe." I mean really?? We kind of just laughed it off though. The wait and bad service for the soufflés were worth it though. Super tasty and the chocolate one was really rich and sweet. It would probably be best to make reservations here because Cafe Jacqueline is only open a certain amount of house and it gets pretty packed. I would definitely come here again!
author: Caroline L.

description: My husband and I return to Jacqueline every time we are in San Francisco, and it never disappoints.  YES, you have to prepare yourself for a wait, and by all means go with people you enjoy - this is not a first date or job interview place.  Go through the tiny kitchen and marvel at Jacqueline and her small crew working their magic.  I do not want to repeat what all the other reviews have said but the onion soup, bread, spinach salad, and of course the souffles were all excellent.  The wait staff (Scott, and the other fellow with the groovy 'stache) were solicitous and helpful, particularly with choosing wine.  Tip: be sure to book ahead, especially on weekends.
author: Katie K.

description: I love this place!!!  Every time I go I leave with the best feeling in my stomach and heart.  The staff are warm and friendly, the service is great!  When you have to use the restroom, you have no other way but to walk through the kitchen where Jacqueline is cooking away.  A large bowl of eggs sits on the counter in her tiny little kitchen, and behind it she looks up to greet you like family!  She's wonderful and so is her food.  Best comfort food with a romantic atmosphere, the best combination if you ask me!  This will be one of my favorite and most memorable restaurants for the rest of my life!
author: Marissa J.

description:
You'll love this place for two things, and two things only: onion soup and souffles. If you're looking for anything else that's french, go to Chapeau. 

And Jacqueline does these two things superbly. I used to be on this mission to seek out and consume all the different versions of tiramisu offered in this world. But now, I'm into french onion soup. And the soup here is phenomenal. Like the souffles, the soup is seasoned just right...not too salty, with just the right amount of cheese and crouton on top to provide a nice bite. 

The souffles take a long time to reach the table, but they are so worth the wait: light and fluffy with just the right amount of moisture. We had the chanterelle and garlic version and it was perfectly aromatic, flavorful and deceivingly rich. They have a number of vegetarian selections (if you're a vegetarian that eats eggs, that is), along with seafood souffles. 

The souffles are huge. The entree selections are designed to be shared between two people. The dessert souffles are the same size, but because they are for apres dinner, they're decidedly richer and harder to finish between two people.
author: Virg Y.

description:
Ok so it's been a long time since I went but recently I am addicted to all things french and I remembered Cafe Jacqueline. 

What a horrible experience. 

First we arrive early for a reservation and still had to wait an additional half hour past our reservation time. Waiters are rude, stuck-up, and very inattentive. 

Food was completely overpriced, lobster souffle was watery. I have made better souffles at home. Hardly a romatic experience-just a large room with entirely too many tables. Not an enjoyable occasion. 

And if this is possible, even worse service was provided to my son (age 13 at the time). This is a child who has been going to fine dine since he was a toddler: Kokkari, Farallon, Boulevard, among others. So even he could yelp the restaurants. They seemed to not even notice him when he would ask for something. 

This was a waste of money and time. Would NEVER go back.
author: Maria M.

description:
I adore Cafe Jacqueline!  I have heard about it for many years and am so pleased it lived up to my expectations.  

I loved the small, nondescript atmosphere.  The soft lighting.  The feeling that you are waiting for something really special.  And you are.  How many restaurants have a chef in the kitchen whipping up each soufflé to order?  And such a lovely, charming chef she is.  I kept running to the restroom so I could pass by and watch her work.  

Our waiter, Matthew, was absolutely charming and funny.  We were prepared to wait, and he stayed with us, waiting for the "ding!" that signals a soufflé is ready to be picked up.  I felt like we were fast friends by the end of the night.  He knew the menu and wines inside and out.  

I wasn't prepared for our salad to be much of anything, but it was delicious.  The french onion soup is beyond compare.  We savored every bite of our leek soufflé, and were thrilled with lemon and chocolate soufflés for dessert.  It was a memorable and unique evening, and I will make reservations well in advance to ensure I have a table waiting for me next time.  Soon.
author: Kristy M.

description:
I was there Friday 12/9/11. Hadn't been here in a few years.
Caviar appetizer was 3 bits for $40 was not worth it. The sour cream over powered the rest of the ingredients.
The Wait for the food was very long and it wasn't as good as it used to be...too salty for the lobster. not recommended.

The only good thing was the Strawberry desert. I would come back for this if I could order in advance.

Service was good, but it got very load once the place filled up and it's not a very big place.

Come here for the deserts, save your money and eat your dinner at home.
author: Patrick L.

description:
This is definitely not a first date place as dinner can be an event (2+ hours).  Make sure you order your main and dessert souffles at the same time.  A little expensive but a great place to take that special someone on a very special occasion.  Very romantical. 

He/She should definitely put out afterwards.  Bon Appetit! :)
author: Paul D.

description:
Good Lord, I don't know why I haven't reviewed this gem of a place yet. Everything is very special here. The moment you walk in the door it is the epitome of romance, from their fresh roses on each table to the soft lighting and simple, quiet ambiance. My bf and I come here after dinner for the chocolate souffle. During my first visit, I didn't really know what to expect from such a tiny place. However, I was so blown away--the souffle undoubtedly deserves one of these:
http://www.sfgate.com/templates/types/entertainment/graphics/littleman/5.0.gif
(Movie review guy jumping out of seat)

Incredible. And to think, each souffle is handmade by Jacqueline herself, a very warm, kind older lady (think Grandma you wish you had) who always smiles at everyone passing by; you can watch her hard at work as you pass through the kitchen to get to the restroom. She is truly an angel! Sadly, I'm afraid to think of what will happen to this place once Jacqueline goes to heaven...

As for the chocolate souffle. It's served with a dusting of powdered sugar. One taste of this and you'll fall madly in love. Literally. It's like I fell in love w/my bf all over again during dessert here! :) Light and fluffy in the middle and crisp at the edges, the chocolate souffle is a work of edible art. It's almost surreal how good it is. Do note that the serving size is huge for 2 people so expect some leftovers. And also expect to be fantastically full upon leaving. But it's so worth it. I can't wait to come back.

Cafe Jacqueline is a beautiful ending to a beautiful evening.
author: Michelle G.

description:
Went there with my girlfriend a few months ago and I loved the restaurant!  It's a small place with just a few tables and reminded me of a neighborhood restaurant in Paris.  Since it wasn't too loud, it was a great place to catch up with an old friend.  However, I could totally see this as a great date place too :)

We started with the French onion soup and I have to admit, it was a little too salty for my taste.  For entree, we had wanted the crab souffle but they ran out so we shared the prosciutto and leek souffle and it came out soft and very satisfying--just the way you'd want a savory souffle.  For dessert, we got the chocolate souffle and grand marnier sauce and that was decadently delicious!  We saw two boys who walked in around 9 pm and just ordered the chocolate souffle so I hope that tells you just how good it is.  

One word of caution--the food comes out pretty slow, as to be expected since each souffle is made to order, so make sure you come with good company.
author: Sandy W.

description:
my fiance and i came here just for dessert. we ordered the strawberry souffle for $35 + tax + tip. 

it was good. i'm glad i tried it. 

jacqueline is nice. I thanked her on my way to the restroom for the delicious dessert, she responded with , "merci merci".
author: John S.

description: I've been there twice and would say it's probably one of the best romantic dinners I've ever had.
author: Victor T.

description:
This place is probably one of the few gems in North Beach.  I came here one night to have dinner with my better half.  We got the onion soup, endives, scallions and chestnut souffle, and chocolate souffle.  The entire dinner took 3 hours and was excellent.

Though I probably won't come back for a full meal, but I would definitely come back for a dessert when I'm in the area.
author: Tim L.

description:
This place is cute, cute, cute. Perfect for a date. It is so unique and special. The main food item here is the souffle. You choose what kind of souffle you want (they're probably ALL delicious but we had the broccoli and cheese and it was gooooood). This giant souffle comes out (for two) and it's this warm, fluffy, beautiful thing... Dessert is also souffle, chocolate. I have to say this was one of those dinner experiences that I will always remember. You need a reservation though because it's a small place, and there's one woman in the back making all of this food.

Please do yourself a favor and go to Jacqeline's. And take someone special!!!
author: Kanna L.

description:
Note that the 5 stars are strictly for their dessert souffle!!  

We had a full course meal, while I thought the entree souffle (it was their special of the day, with garlic and some sort of mushroom) was very good, the strawberry souffle blew me out of my mind.  It was hands down the best dessert I've ever had in my life!!! (the second best being my own creme brulee:)  The onion soup was also the best I've ever had, no I'm not exaggerating!

Very cozy and romantic atmosphere, perfect for a date you'd like to impress.  The 45 minutes for each souffle to be served provides an opportunity for you to interact and know your date better in the cafe's seductive environment.  It took 2 hours and 20 minutes for our meal as we were the second table of the night, be prepared to spend up to three hours here if you have more parties arrive before you.

Service was a bit snooty, but it didn't get on my nerves for some reason.  Take away from this review?  GET THE ONION SOUP AND STRAWBERRY SOUFFLE!!!
author: J D.

description:
Yum yum. When my boyfriend told me he was going to bring me somewhere special for our anniversary, I was thinking "oooh... he'll finally bring me to Gary Danko's!" No such luck. A whole meal of just souffles?? hmmmm....

I was surprisingly impressed with this place. It's a cute little romantic restaurant. Make sure that you have at least 3 hours worth of conversation topics with your date or friend or else you will be bored to death of waiting and waiting!! 

We started off with a French Onion soup.  I'm usually not a huge fan of French Onion, but this was delicious!! Lots of melted cheese (try not to think about the thousands of calories that you will be consuming throughout the night).

We waited for a while (almost an hour) before we got our Lobster souffle (this is large enough to share). We noticed that they come out in batches. We got our food at the same time that another couple got theirs. There were sooo many chunks of lobster in there. There were slices of lemon on top to give it a little tang. Mmmmm...Surprisingly, it was pretty filling.

The dessert was a white chocolate souffle. Needless to say...omg omg. So heavenly.
author: Ring K.

description:
I've been looking forward to trying this restaurant for so long (better part of 5 years).  I had always postponed due to the "special occasion" this small restaurant seems to merit.  It's also expensive!  On a whim, I called last minute and was able to secure a 7PM reservation.  We were promptly seated at our table and about 2.5 hrs later...we were generally disappointed.  I so wanted to enjoy this restaurant and expected to give it a 5 star rating but alas...what a let down.

Decor - 4 stars - Small and cute.  It could've been better lit but I guess it's supposed to be "romantic."  A woman at the table next to us even had to request an extra candle since she couldn't read the menu.

Service - 4 stars - Quite attentive and nice.

Food - 2 stars - I was looking forward to the fluffiness that everyone raves about.  Nope, did not encounter said fluffiness.  Our souffles were not very fluffy at all and one was absolutely runny even.  It would've been nice if there were more meat souffles on the menu too.  We ordered...

-French Onion Soup - This was excellent!  You sort of have to order some appetizers to start since the souffles take quite a while to make.
-Corn ginger garlic souffle - The waiter said this was one of their signature souffles.  It was underwhelming but ok.  The corn was very sweet and I loved the ginger flavor but it just wasn't that light and fluffy.
-Prosciutto mushroom souffle - Again, not fluffy enough for me and extremely salty.  The souffle just seemed like a mushy mess.  Pass.
-Chocolate souffle - We added this extra dessert souffle even though we knew it was more than what we could eat.  The Yelp reviews touted this as the most popular dessert so we felt like we "had" to order this even though I'm not a big chocolate person.  It was extremely RUNNY!  I even asked the waiter if this is how it's supposed to be and he stated that it was indeed intended.  ?!?  Ok, I'm no souffle expert but I thought souffles were supposed to be light and fluffy, no?  It was like a chocolate soup inside.  At $33, I think it was a rip off.
-Strawberry souffle - This is the seasonable fruit souffle and it was the only shining light in the evening's picks.  The flavor was outstanding and while not that light, it was probably the fluffiest of the bunch.  I would come back to order this for dessert again.

Too bad.  I wish I liked this place more.  : (  Maybe it was an off night?
author: Jennifer I.

description:
What a great experience!

We nearly walked past the restaurant the lights were so low inside.  Upon stepping in, we were greeted with soft classical music and a friendly waiter who offered to take our coats and seated us.  The interior of the restaurant had some beautiful lights, and created a perfect atmosphere for quiet conversation.

We began with a nice half bottle of white wine, and had some delicious figs wrapped in prosciutto, which were cut and presented resembling 3 flowers.  I had read how long the souffles took and made sure to order those to tide us over, and I'm glad I did!

This really is key: you really SHOULD NOT come here if you are trying to get in and out.  The food takes so long to prepare because it is made fresh, so expect to spend at least 2 hours waiting in anticipation.  But when it arrives, what a treat!

We ordered the Lobster souffle, and when it arrived there was a great ceremony of dividing it up for us.  The souffle was good, but I don't know if it was $50 good!  Next time I think I'll try a cheaper one.  The dessert souffle was tasty too, but we were so full from the first souffle that we couldn't really finish.

All in all a costly (end bill for dinner for 2 was around $150) but very pleasant dining experience!
author: Corey C.

description: So yum! I started with the Tomato & Herb salad and the Endives with Roquefort, both very good. This was of course good news, because if a souffle place is making excellent salads it is only up from there for the main course! I had the leek chestnut for my main, which was the perfect balance of flavors and textures. Somehow both light and heavy, very savory, and perfect in terms of portion. For dessert I had the chocolate souffle, which I was actually surprised that it wasn't my favorite. It was very good, but the star of the show was the main course. If you want a phenomenal chocolate souffle, head to Alexander's, but this place was solidly very good from start to finish. I also loved that you walk through the kitchen to get to the bathroom, where you can see the biggest bowl of eggs I've ever seen, and the cutest older French woman making her magic! I'd definitely come back.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
The dessert soufflés are the bomb!!!! 5 stars there. We ordered the fresh strawberry and I wish we got more dessert! 

The savory ones were only so-so. 3 stars here. I thought they were a bit salty. The French onion soup is a must, especially since the soufflés take 30 minutes or so to prepare. Oh yeah, don't come here on a first date. It could be horrible if you guys don't get along since dinner can take up to 3 hrs!
author: Karen C.

description:
After some reviews from yelp I heard they have a very tasty soufflés, so Iast time when I had a trip in SF, I guess I have to make a try. Well I got there late night for desserts, small tiny cozy Cafe, simple decor but clean, half open kitchen, friendly service, in general not too bad! I shared one Soufflés with my friend, lemon soufflés, taste good! As a Chicagoan is great to see a restaurant like Cafe Jacqueline in SF, soufflés is not easy to make so I wouldn't mind a little more to have a nice one, I guess I will go back again when next time I'm in bay area again!

I wish Cafe Jacqueline in Chicago!
author: Vick C.

description:
Beautifully warm/romantic/cozy setting.  On to the food.

Never had a savory souffle before, but I have to say that the Salmon Asparagus souffle was quite delicious and just the right amount for 2 people.

Now, when it came time to choose the dessert souffle, we asked about the fresh fruit souffle.  To our sadness, the waiter said that they had run out of the fresh fruit...what's worse, we followed that up by asking what the fruit was and he responded, "Strawberries."  GAH!  We shouldn't have asked.  

So we opted for the second string dessert: the chocolate souffle was good as well, but definitely enough to feed 4.  And as good as it was, we'll definitely have to go back for the Strawberry souffle.

(Number of times the word "souffle" was used = 6)
author: Brian L.

description:
Cafe Jacqueline is one of my favorite, intimate date spots in San Francisco. The restaurant is run by Madame Jacqueline, a darling older French lady with a delightful accent and a talent for making decadent and delicious souffles. 

My husband and i visited here last night for our first wedding anniversary. It was our second visit to Cafe Jacqueline and it was even better than the first time we went there about a year and a half ago. 

The first time, we got the spinach and gruyere souffle, the chocolate souffle and the grand marnier souffle. Yes, we were gluttons! 

This time, we started with an apertif of white Lillet with an orange slice in it. Bonus to this restaurant for having a heavy pour! 

We then moved onto the onion soup appetizer, which was truly some of the best onion soup I've ever had. Dip some of the wonderful crusty French baguette in the broth too....it is oh so yummy and divine.

For our entreee, we had the white corn, ginger and garlic savory souffle. OMG, it was soooooo good. I liked this more than the spinach one we got last time, even though that was delicious too. The slightly crunchy texture of the corn with the creaminess and fluffiness of the souffle is wonderful. 

For dessert, we had to do the grand marnier souffle again. It is one of the best tasting desserts I've ever had and could probably eat one every night if it wouldn't make my thighs look like souffle too!

I'm not sure what the quality of the wine list is. The two times we've been there, we've brought our own bottle of Veuve Cliquot champagne ($35 at Safeway or $33 each for a six-pack!) and paid the $20 corkage fee. 

This is a very small restaurant with only I think eight two-seater tables, one six-person table and three four-person tables. The lighting is low and romantic with roses on every table. The rest of the decor is very simple. Nothing on the walls to really speak of. 

Madame Jacqueline is the real deal and makes all the souffles with a staff of two sous chefs and two waiters running the front of the house. I highly recommend visiting this place while it lasts. I don't know when Madame Jacqueline plans to retire, but once she does, there will no longer be a Cafe Jacqueline!  

Keep in mind that souffles take about an hour to cook, so you should plan to order your entire meal -- appetizer, entree and dessert -- all at once so they can time your meal properly. If you're someone who likes to eat and run, this isn't the restaurant for you. Cafe Jacqueline is all about lingering and savoring the atmosphere, your company, and the food.
author: Christine P.

description:
The menu: Souffle and souffle

The code is simple; do not be loud and annoying (souffle is very temperamental), do not take forever on your order, do not try to make small talk with the "Souffle" Nazi,  do not make complaints about your order; however, do order your wine in French and do sit around idly (place your order, then wait and wait and wait).

Just don't ask me where Jacqueline keeps her recipe.
author: Tu R.

description: Given the wait time and the price, not so satisfied. Good soufflet, but wasn't worth the 2 hr wait at all!
author: Shirin E.

description:
This was an amazing place to eat.  I went here for my first wedding anniversary, and it was great.  It's terrific for a special romantic evening because they only have 12 tables in the restaurant, and dinner takes 2-3 hours.  Just be sure to make a reservation.

I started off with the french onion soup because I'd seen how highly it was rated by everyone.  It was perfect - I can't even put it into words.  My husband got their cream of bell pepper soup, which also tasted great, but could compare the to french onion soup.

We got the mushroom souffle for dinner and the strawberry souffle for dessert, at the suggestion of our server.  Both were amazing and light as air, and they complemented each other wonderfully.

I highly recommend this restaurant for a special occasion or romantic evening.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Not sure I will ever go back. 

The food was fine - we had a sweet strawberry souffle - it was fluffy and oozy. It comes in such a big dish (6inches) and so it deflates pretty fast which isn't great, because then you are left with a very soft and watery custard. 

The problem was the waiter. He was really rude. When we got there, he wouldn't let us wait inside and shuffled us to wait outside. We ask for water and it took forever. We asked for the check and even that took forever. We asked for a business card (so that my friends can come back) and he said they are completely out. He just gave the attitude that we are not welcome. There is nothing worst to a restaurant experience than when the service impacts your friends. I was very disappointed.
author: Emily L.

description: Okay . . . my fiance and I went in on a Thursday for dinner.  Our reservation was for 7:00 pm and we arrived about 15 minutes early and were greeted by the waiter with the handle-bar mustache who seated us promptly.  While he was seating us we both noticed "his aroma".  Putting it mildly, his body odor was enough to make you gag if you smelled it for a prolonged period.  He gave us menus and said he'd be back to take our order momentarily.  When we were ready to order wine we tried to get the other waiter (tall blonde guy) to take our order but when we started to tell him what we had selected "The Mustache" shoved him out of the way and told us he would be taking our order.  My girlfriend literally put the collar of her blouse over her nose while I tried to look down and keep my head turned the other way while taking shallow breathes through my mouth so I wouldn't have to smell him.  I kid you not, his b.o. was horrific.  We ordered an onion soup to share,  the lobster souffle for our entree,  and the seasonal fruit souffle for dessert which was strawberry.  All of their dishes including the onion soup are big enough to share between 2 people.  After I gave him our order and he left to place it in the kitchen my girlfriend asked if I had seen his vest.  She said it was literally crusted with what we're guessing was dried food.  I informed her I hadn't because I was looking away so as not to smell him.  She said it reminded her of Monica Lewinsky's dress to which we both started laughing so loud the other diners shot us looks.  We also gave "The Mustache" the nick-name "Musty" for short.  When he came back with our wine he opened it and put the bottle back in the fridge so anytime we wanted to re-fill our glasses we had to call him over.  We kept trying to get the other waiter to assist us but if he came over "Musty" would jump in and ask if everything is okay.  I guess the other guy was a food runner or something.  He smelled nice and was clean btw.  This is a true classic french bistro with a true classically trained cordon-bleu chef to run it.  Please feel free to insert the obvious joke about the french and their bathing habits.  We did.  On top of this the week that we chose to dine ther was one of the warmest in recent memory and the restaurant is not air conditioned nor ventilated really.  Anytime "Musty"came to a neighboring table we were forced to hold our breathe.  At one point the gentleman from another table got up and opened the door which was welcomed by everyone seated in this small room. Less than 30 seconds after the door was opened "Musty" comes in from the kitchen and shuts it.  The gentleman who opened it asked if it could be left open for a little breeze to which "Musty" rudely replied  "NO ! because it screws up the oven flame."  ? ? ?  W T F.  Is it an easy bake oven?  When he said this everyone in the place all gave each other quizical looks, while "Musty" smirks and struts into the kitchen.  I kid you not.  On to the food . . . the onion soup was the single best onion soup that either of us had ever tasted in our entire lives.  It was what I imagine food in heaven will be like if it it happens to exist.  It took about 45 minuted to come but we were prepared to wait that long as we had read reviews prior to dining here.  It was phenominal.  Really.  After another 45 minutes we got our dinner souffle.  Again,  food of the gods !  Lots of chunks of lobster,  tender and succulent,  seasoned to perfection and that rich buttery texture that the flesh of a fresh lobster gives you.  Not overly fishy or briny.  We had read reviews on here that the chef over-salted her food but that was not the case with either of our savory dishes.  The he presentation was simple and not overdone.  Jacueline truly is an artist.  about another hour for the dessert souffle but between the wine and conversation the time flew.  Make sure you go with someone you love or atleast like and be prepared to have a couple of hours of chatter.  The strawberry souffle was light, airy, and the perfect balance of sweet and mildly tart which a strawberry should have.  (atleast in my opinion)  It was heaped with fresh sliced strawberries on top.  .  Food wise this is on of our top 5 meals we have ever had as a couple.  The waiter was what killed the meal for both of us.  We can deal with mediocre service if the food is superlative, which this was beyond a doubt.  But when the waiter is downright rude,  and smells like an old gym bag that has been allowed to ferment that's a deal breaker.  We won't be back.
author: Robert K.

description: The food is out of this world.  The onion soup brought tears to my eyes as it took me back to a vacation in Paris.  Please, please forget all of the reviews below that say the waiters are horrible.  NOT TRUE - they were very professional and they told jokes, told stories of the restaurant - they were engaging and wonderful. Please do not believe what some have said.  Jacqueline is full of love and gives love to her cooking.  She was cracking & separating eggs by herself in the kitchen and creating each souffle.  She had assistants, but it looked like she was creating the masterpieces herself.  It took 2 1/2 hours to eat there, but we were never rushed and the pacing was romantic & wonderful.  I highly recommend it.
author: Jeffrey L.

description:
I WANT TO SCREAM FROM THE MOUNTAIN TOPS, well at least the SF hill tops...

JACQUELINE, Vous tes un plaisir et je sais que chaque souffle a fait est un morceau de votre me effervescente!  Grands merci vous!

(Translation: You are a pleasure and I know that every souffle you make is a piece of your effervescent soul!)

First time visitors to this quintessential hole-in-the-wall need to simply indulge in dessert - specifically the chocolate souffle.  And maybe an accompanying glass of wine.  Taking only a few spoonfuls, I imagined that there were 16 eggs involved in the making of this masterpiece to garner its enormity and richness.  Upon learning of my 'egg-hypothesis,' Jacqueline advised my boyfriend that he shouldn't take me out shopping as I may be an expensive delight!  Ha ha ha...so it's only 4 eggs per souffle - can't a girl dream!

P.S.  They take reservations, so make one!  The place is small, seating is limited and it takes about 20-30 minutes to make each souffle!  Suggestion: Bring people with who you enjoy to converse!

Enjoy!
author: Sienna G.

description: What an incredibly special soufflé, what incredibly terrible service.  It's pretty much not worth it.  Madame Jacqueline is such a lovely person (meet her in the kitchen).  If I were to draft a business model for driving a wonderful business into the ground, it would include hiring the two guys managing the floor at Chez Jacqueline.  Tant pis!
author: Nancy G.

description:
oh, the green minty walls, the soft lighting, the high ceillings, the scent of egg and roses all wafting on a breeze from the open back door...I could write a little novelette about this place.  I felt like I was in Paris in a cloud....
really, I think we tried everything that night - champagne with cassis, a beautiful red, the pine nut and green salad (just solid enough for a starter, but light)...and speaking of light, there is the souffle - cauliflour and brie, broccoli and something else I can't remember, and then the chocolate with an espresso to finish.  I don't know how long we stayed but the waiter was so informative and kind that I felt like an honoured guest.   Go for a quiet night and then sleep like a baby (but not at your table, that's rude)
author: Catherine F.

description:
Don't come here if you don't like souffles. That being said, I'm not particularly a huge fan of souffles (they're a little too wet for my taste), but it was quite amazing. The dessert souffle was amazing and the french onion soup was to die for. The entree souffle was too wet for my taste, but I can see why someone would like it. 

Atmosphere was so cute and quaint too. A little old lady was there in the back making souffles and her husband walked in around closing time to pick her up =). It's cute, but it does make the wait time around 2 hrs for food.

Next time my bf and I do this, we will just stick to the french onion soup and dessert souffle.
author: Angela L.

description: My boyfriend took me here for my birthday a few months ago. AMAZING!! I had never had a souflee before and we splurged and got two one for dinner and one for dessert. Also french onion soup was to die for, as well as the salad. I loved the ambiance and I looooved the two servers. If anyone dosnt like them it is because you are just one of those annoying type of people who need someone to kiss your ass all the time. I highly suggest you try the place. Glad we read reviews about the wait and luckily gave me and my honey a chance to catch up :)
author: K H.

description: To sum it up so-so. My sister recommended this spot and she really likes it. Maybe I'm just not a breakfast for dinner sort of guy. At least that is what I think about soufflé. So if you are really into soufflé or want to try something different give it a shot. The onion soup was ok, not great, and the dessert soufflés were good not fantastic.  I did like the wine selection and the wait staff was very pleasant. I just don't see myself coming back here too often.
author: Rob M.

description:
Finally got to Cafe Jacqueline and sample the lovely souffles. They were excellent- light and full of flavor. The wait for the souffles was minimal- but were we there early in the night. Wait staff was pleasant, attentive and very helpful.

We had one dinner and one dessert (chocolate- yum!) souffle. We did not have any starters. We left well satisfied- just right.

Coupled with the great ambiance of the place- I heartily recommend it! Best to make a reservation.
author: kent L.

description:
Yummy! This place is super cute. There are only like 12 tables and you can chat up the owner/chef  and watch her make souffles. 

The onion soup is sooo good and the endive salad was really good too. We ordered the white corn, garlic and cheese souffle as well as the crab souffle. Loved the table-side serving. We ate every last drop in those bowls.

Also order the white chocolate souffle for dessert...amazing!

Definitely be prepared for a 2.5 hour dinner (service was a little slow and the waiter was a bit snippy with my mom when she mentioned we were on a timeline of under 3 hours, hence the 4 stars.) Also would recommend going with a group of 4 since each souffle serves 2 people - it's just more fun to try more than one. Also make a reservation, the place is so small, they really don't take any walk-ins.
author: elissa w.

description:
Romantic restaurant, good for date, especially dessert.

This place is pretty much for souffle only.
While the souffle is good, I personally think souffle is best for dessert.

The onion soup is the best I ever had, and the crunchy bread goes perfect with the soup.

If I come again, I might just order the onion soup and salad, then go straight to the dessert souffle.

Eating two souffle is just too much even for two people, and the main course souffle kinda ruin how good the dessert souffle is.
author: Jeff C.

description:
white corn and garlic; lobster; grand marnier!
irreverent waiter.  came w/ john
author: Derek T.

description:
I came here last year and it is definitely a nice spot for a romantic date. Low light and reasonable calm atmosphere make conversation easy and the food will definitely fill you up. I wasn't overwhelmed with the quality of the food despite the pleasant waiters or the friendly lady in the back putting them all together.

It's all souffles here. We had a salad, a cheese and broccoli entree to share and a massive chocolate one at the end which I think put me to sleep. Like I said, they were good - but nothing amazing and it was a tad pricey for what we had.

That being said I'd still recommend people go for the experience. Just set your expectations appropriately. ;-)
author: Aaron F.

description:
The most romantic restaurant I have found so far in the city. Yes the wait is a little long, but now you know that going in... so it is not an issue. And if you stop to think about WHY it is long, it just makes you appreciate the entire experience more. So go in the company of someone you enjoy spending time with, and relax and prepare yourself for an amazing treat. 

The negative reviews I have seen here are primarily due to what the writers deem as "bad" service. Well, I hate to be the bearer of bad news, but the Bay Area, as most of America sadly tends to be, is loaded with pretentious, arrogant snobs with an inflated sense of self-entitlement. Here, just like Europe, you will get what you give. If you come in here with an attitude or sense of entitlement, you are going to get it shoved back in your face. A trait that makes me love the place even more. 

The staff is down to earth and hilarious. I was entertained and the environment was so welcoming that even though it was my first time there, I felt like a regular or even a long-time personal friend of our waiter.

The food was divine. Unmatched. More than worth the wait.

This place is a treat, and I will be coming here for a special night out for many years to come. What a gem.
author: Scott K.

description:
When I first heard about this place where they only serve souffles:  I was excited!!! fluffy puffy warm moist delights!

My $30 chocolate souffle was fluffy, puffy, and moist alright, but it left me unsatisfied. Even though I shared it with 4 other people, the fact wasn't that I didn't get enough of it. HECK if I ate the whole thing by myself I still would've felt the same. It just wasn't filling, chocolatey, or mouth-watering enough as a dessert should be! some might argue that a souffle is suppose to be light since its pretty much just beaten eggs and sugar? but its chocolate!!!! chocolate is suppose to be rich! maybe im just not a souffle fan. or maybe it was also partially because of the horrible service I endured that cast a dark moody cloud over the romantically lit cafe which prevented me from enjoying my meal.

probably NEVER going back.... service here was dreadful! my friend made reservations for 10pm to have dessert, but he insisted we had made it for 9pm, so as soon as we walked in, he said we were late! and it looked like he wanted to refuse to serve us in their empty not even close to crowded cafe!!!! not only was this particular waiter rude! but he never once smiled or welcomed us from the moment we walked in. his face was wrinkled the whole night from his frowning. talk about a PMS-ing male waiter!!! the whole time i felt like he hated us and probably shat in our waters. he just made us feel like we were in trouble allllll night, for a mistake he made in messing up our reservation time!
author: Sue Y.

description:
We want here for my birthday yesterday and Cafe Jacqueline lived up to its top billing.  When people write about souffles, they really are talking about souffles.  Big, honking, leave you "stuffed" with French-exquisiteness souffles.  Yes, we are a Chinese couple, but after spending three hours at this establishment, we turned into a "oui."  

We had the French onion soup and soup du jour for starters.  Very, very good soups.  The French onion soup was a bit cheesy, but once you get into the soup-part, it's like drinking onion nectar.  Very delish.  A had a green bell pepper puree soup.  A said it was much better than split pea (he was referring to the fact that it looked like split pea soup).  

We shared the salmon and asparagus souffle.  It was ginormous.  As we were waiting (yes, it's quite a wait) for our entree souffle, we started noticing how big other people's souffle was.  It intimidated us, even A, whose stomach is elastic like Mr. Fantastic (like the rhyme?).  You can taste the protein (from the egg whites) oozing out of each savory bite.  A is not a fan of entree souffles, but he had to admit it was a good, filling meal.

We waited another hour for our dessert souffle-- chocolate.  A had never failed a dessert mission before!  But he did yesterday.  We left the dessert souffle 80% finished.  The dessert souffle needs to split at least three ways.  Two people CANNOT finish the dessert-- unless you're an eating champion of some sort.

The ambiance is very home-y.  If you're wondering about the "dressy" attire that it says in Yelp, don't worry... it's actually pretty casual.  Wear a nice pair of designer jeans with some Diesels and you should be fine.  Just don't come in after a 45-min jog in Asics and a sports bra.

Bottom line: long wait, but a quality meal.  Parking is horrible, but that's with any restaurant in North Beach.  Expect to pay at least $100 for two people (without wine).
author: Kel S.

description:
I've been to this restaurant several times and, I have to say, it's one of my favorites. You feel like you are in another time and place - like Paris circa 1945 (due to the war torn views of North Beach through the gigantic plate glass windows.) The concept is so unique. The food is all amazing. The grandma in the kitchen with her stand mixer, freshly chopped herbs, slabs of cheese, and grand daddy bowl of eggs is like out of a movie or something. The atmosphere is very romantic and it's fun to hang out on the back patio in between courses on a warm evening. The service takes time to appreciate. At first, I thought that the one waiter that we always seem to get was a total jacka$$. He seemed snobby. But, after a while and upon more visits, he's cool enough and can recommend some great wines. 

Dinner at Cafe Jacqueline takes longer than a dinner at French Laundry. At first, I was starving, which leads to anger. But then I realized that I am in Paris, it's 1945, and I am getting a custom made souffle that's the size of a basketball for dinner, made by some grandma in the back. She makes it with love, and that takes time.
author: Leah A.

description:
After hearing about how you can expect to spend 3 hours here during dinner, I realized it was a risky choice as a date spot but figured that it would be a good red light-green light indicator. We ordered the spinach goat cheese salad, brie & broccoli souffle, and strawberry souffle. Everything was delicious and lived up to expectations. 

I spoke to Jacqueline herself as I walked through the kitchen on my way to the bathroom. She's a sweet French lady who has been there for 30 years. When I asked how she was doing, she said, "I cracked a lot of eggs tonight!" 

Since I was with someone who was good about keeping up conversation, hardly noticed any waiting time. Green light.
author: Tony P.

description:
I love this place. This place is very unique with their suffles. Dessert suffles are amazing. Try something with seasonal fruits. 

For some reason I can't rate 5 here. Food is definitely 5 but service and coffee would be 2. 

Service - Everytime I go there, I am so flustrated with the poor attitude of one waiter person. I've been here several times and served by him. He never smiles at us. He takes our order in a tone of belligerence. He never says "Thank you" when we paid. Overall, he is so rude. 
Also service at this restaurant is very slow. Visit here when you are not in a rush.

Coffee - Don't order coffee if you visit here for late time  i.e.9 pm.  It tastes as if it's been boiled for all day long. Have some wine here, and go to Cafe Trieste if you need some coffee.
author: Yoko S.

description:
We really enjoyed our experience.  Yes, our dinner took over 2 hours which we had no complaints about.  It really was a treat to enjoy a nice long dinner after a hectic day of work.  It's nice not to go to a restaurant where your waiter stops at your table every 5 minutes.  Or places where they rush you on your meal so they can seat others.  

The bread was nice and warm.  We shared the french onion soup - so good that I had to scrape off the cheese from the side of the bowl.  We had the prosciuotto (sp?) and mushroom souffle and ended with the white chocolate souffle.  Very filling dinner. experience.  Went straight to sleep after we got home.  We'd definitely come back.
author: Johannah P.

description:
Here's a little heads up... this is a place where time is not important at all. It took us 3 hrs to complete the dinner. For the whole three hours, we witness endless rejections and "come back later" to other patrons who eagerly awaits for their seating.  But this is all understandable cause Souffle does take a long time to make. 
Here's a break down of the night

Food:
1) Onion soup - very tasty and savory
2) Fruit De Mar Souffle- very cheesy crust but a tad salty. Still pretty good.
3) Salmon and Asparagus Souffle- sounds gross but it's very tasty

4) Peach Souffle- OMG! I was kicking myself when I had this because I lost three hours waiting for all the other dishes when I could have just ordered this instead. This dish is really really good because it is not super sweet and very fragrant. From what I can tell, they used Fresh white peach, Peach schnapps and peach skin. The crust was perfect! I was actually finding myself scratching the sides of the corning ware for the crumbs and pieces. :P 

Service:
Just think you are actually eating in Paris and you won't be offended cause the waiters certainly has some attitude. I guess they were just trying to make us feel like we are in Paris.. that's all.
author: Hubert C.

description: Little treasure on Grant Street.  I loved everything about this place.  Food was exceptional.....Lemon souffle was too good for words, and the escorgot was phenomenal.  Staff is attentive and makes great wine suggestions. Will definately go back!!
author: Donna W.

description:
I've only been here for dessert.
We as a group of 4 shared the Souffle.  It's good and decent seize for 4 people as a dessert.  If the price is little bit cheaper, I would rate 4 stars, and if the waiter was nicer, I would rate 5 stars.
But the souffle is very good so if you've never tried, it's good to try at least once.  
Oh, but don't ever never go there when you don't have time.  it will take about 40 min. after you order since it will be made after you order.
author: Ringo T.

description:
I am a sucker for souffles so I absolutely loved this place.  I even surprised myself by enjoying the savory one more then the sweet.   

We tried the french onion soup to start, only because I love love love french onion soup but I was a bit disappointed and will skip it next time.  Ordering two souffles (savory and sweet) for two people is a lot of food anyway.  If you do want to start with something light a salad is probably a better idea.  For the souffles we went with the waitor's recommendation which was to order the basic savory souffle since it was our first time there and it was amazing.  For dessert we had the chocolate which too was really delicious but next time I am going to try the Grand Marnier.

If you are going to check it out do give yourselves plenty of time as we were there for 3 hours.
author: Liz D.

description:
This restaurant is best described with one word: romantic.

Every night they set up each table with a singular red rose and a candle. Jacqueline, with vigor belying her age, starts breaking the eggs and the waiters work on their French charm.

This restaurant exclusively serves souffles, and oh my are they delicious. I'll allow that I'm no  souffle expert, but I do know what I taste and what I tasted there was wonderful. They serve a variety of types: seafood, meat, fruit, and of course the obligatory chocolate.

Don't come here on a first date. The romantic pressure would be overwhelming. Cafe Jacqueline is also not a terribly good family restaurant as the atmosphere is very quiet. There is no valet, so leave plenty of time for parking. And be sure to have a reservation!
author: Keith C.

description:
It's definably a 3-hour dinner but it's worthy of the wait if it's the first time experience.  Some people walked in and out for phone calls and even buying lottery cross street.  Some people just kept talking or doing fun games.    No complaining is the norm here.

We had the pepper soup of the day instead of the regular French onion soup.  It came pretty fast and also didn't disappoint us.  We had the simple salad of butter lettuce.  It's not fancy but we're sure the veggies came from quality source and well preserved by the cafe and tossed in dedicated hands.
