Bf ordered the spinach souffle.  It's light, but full of flavor.  That's the longest wait during the whole night.  The portion was good for 2 - 3 people sharing if you want to save room for dessert.

They ran out of every special dessert choice early in the evening already.  Maybe everyone opt for the specials since they're not commonly found in other places.  So we ordered the lemon on the regular menu since the chocolate and Grand Marnier souffle were not new to us.  After first bite, I no longer regret missing the special menu b/c it was SO good.  Light + Refreshing....


During the wait, we enjoyed the simple cafe design.  The long stem roses in glass bottle against the green wall really reminded me of petite street cafe in France.

I think it's a good place for its souffle dessert if we would like to skip 2.5 hour wait.  Actually many customers came for dessert only and we glad that the restaurant had no problem for it.
author: Ile F.

description:
[PRO]
-Good-sized portions
-Prosciutto and Mushroom Soufflé (rich, delectable blend of complimentary flavors)
-Peach Soufflé (light, fluffy; more than enough for two)
-Fresh, hot, toasted, fluffy sliced baguette

[CON]
-Aggressive service
-Slow food preparation

[UNIQUE]
-Diverse selection of large, luscious soufflés
-Jacqueline cooking with a copious basket full of eggs in the open kitchen, visible on the walk to the restroom
author: Annie K.

description: A special evening required special food...and that is where Cafe Jacqueline enters the scene.  Everytime we come, we never leave unhappy.  The savory souffles are amazing.  They are perfectly good with the most amazing flavours.  Be sure to order the white chocolate souffle with white chocolate coins on top.  We were not disappointed (usually get the fresh fruit souffle).  So our dinner:  starters were butter lettuce salad - so simple yet so flavourful.  French onion soup - to DIE for.  the broth is perfectly seasoned.  Shared the asparagus and salmon and ended the meal with white chocolate souffle.  be sure to go in back to see Madame.  She is pretty special...so is her cafe.
author: Sonia C.

description:
This place is charming and terribly romantic.  I love everything on the menu from the escargot to the creative dessert souffles.  I also enjoy seeing Jaqueline beating a large bowl of eggs as you walk through the kitchen to the restroom.  She always has a welcoming smile and greets you with a cheerful "Bon Jour" and "Merci". 

Sweet and tucked away in the streets of North Beach.  Don't forget to make a reservation or plan to arrive early in the evening or you won't be dining at Cafe Jacqueline.  Also remember to ask for wine suggestions.
author: Moto L.

description:
Cafe Jacqueline is the perfect place for an "occasion"...anniversary, birthday, something special.  

Their soufles are something special and a treat!  We love the gruyere cheese soufle or the fruit de mare (seafood) soufle for the main course and the chocolate soufle for dessert.  

They have a great wine list but made a face when we brought our own special botter for our wedding anniversary.  We also ordered a bottle of their wine but were glad we had our own stash.  This place is SUPER yum!  Parking sucks so you could valet at Mooses which is a block away.  

The food is 5 star but I gave a 4 b/c the ambiance could use a little help...it is dark in there and candle lit so it isn't that bad but they could use a little help with thier dusting and cleaning and some interior design.  The FOOD is awesome and the place is definately romantic.  I have NEVER had better soufle - not even in Paris.
author: Super Star S.

description:
Just went here for a belated Valentine's Day dinner.  The service was very doting and the staff very nice.  We had one waiter who kept joking that there "seemed to be a dark cloud" over our table...maybe we seemed a bit serious whenever he walked by?...either way, I kind of felt like he broke the 4th wall or something.  I want to feel anonymous when I am out with my honey...

The food was awesome and we had a lot of fun trying new things.  The lobster souffle and the chocolate souffle were both really great.  We also had the onion soup--sooo good--and the endive with roquefort salad--also yum.
author: Mr. And Mrs. G.

description:
Without doubt the place deserves full 5 stars. I was compelled to take the last star off for the service. 
Too many reviewers have commented on the service and my experience was just the same. When the waiter first came to our table to take our order, we said - this is our first time here and need a little help deciding. The rude a$$h0le just walked away. Anyway, I managed to keep my cool. 
Anyway, the food and madame Jacqueline herself are simply awesome!
We ordered the onion soup to begin with - was superb!
White corn+ginger+garlic souffle - was superb!
Strawberry souffle - was superb!
We went to say hi to Jacqueline when we were done with the entree and were waiting for our dessert. She is so warm and charming - grandmotherly loving! She told us she moved to this country - first to NY - in 1958. Lived there for some time, but hated the snow. Then moved to Hawaii for 5 years. She's been making souffles at Cafe Jacqueline for the past 32 years now!
Anyway, most of the points to be aware of this place have been mentioned several times by several reviewers:
a) Souffles are extremely "eggy". Jacqueline told us the entree souffle has 3 eggs and the desert souffle we ordered had 4. 
b) One souffle easily serves three people. 
c) They are pricey. 
d) The service is not good. 
e) Jacueline is an extremely affectionate grandmotherly lady and pours a lot of love into the souffles.
author: Aniket D.

description:
Gentlemen -- 10x the effect of my Rotunda Room sitting strategy recommendation. Guaranteed love or lurvin. As you approach the restaurant you cannot help but feel you're peeking in on couples immersed in sweet conversation. Creative lighting transforms the crowded table arrangements into a sea of tiny islands. 

Oh so lovely. Shared a spinach salad drizzled with olive oil, toasted pine nuts that had just a hint of mustard and bacon in the mix. The chanterelle mushroom and garlic souffle was mouthwatering. Unfortunately, my PMS callings steered my focus to the half-eaten chocolate souffle at the next table over, drowning out my 'is-this-a-date-or-hangout-dinner' companion's thoughts on one of the special election propositions.

Such a quietly magical place, you'll either end up visiting the pleasure palace or proposing...so keep your wits about you.
author: Tanya P.

description: Awesome, Awesome, Awesome!!! Had an incredible lobster souffle for dinner and strawberry souffle for dessert. I was lucky enough to get last minute reservations for this place while on vacay in S.F. and no regrets.... not even after getting the bill. A definite must if you ever get a chance.
author: Jacquie L.

description:
Me to my friend-"Go to the bathroom?"
Friend-"What? I dont have to go"
Me-"No, really. GOOO to the bathroom"

This bathroom trip is a MUST when you come here. You get the amazing opportunity to see the huge bowl of eggs and Jacqueline whipping and whipping and whipping to make here amazing souffle. We had an onion one with tons of yummy cheese. Spinach salads, and a fresh strawberry souffle for dessert. Be prepared for a long meal. Because they are all made to order, it takes a while. I truly didnt mind. It was a very enjoyable meal. Yeah, its a but pricey, but honestly this is NOT the place to go to for an everyday meal. You come here for a special occasion.
author: Spencer N.

description:
Not a light meal by any stretch of the imagination.

Been hearing a lot about this souffle-only joint in North Beeyotch.
You gotta walk through a lot of tourist traps, frat boys, and bar-fly skanks to get to Cafe Jacqueline, but the voyage is worth it.

You might not think souffles are very filling considering they're mostly air, but these suckers are RICH and totally wiped us out.  Wifey and I ordered an oddball (but tasty) oyster, spinich, and garlic souffle as our entree followed by the white chocolate coronary killer to finish the job.

Deeee-lish!

The setting is cozy but make sure to bring some reading material, a nintendo DS, or someone more interesting than my wifey as the wait can be REALLLLY LOOOOONG... they make your souffles to order, after all.
author: Gracie-C Y.

description:
Soooo delicious. Yes, it can take a long time, but that's to be expected since the kitchen is essentially a one woman show. 
Be sure to go to the bathroom..you'll walk right through the kitchen, and you can see everything that's going on, as well as the HUGE bowl of eggs that go into the delicious souffles. YUM!
author: Brianne K.

description:
AMAZING! We had the broccoli brie souffle and the lemon souffle for dessert (washed down with a bottle of wine, of course). I completely expected that it would be so rich that I'd barely be able to eat it -- and I was so, so wrong. We ate pretty much all of it!

The service was perfect! Attentive without being annoying, friendly and sophisticated without being snooty. The atmosphere was cozy and romantic and the time flew right by.

And yes, if you do go to the restroom, make sure you check out the enormous basket of eggs in the kitchen.

I would absolutely come back here. In fact, if the thought of consuming that many eggs in a lifetime wasn't so horrifying, I might even want to come eat here every day. Yum!
author: Tamara M.

description: We had one of the most disappointing restaurant experiences ever in August at Café Jacqueline. From the moment we walked in the door the head waiter was surly, greeting us with a frown and suggesting he couldn't find our reservation (until he did.... but it was a very unfriendly welcome). We had had to call three times for a reservation ourselves - got a call back a week later. We heard the waiter apologizing on the phone to several people for "losing their reservations", which suggests that no one had been manning the phones carefully, As we were very hungry we asked for bread and got no response for quite some time despite being the only patrons there for an hour and a half. While we were willing to wait an hour for a dinner soufflé, we ended up waiting 2 and 1/2 hours from the time we ordered for our dessert soufflé, which only arrived after we complained twice. It was totally uncooked, resembling tepid scrambled eggs with cold peaches in the middle. When we complained to the waiter he didn't even acknowledge our presence. It was a high price for a meal that was memorable for the wrong reasons. We concluded that Jacqueline must spend August in France.
author: Martha A.

description:
After wanting to for months, my boyfriend and I finally had dinner here last night. Cafe Jacqueline is a charming little French place tucked away in North Beach. After reading some of the Yelp reviews, I was concerned that our servers were going to be rude but they were very friendly and gracious. They took our coats and even remembered which ones belonged to us when we left.

For starters, we had the French onion soup. It was good but nothing exceptional. Hot, oniony, appropriately cheesy. 

Then came our corn, ginger, and garlic souffle. I've never had a real souffle before and wasn't sure what to expect. The top part of the souffle is much saltier, tinged with burnt cheese, and has almost a popcorn consistency to it. The innards of the souffle are pale, soft and fluffy, almost like "hot angel food cake" (my boyfriend's assessment) and tasted like corn-y egg scramble. I normally dislike ginger but didn't mind its presence here. It went well with the corn and garlic and the overall lightness of our souffle. I'm no souffle expert but I decided that I liked it enough to eat it again. 

The best part of our meal was definitely the lemon souffle. Huge and covered in a snow of powdered sugar and lemon zest, it was like eating a hot lemon cloud. It was just sweet enough and there was molten lemon curd at the bottom for even more sugary goodness. Be careful with all the powdered sugar, though. Both of us experienced small coughing fits from inhaling.

We arrived at 6:05 and were out at 8:30. It is an intimate little place with dim lights and roses in a heart-shaped vase at your table. Don't come here with someone you can't talk to for two and a half hours. Also, the portions are really for two people so plan to share. 

Overall it was a very pleasant experience. I will definitely go back to try the other dessert souffles. I don't eat crab but the crab souffle is #61 on 7x7's "100 Things to Try Before You Die". Probably worth checking out for you seafood lovers.
author: Annie C.

description:
My mom always taught me that if you cook with love, you don't need a recipe. I've had my share of homestyle cooking, but nothing's come close to Jacqueline. The decor feels southern French, somewhere around the Rhone valley. Everything feels so personal, as if your aunt decided to open a restaurant in her den.

The wine list is hand selected and its inconstancies are absolutely charming. Yes, you read that right. You can tell it was formed by a wine lover, not a professional sommelier (which normally would deduct stars, but in a setting this homey, it feels necessary. You wouldn't dare fault your aunt for favoring Chablis over Pinot Gris, would you?). It's almost as though certain vineyards didn't make the list because their solicitors just weren't "nice" to Jacqueline. At least that how I imagine it.

Onto the food, which really needs no more description than most Yelpers have already gone to say. Everything is cooked to perfection, and if you get curious, just walk through the kitchen en route to the rest room and say hello to Jacqueline. I highly recommend the cauliflower souffle, ask to have a bit of garlic in there, and if feeling adventurous you can also substitute brie for the standard gruyere.

You cannot skimp out on dessert. Even if it means you win the North Beach fatty award, you simply must get the chocolate souffle. Or whatever souffle is the special of the evening. Man, just thinking about it invokes the pavlovian response in my brain, I best stop typing before the keyboard starts looking tasty and chocolate covered..
author: Tal K.

description:
Great romantic place.  The food is five stars, parking is difficult on most nights, but I have gotten rock star parking once there.

Don't go here for a first date... the souffles take a fair amount of time and you can have the long awkward pauses without something to shove in your pie hole.

But, it is a perfect third date place.  They waitstaff is very friendly, and the dessert souffles are great.  Try to safe room for one.  You won't be disappointed.

Maybe try to get a table away from the door as during the colder months it seemed a little chilly with the door opening and closing.
author: Will A.

description: Crap this place was expensive. I had never eaten souffle before until I came here; and I ordered the crab souffle. It was really cheesy and didn't taste all too great. The thing that won me over was their white chocolate souffle that I had for dessert. I think I spent around $100 on those two items and it was just for me and my girlfriend. It's good, but not that good.
author: Nathaniel C.

description:
Excellent selection of French wines at reasonable prices ($30-60).
Jacqueline herself makes all the souffles.  She's really sweet, and you can chat with her in the open kitchen while she's working.  (helps if you know some french).  She told me she's been doing this for 32 years!
All souffles are made to order, which means there's a bit of a wait, but then again, you're getting the ultimate in freshness.
The waiters are a bit eccentric. 
The only main course choices are ... souffles!  We had soup, salad, and then a dessert souffle.  This was enough if you prefer to eat lightly.  The salads were fresh and tasty.  The soups were good. 
If you're starving, and you don't want to have souffle for main course, you might want to just come here for dessert. 
The souffle style here, as others have mentioned, is a very light airy and dry center.  I prefer this to the gooey style.  Would be even better if they came with some sauce to pour over.
This restaurant is not trying to be everything to everyone.  It's a truly unique place, fueled by one woman's love of making souffles.
author: David M.

description:
Last Night, Friday the 2ed of Oct, I was with friends and we had 8:30 reservations ..we arrived and I must say IT WAS THE WORST RESTAURANT EXPERIENCE I HAVE EVER EXPERIENCED IN MY LIFE.
We did not get our dinner until 11:00 our salad was served 45 minutes after we arrived and dinner nearly 3 hours.......the waiter should have told us....we would have left......when the food finally arrived, we were exhausted, stressed, furious, and than it was HORRIBLE.....dishes were salty and tasted similar, they were really awful, we canceled desert when we found out that was going to be more much more time.  I had been there before and was excited to share with out of town friends but unfortunately  it turned out to be a disaster, ruined the weekend, today exhausted and beat up from the evening did I mention expensive, it was!
author: Maria D.

description: Cafe Jacqueline is the show! Plan on 3 plus hours with a great conversationist for a unique food experience. You won't be disappointed.
author: Sharayn F.

description: we have dined there twice in the last ten years for our birthday and anniversary.    We were there in June and i still can not stop thinking about the Lime souffle.  It was to die for.  Jacqueline is always in the kitchen.  You can definitely taste the love.  Would recommend it for any occasion.   Jacqueline rules!!!!!!
author: lisa r.

description: The heavy hand with  salt flawed both the onion soup and the cauliflower soufflé. Our complaint was met with disinterest by two different waiters.  Pricey and disappointing.
author: rose k.

description:
Very small, quiet and quant.  A place where people speak softly and take their time through dinner, enjoying every course and the experience of dining itself.  The perfect place for a romantic dinner out, you can even dress up if you choose.  

The soufflé's are delicious even for those that don't particularly love soufflé.  Make sure to save room for the dessert Soufflé, as these are the best.  We have actually gone and only had dessert Soufflé b/c they are just so good!  If you get a chance step back into the kitchen and say hello to Chef Jacqueline, she is very sweet and friendly.
author: Rosie C.

description:
My fiance has lived in North Beach for 13 years, and I am the lucky girl who he has been waiting for to:
a) ask to marry
b) take to Cafe Jacqueline

The food was fabulous...the onion soup was decadent.  I swear I was chewing my spoon there was so much yummy, gooey cheese on it with every sip.  We had the corn and ginger souffle, and it was so incredible.  I was really looking forward to a nice cup of coffee to enjoy with the chocolate souffle, but that's where this review drops to 4 stars.

We waited about 10 minutes before our waiter brusquely served us water and gave us menus.  After he took our orders, it was about 45 minutes until we got our starters.  We slooowly enjoyed them, knowing that souffles take a lot of time to bake to perfection.  After another hour, we're ordering more wine, and gently asking about the status of our entree.  "It takes 45 minutes to make a souffle, so we must be patient."  Hmph.  It came out moments later, and it was great.  OMG, but wait!  Are we going to have to wait another hour for dessert?  I am already SO sleepy.  Our waiter let us know that it will be a while longer for the dessert, so we can opt out if we'd like.  We did, and I wasn't able to enjoy what I was most looking forward to.  Will maybe have to do another stop here just to get dessert.
author: Karen C.

description:
French Onion soup: a bit on salty side which drown out the onion sweetness

Shiitake, basil, garlic : wow tasty.. can't get enough of the crusts

Yellow peaches: even bigger portion than entree souffle..  yummy
author: Agustinus T.

description: My husband and I love Cafe Jacqueline. We come here to celebrate special events in our lives. The ambiance is the most romantic in the city and the food, of course, is delicious every time. We like both the waiters very much, even the one everyone thinks is so crabby. He's actually very nice, just a little rough around the edges. And, even when he's crabby, he's our crab and we love him. :)
author: Penelope T.

description:
I don't know, I'm so conflicted. The service was rude to start, almost shockingly so, but we ordered some nice wines (very necessary for the wait) and sat it out. By the time we were the last ones in the restaurant, our server was positively jovial. 

 Souffle is, I admit, not a favorite of mine but I was prepared to like what has been touted as the best souffle on the West Coast. And....
honestly, I thought it was soooo salty. However, the spinach salad and french onion soup (which was vegetarian!!) were amazing. The strawberry dessert souffle was good. Yes, just good. 

Warning: the soup is served so f-ing hot that a week later I swear my tongue is still raw. Once it cooled (and I resumed sensation in my mouth), it was delicious. Still ... my favorite parts of a surprisingly expensive meal were the salad and the soup. Hmmm....
author: Michelle M.

description:
Sweet Jesus! Jacqueline is the best, most friendly chef. I visited Cafe Jacqueline for the first time last night and it was my friend's treat. We went all out and had a great time joking with the two cute, smart waiters who gave us a great Pinot Blanc recommendation and then (thankfully) convinced us to have port with our chocolate souffle. 

We had the watercress & cucumber salads, respectively, which were nicely balanced, fresh, and refreshingly simple--the taste depended entirely on the quality of the watercress/cucumber, and on the balancing act of the dressing. 

We also had the white corn/ginger/garlic souffle, and though I had a little beef with the way the corn seperated from the rest of the souffle, it was a very nice harmony of flavors, not too sweet or too grassy from the ginger. 

And for dessert my friend, who has been there before, insisted we get the chocolate souffle which--no offense, mom--blew my mother's chocolate souffe out of the water. Light, super moist, runny in the middle. Oh_my_god. 

Even with the orgasmic result of the chocolate souffle, I still want to try the lime souffle next time.
author: Caroline C.

description:
Salut!
Merci bien a Jacqueline! Vos souffles sont "le bomb."

Pour l'anniversaire de mon ami, nous sommes alles toujour a Cafe Jacqueline. Comme d'habitude, l'ambiance est parfait.

A bientot!

En anglais....:
Hello -
Thanks so much to Jacqueline! Your souffles are "the bomb."

For my friend's birthday, we always go to Cafe Jacqueline. Like always, the ambiance was perfect. See you soon!
author: dj z.

description:
A romantic, quaint souffle restaurant. The owner and chef can be seen with a huge bowl of eggs in her kitchen as you pass it to use the loo.

I came here with 2 girlfriends for dinner. We shared 2 savory souffles and 1 dessert souffle. We were surprised how filling the savory souffles were. They were good, but not as special as the dessert souffles.  We agreed that next time we come, it would hopefully be for a romantic dessert with our significant other.
author: vicki c.

description:
My significant other and I came early to this place for parking (it's north beach so parking can be real tough) and because we've heard others recommending reserving in advance.  We didn't have time to make reservations so we got there right when they opened (at 5:30pm) and were immediately seated (I guess for a bigger party you would need reservations but surprisingly the place was NOT crowded at all for a Saturday nite, but then again, who really goes out to dinner at 5:30?).  Keep in mind that there are 2 waiters for 10 tables but we got pretty good waiting service.  Our glasses of water was always full!

The bread was nice and warm-right out of the oven!  The souffles are made fresh from scratch.  The minute you order your food, you see a cute old woman in the back with a chef hat cracking the eggs and rolling bread!  You should definitely order some appetizers or salad while waiting for your souffle, but it is definitely worth the wait!  We ordered the Shiitake, Basil and Garlic-which is yummy and perfect for a party of two.  I couldn't really taste the mushroom or garlic but my partner did.

My favorite was the chocolate souffle which was oozing with warm chocolate inside!  We were stuffed from the bread, salad and SBG souffle so we didn't finish our dessert and took half of it home.  I must say that the chocolate souffle was also VERY GOOD cold.  It was like eating a chocolate mousse cake.  I would definitely come here again to try different souffles!

BTW, I noticed that some people have mentioned this as a "date" place but I want to mention that I saw a family of 3 and a group of 4 female friends at the restaurant.

Also I want to mention that there are a few bars on the same street that look pretty cool.  There's a bar right next door that had a live band playing jazz music so that was neat.
author: Hanh L.

description:
So, definitely a good place to go if you've got a few things on your hands: time and money.  I was pleasantly surprised with the quality of service and food, but quite taken aback by the price tag at the end of the night.  

I would highly recommend a reservation, as it fills up quite quickly (especially on weekends)...
author: Kalie M.

description:
French onion soup--one of the best I've ever had. Lobster pot pie & mushroom/proscuitto souffle--divine. Strawberry souffle--dreamy!

My friends and I had a great dinner here...I wish we'd only ordered one entree souffle so that we'd have more room for dessert. And Jacqueline is super cute.

The waiter is a bit of a caricature but it adds to the charm of the restaurant. I can't wait to go back.
author: L N.

description:
YUMMY!!! Boyfriend and I wanted to try something different, and Cafe Jacqueline was the place.  Our waiter was nice and attentive.  The food was fantastic!!!  It was one of the BEST FRENCH ONION SOUP I have ever tasted!!!  The savory, cheesy, lobster souffle was DEE - LI - CIOUS!!!  It was a bit on the salty side due to the cheese, but pairing it with the wine made it wow!!!  

My favorite was the dessert.  We tried the seasonal peach fruit souffle.YUMMY!!  I highly recommend!!
author: Carrie-C N.

description:
The definitive Bay Area destination for soufflé, but also for a very savory French onion soup. What's great is that the chef uses an onion base, rather than beef or chicken broth. I would guess the onions were roasted for an eternity to get such a rich broth. Whatever the technique, it's a great twist on an old classic.

We tried three soufflés: two at dinner, and we brought one home for the next day. All were prepared in a meticulous manner, with the crab soufflé having generous amounts of crab. The Grand Marnier soufflé stood out as the most memorable, so good that I would likely forsake dessert at other Telegraph Hill restaurants to make the after-dinner trip here. It'd be worth the wait (plus the soufflé is so filling, you'd likely need the preparation time to rejuvenate your appetite).

The prosciutto/mushroom soufflé stood up well overnight in the fridge and tasted wonderful cold for brunch the next day. 

As others have noted, make this the main event for an evening as it takes time preparing soufflés to order.
author: Darrin K.

description:
My boy has been telling me about this place for 5 years.  At long last, I got to experience it for myself when he surprised me  with reservations for my birthday.  You would think that 5 years of hype would have to disappoint, but no.  It was great. 

We split the spinach & goat cheese salad and onion soup.  OH MY GOD that soup is off the hook.  Then we had a mushroom & prosciutto souffle, followed by the chocolate dessert souffle.  *sigh*  Getting weepy just thinking about how excellent it all was.  

It's true that this place only has one item: souffle.  And, that particular dish takes a very long time to prepare.  (In fact, you order your dinner and dessert at the same time.)  But if you only made one thing for your entire culinary career, I bet you'd be good at it too.   

Our waiter was very nice and helpful, recommending wine to compliment our meal.  He was attentive and knowledgeable and had a good sense of humor. 

Prepare to spend 3 hours here.  If you like the person you go there with, that shouldn't be a problem.  I personally think it's great for a date.  I would send anyone there without hesitation.
author: Gaping F.

description:
We've eaten here once, and remember it as a most exceptional experience.  Cannot add to what you read in these reviews except to add another "Five Stars" and concur.
The dessert souffle are simply the best you may ever enjoy, and the atmosphere unique.  Oui; the servers act French (or ze try) and yet it adds to the experience.  As in Paris, if you're pleasant and subtle to them you get the same back.  Sure it can be slow, but this is a romantic restaurant.   Savor......
author: Jon R.

description: It's worth the wait! That atmosphere is very intimate, the food is nothing short of superb, the service is nice...everything is just perfect. This is easily one of my favorite restaurants of all time. This place is ideal for dates too and every time I've been here someone was getting proposed to.  Go early and take a stroll around North Beach and Washington Square park after.
author: Chris W.

description:
So rich, SO fresh, so savory. This place is intimate, as there are only about 8 tables, a few of which seat 4 people, the rest seat two.

Jacqueline herself, the French cook in her early 70s I'd guess, is back in the small kitchen making all the souflets herself!!

The french bread is delic, great wine selection.
AMAZING! Worth the wait!
author: Sarah B.

description:
The food here is fantastic. Hands down the best Souffle we've ever had. The reason why I give two stars (after my second visit) is because our experience last night was quite possibly the worst service I've ever received. Our waiter was rude, inconsiderate and he decided to tell us "you're confused about the type of wine you like" after I asked for a recommendation. He did not only come off like a complete jerk when failing to recommend a bottle but when I asked which bottle he was referring to on the menu he feverishly pointed at the menu and gave up by saying "oh I'm not really sure". He walked away, came back a moment later with a glass and said "here taste it"... Had it not been our early valentines day dinner I would have walked out. 

Sure maybe he had a bad night, maybe he caught his girlfriend in bed with some other waiter or maybe he's just normally like that but I will forever deem this place as the worst service I've ever encountered. Mr. attitude you need to re-attend the class on waiter etiquette 101.

Jacqueline...Step out of the kitchen, read the other postings listed here in regards to *some* of your wait staff...

In all fairness the older gentleman waiter that served us on our last visit was delightful and very knowledgeable and gave the same service last night when serving the table next to us.
author: Joshua T.

description:
See that picture up there...yes, that one at the top of your screen...that is the Chocolate souffle and it is a small little bit of heaven, melting away in your mouth! 

Phenomenal! The place is somewhat expensive, but the souffles are HUGE and definitely recommended. It is such a cute little place, it's almost like you left SF and went to Paris. I loved it! Such a romantic little place....

Try it....I guarantee you won't be disappointed!
author: Lindsay C.

description:
I love this place.  Souffles are soooooooooo good.  Limited supply each day.  Souffles bigger than your face.  Definitely very very romantic.  So unless you are really into your date, I don't recommend you bringing them there.

One of the most memorable experiences.
author: Helen C.

description:
If i were going just for dessert, CJ would get the full 5 star spectacular.

BUT, we went for the complete dinner with the savory souffles and all. And it was nice, I would give it 3.5, but I just wasn't blown away. 

We started with the french onion soup, which was decent, very classic with the oozy cheese. We had the lobster souffle, which sounds amazing no? Not particularly .. it wasn't light or fluffy, it was a little heavy on the salt and cheese. We also got the special, mushroom and leek? The fact that I don't remember just means it wasn't memorable. They were definitely unique, where else in SF can you get savory souffles the size of your head? Just weren't total joy in my mouth. 

The serious punches came out with dessert -- we got the grand marnier souffle. It was TO DIE FOR. Hands down the best souffle I've had in the Bay Area. 

There was a $20 corkage, but they have a pretty decent wine list. 

Beware, this is also a sloooowww dinner. It's lovely, cozy, but definitely bring someone you can converse with easily or the awkward silences over 3 hours will kill you slowly. 


Overall, it's totally worth a try, but I'm sticking with dessert runs from now on.
author: Subie C.

description:
I only get one thing here as well and thats the souffle. To die for and I never eat souffle. This place is a very little tucked away restaurant in North Beach, but if you truly know and love the city, you will truly know and love Cafe Jacqueline. The owner bakes the souffles herself. This very old, very sweet lady who just spends her whole time back there cracking eggs and baking souffles. The epitome of old world Europe of learning one trait and then mastering it.

Such a romantic place. Only candle lit ambience. Try and get the table by the window. Its the only one and the most desirable (Just like Nob Hill Cafe).
author: Xavier P.

description: Just went again last night! It was amazing... the best onion soup, period. The Grand Marnier souffle had this depth of flavor that my wife and I were just mesmerized by... not to mention that they have Condrieu on the wine list! Cheers!
author: Edgar P.

description:
The onion soup was delicious, the gruyere/tomato/basil/garlic souflee was perfect, the chocolate souflee was amazing!

So the food was good.  The service was so-so.  The waiter was very attentive at first but I felt he had a condescending attitude.  Then toward the latter half of the meal we had to shoot off a signal flair to get attention even though the place is tiny with only 10 tables or so.

The meal took about three hours start to finish but that's what we expected going in.  It was very relaxing and unhurried which gave plenty of time for conversation.

I recommend using the bathroom while you're there because it's in an outside courtyard and you have to walk through the kitchen past an ENORMOUS bowl of eggs and you get to see the chefs slicing up the ingredients.  Kind of a cool behind-the-scenes tour.

The dishes were quite expensive but the flavor, texture, and presentation makes it worth it for an every-once-in-a-while experience.

The quality of the food and the unmistakable feeling of eating in a San Francisco landmark (30 years there with Jacqueline at the helm) make this a solid four-star review.
author: Xander M.

description:
Unbelievable food and ambiance and a reasonable price for the amount of food and the love and care that goes into each souffle.

By the way, all they really serve here is souffles.  Not souflees.  Not souflles.  Just souffles.
author: Frankie D.

description:
Small restaurant, very romantic but even if you go with a friend like a did you don't feel weird at all. Especially when they roll out the menu of souffles. We had the mushroom and prosciutto souffle which was divine. Be sure to order salads and soups beforehand as the souffles do take some time. But its so worth the wait. Chocolate souffle was magnifique. 

One chef was in the house, which I believe was Jacqueline herself. Two waiters so be patient. We felt very well taken care of but just make this a very leisure evening. This restaurant can't be rushed.
author: Elaine A.

description:
I've been here for more than one romantic dinner with my SO.

Always had wonderful food, enjoyed the atmosphere and left happy.

Tried it with friends, a group of six, it translated very well.
author: Slim B.

description: Actually ate here back in early November, but just now doing my reviews of the city. I must say that even though it has been 4 months since I ate here, I am still thinking about this dinner. The onion soup is the best I ever had, so amazing! We also had the raspberry souffle. It was my first time having one and it was really good. I know that some people complain about the service, but we didn't have any problems at all. People also have to understand that the souffles are made to order and they take time to make. Plan on being at the restaurant for about two to three hours. We also had an early evening seating, which was great. By the time we left, the place was packed.
author: Anne D.

description: Cafe Jacqueline is truly a very special dining experience.  The Chef - Jacqueline is an amazing lady, very talented and skilled at the craft of creating the perfect soufflé.   The waiters work hard to make sure your meal is outstanding; good wine, great onion soup, and the right souffle. A meal at Cafe Jacqueline is a time to relax, enjoy the interactions with knowlegable staff and savor an outstanding meal. When we want to introduce friends to one of the hidden treasures of SF we go Cafe Jacqueline.
author: Keo H.

description:
A great little restaurant with fantastic food. My wife and I had a fantastic meal here: she had French Onion soup and I had a bowl of fantastic puree of leek soup, which was the soup du jour. We shared the Prosciutto and Mushroom souffle for dinner and a chocolate souffle for dessert. Both were excellent.

The key to a good experience here is to know what to expect: the only entrees are souffles, so if that isn't for you then come only for dessert (also souffles) or don't come at all. As others have said, it take a long time to eat, so be prepared to spend the whole evening. Make a reservation in advance--you probably won't be able to just walk in. Most important, get an *early* reservation. We were the second party seated for the evening (6PM reservation) and I heard the waiter say they were out of the soup du jour when the fourth party of the evening was ordering. When you make a reservation, call between 4 and 5PM so that you can talk to a live person before the service has started. Yelp's attire choices are too limited--I wouldn't want to show up in shorts, but this is California after all so you don't really need to be "Dressy".

Street parking in this neighborhood is impossible, but there are cheap garages available over closer to Chinatown (Vallejo St).

It's a little pricey, but makes a great "special occasion" restaurant for 2-4 people. My wife and I can't wait for an opportunity to come back.
author: Josh T.

description:
The four stars is strictly for the the food, ambiance, and charming old Chef Jacqueline herself, and 1/2 of the waitstaff. I would give a minus 5 stars to that one, crazy, psychotic, humorless, serial-killer-like crazy, waiter with the bad attitude. How he is still working there, i'll never know unless he is actually the owner of the place or he has a controlling interest of some kind. As mentioned before by others, if you happen to be served by the gray haired gentleman only, you'll have a good time, I'm sure.

I would have never gone back, but my best friend wanted to go there for his birthday, so my wife and I went along, with his family.  It was a mistake to take his kids. My advice is not to take the kids along because they will be bored out of their minds, like my friend's kids were. The whole meal lasted at least 3 hours. Now this length of time would work if it was a romantic dinner for two while the couple gazes into each others' eyes and whisper sweet nothings at each other while sipping wine and waiting for the next course, but this just won't happen if the kids are climbing the walls going through gameboy withdrawal.

if you've always wanted to have some really incredible, mind blowing souffle, you need to try Cafe Jacqueline, just go prepared to put up with its idiosyncracies (loooooong wait for dinner, the worse waiter on the planet,  if you're not lucky to get the good one).
author: Warren T.

description: Might not be for everyone, but I loved it. Most nice restaurants in SF are crowded, noisy, and obnoxious. If you want someplace to talk or actually enjoy your dinner companion, this is it. The meals do take a LONG time; my last was 4 hours. But I consider that a bit of a plus sometimes. Food was excellent, and very reasonably priced considering the low turnover.
author: ellen r.

description:
The staff lost our number and didn't call us to confirm our reservation.  So they gave it away.  Upon arriving we find that we have no table, and it would be a 4 hour wait.  Why did we bother calling ahead?

They'd probably get a better review if we had tasted the food, but the way they handled the reservation didn't leave any in our party wanting to go back.
author: D X.

description:
I was looking for a last minute place to eat in SF and decided to check last year's Big Eat SF: 100 Things to Try Before You Die list, and saw Cafe Jacqueline on it and decided to try it since I've never been.

Called to make a last minute reservation and was glad to hear that they could take us in. Parking was a bit hard to find but hey, it's SF.
As soon as I walked in the restaurant I could smell a very pleasant baked cheese aroma...mmm...:) The ambiance was really nice, very romantic. We ordered the french onion soup to start, mushroom souffle for our main, and strawberry souffle for dessert. The order took a while but I was prepared for the wait. The french onion came first and it was sooo gooood!!! The broth was a little thicker than others that I've had, and the cheese was very gooey. Around 45 minutes later the mushroom souffle came. It was sooooooooo fluffy!!! I was worried that it would just be mushroom and no cheese, but it was actually a cheese & mushroom souffle. It was rich and light at the same time. The strawberry souffle was excellent too...the real strawberries on top were a little tart and a good combination with the warm, gooey, souffle. 

Overall a good experience. Total dinner took 2 hours, so be warned.
author: Marcela Y.

description:
Went to this place after many people (and loyal yelpers) gave it glowing reviews.  I must say that this place does live up to its name.  The food is a little salty for my taste that I saw Chef Jacqueline herself making our souffles!

The place is a little small so you have to make reservations at least 2 weeks in advance.  The waiters are relatively attentive but given the nature of the souffle process, it took up about an hour to get our food.  

For four of us, we got two French Onion Soups which were pretty good (not the best I've ever had but pretty darn close)...one lobster souffle and one crab souffle.  Both were pretty darn good (I've never had savory souffles in the past so I have nothing to compare them too).  I wouldn't necessarily come back for them.  Each savory souffle is certainly big enough to share between two people (if not 3 if you're not that hungry).  Then we ended our dinner with the chocolate souffle split between 4 people which was very light and pretty tasty.  We were all pretty full when we rolled out of that place.  

I would give this place 3.5 stars if I could but I rounded up because the service wasn't bad and the place was clean and very quaint.  Next time I go, I'd probably only want to try their blueberry souffle after a cheaper meal somewhere else.  

Merci Chef Jacqueline!
author: Kristie G.

description:
reminds me of paris...good atmosphere, good food, BAD service...the two waiters (and they're not even FRENCH, so spare me of the attitude!) belittled us the entire night, from the moment my friend left his name and phone number for the waitlist, all the way to the end of dinner when we paid...i don't mind the wait; it's just really bad service...

and for those who kept saying a "French woman" cooking in the kitchen, i went through the kitchen to go to the bathroom in the back, and all i saw was a busy kitchen aid blender mixing the egg batter, while three Hispanic looking workers standing by the oven, just standing there...
author: Lulu M.

description: the soufflé are amazing.  We have been there at least 3 times...the place is also very romantic and sharing the soufflés  just adds to this atmosphere.  It is not on the cheap side though if you go and have a "main course soufle (mushroom is great)" and the "desert soufflé (hmmm... strawberry).  Also and this would be my main tip try to avoid the weekends as the wait times get out of hand. We had to wait almost  90 minutes for one of the soufflé. I know it takes a while to make them but at some point it gets out of hand. During the week you do not run into this sort of problem.
author: jan w.

description:
Mmmmm....j'adore Cafe Jacqueline.  My boyfriend took for my birthday almost three years ago and I was enchanted.  I was so impressed, in fact, that we didn't go back until last night because we were afraid it couldn't live up to our high expectations.  We had nothing to fear.  The service was better than it was three years ago, and the souffles were delicious.   We had the tomato and cilantro with garlic and the white chocolate.  Yummy yummy.

Expect to spend three hours here, but they'll be a delicious three hours, so don't complain!

Oh, and unless I missed a secret back entrance, the restaurant is not wheelchair accessible (though it says above that it is).  There is a 6 or so inch step when entering the restaurant.
author: Lizabeth S.

description:
My wife and I love Cafe Jacqueline.  We had our first date here, our rehearsal dinner here and our first anniversary dinner here.  We went there tonight with two of her cousins and again we were not disappointed.  We had a fantastic meal, great service and spent 3 wonderful hours enjoying the company we were with.

For those who don't know, do NOT go expecting a fast meal.  You WILL wait for food - and it will be worth the wait.  From the time you order expect that it will take at least an hour to get your first souffle - everything is done to order and is fresh made.  Souffle's take time to make and time to bake.  It's all served direct out of the oven - there are no heat lamps or "guessing" when you'll be ready.  

They bring you warm crusty french bread that is great.  The salads are simple and delicious.  The onion soup is among the best I've had.  

This is also unlike most other restaurants in that the mostly french wine list is very reasonably priced - we had a nice bottle of French Chardonnay for $30.

Tonight the four of us shared two dinner souffles - Lobster, which was fantastic - it was like a lobster thermidor souffle... the other one was prosciutto and mushroom that was also delicious.  For dessert we had the strawberry souffle - it's covered on top with fresh ripe strawberries and is incredibly light and fluffy.  My wife is a chocoholic and loves the chocolate souffle - but actually prefers the strawberry - it's the only time she'll order a fruit dessert over chocolate.

So when you're looking for a 2.5-3 hour meal and just want to enjoy a leisurely evening of dining and enjoying the company you're with, this is the place to go.
author: Mark P.

description:
Make reservations for early in the evening and prepare to wait...and wait...and wait...as each eggie dollop is made and served with loving care. Order both the savory and the dessert souffles, because this is a rare chance to stuff yourself with delicious perfection. I was a bit skeptical that fluffy eggs would make one giddy with romance, but now I believe! 

Be sure to take a trip to the bathroom so you can walk through the kitchen to eyeball the amazing Jacqueline and her giant bowl of eggs. 

Thank you magic egg lady!
author: michele K.

description: My husband and I just celebrated our 6th anniversary by dining here and it was easily the best meal we have ever had. The spinach and goat cheese salad was incredible, I had no idea spinach could be that good. The onion soup was so flavorful and cheesy, it might have been my favorite dish of the night. We ordered the prosciutto and mushroom souffle for our main course and highly recommend it. And we made sure to save room for dessert and ordered the chocolate souffle, which was to die for. Every bite was light fluffy chocolate intermixed with molten oozing chocolate. EVERYTHING HERE IS AMAZING. Oh and did I mention the champagne?! Our new favorite restaurant, Cafe Jacqueline, has a romantic, cozy atmosphere and the service is impeccable. Thank you for a great evening!
author: Stephanie D.

description:
Bianca, I love you...but I have to voice my opinion on this one.

Cafe Jacqueline is not somewhere I will be returning any time soon.

1.  It's extremely pretentious and stuffy.  This includes the guests and the staff.  It's a shame, because the ambiance is charming and quaint...but the rigid atmosphere is almost unbearable.  It was a bit nerve-wracking, actually.
2.  I found out after dining here that I'm not a big soufflé fan.  The $55 lobster soufflé was mediocre at best (the lobster seemed like it was frozen and not fresh), and the dessert soufflé was undercooked and soupy (at least in my opinion).
3.  I felt like the service was inconsistent between tables;  i.e.- other tables were getting five star treatment and we were getting the short end of the stick the whole dinner.
4.  If you come here, be sure to block out a 3 hour window, because I definitely would not use the word "quick" to describe our experience.
5.  The $10 spinach and goat cheese salad is literally just that- dry spinach with some goat cheese shavings on top.  Be sure to request extra dressing.

I will give them this- they selected a nice wine for me that I really enjoyed, and they had great bread. And, my boyfriend said their French onion soup was the best he's ever had.  But, don't fall for the "French lemonade" recommendation...it's really just French 7up.  Literally.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
Honestly I feel like a downer writing a bad review for this restaurant because there are so many great reviews. My boyfriend and I came to eat here on Valentines Day and we thought the atmosphere was very romantic and cozy. The waiters were nice and attentive and always filling up our cups of water. We didn't mind the wait for the food because we already knew it was going to take 3 hours.
We both had the french onion soup as our appetizers and it was just too salty for the both of us. I love salt but this soup was just too much. The lobster souffle was nice and fluffy but also waaay too salty as well. We felt really bad so we just try to eat as much as we could. We had the salad which was just literally lettuce and salad dressing... The chocolate souffle was what I was most excited for. My boyfriend hated it and maybe I was just expecting too much.. It was only okay..
I really do feel bad for writing this review but we waited a month and a half to eat at this place for Valentine's day only to be disappointed by the food..
author: Olivia W.

description:
cafe jaqueline: ME THINKS NOT

all this time, i thought of me being a true foodie but i guess i'm more of a diner ... i like to think that i'm both, thank you very much ...  OF ALL THE PLACES I'VE VENTURED OUT IN SF, I HAVE TO SAY I FELT SO DISGUSTED WITH THIS PLACE.

KEYWORD: [disgust [-ING!] [-ED!]

disgust        (ds-gst')  
tr.v.   disgusted, disgusting, disgusts

   1. To excite nausea or loathing in; sicken.
   2. To offend the taste or moral sense of; repel.

(credit: american heritage dictionary)

***

you wouldn't believe HOW DISGUSTING this place is ... DISGUSTING, AWFUL, RUDE, JUST SIMPLY YUCK!

did i tell you how i stopped reading YELP reviews many years ago? i've learned after a good 7 months that everyone's experience is entirely different.

anywys, i treated my friend out to dinner here as a token of appreciation of being there for me at the roughest times from the day i moved to san francisco.

okay, so the place is NOT romantic AT ALL ... (but who gives? not that i even came with my man here anyways), small, crowded... OH and UNBELIEVABLY STUFFY! so one may think having 2 red roses on each of the table is semi romantic ... (chokes) you're kidding right?

food? yea, it is what it is .. SOUFFLE GALORE ... everything on the menu was purely SOUFFLE THIS SOUFFLE THAT ... they have quite the variety from mushroom, tomato and cilantro, brie and brocolli and lobster, etc etc starting from $35 and up. dessert, they had like 3-4 to choose from, and i was SO looking forward to their white chocolate. $32 and up.

for appetizers, they have escargot and caviar for $40 and up.

we ordered their basil, shiitake and garlic and can you believe HOW SALTY it was? HOW DISGUSTING. 

i understand the wait is roughly 45 minutes or so, but we even ordered their dessert souffle WHEN WE ORDERED OUR ENTREE,  not 30 minutes after, but the beginning of our order ... and the servers tell us its an additional 45 minutes? why not start MAKING the souffle, 15-20 minutes AFTER our ENTREE, why drag on an extra hour? 

with the wait time AND the horrible DISGUSTING SERVICE, we canceled our souffle because we could not believe how AWFUL it was.. 

the service? DISGUSTING! RUDE, RUDE AND RUDE! you ask what they recommend, they roll their eyes, you ask for water, they get all snappy, you ask this, they look as if theyre going to bite their heads off, you try to flag them down, AND GET THIS, you even get EYE CONTACT with them and they look away. now, prior to me writing this review, i decided to skim through a few reviews in WHAT MADE EVERYONES experience a grand 4-5 spankin stars when i came across the 1 stars, and given that we've experienced the same thing..

my friend once said, you can't correct stupidity and i can't tell you how much i agree like no other ...

Madame Jacqueline, PLEASE MAKE SURE TO TEACH YOUR WAITSTAFF CUSTOMER SERVICE 101 BEFORE YOU DECIDE TO LET THEM LOOSE LIKE WILD HYENAS!!!

i swear, this is one of those places i could tell that most people would like to boast that they've been here, but honestly, it's not all that ... i give you my life on that ... 

the WORST $ ive ever spent EVAR in SF HISTORY and i swear, i TOTALLY TOTALLY don't recommend this place to ANYONE, esp on a date! i swear, you're date will dump you esp how SOUR and how FOUL this place is ...

i tried uploading my picture but my iphone is acting up. sry, but will be posted in due time, just keep checking back if you want.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Sigh...finally, a sign that romance is not dead!  Cafe Jacqueline is one of the most romantic spots on Earth.  I had an out-of-body experience eating the souffles here.  Don't leave without trying their dessert souffles...that would be criminal.  Oh, and it's very rich food, so starve yourself before you go.
author: Kristina R.

description:
Have been to Cafe Jacqueline many times over the years, but our most recent visit was the best experience yet.  Our table was not yet ready at our reserved time, but the waiter could not have been more gracious in accommodating us.  While we waited next door at the Savoy he came over and took our dinner order in advance so we would not have to wait for our food when finally seated.  He also comped one of our desserts to repay us for the wait, which was a nice touch.  The first course salads were cold, crisp and fresh and delicious paired with the hot crispy french bread.  We tried a few of the special entree souffles of the night and each one was better than the next...the leek and chestnut was especially delicious.  The lime souffle for dessert (a new addition) was incredible...sweet, tangy and luscious.  As always the hard working Jacqueline was in the kitchen with her giant mixer whirling at top speed.  Our dinner took over three hours but we expected that...you have to get into a "european" mindset when visiting this restaurant.  Savor the experience, the company and lots of good wine...whats the rush?  

Just a note to the ladies:  please no jeans and sweatshirts like we saw on someone here--that is just so tacky.  Please gals, if for no other reason than to show some respect for a fine restaurant, make the effort and put on a dress!
author: SFnativeGal ..

description: Finally visited this weekend and, while more's still to come, I need to say I can still taste the powdery-airy-soft-warm-custardy layers of lemon souffle. Lemongasm with a capital L.
author: Spratt M.

description:
I recently dined at Cafe Jacqueline with the hubby for his birthday.  Neither of us have had much experience eating souffles, so we really didn't know what to expect.  Fortunately, we had consulted Yelp prior to arriving, so we knew that the dinner event would last approximately 2.5 hours.  

First, the decor of the restaurant is very European, and correspondingly very intimate.  There aren't a ton of tables in this place--consider it the anti-Cheesecake Factory.  There was one server waiting on approximately a dozen tables, with about half the tables being occupied.  Based on the suggestion of other Yelpers, the hubby and I each went to the restroom, which is located past the kitchen and through a courtyard.  As you go by the kitchen, you'll see a gigantic bucket of eggs, along with Chef Jacqueline herself plugging away at her specialty.

Second, the wait time was indeed long, compared to other restaurants.  That said, souffles take a long time to make, and an even longer time to make properly.  So, as other Yelpers have said, don't come here unless you arrive with good conversational company.

Third, as for the food, we think it was pretty good, but we realized that perhaps our palates simply didn't like souffles that much.  We started with the onion soup (which is just called onion soup, not French Onion Soup, just like ordering a burger is just asking for a burger, not an American Burger).  The soup was quite tasty, and surprisingly vegetarian.  I would have preferred it to be made with beef stock, but it was good nevertheless, albeit very salty.  We ordered a crab souffle, which had real pieces of crab.  The souffle itself tasted great, with just the right amount of lemon for some kick.  Similar to the onion soup, the souffle also suffered from being oversalted.  I think I drank a gallon of water in one meal.  Finally, we shared a chocolate souffle.  The dessert souffles are gigantic, and simply much too big for 2 people--I'd recommend it more for 4 people.  It appeared to be made very well, but the hubby and I probably would have preferred a less refined dessert, like a big fat brownie and some ice cream.  That said, based on what I know about souffles (which is admittedly little), if you like souffles, I'm pretty sure that you'll love the chocolate souffle here.

We're happy we tried authentic French souffles, but it's not really our thing.  But if it's your thing, you definitely need to try this joint, because everyone else seemed to love it!
author: Alexis N.

description:
i don't know how i can forget to write a review for cafe jacueline.  this cute little place is hidden in the streets of north beach.  we came here for a christmas dinner and gift exchange this past christmas.  i made reservations 2 weeks prior to our dinner (i had to leave a msg on the answering machine).  

we ordered the french onion soup - it was pipping hot and it was GOOD! i am not a big fan of french onion soup but this was GOOD!  we also ordered 2 souffle (seafood souffle and prosciutto/mushroom souffle) - i like the prosciutto/mushroom souffle more than the seafood. maybe cuz i m a big fan of prosciutto! for dessert, we ordered the chocolate souffle - now that's a souffle!!! it was soooo good.  man, i am thinking of going back while i write this review! 

this is a great place to go for a date! nice atmosphere! dim lights! quiet! the only downside might be parking.  i circled 45 minutes for a parking space... argh... (knocking off 1 star for that!)
author: Kapo T.

description: Okay, okay, yes, tasty souffles (of course! that's all they sell!) but let's not beat around the bush.... We were seated at 6:30pm and didn't escape until 9:30. That's right - a 3 hour meal. Not that we were in a rush, but, the souffle-eating took about 10 minutes max (it's a small, rich dish) and the rest of the time was spent watching other, larger, parties be seated, order, enjoy their dinner and leave. We watched almost every table in the restaurant turn over twice while we were there. After 2 hours we asked about our long lost dinner, and did not receive even a token apology from the waiter. We wanted to bail after the main course but of course we had been asked to order dessert up front, so that was another 1 hr wait. By 9:30pm, it was hard to know whether the rude service, our $140 bill, or my stomachache was the finale.
author: Emily B.

description: Still as romantic and lovely as our dinner here 9 years ago - just a few days before we got engaged.  Our waiter was charming and attentive and we loved every tiny morsel of our savory and chocolate souffles.  We especially loved the kitchen, the big bowl of eggs, and the sweet chef!  This place is  truly a gem!
author: LeAndra M.

description: Many times after a fairly decent dinner, you feel that a change of scenery is needed for dessert.  Cafe Jacqueline fills that need for a nice romantic and intimate setting with their low lights and warm ambiance.  The menu is really basic and really all you need to do is order the "Souffle" of your choice.  Made in both Savory style or Sweet style, but really who are you kidding...  Get a couple of glasses of champagne and get the chocolate or strawberry souffle!  More than enough for the two of you, Madame Jacqueline whips together a large masterpiece of a dessert!  Some say they can be mean or rude, but that wasn't the case when we visited.  Just come equipped with a couple of French phrases and use them properly!  (Merci Beaucoup, Bonsoir, Pardon Garcon, etc.)
author: Jason A.

description: One of my former classmates was visiting from London for only one day and this is the place I chose to take him. I loved being at Cafe Jacqueline, and I loved sharing words there. The food is excellent and well-presented, but it's the setting that makes the place an amazing destination...everyone looks good in this restaurant because everyone seems to be in love...it's that kind of place...of course, reality awaits on the other side of the door, as always.
author: kimb s.

description: Go here for dessert, its pricey but a souffle between friends w a good glass of wine is the way to go. You MUST use the restroom while there and check out the kitchen, its about as big as a dorm room kitchenette. And somehow Jacqeline manages to cook all the souffles in that tiny space.
author: Senorita V.

description:
MY NEW FAVORITE RESTAURANT!

My husband and I had what was probably one of our favorite dining experiences at Cafe Jacqueline almost two weeks ago.

Everything was just absolutely delightful! The setting is quaint and welcoming, the food is fabulous, and great service as well.

1) Although the restaurant is small, the tables are roomy and spaced out well so you don't feel like you're giving your neighbor a lap dance whenever you need to get up.

2) The staff at the restaurant is awesome - knowledgeable, professional and a sense of humor.

3) The quiches - PHENOMENAL. We were going to try the salmon & asparagus, however, after speaking to our waiter, we switched over to the leek. Me and the hubby love leeks - and this just made us heart them a million times more! The dessert quiche - seasonal peach (and thank you Jacqueline for using white peaches ...such delicate flavor!) I felt like I was eating warm clouds of summery goodness! Not to mention that Jacqueline decorated the peach quiche with a ring of sliced peaches - without the slightest disturbance to it's perky form! WOW! 

4) The onion soup - ok I'd read about it and was interested to try it. OMG - I've gone to ooey, gooey cheesy onion heaven. When the waiter came to take my bowl, I said "Please do, before I make a spectacle and start chipping away at the crispy cheese on the bowl." Without missing a beat he said "I do that too. I'll be back in a few minutes." I abstained and laughed ...but I must say he earned a special place in my heart for that! Seriously, it's the best part!

5) And finally Jacqueline herself - the woman is like straight out of a French movie. To Jacqueline - I applaud you and your mastery of eggs over the past 30 years!

I'm sure that my two lillet blancs and nice little bottle of red burgundy (highly recommend a Chablis or Sancerre for next time...but I was cravin' the Pinot) gave the experience a rosier glow. However, Cafe Jacqueline had been on my list of restaurants for the last 3 or 4 years and I kick myself that it took us so long to finally try it out. Seriously, if you are looking for an uber romantic and relaxing meal where you're temporarily transported to France for 3 hours........YOU MUST GO TO CAFE JACQUELINE!!! After six years of marriage, I felt like my husband and I were on a date again!  (Cyrus and Danko ain't got nothin' on you Cafe Jacqueline!)

There are a lot of great restaurants in SF, but only a very small number of them can deliver the whole package at "great" like Cafe Jacqueline!

I CAN NOT WAIT TO COME BACK!!!
author: Detox B.

description:
a place with only souffles??  redonkulous.  and genius.  

it's a charming place... and like most charming places, parking sucks.  so you should cab it to this one.

the souffles were okay, but the soup here was way too salty.  the waiter became indignant when we informed him it was too salty, and told us such a thing never happens.  his reaction was odd but i didn't feel that strongly about it so we let it go.  he later came back to apologize, and told us other patrons had complained about the overly salty soup. 

i didn't come back because i'm not big enough of a fan of souffles to eat at a place with only souffles.  but the idea is novel and the place is romantic... worth taking a date to.
author: Erika C.

description: So cute, so fun and SO tasty.  I never knew souffles could be that amazing.  The broccoli/brie one was other worldly...they'll run you about $30 for two people which, when you think about it, is a really good price for dinner.  Make sure you have time for the dining cause things go at a bit slower pace here.
author: Allison K.

description:
the souffles here are the *best* i've ever had. they really are made by a little french lady named jacqueline. if you use the restroom, you'll pass by her. say what's up. she likes it.  

things to note: 1) this place is small..make reservations, 2) this place is romantic...bring a date or at least a good looking friend to stare at, 3) please don't bring a baby...see item 1 and 2 above, 4) the souffles need to be shared...the portions are for two or three

i recommend the spinach souffle and be sure to order the chocolate souffle for dessert (an hour in advance - it takes a while to make)...oh ya and the spinach salad w/ the goat cheese is delish!
author: Natalie L.

description:
i defintiely would have given this the deserved FIVE STARS, but apparently, the waiter who waited on us was having a bad day.  i don't know why i'm being nice about it, but i felt very uncomfortable the moment we walked in. he was really rude and very short and dismissive.  he eventually became nice and attentive, but it really ruined our evening. 

we ordered the chocolate souffle!  it was so, BIG and so good!  it was up there with my search for the best souffle!  it served up to four people and it took a while to bake. in the meantime i had a latte and my friend has a coffee. both were excellent.  

if you are ever interested in going, you are better off calling ahead with reservations and ordering your souffle in advance.  they have dinner souffles, but the desserts ones are to die for!
author: Jodie C.

description:
one of the most singularly endearing, charming, magical, and unique restaurants in all of the bay area. a true gem. 

the food is exquisite, but the overall experience is the real gift...something very special. 

this is the epitome of the phrase "labor of love."
see it in action at cafe jacqueline, where the namesake of this restaurant is an extraordinary solo act, a fierce souffle master with a sweet, gregarious smile. 

everything was overwhelmingly sublime:  from the hot bread and spinach/bacon/pine nut salad, to the french onion soup, to the prosciutto/mushroom souffle and the grand marnier souffle.

the souffles were fluffy, moist, flavorful, billowy, and rich with flavor.

in addition to souffles, cafe jacqueline has raised the bar impossibly high for spinach salad and french onion soup. i could probably devote a thesis-length exposition on the wonders of this very soup alone.

{i wonder if it's possible to get some chocolate sauce and a side of fresh berries w/the dessert souffles? i know it's best to leave things as the chef intended them, unfettered and "pure." but still, it's a curiosity.}
author: jennifer y.

description:
We came here for my B-day dinner.  The entire dinner took 3 hours so be prepare to wait for your food and have lots to talk about with your date!! It might be a good idea to even have a little snack before coming here.  The restaurant is somewhat plain, old and dark.  The candle lights add a nice touch. 

We started off with the onion soup which was really yummy.  It was one of the best I had. We also had the spinach salad which was o.k.  The wait to get the starters were about 45 minutes. Then we wait and waited and finally we got our entre souffl (prosciutto and mushroom).  It tasted good, but after all that anticipation I expected something more. Dessert took another 45 minutes or so, but it was worth it. The strawberry souffl was excellent!! It was huge, but we managed to finish it. 

The entre souffls are about $35 and up.  Dessert souffls are $35. These souffls are huge and can be shared with three people. 

Service was ok. It could have been better.
author: vernice l.

description:
Charming! Amazing food! Perfect ambiance! Did I mention- CHARMING?!!
My boyfriend and I went to this sweet spot after hearing about Ms. Jacqueline- The 79 year old expert souffle goddess that has been standing in the same spot, in the same kitchen, in NorthBeach for over 35 years.  

The place is simple and sweet in the seating area with only a few tables, white tablecloths, and two fresh rose stems extending out of a loosely shaped heart glass vase.  The lighting was soft, the waiter was attentive, and when we ran out of our bottle of wine and still had dessert to go, he came over and filled our glasses with more of the same wine, only saying, "A little something to keep you rolling here...". It's that kind of attentive, no B.S. kind of attitude that makes you want to come back to a place, but the FOOD is what has made me a comitted customer of Cafe Jacqueline.  

The french onion soup was the best I've ever had, the spinach salad was light and delicious, the white corn/ginger/garlic souffle was hard to eat because we were smiling so much, and the strawberry souffle at the end... Ugh, there are no words! 

And, the best part: You can see Jacqueline masterfully beating eggs and making the souffles, lovingly, one at a time.  In order to get to the restroom you literally have to walk through the kitchen, and there you will find a sweet women dressed in white and a chefs hat, in a tiny kitchen with a smile on her face... Looking up to greet you with a delightful, "Bonsoir!"

There's nothing sweeter I've found in San Francisco.
author: Rachel O.

description: Smells like butter and chocolate - just like France. Romantic, expensive, you need reservations. This is a soufflé only place - both savory and dessert, although there are escargot, soup and salad for appetizers while you wait for your souffles. The blue cheese and the crab soufflés are amazing. The milk chocolate soufflé is better than the white chocolate souffle.
author: Vena V.

description: for me, cafe jacqueline was an experience to be tried once but not really necessary to repeat... and now that i've tried it, i don't feel the need to go back. the souffles were good, but sort of bland and too airy and insubstantial to be filling, although i was full by the end of our lengthy (3 hour?) meal. full, but not satisfied, if that makes sense. we ordered a salad to take the edge off our hunger, since the souffles take like an hour. for our main course, we ordered a broccoli and cheese souffle, which wasn't bad, but i found myself wishing it were a quiche instead. with a flaky crust. mmm. then dessert was a strawberry souffle, which i would have preferred to be sweeter and maybe not hot. i'm thinking i'm just not a souffle person... which is why one visit is enough for me. i did think it was a quaint, semi-fun, expensive experience though. :P
author: Clara K.

description: Impossibly romantic --- like wandering into France for a few hours. We had the soup of the day, a tomato and herb salad, the Brie and broccoli souffle, and the Grand Marnier souffle. All of it was perfect. Light and fluffy and full of flavor. The staff was great about helping us choose a wine to go with our meal. We told our waiter what we were interested in and he brought us out about six bottles to look at, talk about, and choose from. This is definitely a date sorta place and best when you aren't in a rush. Savor this place!
author: Leigh M.

description: I went here months ago but recently recommended it to a friend.  Not only was the food fantastic but the atmosphere is very romantic.  It's very quaint and they have a huge basket of eggs in the back.  I couldn't have asked for more.
author: Candice P.

description: I'm not really a souffle person, plus when I went, we made the mistake of ordering an entree and dessert souffle.  So, so wrong.  I think we had some kind of cheese flavored souffle that was great but heavy.  I prefer savory things anyway so by the time the dessert chocolate souffle came out, I could barely look at it.  I think if I had come just for dessert, I would've been happier, I might give this place 4 stars.  People told me beforehand the service would be snotty and indifferent but I thought it was fine.
author: Seong P.

description: These souffles are to die for! The lobster souffle is off the charts as was the hazelnut dessert souffle. It is so worth the wait and such a treat to see adorable Jacqueline (I'm guessing it's her) in the back with her lovely bowl of eggs and wire whisk, whipping up each scrumptious little dish. Yum.
author: Grace K.

description:
Went there last week.  Food was very good.  Service was mediocre.

Started with a Kir Royale.  Later had a Dubonet Rouge which was much nicer.

Had the snails as an appetizer.  Beautiful shells.  Lots of butter.

They bake their own bread, which comes out warm with a crispy crust - very nice.

We ordered the Prosciutto Soufflé and were disappointed.  The Prosciutto was draped across the top of the soufflé - we had expected it to be incorporated into the soufflé.  The prosciutto was VERY salty.  Also, since the prosciutto was warm from being draped across the soufflé, it tasted like ham.  The top of this soufflé also tasted burnt.  

We ordered the amaretto and hazelnut soufflé for dessert.  We liked that alot, though by this time we'd been through an appetizer and a main course, so only had space for half the dessert.  It was like eating warm marzipan. which we both like.

Service was not welcoming.  The waiter was snooty, and seemed to not have time to explain anything.  Strange, since we had to wait an hour and half before out main soufflé turned up (which we didn't mind that much, since we were noshing on snails and chatting).  When we asked whether or not we should order the dessert soufflé at the same time as the savory soufflé, we were told somewhat snootily "you'd be well advised to order it now."  A simple "yes" would have sufficed.

Overall, a nice leisurely experience - don't go there if you are in a hurry.
author: Nick K.

description: This is one of the most expensive restaurants I have ever been to.  My boyfriend (poor student) was so sweet to bring me here for my birthday - it was very cute and cozy.  However, I don't understand why it costs so much for a souffle - I've never made one so maybe I just don't know how much work it is...because it can't be the ingredients that cost a lot...I  mean, Safeway sells dozen packages of eggs for "buy one get one free" on most days!  I do have to say, though - that the chocolate souffle was super good.  It was way too big for two people to share though.
author: Tabatha Y.

description:
As a well-traveled foodie, this experience definitely stood out as a unique place and menu.   Wonderful food and atmosphere.   Definitely a date-night location.   A business dinner might seem a bit awkward unless it is a group.  

The spinach souffle was quite tasty yet slightly too salty.  Hence the lost star.

But, the Lemon souffle was - WOW!   First, it arrives as large as the savory souffles - which is scary because you are already too full from that dish.  The lemon aroma hits you first.  Then your first bite almost disappears as it melts in your mouth.   We almost finished it and I'm looking forward to the doggy bag!

I strongly recommend a glass or two of champagne.  It cleansed our palate for the souffle better then would other wines.  

The waiter was certainly a personality, but you could tell he really loved working there and was proud of the food.  We read some negative reviews while sitting at the table, and I can see how some would interpret his as having 'attitude', but we had a wonderful experience with him.  We would return to try another souffle - especially the chocolate dessert one because of all of the fantastic reviews.
author: Joseph U.

description:
dessert souffle here = to die for :)
we shared the white chocolate and grand marnier souffle for 5 of us...
only thing was, I thought the menu says "18% gratuity included for party of 5 or more" but the check came as 20% gratuity... what gives???
author: dannydan d.

description: My girlfriend took me here for my birthday this past weekend and what a surprise. This cute and unsuspecting place serves the best souffles. We shared the endive salad, escargot, leeks and chestnut souffles and strawberry souffle. Everything was done so well. It is a long dinner but the wait just allows all the other food to settle. The coffee was out of site. Definitely a place we will go back to.
author: McCall T.

description:
Went here with my husband and 2 friends.  This place is fantastic if you enjoy long lesuirely meals (we arrived at 6:15 and didn't leave until 10:30pm).
