It's perfect for couples on dates or anniversary or a small group of friends to catch up and chat the night away.    I have to admit though that i enjoyed the dessert souffle more than the savory ones.    I felt the dinner souffle was just a tad bit too salty. still yummy.    OH but the dessert was wonderful. we had the White chocolate souffle and the Rasberry souffle.  We felt the Rasberry was a bit too liquidy, but i found when combinging the fluffy white chocolate souffle with the rasberry one made a delicious combination.  :)

Of course we followed the advice of other yelpers and strolled back to the bathroom to watch Jacqueline herself stirring her magic in the kitchen.     Enjoy this place while you can before she decides to retire!

The cost for four of us, for a total of four souffles (2 savory and 2 dessert) and drink each (wine) our bill came out to be about $70 per person including tip.
author: Winnie C.

description: Amazing amazing souffle!! Strawberries and souffle...absolutely heavenly! Loved it! Romantic and quiet setting....
author: Yan M.

description:
I want to give this place more than just 3 stars mainly because, it is all about souffle.  Not that its a bad thing.  Au contraire!  C'est magnifique comme ca...
They do souffle and they do them very well.  As one other reviewer mentioned, only Gary Danko's chocolate souffle with 2 sauces can come close.  
Having said that, I would recommend coming her for either appetizer and meal, then go somewhere else for dessert OR go somewhere else for the appetizer and meal, then come here for dessert.
We frequented Cafe Jacqueline and, over and over again, my tummy always feels so bloated after the dinner.  In French "souffler" literally means "to puff up" and you do feel puffed-up after having souffle for a meal and then dessert.
The ambiance is very romantic.  Lots of table for 2 and very, very low lighting.  Its actually embarrassing coming there sometimes because I see a lot of friends and acquaintance with their dates.  :-D
Nevertheless, this place is definitely unbeatable for their specialty...The Souffle...
Bon Appetit!

Follow me in twitter... http://twitter.com/aptinfrance
author: Maria G.

description: This restaurant is the perfect place for a long romantic evening.  The lobster souffle as an entree and strawberry for dessert are my favorites.
author: Meghan S.

description: The thing about Cafe Jacqueline is not that the food is good (it's better than good), and not that it seems like a secret garden (like the book, special, and sort of hidden) (even to the loo in back).  It's that it's surprising how filling souffles are, especially after your main course sits in your stomach for a bit, and dessert arrives.  The souffles are terrific, but they seem light, and you think you have room for dessert, and you really don't.   I always wish that I had just come for one, or the other.  Not both.  I love the aesthetics of it.  Very sweet.  One might call it an excellent Valentine's Day spot, though I know guys who like it too.  It feels very romantic.
author: Laurel B.

description: I had a perfect evening the other night.  I absolutely loved the entire experience.  I came here with four others and we ordered  two savories and two dessert, which we all shared.  First I had the cucumber salad which was really refreshing and as I love cucumbers, it was perfect for me.  We had ordered the white corn/ ginger/garlic souffle and the proscuitto/mushroom souffle.  Both excellent, but I would have to say that the white corn/ginger/garlic souffle was the star of the entrees.  And then our desserts were the lemon souffle and the apricot souffle.  Again, both very good, but the lemon souffle was out of this world.  To die for!   We even met Jacqueline, a very sweet woman with a cheery, smiling face.  Great company, interesting conversation, helpful waiter, and food out of this world.  What more can I ask for?
author: Magdalena ..

description:
i love to make souffles but it's much more enjoyable to focus on conversation instead of the logistics of souffle-making (there are several factors requiring attention to detail...not good if you get easily distracted, have to pee mid-whip, can't find the oven thermometer). 

this is a small, quiet restaurant with dim lighting, beautifully-prepared sweet and savory souffles (fresh peach and salmon are my two favorites). food that has been lovingly created by hand...

so take your best friend, someone you love (ou quelqu'un que veux voulez tu aimer) and let jacqueline work her magic. the waiters are sometimes gruff but they are charming when you get to know them - they are also talented at pairing wines and rebuffing children/tourists/whiners.

note: i would not recommend going if you care about a fast, inexpensive meal or mind the trek to the outdoor bathroom/outhouse - scary for some, great for me: i say hello to jacqueline in the kitchen + contemplate the occasional date exit strategy in the back garden. 

note: Maykadeh persian restaurant around the corner will valet your car for $15. well worth it, or that $200 meal just became a $250 meal courtesy of DPT :)

10/22 update: $265!
author: Lola S.

description: For a romantic, quiet dinner - avoid Cafe Jacqueline!  We've enjoyed their souffles for years, but on our last visit a table of 10 in the middle of the small dining room celebrating an event as loudly as possible made it impossible for us to even talk to the couple we were with.  Others entered, saw the scene and left.  The waiter was appologetic, but no one was willing to tell them to quiet down.  A letter suggesting that if they wanted to host large, noisy celebrations they should put them at one end of the room and possibly screen them off was never answered.  I'm sure the other couples eating there that night will never return.
author: Bruce M.

description:
I am really giving them six stars!

Cafe Jacqueline is exquisite.  We stopped in on a whim, in hopes that they would have a table available for "walk-ins" and they did.  Lucky us!  
I know it sounds cheesy but this place is magical.   I love the romantic ambiance --- it's very quaint with fresh flowers, warm tones, and dim lighting.  The conversations were hushed.  
We started with salads, which were perfectly dressed and presented.  Then came the mushroom souffle, which was incredible - very rich.  We finished with a chocolate souffle.  We could only eat about half of it - it really is huge!  But our waiter told us to take it home and it would be delicious cold the next day.  Overall, it was just enough food to fill us up without making us sick from over-eating.  
Our waiter was great.  He recommended great wines and provided just enough service but was completely unobtrusive.  
As long as you know what to expect, you will have an amazing time here.  I would recommend going with someone you feel comfortable spending about three hours with because the souffles do take a lot of time.  And it's on the pricy side, but I felt it was completely reasonable considering the quality.
author: MJ E.

description: Boo. If you ever go to dinner here, be sure to pack a snack. Totally understandable that it takes a long time to prepare a souffle. Not understandable that the waitstaff might also go MIA for the two hours between ordering and eating. Boo.
author: Kent G.

description: My boyfriend took me here for date night.  We had the french onion soup (nice stinky cheese - awesome), the shitake, basil, and garlic souffle (ridiculously amazing), and the chocolate souffle (yes, we were little oinkers - and completely demolished it record time).  The waiter helped us with wine and was just a joy to talk with.  We even went to the bathroom several times to watch Jacqueline break and whisk eggs, one by one, with fascination!  Such a treat to come to this little cafe.  I will definitely come back.  Great place for a date or 3-4 girls for a dessert souffle and wine.
author: Tabatha U.

description: Be prepared to have 3 hrs for dinner....a very good souffle dinner.  Get a savory one and a dessert one.  It's a cozy and romantic restaurant.  Must get reservations!  Truly unique SF experience.
author: Julia H.

description:
Before coming here, I never considered a souffle as a main dish, that it could have, for example, vegetables in it. Souffle was always a dessert to me. Cafe Jacqueline changed all of that. 

The French onion soup here is also really great. It's probably the best French onion soup I've ever had.
author: Aileen P.

description: Wonderfully intimate setting, kind of a country-esque french shabby chic and incredible soufflés.   Not the place to go if you don't want to completely indulge yourself.
author: rhiannon g.

description: this is not the place for us.  We probably went on an off day because our seafood souffle was too salty and our chocolate souffle didn't seem to have enough sugar in it.  I don't like my desert too sweet but sweet enough so i know it's a desert.  I admit the place is cute and I like the fact that the owner/chef makes all the souffle as you order them.  The wait though is too long for me.  We were there for about 3 hours for a 3 course meal.  If you're going to go here, be prepare for the long wait.
author: lani h.

description: Went back, had the chocolate souffle, beat the others I've had by miles. 5 stars still. I even had the same charming neurotically impatient waiter, haha.
author: Matt S.

description: Utterly and completely fantastic little romantic food cult. Though the waiters are initially somewhat scary, once the show starts they are conductors of a grand show, consisting of religious onion soup, bicthin' bread and SOUFFLE. To the uninitiated(of which I was one)souffle is downright mystical and gooey in equal measure. And dig this, a totally reasonably priced and well selected wine list,especially in the realm of the french esoterics. Add in perfect pacing(four courses in about three hours)and Jaqueline herself(straight out of a quirky old french art house flick)I challenge folks to find a better experience. Of course if ones idea of fine dining is silent food monks genuflecting before every dish and forks being replaced at a perfect angle every three seconds-GO ELSEWHERE. But if you love an evening of decadent goodies and service with an actual soul go no further. After twenty years in the front of the house, Cafe Jacqueline reminds me why I'm in the business.
author: Frank D.

description:
I would echo Danielle L's thoughts. The service is just abominable. Let me recount my experience for your reference.

My first time to Cafe Jacqueline was about 2 years ago. The decor was less than spectular, but it was a charming little house structure with tall ceilings. Romantic and intimate in an old-fashioned sense.

The food that time was good. I remember the souffles were good, but I was not in awe with them. There're lots of great restaurants like La Folie and Gary Danko in the city where they also serve excellent souffles. Of course they also come with different price tags for an entire meal, of course, but cafe Jacqueline is certainly no bargain. I remember walking away feeling pretty good about the place. Not spectular in any sense, but good.

This time the experience was different. We arrived early at the restaurant. We had made a reservation at 8:30 pm for desserts, but our dinner ended early at night, so when we got to Cafe Jacqueline, it was about 8:10 pm. What I'm going to tell you about the subsequent experience will be *shocking*. 

The waiter (most likely the same waiter as Danielle L. spoke about, since this kind of rude service is very hard to find) came to us at the door, and asked for our reservation. We told him we arrived early and he told us there wouldn't be a table available until 8:30 pm, which is completely understandable. He then tried to convince us to cancel our reservation and go elsewhere. Yes! He told us to go elsewhere, because we arrived 20 minutes earlier than our reservation. He didn't ask us to take a walk and come back in 20 minutes (it was freezing cold outside) for our reservation. He told us to cancel the reservation to go elsewhere. He then tried to physically gesture us towards the door.

This is unbelievable. We've been to places with excellent service (in the bay area, I would nominate Manresa and Gary Danko to have the best service), but we haven't been to places where the service is so bad they would turn away customers! I have no idea why they would do that.

Madame Jacqueline, if you care about your restaurant, please be aware that you have a waiter working there that's turning away business. I would not go back to your restaurant and I will tell all my friends not to go to your restaurant. The bottomline is, while you care so deeply about your souffles, there's someone working in your restaurant that cares deeply about turning away customers.

Bottomline, worst service ever. The waiter kicked us out the door simply because we were 20 minutes earlier than our reservation.
author: Paul W.

description: Bring friends to help you finish a dessert souffle. Adorable. North Beach at it's best. Inexplicably under-the-radar. Shame no one talks about Cafe Jacqueline, no wait, shhh...
author: Brandon R.

description: This is the place to go for a romantic night for two. Or to pig out on souffles. Or both. While you stare into your date's eyes and sip lucious wine while attended to, Jacquelline whips up amazing souffles (for two) in the quaint kitchen. This is THE place to go for anniversaries, birthdays, and celebrations. I may just have to celebrate this review with a souffle! Tres bon!
author: Bee H.

description: Top notch!  Unique and original!  Save room for the chocolate souffle!  It will take a while for the preparation but, the fare is wonderful.  Of course you have to get a souffle!  And having one for dinner and dessert is still enjoyable.  Anyone visiting San Francisco should stop on by.  It is one of those restaurants that won't disappoint.
author: matt g.

description: Awwww. Cafe Jacqueline is so cute, sooo French! A great night for a loved one, a soup and salad, bottle of wine, a cheese souffle, and the chocolate souffle with Grand Marnier poured on top and then lit on fire! Next time I have to try the souffle with fresh fruit.
author: Abbie B.

description: I took my girlfriend to Cafe Jacqueline on her birthday coz I remember reading how it's "romantic" on Yelp Talk... It was alright, the french onion soup was really good, but I'm not really into the souffles myself... I thought everything took freakin forever to come out and it was a bit overpriced...  4 stars coz the dessert souffles (strawberries souffles) was really good...
author: Andrew N.

description: When someone asks me to recommend a romantic restaurant, this is one of the first that comes to mind.  It's intimate and the food is just decadent.  I had the crab souffle and the chocolate souffle for dessert.  Both melted in my mouth.  The only thing that was disappointing was the children at the next table.  Why would you bring 2 children under 6 to this restaurant?  And then let them run around? Go to Denny's!  The waiter cracked me up though, came up as were were seated and said "the kiddie show will be ending shortly".
author: David S.

description: OMG! So romantic!! But honestly the souffle's were mind blowing! The seasonal fruit Souffle was crazy good. If I wasnt in a public setting I would have eaten the darn thing with my hands ahah... Ok J/K....not really ;)
author: Janet m.

description: Tres romantic! How can you go wrong with an all-souffle resturaunt?
author: Kezia P.

description: Went last night for the bf's birthday and I was in eggy, cheesy heaven.  After reading the other yelp reviews, I knew it was a necessity to get a starter since we arrived hungry and the cucumber salad was perfect- light, refreshing, but not heavy.  Our entree souffle was a white corn, ginger, and garlic and was just perfect- the corn added sweetness, the ginger and garlic the right amount of bite. But, it was the dessert that made my entire dinner- best thing I've ever eaten in my life. And I eat a lot. The strawberry souffle was just the most amazing thing- and it is huge, but we ate the entire thing between the two of us. Actually, I probably ate 2/3 of it and still wanted more. I'm kind of a glutton, I suppose.
author: Noelle Q.

description: I don't even know what to say, this place is amazing.  I like onion soup and this one is one of the best.  The lobster souffl is mind blowing.  My only suggestion might be a slightly larger dinner souffl and a smaller desert souffl?  Then again, I'm not going to tell Jacqueline how to run her kitchen.
author: Ryan P.

description:
Jacqueline is a food rock-star.   On the level of Mick and Dave, she's been doin' what she does for 30+ years.   Her elegant waiters are the cuisine-de-guards ~ ensuring that before you sit down you know what you are in for.  And what is that?   It is transformation of the huge bowl of eggs that you see in the walk-through kitchen that are beaten into clouds of perfection.   And that transformation (like transformation things) takes time.   There are no short cuts to a souffle.   

But hang out and surrender to the souffle magic and you are transported to France where technique and the most precious ingredients are paramount.  

The results are not those mini-souffles that you might get for dessert at any other place.  They are huge, San Francisco-fog-light creations that make you want to pull a stool up in the tiny kitchen to see how the hell she does it.   The flavor is intense but light as air.   

Viva la Jacqueline!
author: Veronica F.

description: horrible service, salty food, overpriced.  we didn't even get bread until after an hour of sitting there drinking our ice water.  our waiter also lost our order altogether (or forgot to place it with the kitchen) and we had to put our order in again after over an hour of thinking our souffle was in the oven.  so it took them close to 3 hours to bring our savory souffle (crab) out.  IF the souffle was exceptional (you'd think it would be considering how expensive it is), we would have overlooked some of the issues, but the crab souffle was SO salty and just disgusting.  and the dessert souffle (we had the lemon) wasn't bad but not good enough for us to ever want to come back to this place.
author: Nana S.

description: Great date place, amazing souffles, friendly service. All the souffles are to share, the entrees server two, the desserts serve two to four. Souffles start at $25. Skip it if you are in a rush though, dinner here will take at least two hours (It's worth it).
author: Ossama A.

description: They gave me a reservation the same day I called (a few hours before the dinner rush) and I didnt have any hookups or need to sleep with anyone to get it.  Service was friendly.  Atmosphere was simple and comfortable (good mood lighting).  The souffle was done to perfection (dont trust my judgement because I am not an expert).  Be warned, it is a lot of food for just two thin non-bulemic people.  Leave room to try all everything you order.  If you are bulemic, the washroom is nice.
author: H C.

description: Great idea for a unique experience. Very cute & quaint - reminded me of my Dad's resto in the Castro decades ago. Entrees and desserts are all souffles and Jacqueline herself still makes them. You can walk through the kitchen and take a peek since the bathroom is in the back. I love the idea but the food left me a bit disappointed. We started off w/ a simple spinach salad, shared the broccoli and brie souffle and finished w/ the chocolate souffle - recommended by our server. Suffice to say, I've MADE better. Then again, my opinion is biased ;) Maybe I was expecting too much, but you can get a better chocolate souffle elsewhere.
author: Cheryl P.

description: This is absolutely at the top of my romantic dining list!  You have to go with a compatible dining partner as most everything is shared.  The souffle is by far the best I've had, and every one is made with love by the chef/owner that, who you can see on your trip to the bathroom (quite possibly the cutest thing I've ever seen...check it out, you'll know exactly what I mean).  The French onion soup is a must to start!
author: Sarah D.

description: A beautiful intimate French restaurant on upper Grant where the service is friendly and the souffles are magical.
author: Mary B.

description: Pricey, but amazing! All Jaqueline makes is souffles (ok, some salads, too). Romantic!
author: Dana B.

description: Souffles!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  Who doesn't love them?!  I recommend for anyone who wants a nice romantic dinner.  The French Onion soup is delicious and so are the escargots!  Be sure to make reservations.
author: Kit E.

description: One of my fave restaurants in SF.  I think it's great to go in a group so you can sample a few of the souffles (since they feed about 2-3 people each), both savoury and sweet.  The few times I've gone with about 4 other friends, we always had about 3 savoury ones and 2 dessert ones.  The salads are fresh and delightful, and the souffles are to die for!   Wine selection is pretty good as well.
author: Darlene L.

description: Great souffles.  The white chocolate one is great.  Make sure you make a reservation!  Also, you have to budget at least three hours, it takes awhile to cook these souffles.
author: Benji J.

description: A romantic and unique resturant serving art you can eat. Also, a wonderful wine selection and friendly staff. A great place to impress a date without seeming like you're trying to impress your date.
author: Eric ..

description: the staff is extremely rude and condescending, I will definitely think twice before coming here.
author: Lilly D.

description: Tres perfect!  This place is so cute and the souffles are great, albeit very rich.  Try your best to save room for the dessert souffles, they are not to be missed, plan on sharing everything here because the souffles are huge.  The service here is impeccable and you might even get a waiter with an authentic French accent.  The dining area is a romantic little nook, wonderful place for a date, or for a double date even so there are more people to share in the delicious-ness.
author: Katie P.

description: There's gotta be a more efficient way to make souffles than having one person hand make them all.  But alas, I guess that is part of the charm.  It's fun to try out this place and have souffles for almost all parts of your meal (and the biggest souffles I've ever seen at that) but I don't think I'd go very often.  Don't expect a quick meal (good for sloooow eaters).  I give 5 stars to support women entrepreneurs though I think I'd actually rate it 4 stars.
author: Chris P.

description: One of my favorite places in the City. We have been going to Jacqueline for our anniversary since 1998. The same server (Matt) has been there each time and has always offered excellent service. The menu doesn't change much, but hey, it's consistently tasty. What a romantic setting, too.
author: Holly B.

description: It's AMAZING. I walk by everyday on my way to and from work and have been wanting to go ever since I moved to NB. I finally went and it exceeded my expectations. I went with a group of four, which I recommend. Any more than a group of four would overwhelm the small restaurant feel, and while I would go back with just one other person, four is better so you can try more (each entree souffle serves 2). We asked the waiter what was his favorite and he said the cauliflower, looking at the menu this one stood out the least, but we trusted him and went with it and ordered the prosciutto as well. They were both delicious, but the cauliflower was by far our fav. For dessert we had the lemon souffle and it was perfect. Overall, it was the best meal I have ever had. I know that is a strong statement, but it was. It just feels real.
author: Rose K.

description:
haven't been here in a few years, BUT... it is still at the top of my all time best dining experiences. everything was impeccable:
- atmosphere perfectly balanced, pools of candle light at each table, subtle but real music palying (Gotan Project when I was there, a bonus for a tango dancer).
- service, like the place, elegant friendly but NOT pretentious. they are the best, they know it, and it's not a big deal.
- souffles were incredible, just perfect. didn't try anything else, but i wouldn't hesitate.

and my ultimate test: the bathroom was also nicely done, you have to duck through the kitchen (check out the HUGE bowl of eggs ;-) - and into a rear courtyard. toilet room had flowers, a small painting, just perfect!
author: Demetrius G.

description: Very salty food, bad interior, and bad service- this is how I want to introduce this restaurant. First of all, a lot of things on the menu weren't available and food was soooooooooo salty. I couldn't finish it. I had two bites and didn't eat rest of them. However, I gave two star instead of one because desert was ok. But I would never go back to this place and will never recommend to anyone.
author: angie s.

description:
Cafe Jacqueline is a different concept - when you think "all soufflees", it sounds super tempting, but the truth is, it gets really old. The soufflee is very rich (we had the highly recommended sweet corn, ginger, and garlic) and starts to taste really salty about half way through.  The consistency of the soufflee was excellent, but honestly,  I was done about 5 bites into the entree soufflee.

The wait, as everyone has indicated, is horrendous. We arrived at 8pm and didn't leave til 11pm. I felt like they needed better time management. The table next to us arrived at least 20 minutes later and received their souffle at least 20 minutes before us (we ordered an entree, they ordered dessert).  I think what happened is that they waited until we finished our french onion soup before ordering the soufflee - when they could have ordered the soufflee midway through our soup. Likewise with the dessert soufflee (could have been ordered much earlier).

The time between the entree and the dessert was so long we almost fell alseep, but finally it arrived. I ordered the white chocolate soufflee - truly divine but way large for 2 people. I ended up taking half home, and my husband barely rolled out (he was so sleepy from the wait and the heavy food).

Bottom line: if you want a leisurely meal where you can gaze into each other's eyes and sip wine, not caring when the food arrives or how long you gaze, come for dinner. If not, skip dinner. Personally for me, dessert soufflee is the best anyway, so come for dessert and be prepared to wait.  My white chocolate soufflee was amazing. The table next to us had chocolate soufflee, and several people ordered the strawberry soufflee, topped with fresh strawberries, it looked divine.  One thing about the dessert soufflee - they put a ton of powdered sugar on it, which makes me cough - so you might want to ask them to hold the powdered sugar.

Service is nothing extraordinary. My server was not really "with it" - the head waiter took over 3/4 of the way and the service went up a notch but by then it was already too late.
author: mai p.

description:
I've been coming here at least once a year for the last 12 years.  You cannot get a better souffle in San Francisco, and I've never had a better one anywhere else either.  Impeccable food, Impeccable service and the most romantic atmosphere I've found in a restaurant.

Reservations can be hard to get, calling around 4:30 or 5 a week or so in advance seems to help, but reservations around Valentine's day almost always fill up a month or even three in advance.  There's only about 9 tables, most of which are for 2 people.  But you can exploit some last minute cancellations by walking by or trying to just get a last minute dessert near the end of your evening.

Note that everything is made to order and souffles take a while.  If you're hungry, the crusty bread is baked fresh and the soups are generally delicious.  It's about a 3 hour meal, assuming you order a savory and dessert souffle.  But relax, soak in the atmosphere and enjoy yourself.  That's why you went out on a romantic date, right?
author: Lamont L.

description: You'd better go with good company. If you take desert you'll be there for 3 hours. Our chocolate souffle was not lifted on one side and it was all liquid as opposed to the cloud like texture of the souffle. A little desappointed on this one. Will not be back
author: Carpe D.

description: I loved this place.  I've never had such great Soufle's.  I don't actually like eggs that much so someone else might give this place a better review, but it was an experience unlike I've had before.  Be prepared to wait an hour for your food because they make the Souflet from scratch.
author: Patrick M.

description: A former resident of  Russian Hill, I was in town for a meeting and had to make it to my favorite restaurant in America! The intimate surroundings, open kitchen, hand crafted souffles, amazing herb garden in back and superb service will always attract me. The waiters, Matt and Scott, could not have been nicer nor more helpful with ordering, and I enjoyed two souffles (or at least 1/2 of each): the shitake w/gruyere and Lime. Both were incredible, and tasted great the next day after sitting in my hotel's refrigerator overnight, washed down by some French Press Graffeo Coffee (a longtime SF North Beach fine coffee purveyor). Scott helped me with some excellent wine by the glass suggestions, and Matt was enthusiastic about the freshly made carrot soup, which was incredible! Come prepared with a good book (if you are eating alone as I was) or with someone whose company you enjoy, because Jacqueline makes each souffle from scratch, something you can watch enroute to the herb garden and bathroom in the back. Cafe Jacqueline is a one of a kind restaurant w/superb food that you must visit while in San Francisco (resident or visitor)-you will not be disappointed!
author: T. Bruce S.

description: ...just wanted to give jacqueline another 5 because she deserves it...this is a perfect restaurant with excellent food and service...take friends or date(s) you wanna impress....have been 10 times over ten years and always impresses and fills...
author: Bob L.

description: This place has been here for a very long time. I've eaten here quite a few times, so I must really like it . I love souffle, and Jacqueline makes a good one. Yes, that elderly French woman you pass in the kitchen on your way to the loo is Jacqueline. It looses a star because the service can suck. But the souffle's , both savory and desert, are first class. A butter letuce salad to start, lobster souffle, a good white burgundy, and a date you really like spending time with, because you'll be there for awhile. Worth it!
author: jeff b.

description:
i love this place, it's like a 3 hour vacation, no passport or tsa, the service is fun, crisp and a little french i wouldn't change a thing
slow down eat a souffle
author: karen k.

description: HOE-LEE-JEEBUS!  Wow.  From the soup, to the crab souffle, to the peach souffle, to the coffee, to the wine recommendation, it was AMAZING.  AM-AZ-ING.  The onion soup was phenomenal - most french onion soups are skimpy with the bread and cheese so that when you get to the end its pure broth - here I had a delicious string of Gruyere with ever mouthwatering bite.  The crab souffle was incredibly rich yet light and fluffy at the same time, and the crab showed through even with all the cheesy goodness to be the star.  After the crab souffle I was stuffed and regretted the decision to also get dessert, but that regret soon vanished the second I spooned the peachy goodness into my mouth.  Despite both being beyond full we finished the whole thing because we just couldn't stop ourselves - it felt like we were eating fresh peach air it was so fluffy.  After the meal we went to go thank the chef, who is Jacqueline and only Jacqueline, and it was all I could do not to steal her, take her home and force her to be my grandmother and read me bedtime stories, she was ADORABLE.  I moaned the whole way home from sheer fullness but it was the best kind of moaning imaginable.    Go here.  Go here now.  Bring your mom.  Bring your girlfriend.  Bring that lady who you always see out front who might be a crack whore.  Just go.
author: Caleb R.

description: So romantic (just look at how many women say so!). It's all-souffle all-the-time here and they're really tasty. If you haven't been, choose a romantic occassion and go. You won't regret it and she won't forget it.
author: C. A. S.

description:
A great place for a first date, last date or no date.  Whatever the occasion, it's truly a toe curling experience.  I have to admit I was drawn to the cafe for its legendary chocolate souffl but have become a big fan of the lobster souffl.  In fact, the lobster souffl is so fabulous; I could probably skip dessert all together.

Despite the spotty service, Cafe Jacqueline is a must anytime you can justify the splurge.
author: Maria R.

description: If you have time to sit back and relax while Chef Jacqueline prepares heavenly souffles for you, go to this place.  It does take a while but it's worth it.  I would recommend reservations as it's a small place and tables do not turn over frequently.  It's cool to go through the kitchen on the way to the bathroom and see that enormous bowl of eggs and Jacqueline back there working her magic.
author: Janet L.

description: Romantic. Exquisite. I only wish my partner weren't lactose intolerant.
author: Paige T.

description: One of the most romantic restaurants in all of San Francisco. Tucked away on a narrow street in North Beach, the restaurant is just a cute little mish mash of French knickknacks and somewhat cheesy accoutrement that somehow suddenly don't seem cheesy in the confines of the restaurant. Lovely, lovely, lovely. My husband and I came here for a nice date night and we could not have been more pleased. Be prepared for a loooooong meal. They must only do one seating a night because we had a reservation at 6:15 and did not leave before 9:00. It was just a nice leisurely eating experience which gave us time to relax, chat and enjoy each other's company. The menu is limited, only a few salads and lots of souffles but with souffles this perfect what more do you need? We started off with salads which were simply but perfectly dressed. Butter lettuce with a nice lemony dressing with maybe a hint of tarragon. Delicious! And then the crab souffle which was wonderful. Light and airy and extremely generous with crab. And then, the most sublime moment of the night, the fresh strawberry souffle. It was decadent and transcendent, my first bite and I was transported away to culinary heaven. Seriously, this is one of the best things I've ever had in my life. And I've done a lot of eating. Next time you want to impress a date, look no farther, this is the best date restaurant in town.
author: Cathy T.

description: Well, unfortunately I cannot comment on the food, because having had an 8:30 pm reservation, and ariving on time, we had still not received our soup after 10 pm.  We paid for our wine and left.  We have been here before and enjoyed it, but the fake snottiness of the waiters is wearing and unnecessary, and frankly, we were just hungry.  There is simply no excuse. It is a shame, because the idea of the restaurant is fabulous, its just that the reality does not meet the expectation.
author: Jen S.

description: of course this is on my romantic list! its an adorable 'very authentic' little french restaurant. small, quaint, beautifully decorated and soft mood lighting. even before getting inside, you can smell the wonderful food and you just know its going to be good.
author: Michelle I.

description:
the bf took me here for christmas a few years back and it's since been one of my favs. a hidden gem in northbeach. one room, a few tables and one very dear french chef who makes souffles as you order. go with people you like -- it's a long meal. 

and go to the bathroom so you have an excuse to see jacqueline in her element. 

this is a solid never-fails date night spot...
author: Emily J.

description: If you're a lover a Souffles, you will not be disappointed.  This is all they do, and they do it like no one else here in California.  Yes we're talking about savory souffles as well as sweet ones, so, don't plan to go here if you're just looking for dessert.  Classic, simple, authentic are words that always come to mind.  The onion soup and escargot are also reliable favorites.  Be prepared for a long meal (yes these things take a long time to prepare) as they are made to order.  So don't come if you're on your way to the theatre.  Come if you've got good company, and and looking to enjoy a pleasant slow paced evening, and some gosh darn good souffles.  Also, these things are relatively large and meant to be shared, so bring a few friends so you can sample a number of savory and sweet varieties.  Ask them what's good as the seasonal varieties are amazing.
author: Hungry Rat S.

description: If i could speak french i'd write this review in french, but instead all i can do is dream of speaking and tromping around in france and eating souffle's and bread and wine as good as this every weekend.  sitting amidst the pale sea green and high-cieling'ed white walls (not the least bit hospital-or-asylum-like as i feared) with candle flickering and low lights glowing all around, i wished i could wish so hard that when i walked out i would see stone cathedrals and palaces predating napoleon, and maybe the seine river instead of coit tower.  this was, like everyone else warns, a nearly 3 hour meal, and plan on spending a lot of money and splurging for a bottle of good wine to sip in between soups, salads, dinner and desert souffles.  And yes, make sure you go with someone who you know you can safely share with.  ...this created a few battles between me and a certain soon to be ex as we fought over the crusty shell...  service is impeccable and straightforward, concise.  the trip to the bathroom, through the tiny quaint kitchen into the courtyard garden, is a must at some point, plus it's a nice leg-stretch midway through.  We got the shitake, garlic and basil souffle and it was wonderful.  The chocolate souffle was rich and light, like steaming mousse.  i think i got a bit of chocolate overdose, which i'm still savoring, but which i think knocked a certain soon to be ex out midway through, which was all the more perfect for letting me indulge in the chocolate feast.  damn, even the watercress salad, simple watercress with oil dressing, was great.
author: Today Y.

description: This was one of the single most awful dining experiences I have ever had!  Yes, patience is a virtue, but you'll need more than that to endure this excruciatingly SLOW hole that is Cafe Jacqueline.  We knew before going in there, and from the depleted looks of the other diners, that we would have to wait a little bit for our souffle, but more than 2 hours long for a just adequate souffle is unacceptable.  You would think a restaurant that has been around for some time would have gotten all of the kinks out and would run more smoothly. Not so at this place! Not so!  What's more, the two damn idiots that ran the restaurant that night did not even utter a word of apology or appease us with any explanation for what went wrong.  Ugh!!  We left the restaurant without a taste of the chocolate souffle that we ordered at the start because doing so would have meant another hour or so of waiting.  No thanks!
author: Sarah H.

description:
"You've got to be kidding me. The souffles are good, but very over priced. If you ask for whipped cream, Jacqueline will gladly whip some up for you for $10 extra. Jacqueline is out of her f# mind. Give me a break. What a tragedy this place was. $40 is the average souffle price-egg whites and cheese or whatever other flavor you choose. 

If you want to be very dissapointed, go to Cafe Jacqueline. Instead, take your hard earned cash elsewhere. You will be happy you did."

The above review was written by my husband a few minutes ago while i was looking in on our kids. We just got back about an hour ago and i was about to leave a review and saw this. i didn't know he was logged into my account and when i read it i thought someone else was reading my mind. 

ok, this is the scoop. i thought the food was very good. my husband and i took his sister out for her birthday. he could not believe we were at a restaurant that only served souffles. i was trying to tell him how well reviewed this place is and souffles are not something you could just get anywhere. i have been wanting to come here for years but never got around to it. my husband freaked at the prices for what basically amounts to egg whites and cheese for $40 a dish. this man has no problem dropping $150 for dinner for 2 - that is, if there is meat involved. we are hard core food nazi's. he and i LOVE good food and eat out a lot. 

i got the onion soup which was very, very good. that was $10.50. i got a butter lettuce salad for $8 or $9. don't remember. it was just a small amount of lettuce and dressing. what a butter lettuce salad usually consists of and i really wanted it so there goes. we got 2 souffles - the roquefort and the special - oyster (for the love of g*d, bleck). i did not want any part of the oyster. anyway, should have thought this through more - the roquefort souffle. it is straight up roquefort and egg whites. in a reasonable portion, that might be ok. it was waaaaay too salty in such a large quantity. the souffles are so friggin big. i love salt in the worst way too but i was so thirsty due to all of that salt. should have gotten something like tomato/cilantro or asparagus. they all come with gruyere which would have satisfied the need for cheese. 

the the white chocolate souffle was the baked love of angels. i can't stop thinking about it. i want more of it. RIGHT NOW! funny thing is, i don't like white chocolate. 

suffice to say, we will only go back for dessert. i think one souffle must have 12-16 egg whites in it. seriously. i am desperate to know what becomes of all of those unused egg yolks. the story about the whipped cream was no joke. the waiter said we should have asked for it earlier because jacqueline "makes it herself by hand". have you ever made whipped cream by yourself? it involves WHIPPING CREAM AND SOMETHING TO WHIP WITH. my 5 year old son has been making whipped cream since he was 3. we pour a container of whipping cream in a tall container and give him the hand blender and he goes at for 5 minutes. i mean, come on! $10 can buy you 2 gallons of whipping cream and a 5 year old child hours of entertainment. i was imaging jacqueline is 100 years old, chained to a stove, has carpal tunnel syndrome with a touch of arthritis and has to whip the cream with a toothpick. that would, therefore, justify the price. 

this place opened in the 80's when everyone was throwing around their sacks of cash, snorting coke for a lack of something better to with all their money. i think the reputation and the high prices stuck. all in all i'm glad i went. as i have said, i have been wanting to go for years. it was good but just too much for not enough. 

my idea would be to halve the portions and make them individual size so you and your company are not forced to share one thing. the average souffle is $40-$50 and serves 2 people. even if the portions were halved and cost half as much, they still would have cost too much at $20 to $25 apiece. take it down a notch and price them at $14-$18. that way you can share and get a variety. 

one last thing, the service was very good. it did take 3 hours. no prob, was expecting it due to other reviews. but boy, is my husband pissed off!
author: Heather J.

description:
i really enjoyed myself!  i found the atmosphere to be romantic and cozy, the service to be friendly, and the food was pretty much out of this world. 

my boyfriend however, was basically irritated with it the entire time.  it took 45 mins. from ordering to recieve even our soup course (which was incredible BTW) and unfortunately, the bottle of wine the waiter recommended was TERRIBLE.  the courses were spacesd very sporadically the rest of the night, which he found very frustrating and left him eating two loaves of bread.  i really had no problem waiting because i had read previous reviews and felt it was worth the wait.  i guess i found the idea of one chef charming, and my man found it frustrating.  it's also VERY expensive which usually makes for high expectations of efficiency of service.  i found the pricing to be mostly acceptable,as almost all the courses were so fantastic!  the french onion soup and lobster souffle were mindblowlingly delicious, but i will say the white chocolate souffle we ordered for dessert was pretty underwhelming for thirty dollars.

i would totally come back here, but next time bring girlfriends and leave the man at home.
author: Jessie J.

description: Best souffle anywhere.  Don't let the waiters bother you, they aren't as bad as some people are saying.  Remember you are there for a souffle.  Ms. Jacqueline is very cool as well. Oh, and don't be cheap, get the ingredients and make one yourself and then see how you feel about the price.
author: Joe P.

description: The best souflee ever. Very long wait. Good for a romatic night out. It is about a 3 hour dinner but so worth it. We went for our anniversary.
author: Bella G.

description:
definitely very good souffles.

i came here with hubby about 3-4 years back, jacqueline was still beating these by hand.  it took 4 hrs for a dinner.

now, she has a kitchen aid.  they come out as good, and in 30 mins.  try the corn, ginger and garlic for savory.  the seasonal fruit souffle is really good.  so is the grand marnier one.  

the french onion soup is to die for.  so is the potato/leek soup.

the service is much improved as well.  so are the attitudes of the waiters, they are still the same ones.  it almost feels like a close tight knit family running the place.  

good wine selection.  very reasonable prices.

i recommend that if you are thinking of going, go soon.  jacqueline isn't young and i don't see her training an assistant.
author: tc h.

description: let's just say....the souffles are awesome and deserves 4 1/2 stars but the service is TERRIBLE!! that's why i'm giving it 2 stars. you would imagine a place makes you pay that much can afford a nicer waiter but i guess i was definitely wrong. i probably wont come back because of the service.
author: Cam N.

description: The color decor in the small and intimate Cafe Jacqueline is soft and very relaxing.  The only dish on the menu is soufflé. There are some delicious home-made soups and green crisp salads to start with, along with relaxing and drinking wine to pass the time as your soufflé bakes in the oven. Soufflé choices include cheese, garlic and lobster, among others. For dessert, chocolate, strawberry and seasonal specials are available. The service is warm and efficient for the upscale clientele here, and the wine list has a good selection of imported and domestic vintages.  This is perfectly French and my new French wife loves to come here for the delicious souffle.
author: Michael S.

description: Cafe Jacqueline is located in North Beach.  I always wanted to come here as it has been recommended to me a few times so I had to try it. It was a great dinner.  I didn't realize that all the entree's were souffles...I guess I should have Yelped them first! Anwyway, we started with the carrot soup and cucumber salad which were both very good.  We ordered the prosciutto and mushroom souffle which was excellent.  There was such an interesting selection of suffles that I had a hard time picking one.  One suffle is enough for 2 people.  Than for dessert we had the chocolate souffle which was awesome!  But be careful, the top of the chocolate suffle is covered with powdered sugar.  When my GF laughed while leaning towards the souffle, she got covered in white powder which made her look like a coke-head which she had a lot of fun impersonating for the rest of the evening.  We had to rush through dinner a bit because we were going to a comedy show so be sure to allow a lot of time for dinner.  You'll need at least 2.5 hours for dinner.
author: V C.

description: Delicious souffls.  That's the only thing they serve there.  Definitely a excellent date spot -- very unassumingly romantic.   Go with someone you can have an excellent conversation with.  You will need to make reservations and be prepared to wait at least 45 mins for each souffle because they are made from scratch.  Entree & Dessert souffles are delightful.
author: Suen L.

description: Cafe Jacqueline is definitely quaint and charming. My boyfriend took me here for my birthday and we enjoyed ourselves.  But, I thought of it as a once in a lifetime dining experience - meaning it was memorable, but not coming back.  The food was tasty, but nothing special.  We had for the first course French Onion Soup, second course seafood souffle, and third course chocolate souffle.  My boyfriend commented that the ingredients were very simple.  After all, it was just eggs and seafood - come on now.  I suppose there is an art to making the souffle rise and you pay for that, not the ingredients.  The pricing was moderate to expensive.  I definitely recommend the chocolate souffle dessert. It was delicious and huge.  We finished everything.  I would come back, but only for the dessert.  I saw several people reserve a table just for the chocolate dessert.  It is huge enough to feed 4 people for dessert (although it comes with a hefty price tag of about $30 for a chocolate souffle).  If you're pressed for time Cafe Jacqueline isn't for you.  Our dining experience took 2.5 hours and my boyfriend was plenty hungry by the time our 2nd course came.
author: Dbear T.

description: Waited over an hour for our souffles but not disappointed. Broccoli and cheese, seafood, chocolate...the seafood came undercook (the shrimps were still grey) so it had to be sent back to the oven. The salad and soup are great, too, although the wait for them was almost equally long.
author: Bias W.

description: If it didn't take an 1 hour and 45 min to get our entree, I'd give it 5 stars. The service was very slow and not attentive- be prepared to wait a long time between courses or to get your wine refilled. I took the suggestion of other reviewers and ordered the onion soup. It was served piping hot (it took a full 10 min before it was edible), and very salty. The lobster souffle was tasty, but took way too long to arrive. By that point, I just wanted the check.
author: ofelia R.

description: This is a cozy, cozy place.  Very romantic, off the beated path, quaint etc. etc. etc.  In love? Share a dessert. Been dumped?  Eat the whole damn thing.
author: Misti L.

description: Go here go here go here!  The souffle is to die for.  So light and airy it melts in your mouth to a bevy of delicious flavors.  The lobster, crab and cheese souffles will make you tear at their sheer perfection. And the dessert souffles are just a fabulous.  It's like a tiny little Parisian gem of a restaurant tucked into North Beach (you can totally pretend you're in Paris). And did I mention it's a tiny place with small tables and just about, if not, the most romantic restaurant in San Francisco?!?!??!  If Cafe Jacqueline can't end your dry spell, you got bigger issues.  And you MUST visit the restroom so you can see Jacqueline herself with her big floppy white chef hat and huge basket of eggs in the kitchen creating her souffle masterpieces.  Man, I love this place.
author: Jane M.

description: Wow. I love souffles but I've never loved any (save the ones I've cooked with my gf) as much as the ones we had here! Quick tip, plan on being here at least 90min if not more if you go for a 3 course meal (appetizer(s), dinner souffle and dessert souffle). They make everything to order so it takes awhile. However the wine list is very affordable and it's a great opportunity to order a well priced Bourdeaux and catch up on good conversation. The waiters are very knowledgeable about everything on the menu so if you have any questions, or can't decide, definitely ask! We had a French Onion Soup (high up on the list of best ones I've ever had), Cucumber Salad (good, not great but good), broccoli dinner souffle (amazing! I wouldn't have thought that it would be as tasty as it was) and a chocolate dessert souffle with a grand marnier flambe on top (not on the menu, just ask, it's a great option if you can't decide between the two). Very filling and well worth the wait for them to come out. Definitely come hungry though, we barely finished that menu between the two of us and we were starving when we went!
author: Chris D.

description: Great restaurant for a quaint, romantic dinner.  I noticed there were small groups of friends and families who were there too. The restaurant is small.  The maximum it fits is probably 5 to a table with a seating capacity of about 30 people.  Call for reservations. Street parking is very difficult.  If you ask the waiter at the restaurant, there's a parking deck they recommend near by. The dessert souffle (lemon) was excellent.  We got onion soup (very good), one entree souffle which was good for souffle (I am not a fan of entree souffles) and the dessert souffle.  If I go again, I will definitely do the same soup, and salad and then the dessert souffle which is large enough for 4 people.  The dessert souffle was great as leftovers.  As we were about the leave the water asked us to go speak with Madame Jacqueline in the back.  She was very nice!  I highly recommend this restaurant.  Also they are open til 11pm on the nights they are open!
author: Maya N.

description: A review I read prior to going said that the place was "heartbreakingly romantic" and that could not be more true.  Don't go with someone from work.  Cafe Josephine was top flight - the ambiance, the souffles, and the opportunity to chat with the chef on the way out to the restroom in the courtyard.
author: Andrea P.

description: Make sure to take your statins before you come: lipitor or zocor will work just fine. You'll be fighting against the tasty but heavy triumvirate of cream, butter, and eggs. You start off with a salad or soup appetizers. The three pepper soup I had was delicious. No matter your predilection get an appetizer; souffles take a long time and you'll be starving if you skip the apps. Then you share a souffle and they have a bevy to choose from. The lobster souffle we had, had a carmelized cheesy crust, rich egginess, and huge chunks of lobster. We were scraping the ramekin trying to get the last bits. Lastly you split a dessert souffle and we went with the classic of chocolate. When it comes you must be careful not to inhale the powdered sugar which coats the top. It could cause a choking frenzy which would be an unwelcome scene in the small space. With little lighting and marginal decor, our powdered sugar choking fit had the whole restaurant looking at us. We sure filled up on the chocolate souffle though, and there was NOTHING left in the ramekin. It really is an amazingly delicious and large souffle. Service was lacking, but you really only come here just for the souffles. The wine list is very reasonably priced and complements the menu well with mostly French selections.
author: Keith R.

description: delicious souffles, both savory and sweet. make sure you order a chocolate souffle which is liberally dusted with powdered sugar, and then lean in and blow all the powdered sugar on your dinner mate.  it is sort of an asshole manuever, but it is funny to see people covered in snowy sugary goodness.
author: Marina F.

description: This place is fantastic. I have been here 6 or 7 times and it has yet to disappoint. You have to be an adult to enjoy it. Yes, it is a long evening order a couple of bottles of wine and enjoy. It takes a long time to handmake all of those souffles and it is worth it. The quality and selection is fantastic. The waiters can be a little surly, but after I killed mine with kindness he was fine. You can't complain about the menu as it is all about souffles. You can't fault them for the parking situation, it has nothing to do with the restaurant or food. If you want an ultra-romantic spot, this is it. Don't rush it, enjoy it. If you want fast food there are plenty of other (not better) places to go.
author: Timothy S.

description: It starts when the owner (is her name actually Jacqueline?) calls you back to confirm your reservations... I've never had my name mispronounced so beautifully - something about the accent just makes anything sound good!  The food was phenomenal - a rich cheese and broccoli souffle followed by a chocolate souffle where the chocolate literally pours (like the world's best fountain) right out of the top... I lament that I only had but one stomach to give.
author: Anjali K.

description: Delish. Went on a Sunday night as a couple. Ambiance was mellow and food was excellent. The waiter was short with us but not rude. The chef is just precious (worth the trip to the bathroom). We had the spinach bacon and pine nuts salad to start - which was light but not the star of the meal. We then had the prosciutto (sp?) and mushroom souffle, then the ooey gooey chocolate souffle for dessert. Plenty of food for us two good eaters - almost finished it all. Waiter's wine choice was perfect for what we were looking to accompany the meal.  Overall an excellent experience and meal - will definitely return. If only north beach had more parking!
author: Anna M.

description: I absolutely LOVEEEE this place! Ever since the first souffle I had here, I don't think any other souffle tastes as good. I've had almost every single one of their dessert souffle and also the lobster and crab. I'd def. order the crab again. It's baked with lemon on top and bottom and it went soooo well with the cheese! And the bread....ohhh the bread. It's the best French bread I've had in SF. Dessert wise, I think strawberry and white chocolate are the best! Despite the fact that the place is oven-temperature (to keep the souffle from flapping when it's served) and the almost impossible-to-find parking space, this place is def. worth the wait and hassle. I don't think service is as bad as everyone mentions, just don't expect it to be like 5-star hotels. Sometimes you do get a feeling that they don't need your business cause well....they don't. I have had the luck to talk to Chef Jacqueline a couple of times and she's actually a very nice person. If you try to talk to the waiters, they would joke around with you when they're not  busy!
author: Eva L.

description: Overpriced with a robotic waitstaff. Go for a dessert souffle but definitely not worth it for a full dinner. Lobster souffle was over salted, had 3 small bits of lobster ,and was in the  $50+ dollar range alone.  Old North Beach charm but I'm not rushing back anytime soon.
author: S T.

description: Love this place!  Super tasty souffles...who knew they could be this good.  The venue is a little small (and a bit slow), but if you want good food and and have time to spare in a nice, quiet, romantic place (and really, who doesn't?), this is a great choice.
author: P P.

description: Came here just for dessert.  They had the largest souffle I've ever seen, and very very delish.  Definitely worth the $30 cause it can easily feed 4 people.  But don't expect friendly service.
author: Heidy M.

description: If there's a zero star.. I will rate this restaurant zero... or even negative!! I made a reservation two days ahead for 2 people at 8pm under the name "Mimi". I called today, and the lady said she cannot find my name. I insisted that I made a reservation, and she heads the phone to a guy. He said " I TRIED to BELIEVE you.. but I can't find you name!"... What?!?!?! so he thinks I m lying! He gave me a really big attitude and think I am lying to him. Then he made it sounds like he is doing me a favor and asked me how many I have... then i said i don't want to eat here any more.. and right away he said ok and hang me up! I was really mad at his attitude and I called back... the lady picks up the phone again... then she said... "oh.. i think i wrote you down as 'Amy'!" !!!!!!!!!!!!! OMG!!!!!!  I told her that I called back becasue he was really rude and i don't deserve this kind of serve. After arguing with me for 5 mins... they finally found out they wrote my name wrong!!! After I told them my name is "Mimi".. i even spell it out to her because a lot of times people don't know how to spell my name... I just she wasn't listening to my at all when i spell it to her! I wonder if that guy is the owner of the restaurant... if not he should be fire! I will never eat at that restaurant!! SUPER BAD SERVE on the phone already... i can't imagine what i will get when i eat there.... they think they have a lot of customers already that they can treat me this way! If they are reading this review... I hope they will never accuse people next time... you are not gary danko or french laundry.. no one will fake a reservation to eat at your place!
author: Oi T.

description: the hype for how romantic this place is prompted me to bring my sister ;P  let me explain my logic.   when a restaurant has a rep for being THE date place to go, well, there's just entirely too much pressure when you actually go on a date there for you to fully enjoy the food . . .so, being the fervent foodie i am, i decided to bring my sister.  the restaurant itself is small but there's enough room between tables to faciliate a nice low level of chatter that fits with the overall coziness of the place.  my sister and i had salad, the lobster souffle and then finished with the strawberry souffle for dessert.  honestly, we got a bit souffled out halfway through the lobster souffle (they are indeed huge . . but i think it's more the boredom of the same exact texture bite after bite.  don't get me wrong . .the first 10 bites are pure heaven!).  thus we were pleasantly surprised to feel our souffle tastebuds renewed with the delicate flavors of the strawberry souffle, which was topped with dozens of paper-thin fresh strawberry slices to create a beautiful effect.  my suggestion is to have dinner elsewhere and then come here for dessert in order to fully relish in the souffle experience ;D  be sure to use the restroom hidden in back so that you get to walk through the kitchen and catch a glimpse of jacqueline herself whipping up the souffle masterpieces!
author: tiffany t.

description: meet the chef/owner as you walk down to the bathroom through the open kitchen... she smiles big time all the time! her souffles are huge and light!!
author: E H.
